englishTitle: THE STORY OF ENGLAND: BY ROBERT MANNING OF BRUNNE, A.D. 1338.: PART I.: THE STORY OF ENGLAND: BY ROBERT MANNING OF BRUNNE, A.D. 1338.: PART II.

text.0: The first 198 lines are from the Inner Temple MS., Petyt MSS. No. 511, vol. 7. The dots on the left of certain lines show that the lines dotted are not translated from Wace, as he is shown by the Paris MS. du Roi, No. 27, printed by Le Roux de Lincy, Rouen, 1836. Incipit Prologus de Historia Britannie transumpta per Robertum in materna lingua. Lordynges that be now here, if &yogh;e wille listene & lere All the story of Inglande als Robert Mannyng wryten it fand, & on Inglysch has it schewed, not for þe lerid bot for þe lewed, ffor þo þat in þis land[e] wone þat þe Latyn no Frankys cone, ffor to haf solace & gamen In felawschip when þai sitt samen. And it is wisdom for to wytten þe state of þe land, & haf it wryten, what manere of folk first it wan, & of what kynde it first began; And gude it is for many thynges for to here þe dedis of kynges, whilk were foles, & whilk were wyse, & whilk of þam couthe most quantyse, and whilk did wrong, & whilk ryght, & whilk maynten[e]d pes & fyght. Of þare dedes sall be my sawe; & what tyme, & of what lawe I sall yow schewe fro gre to gre sen þe tyme of sir Noe, ffro Noe vnto Eneas, & what betwix þam was; And fro Eneas till Brutus tyme, . . . . ffro Brutus till Cadwaladres, þe last Bryton þat þis lande lees. All þat kynde & all þe frute þat come of Brutus, þat is þe Brute; And þe ryght Brute is told nomore þan þe Brytons tyme wore. After þe Bretons þe Inglis camen, þe lordschip of þis lande þai namen, Southe & northe, west & est, þat calle men now þe Inglis gest. when þai first [came] amang þe Bretons, þat now ere Inglis, þan were Saxons; Saxons Inglis hight alle oliche; þai aryued vp at Sandwyche In þe kynges tyme Vortogerne, þat þe lande walde þam not werne. þat were Maysters of alle þe toþire, Hengist he hight, & Hors his broþire; þes were hede, als we fynde, where-of is comen oure Inglis kynde. A hundrethe & fifty &yogh;ere þai com or þai receyued cristendom; So lang woned þai þis lande in, or þai herde out of Saynt Austyn, Amang þe Bretons with mykelle wo, In sclaundire & threte, & in thro. þes Inglis dedes &yogh;e may here, as Pers telles alle þe manere. One Mayster Wace þe ffrankes telles, þe Brute, all þat þe Latyn spelles, ffro Eneas till Cadwaladre; þis Mayster Wace þer leues he. And ryght as Mayster Wace says, I telle myn Inglis þe same ways; ffor Mayster Wace þe Latyn alle rymes þat Pers ouerhippis many tymes. Mayster Wace þe Brute alle redes, & Pers tellis alle þe Inglis dedes; þer Mayster Wace of þe Brute left, ryght begynnes Pers [þer] eft, And tellis forth þe Inglis story, & as he says, þan say I. Als þai haf wryten & sayd, haf I alle in myn Inglis layd, In symple speche as I couthe, þat is lightest in mannes mouthe. I mad noght for no disours, ne for no seggers, no harpours, Bot for þe luf of symple men þat strange Inglis can not ken; ffor many it ere þat strange Inglis In ryme wate neuer what it is; And bot þai wist what it mente, ellis me thoght it were alle schente. I made it not forto be praysed, bot at þe lewed men were aysed. If it were made in ryme couwee, or in strangere or enterlace, þat rede Inglis it ere inowe, þat couthe not haf coppled a kowe, þat outhere in couwee or in baston som suld haf ben fordon, so þat fele men þat it herde suld not witte howe þat it ferde: I see in song, in sedgeyng tale of Erceldoun & of Kendale, Non þam says as þai þam wroght, & in þer sayng it semes noght; þat may þou here in sir Tristrem; ouer gestes it has þe steem, Ouer alle that is or was, if men it sayd as made Thomas; But I here it no man so say, þat of som copple som is away; So þare fayre sayng here beforn is þare trauayle nere forlorn; þai sayd it for pride & nobleye, þat non were suylk as þei; And all þat þai wild ouerwhere, all þat ilk will now forfare. þai sayd in so quante Inglis þat many one wate not what it is. þerfore [I] henyed [MS. henþed] wele þe more In strange ryme to trauayle sore; And my witte was oure thynne So strange speche to trauayle in; And forsoth I couth[e] noght so strange Inglis as þai wroght; And men besoght me many a tyme to turne it bot in light[e] ryme; þai sayd, if I in strange it turne, to here it manyon suld skurne; ffor it ere names full selcouthe þat ere not vsed now in mouthe; And þerfore for þe comonalte þat blythely wild listen to me, On light[e] lange I it began, for luf of þe lewed man, to telle þam þe chaunces bolde þat here before was don & tolde. ffor þis makyng I will no mede bot gude prayere when &yogh;e it rede; þerfore, [alle] &yogh;e lordes lewed, ffor wham I haf þis Inglis schewed, Prayes to God he gyf me grace,— I trauayled for &yogh;our solace;— Of Brunne I am, if any me blame, Robert Mannyng is my name; Blissed be he of God of heuene þat me, Robert, with gude wille neuene; In þe third Edwardes tyme was I when I wrote alle þis story, In þe hous of Sixille I was a throwe; Danz Robert of Malton þat &yogh;e know, did it wryte for felawes sake, when þai wild solace make.
text.1: Dares Frigius, qui historiam Troianorum scripsit, ait se militasse vsque dum Troia capta est, hosque duces se vidisse cum indutie essent & partim prelio interfuisse. Dares the Freson of Troie first wrote, & putt it in buke þat we now wote; he was a clerk and a gude knyght, when Troie was lorn he sawe þat fight; Alle þe barons wele he knewe, he tellis þer stature & þer hewe, long or schorte, whyte or blak, alle he telles, gude or lak. Alle þer lymmes, how þai besemed, In his buke has Dares demed, Both of Troie & of Grece, whatkyns schappe was ilka pece; Of manyon he reknes & sayes, both of Troiens & of Gregeis, þat it were oure long to telle, & many wald not þer-in duelle þare names alle forto here, bot þe Latyn is fayre to lere.
text.2: Ego Galfridus Arthurus Monemutensis, qui hanc historiam Britonum de eorum lingua in nos|tram transferre curaui, dimitto fortunas suc|cessoribus meis scribendas. Geffrey Arthure of Minumue, fro Breton speche he did remue, & made it alle in Latyn þat clerkes haf now knawyng in. In Gloucestre was fonden a buke þat þe Inglis couthe not rede no luke On þat langage þai knew no herde; bot an erle þat hyght Roberde, he prayed þat ilk clerk Geffrey to turne it fro þat speche away In-to Latyn, as it mente, þat þe Inglis mot know þe entente; ffor Geffrey knew þe langage wele, In Latyn he broght it ilka dele. Siþen com a clerk, Mayster Wace, to make romance had he grace, & turned it to Latyne, & rymed it in Frankis fyne vnto þe Cadwaladres; no forer, þer makes he ses. Als Geffrey in Latyn sayd, so Mayster Wace in Frankis layd; þe date of Criste was þan þis lyue, A thousand &yogh;ere fifty & fyue. Than com out of Brydlyngton Pers of Langtoft, a chanon; Als Mayster Wace þe same he says, bot he rymed it oþer ways; he begynnes at Eneas, of alle þe Brute he tellis þe pas, & s[i]þen [ or syen] alle þe Inglis dedis; feyrere langage non ne redis. After þe Inglis kynges he says þer pris þat all in metir fulle wele lys; And I, Robert, fulle fayn wald bringe In Inglis tonge þer faire saiynge. The Lambeth MS. begins here, and the text is printed from it. A modern hand has put the following title to the MS.:—"A Chronicle of "England, in olde Englishe meeter, "from Brute to King Richarde y e ".I., made by Piers of Langtofte, "chanonne of Bridlington, and "putte into Englishe ryme by Ro|"bert de Brunne iuxta Depinge .v. "infr. f. lxxiij." The various read|ings are from the Petyt MS. God gyve me grace wel to spede, þys rym on Englische for to rede.

" as in ," P. þe bible seys þe Clerk/,— & þerfore God sente a flood Þat &. fordide al flesche & blood, The later hand puts both for al , and all before blood ; as also both before Man in the next line, and & left before Bot in the line after. Man & best þat beren lyues, Bot foure men & foure wyues. So mykel was þenne þan. mannes trespas, Þat alle þat euer of Adam was Wyþynne a þousand &yogh;er & mo, In þat flod were lorn alle þo. Bot Noe & his þre sones And þeir wyues—þe bible hit mones— Wer none worthi in Godes sight, Ne non bot þese þat liueden lyued. ryght. þyse were þo þes were þai. þat skaped þe deþ, Noe, Seem, Cam, & Sapheþ, Iapheth. And þer wyues þat þai. wiþ þem þam. nam; þo þat now ar, of þys folk þey ere of þes aught. cam. Þyse This. Noe sones, &yogh;e han haf. wel herd How þey departed al þys werd: þe werlde. þey departed [it] parted it. in þre parties, And names gaf at þeir deuis, Assye, Aufryk, & Europe; þys ar þes ere. þe parties, wel y hope. Sem was þe eldest: was eldest. he ches Assye; Cam took Aufryk til to. his partie; Saphet, Iapheth. Europè The accent is in the MS. he took; & þus þey parted, & þis departid. als seyþ þe book.
text.4: Tot terre sunt in vniuerso mundo. How many landes in ilk of þyse, Ilk a partie haþ þeyr has þer. assise: In Assye fiftene landes are, Bot þer names we seye no na. mare: India, Assery, and Partye, Sire, Perce, Mede, Mesapotanie, Capadoce, Palestine, & Armenye, Cylyce, Cades, & Arrabye, Al Egipte, & Lybye; þyse ar ere. þe landes in Assye. ¶ Tyl Aufryk twelf landes longe, lang. Þat Cam til his partie gan fonge: parte vnderfang. Cireneus, Pentapolys, & Lyddya, Ethiope, Tripolitan, & Pysancia, Bizancia. Gentulye, Getulie. Natabrie, Numidye, Maurytan & Tynguytanie; Sirtes þe more & þe lasse, ffor þe twelfte teld hit es. ¶ ffiftene ffouretene. To make 15, the pope's dwelling must be counted as one land. landes ar in Europe, Saphethes partie, þer dwelleþ was Iapheth parte þer es. þe Pope: Romanie, Rome. ( Poille is omitted.) Calabre, Poille, & Spayne, Massedoigne & Alemaygne, Tracye, Dalmank, & Pamonie Dalmatik, Pannonie. Lange-dok, ffraunce, Coloyne, Galle. Acquitonie, Brytaigne, Irland,—þyse arn þes be. þe best,— And al þe Northe toward þe west. Now schal sall. we telle as we fynde How Eneas com of Saphethes Iaphet. kynde; ffol merk hit ys for to here, Bot algate a man may lere.
text.5: Genealogia, siue generacio. Noe þat God saued fro Noe god saued fro þe. deþ. His sone was cald sire was sir. Saphet. Iauan, his sone þat cam com. of hym, He hadde a sone þat hight Setym; Cetim. Setymes Cetim. sone, Ciprius hight, A man of ffame & of myght; So mikel þat tyme was his fame, þe lande of Cipre of for. hym had name. Of þys noble sire Cyprius, Was a sone þat hight men called. Cretus; þis Cretus an ilde he augte, MS. augste ; P. has aught. þe name of hym Cret hit laughte. Cretus sone hyghte Cellius, And Cellius sone was Saturnus; Saturnus sone highte Iubiter, In astronomie he lerede fer. Þis ilk Iubiter had twey þis Iubiter had twa. wyues, Kynges doughtres, faire lyues; Þat on þe ton. hight Maye, þat oþer þe toþer. Electra, Þe þer. ffader hight Aclas Atlans. of þem twa; ffor Aclas alle hise men calde, for Atlans a hill men called. Mons Aclatis Atlantis. &yogh;if hit now halde; Þe þat. hil was so hey, as men hit leet, so hij men lette. Þat heuen (men seye) hit vnder-feet. sayd it vndersette. ? feet=took. Þys noble kynge sire Aclas, Atlas. In his orchard lordschip. a tre þer was, þat gilden apples hit bar ere-more euermore. Al þe tyme þat apples wore; tymes þat appilles are. & alwey on dragon hem kepte; Alle tymes a dragon þam. Syn Siþen. were þey stolen þe while whils. he slepte. þys Iubiter lay dame Maye by, & gat on hure of hir. sire Mercury; Of Electra he gat an oþer, Dardanum, Mercurius Mercury. brother. Iubiter loued wel more Maye And Mercury þan þe oþer twaye, P. omits these two lines. . Wel more Maye & Mercurium Þan Electra or Dardanum. P. omits these two lines. ffor loue of Maye he dide calle Þe monthe of May þat we knowe knaw. alle; ffor in that month made þey feste, Þat time þey helden most honeste. þai helde fairest & Mest. Þys Darda[n]um gaf hym to chiualrie; Mercury gaf him al to clergie. ¶ þys Dardanus was a noble kynge, Hys Godes schewed hym mykel þynge, & bed him gon P. omits gon. til Ytalye, Toward Samo, þorough Tracye; (Tracie for-sothe ys a lond, Samo a contre, y vnderstond;) Þe whilk Dardan þorow maistrie Mad hem Made þam. boþ on, Samo-Tracye; Samo-Tracie haþ at. his deuise. Syþen he wente in-til vnto. ffrise, & gaf hit P. omits hit. name when he þer cam, After him self Dardaniam; Þe name of ffryse calde Dardanye, Als he calde Tracye Samotracye. Of þys Dardan com a sone Erectorius, Erictonius. þat þer gan wone. þys Erectorius a sone he gat, Troius Troys. ; a noble man was þat Of rightfulnesse & pitee; Ouer alle oþer praised was he ffor a rightful man & hende, Of hym ys mynsyng wiþ-outen ende, ffor he made a cite of ioye After his name, & & after his name. calde hit Troye; Of þys Troye, þys troys þe. stori mones, Com of hym to tuo. noble sones, Þat on þe tone. hight Ile, þat oþer Asserak, Þys wer þer names, þe stori spak; Ile was after his ffader kynge, He made a cite of fair byggynge, And after him selue self. made hit ryght, Ilye after Ile hit hight. Of þis Ile a sone was on, & his name was Laomedon; Þys Laomedon a bataille chees; He was slayn wyþ Ercules. Of Troye was mad destructione Þorow Iason, kynge Pelles sone. Of þys nys nought to tellen her, ffor hit ys nought of oure mater. Of Laomedon com Priamus, Volcontus, and Ysypilus; & a doughter of him cam, Hure name was Esionam. ¶ Of Pryamus, eldest & mor, He had a sone men cald Ector, & oþer syxe, & doughtres two, Þe names may &yogh;e here of þo; Alysaundre, Parys, Deyphebum, Elenim, Helenum. Troyl, Amphimacum; & two doughtres þat of him cam, Cassandram & Pollixenam. Of Troies bifore an oþer sone, Asserak, &yogh;e herde me mone. of þys Asserak now geten es A sone men callede Kapes; & of Kapes Enches was, An[d] of Enches cam Eneas: Þys ys þe kynde, fro gre til to. gre, Bytwyxten betuen. Eneas & Noe. ¶ Bot now donward hit ys þus, ffro Eneas vntil till. sire Brutus: Sire Eneas hadde sones twa, Askaneus was by dame Creusa; I þe bataille of Troye y-monge the y has been altered. þe pres, Hys wyf Creusa þere he þer he hir. les. ¶ Whan þe Duk sire Eneas ffro þe bataille a-scaped was, He cam in-to com to. þe lond of Latyne, & þer wedded dame Lauyne. Latin highte þenne þe þan þo. landes þat men sayn þat Rome in þer men says þat rome. standes. By dame Lauyne þat leuedy lady. He gat a sone þat highte Syluy; Hys eldeste sone Ascaneus, He gat a child son (or sone). Cycillius; "ascane siluius" substituted by a later hand; P. has Sisillius. Þylke Cycylli siluius in the later hand; P. has þat ilk Sisilli. gat þat man Brutus, þat al þys land first wan. Of Brutus cam sire Lokeryn, Kamber, Albanak, Euen, Iulyn: How þey departed þys land in þrynne, Þat may &yogh;e heren wel wyþynne. Now haue y s[eyd] MS. rubbed. sayd. al þe kynde Vntil Lokerynes, vnto Loqeryn. as we ffynde; Now ageynward vntil vnto. Noe, Schortly to seye, wilt will. þou se Þe kynde of alle þat y er of I are. spak, And of Troies sones, of troys. Ile & Asserak/. Lokeryn com of Brutus, Brutus was geten of Cicillius; Cicilli, Askaneus sone was, & Askaneus com of Eneas, sir Eneas. Eneas com of Enchise; Enches, Kapes sone was he; Capes com of Asserak; Asserak, of Troies blod he brak, blode brak. Troies cam of Eryctonius, Erycton com of Dardanus, Dardan ? MS. Dardari. com of Iubiter, Iubiter was Saturnus heyr, Saturnus cam of Cellius, & Selius cam of sire Cretus, And Cretus cam of Cyprim, & Ciprius cam of Setym, Setym com of Iauan, & Iauan of Saphet Iaphet. gan, And Saphet Iaphet. cam of sire Noe: Of Asserak þys ys þe degre. Now schul we seye of ylke sall we say of Ile. parti: Ector cam of Pryamy, Priamus com of Laomedon, Laomedon of Ile gan; began. Ile cam of Troyus, & Troyus of Erectonius; Erector Ericton. cam of kynge Dardan, Dardanus of Iubiter ran, And Iubiter cam of Saturnus, And Saturnus of Celius, Celius com of Cretus, And Cretus com of Cyprius, Ciprius of Cetym gan, & Cetyn com of Iauan; Iauan, Iaphethes Iaphet. sone was he, And Saphet Iaphet. com of sire Noe: Of Troius sones þyse ar þe kyndes, Þat bothe in-to Noe byndes. Now, lordynges, hit were to witen Whi þe bataille of Troye was smiten: Þe laste meschaunce & þe peyne Was for þe Quene of Grece, Eleyne; Þe kynges wyf of Grece scheo scho. was, Þat Parys rauisched rauyst. þorow a cas. Þat werre was in tyme ser, & lasted lastand. two & twenty &yogh;er. ffor þat werre þe barons fledde Þat weren in Troye born & fedde; P. omits these two lines. . How hit bigan, þe laste bale, Listneþ, & [I] schal telle þe tale, P. omits these two lines. Of Troye þe firste destructione, Þat cam com (for þat cam ). þorow Iasan, Pelles sone, Þat wan the Ram wiþ the fles fleez. of golde, Þat neuere man of erthe molde Mighte hit Mot it. wynne byfore wiþ fyght, Bot sire Iasan þe gode knyght MS. knynght. Whan wan. þe Ram wyþ with þe. gilden flees, & stryed Troye wiþ alle þe cites; Bot þe kyng sire Pryami Bigged hit a-geyn fol noblely, nobly. & vitailled hit of ston & corn; & vouted it oft ston all corn. Was hit neuer so fair biforn; Bot siþen þe laste sorewe & peyne Was hit neuere bygged ageyne. How hit bygan, þe laste bale, List Listes. a partie of þe tale.
text.6: Exe de Troia de qua causa bellum fuit ammotum. In Troye was a Duc of prys, Pryamy sone þat highte Parys. Custume was bi þo dawes, In tyme of þe elde lawes, Knygtes scholden suld. kepe bestes, Als y haue herd rede[n] in gestes. þe Bible wytnesseþ wittnes. wel þys þynge Of Moyses & Dauid þe kynge; Schold suld. non bot of gentil blod, Erl or duc, or also als. god, Bestes kepe, bot he were knyght, & stalworthe in armes for to fyght, And hardy, & of honur, He kepte bestes y in. þe pastour, Swylk on was þys ilke Parys, A duk hardi, & a knyght wys; hardy knyght & wys. He kepte bestes in þe feld As a knyght armed wiþ scheld. Als Parys as þis Paris. sat at his hole, Out fro Grece þer cam a bole; To Paris bestes was his draught, And wiþ Parys bole he faught.
text.7: Exe pugnum inter Taurum Troie & Taurum Grecie. ¶ Ilkon oþer gan faste assaille, & Parys biheld þeir bataille; Þey foughte so longe, þai faught so long. hit was a wonder, Bot at þe laste þey &yogh;ede a sonder. An oþer day he com ageyn, & foughte to-gydere, þys boles tweyn; So foughte þei mani daies longe, ffelenous felons. batailles & fol stronge. Paris seide, "Now schal y se " Whilk is worthi to haue þe gre, " & whilk of hem maistri schal haue, " To coroune hym y vouche hit saue." vouchsaue. ¶ A day þei foughte fol felonlike, & stalworly stalworþely. to-gyder gon stryke; So longe þey foughte, þat atte long þai faught at þe. laste Þe bole of Troye doun was caste. When Parys saugh his bole doun, þe bole of Grece he gaf þe croun; & þat was gret curtesye, To gyue þe bole þe maistrie, & late hym gon corouned quit quite. Þat hadde ydon his bole despit. Þere biside þre wicches ware, Ladies were cald, & in þe eyr dide fare; þyse þre stoden & byheld þe þre stode & behelde. þe boles bataille in þe feld, & praised mikel sire Paris Þat he gaf þat þe. bole þe pris; Þey seide he was a man of skyl Þat gaf þe dom as fel þer til; ffor he þat was þe pris worþy, He corouned hym, he crouned. and gaf þe maistri. Þyse þre leuedies were of might; Þe principale, þat mast was Iuno scheo hight; Þat oþer Pallas, þe þrydde Venus, Alle þre leuedies highten ladyes hight þus. Iuno, scheo was gyuere of myght, Pallas gaf wysdam & right, Dame Venus, sche scho. gaf loue til man. Bytwyxte betuex. þise þre a strif bigan, Whilk of hem þam. were fayrest: At Paris dom þei wolde dome þai wald. hit kest. Dame Iuno seide, "hit am y;" Þat oþer seid, "nay truely! certanly. " To Paris dom we graunten alle, " Þe whilk of vs fairest schal falle."
text.8: ¶ De consilio Iuno et adulacione sua. Dame Iuno seide hure auys, " We schal don hit vpon sall do it on. text.10: ¶ Exe de Raptu Helene Regine Grecie. text.12: ¶ Epistola Bruti ad Regem Grecorum. " For þe schame & þe outrage " þat ys don þe noble lynage " Of kynge Dardan, our auncessour, " At meschef ys in deshonur, " In cheytifte longe haue caytifte long haf. þey leyn, " Bot now þey hope to come ageyn; " Wiþ In. o wille alle haue þey spoken, " In o conseil alle ar þey loken— " 10 & wyþ þeym alle y am leued— " Me to haue to þer heued; 10 10-10 Me to haf vnto þer heued. & with þam all I am beleued. text.20: ¶ Bellum inter Goffar & Troianos. Goffar swor he schold suore he suld. hym venge: Of mikel folk he made a renge ffor to falle com. on Brutes ost; & Brutus aspied on spied be. what cost, & sente vntil his fflute on flod, þat raskayl þat þare rescaile. ( ringaille , Wace, l. 846.) to þe schip al &yogh;od, And þer vitaille wyþ hem lede Tyl þey wyste how þey schold he suld. spede: " Ne comes nought com not. out, y &yogh;ow forbede, " Tyl þat y come, for doute & drede." Hys men of armes þat wiþ hym war, was. Þey went a-geyn þe ageyn to. kyng Goffar. Þer hostes sone to-gydere mette, Wyþ spere & swerd with dynt of launce. to-gedere sette; Þe Peyteuynes wel on þeym sought, Þe Trogens stode, þey &. failled nought, Þey stoden wel a gret party, Non wyste ho schold haue þe who suld haf. maystri. Coryneus for tene wax al wod wex þat þe Peyteuyns so wel stod. Out of þe renge he &yogh;ede biside, & ches him folk þat dirste abyde, durst wele bide. & trauersed þe Peyteuynes bataille. Þenne bygan þey mykel for. to faille; Þorow þe þorgh þer. host he made hem weye, On ilk a side he dide þem deye. Corineus þer his swerd he lees; suerde les. An ax he wan sone yn wan in all. þat pres, (As auenture fel, hit cam til was it com to. hande,) Agaynes þat mought þer ageyn þat mot. noman stande, Neyþer noiþer. byhynde ne byforn; þat he ouer-rought, ouertok. þe lif was lorn. þe Peyteuines stode & byhelde How Coryneus faught in þe felde; þey saye saw. his grete hardinesse, & his strokes þat were ay fresche; strokes were euer fresse. Byfore hym, euerylkon þey fleyghe, fleih. ffor drede of his hand to deye. ageyn hym nouht non ne deih. Whan he sey þat þey turned sawe þat þei gaf. bak, He folewed fast, þam. & to þem spak: " ffalse folk! why fle &yogh;e? " ffle &yogh;e alle for drede of all only for. me? Brutus & hys men of Troye, ffor þeyr wynnynge þey mad wynnyng made. gret ioye, & desconfyted discomfite had. þeyr enemys; A castel þey dide make did mak. of pris In þe contre als þey nam; On a fair hil þey rested þam, & cam. Þer parlement, þys was þe ende, " Euerylkon to schip schold wende, " & drawe þer vitaille to þe se, " & weyue al þat ilk all þat. contre." text.22: ¶ Hic primo Brutus intrauit Albion cum suo nauigio apud Toteneys. Al holyke All holy. com þer flote In Dertemuthe, at o a. schote; þat ys þe Ilde þat dame Dyane Hyght hete. Brutus & his kynde alane. Out of þe schip þey com tyl land Wiþ mykel ioye, y vnderstand, When þey wyste þat þey were set To wone þer Diane had þem het, In þat Ilde of Albyon, & þenked þer godes euerilkon. þat ylke tyme was nought late,— fful longe hit ys, long tyme. as seyþ þe date,— þat tyme þat þe tyme. Brutes aryued her, . A þousand & two hunded &yogh;er, So mykel was hit byforn Er Iesu was of Marye born. In þat tyme wer here non hauntes Of no men bot of geauntes. (Geaunt ys more þan man; So seys þe bok, for y ne can; Lyke men þey ar ere. in flesche & bon; In my tyme saw y neuere non. Of membres haue þey haf þe. liknes þe lymes alle þat in man ys.) Twenty geauntz were in þys lond; Of on þe name wryten y fond, Gogmagog, þus was told; ffor he was strong, gret, & bold, Gogmagog þus men hym calle; Þey seyden It says. he was most of alle. Þe Troiens, when þey þe geauntz sawe, Wyþ þer bowes at þeym gon drawe, & also wyþ dart & spere. þe geauntz couþe hem nought couth þam not. were; Vp to þe hilles fro þem þey wend, & left þe Troiens þe pleyn lond. A day þe Troiens made þer feste After þe manere of þer geste, Wyþ caroles, trompes, & pypyng, carols & with oþer glewe. ffor ioie of þer newe wonyng. wonyng newe. See the " twenty ," l. 1761 above. þat ylke nyght, & on þe Troiens smyte doun ryght. fformest was sire Gogmagog, He was most, þat foule froge; Þey faught wyþ trees þat þey vp drowe,— Y can nought seye whilk þey slow,— Oþer wepen had þey non, Bot smyten wiþ tres or casten kast with. ston. When þey had fought, & went to fle, In to þe hilles a-gayn to be, Þan are. were þe Troiens þeym bifore, & gaf þem woundes depe & sore, & slowe þem þe moste part Wiþ spere & bowe, swerd & with bowe with spere & with. dart. Gogmagog, þe Troiens tok; toke. þan saide Brutus 'þat þey schold lok brutus sayd þat þei suld loke. ' Wheþer he wer strenger, or Cornyus.' Corineus. A place to pleye, ordeyned Brutus,— Corineus was wel of þat graunt wele o grante. — ffor to wrastle wyþ þat geaunt; On a clyf faste felde fast. by þe se Þe wrastlyng was ordeyned set. to be; Alle þey &yogh;ede, &yogh;onge & elde, Þat wrastlyng to byhelde.

text.24: Brutus ordinauit & fecit manciones per loca. When þe geauntz were o dawe, þe Troiens hadden na more had more no. awe; Tounes, houses, dide þey make, & mesured lond, & dide hit stake þat ilkon dide his owen his owen ilk did. knowe; þen tyled þey þei tilled. lond, & dide hit sowe. þat tyme þys lond hight Albyon; When Brutus cam, þat name was gon; ffor Albion was Brutes wayne, þerfore he dide hit calle Brutayne. When he & hise fro his of. Troye nam, Troiens were called til to. þey þer cam; After þe Troiens þys name was set, ffor name of Brutes first highte was. Bret; Afterward hit turned eftsones, ffor Brutus folk brutus his folk. was cald Brutones. þat name held hit of Bretoun Long syþen sen. þe Incarnacion, Til Gormound cam & he[re] here. gan aryue, Þe Brutons awey he dide hem did he. dryue. Vneþe siþen any on neuer siþen vnneþis non. ros Þat longe bar any los. Þat of his þerof is. spoken mykel in dede; Ney atte nere at. þe ende &yogh;e may hit rede. Coryneus hadde sesed. a god party Of þe lond, for he was worþy. Þer Corineus dide bataille, Þat contre he tok þat highte Waille; toke to waile. Of Corni & Waille, þat was corn & kataile þat is. wynnyng, Hadde Cornewaille þe name gynny[n]g; Cornewaille com of Coryneus, & Brutayne com of sire Brutus. Ilkon to þeym Ilkon. þer frendes drow, & bygged lond[e] for þeir prow: ffro stede to stede gon gan. þey wende; Þer best was, þer wolde wild. þey lende, & þei. multeplyed, & wel þrof, throfe. & woxen riche, kant & cof. wex ryche cante & kofe. In fewe &yogh;eres a fo &yogh;ers. al þe kynde Of folk, þey woxen wex þei. mykel mynde.
text.25: ¶ Constructio Noue Troie, qui iam dicitur Londonia. Brutus byhel[d] þe mountaynes & auised hym o on. þe playnes, biheld þe wodes, watres, water. & ffen, Where esyest wony[n]g were was eyse wonnyng. for men; Als watres ronnen wel, he byheld, & mede wiþ þe eryed feld, & þe medew with ardawfelde. What fruyt he hoped hit wolde bere. His folk wax faste his fast þe. lond to were, He þoughte in herte he wolde þouht in his hert he wald. do make A newe biggyng for Troyes troie. sake; A stede to seche he chese. he &yogh;ede to se, Wher he best þoughte, him thouht best. & most ayse. A water he fond, & cald hit Tamyse, After his langage, þer on his wyse: " Y schal sette her, .I. will here. oure kynde to ioye, " A cite for þe loue luf. of Troye; " ffor Troye was so noble a cite, noble cite. " Newe Troye þe name schal be." Newe Troye longe hit hight, Tyl som men come wiþ till quant men com of. langage lyght,— Schort speche hadde Schorte speche had. þey in haunt,— & cald Newe Troye, Trenouant. Al ys on, ho one who. so hit knewe, Trenouant & Troye newe; Troye newe ys Trenouant, Two wordes in on, & non ys one & nouht is. want. þen cam com. a kyng, Lud was his name, & made a gate in þat þe. same; Kaer Lud þe name laught, lauht. ffor loue of Lud þat hit aught; MS. lauht. þe toune auht. ffor to haue of hym renoun, Kaer Lud þey calde þei called. þe toun. When Saxons whan Sessons. com, þat name ne couthe,— Þer owen speche was best yn mouþe— þey cald hit Ludden & London: þus þe name cam eft don, son. London, on Saxons Sesson. langage. Now Englysche holden þate Anglis hold þat. heritage, Als men of oþer Als oþer of. nations þat han be here syþ þe Bretons; As þe Has ye. names of contres Ben chaunged, & lawes & fees, Bien changed lawes & fees. ffro þe firste þat þey were named, Als straunge folk han hider y-samed. outen folk haf hidere samed. ¶ Whan Brutus had set his cite & burgeys mad, set. & gaf þeym fee, In lawe wysly to welde, & pes to haue in &yogh;onkþe &yogh;outh. & elde, He regned ffoure & twenty &yogh;er In al Bretaigne fer & ner. Al was Brutaigne, by elde tales, Engelond, Scotlond, & Walys, þyse þre were þenne þan. al on, þat erest was cald are was called. Albyon; Albion highte þyse londes þre, ffor þey ar closed al wiþ þe se.
text.26: ¶ Post decessum Bruty, regnauit Lokerynus filius eius. Brutus had wyþ Ignogyn þre childre: þe eldest hight Lokeryn, Þat oþer, þe toþer. Kamber & Albanak; þise lyuede byhynde Brutus bak, & buryed hym, his þise. sones þre. When he was ded in his cite, Þyse þre brethere in loue & pes Parted þe lond, & ilkon ches, & held þem payed on & were paied of. þer partys, Als þe þre royames lys. remes lis. Lokeryn ches first, he was eldest; þys lond of Logres hit fel hym best. Logeres hit ys after his name; P. omits these two lines. ffor Lokeryn, Logers had hit þe name. P. omits these two lines. Kamber til his part gan &yogh;erne North west þe water of Seuerne, In length, in brede, als hit [gan] & brede as it gan. lye, & for his name kald hit Kambrie: Kambrie hit highte, by þo tales, Þat lond þat now ys cleped Wales All þe lond þat is now Wales. Lamb. MS. has Weles. ; & for þe quen dame Galaes, ffor loue of hure, þat name þey ches. Somme now seye Som say. for oþer reson Galeys was cald, for duk Galon: Whylom þys duk was of power, & gret renoun hadde fer & ner. Albanak was &yogh;ongest of alle, þe moste wodeland gan hym falle. Albanak kalde his partie After his name, Albanie: Albanie highte þat now ys þat is. Scotland, As y schal &yogh;ow telle how y As I sall telle &yogh;ow who it. fand: þe name of Scotlon, Scote. þe firste rote Hit was gyuen a mayden Scote; Scote was ffaraones Pharaon. doughter þe kynge, Tyl to. Scotland was scho wedded &yogh;ynge, And was til to. hire gyuen, & scheo hit aughte; Of hire þe name Scotland laughte. ¶ Numbert, Humbert. a kyng o Huneys, A robbour he was al, hit was it. seys; He robbed þe ildes alle a-boute; Of lyþer felon. men he hadde gret route. Of Albanye men til to. hym spak, þat was a childes bot a childe was. Albanak: Wiþ Albanak fayn wold he fyght, & Albanak faste herd. ageyn hym dight; Bot Albanak sone þer he slow; His folk fledde, & southeward drow, & pleyned þem to sire plenyd vnto. Lokeryn How þey ascaped wiþ mykel pyn. Lokeryn vntil Kamber sent; Þey gadered host, & þyder went. A-gayn þeim com sire Numbert; Humbert. Of þeym boþe was he nought ferd. In an arme of þe se Met þey to-gidere alle þre. þe Bretons were wel mo þan he; In-to þat water þey dide hem fle; þe breþer had more powere þen he/ In þat water fast gan he fle. þey ne ascaped He ascaped nouht. for no thyng & so þer drenkled He dronkend þer. Humbert þe kyng. ffor Humbert gan þer mys-falle, Sire Lokeryn dide þe water calle Humber, after sire Humbert, ffor he dreynte þerin in apert. for he dronkend þer in apert. ffro Alemaigne sire Humbert cam, Þe ildes he robbed al so he nam. Sire Lokeryn tok þat he had reft, Þre faire maydenes in his schip þe maydens in his schyppe. were left: þe kynges doughter of Germyne Was þe fairest of alle þase. þre. Sire Lokery[n] byheld faste &yogh;ened mykill. þat may, Scheo was þe fairest til scho was fairest vnto. his pay; Tendrely he dide hure &yogh;eme, Of alle scheo was most til his of alle women scho mot hym. queme; Estrilde þat maiden hight, Was non so fair in Lokerynes non fairere in Lokerin. sight. Corineus, &yogh;it lyued he þo, He hadde a doughter, & & childere. no mo; He had spoken wiþ Lokeryn To wedde his doughter Gwyndolyn; Guendoline. Lokeryn & he were in couenaunt, conaunt. & þey boþe had mad þe graunt, Þat, for þe loue of fair Estrilde, Lokeryn haf brokene hit, fayn he wylde. broken it wilde. Corineus herde hit sone seye: þer Lokeryn was, he tok þe weye; An ax in his hand he tok, On Lokeryn loþliche gan he lok, & angrily til wrothfully to. hym he spak,— Nought bot wrathe ne bot wreth of. his mouþ brak,— He seide, "Lokeryn, þou art a fol! " þy selue dightest dightes. þe to dol: " þy ded of me þen schalt þou haue; " Þer-fro noman schal þe saue. " Why hast haf. þou my doughter forsaken " þat in trouþe þow haddest þou had. taken? " Þat ys þe þank þat þou me cones! " I hope For holpe? halpe , P. to wynne þat þou inne MS. ime. wones. " Y serued þy fader in many nede, " & yuel &yogh;eldest ille &yogh;eldes. þou me my mede. " I auntred me in many chaunce " þy fader Brutus forto auaunce; " Many strok gaf in many stour " To brynge þy fader til his honur; " & &yogh;it þy self auaunce y wylde. " Bot for on þey calle Estrylde, " fforsake[st] Forsakes. my doughter Gwyndolene, " & dost dos. me despit & tene! " Whil (þou wost) Till þou wote. y am on lyue, " Schalt þou haue Sall þou haf. non oþer wyue! " þou bryngest bringe. þe in foul fame, " & dost dos. me gret onoy me dispite. & schame, " & my doughter Gwendolyn!" & leyde hand on Lokeryn, & wolde han venged þer wild haf venged. his tene, Nadde lordes schoten hem & lordynges schet þam. bytwene & departed hem þam. o twynne, And preied Cornyus forto blynne.
text.27: ¶ Lokerinus desponsauit hic Gwendolenam. Þey conseilled sire Lokeryn: He &yogh;ede & wedded Gwyndolyn. Bot he forgat in none on no. manere ffaire Estrilde þat was hym dere: In Londone he dide hure kepe Vnder erthe þe erth. in a seler depe; Estrylde was longe þare, Seuen &yogh;er & somwhat mare. When Lokeryn schold til suld vnto. hire go, To dwelle wiþ hure a day or to, Vntil his wyf þen tolde tald. he " þat he schold suld. go in priuete, " & stille make stilly mak. his sacrifise " Til his Godes þer MS. þ t . vnto his godes , P. wyþ his seruise; " ffor openly ne fel hit in. nought " To do þat seruise þat he had wrought." he wroht. So longe he pleyed wiþ Estrilde Þat scheo hadde scho had. a mayden childe: Sabren hit highte, as whit as white so. glas, & fairere þan þe moder was. Gwyndolene a child sone. had þan, A sone childe. þat highte Madan: Coryneus hadde hit to loke; When tyme was, set hit to boke. Whan MS. What. Whan, P. þat Corineus was ded, Dame Gwyndolene he misbed; misbede. ffor hure fader dide him tene, He drof awey dame Gwyndolene, & tok Estrild[e] til his quene As dame Gwyndolene had bene. Scheo sey no bettere myghte auaille, Scho gadered an ost in Cornewaylle; Tyl hure frendes scheo pleyned hyre; Ageyn Lokeryn þey gon hem gan þam. atyre Wyþ gret host out of mesure. Vpon a water men calde Esture, In Dorsete-schire, þey mette, & to bataille swyþe þey batale smertly. sette. þe kyng was slayn þer wiþ a schote, þe host destruyed discomfet. ilk a crote; þe quen had þer þe heyer hand, Scheo dide seise al þe land, Scheo did þen take faire Estrilde, & Sabrin þat was hure child, & dide þem yn a water cast; ffor þeym þe name ys roted fast; rotefast. Seuerne hit hight, hate. Robert of Brunne leaves out the Fr. à Cirecestre en mer descent , Wace, I. 71, l. 1473, as it is wrong. for þe child Sabren, ffor þat child þat name we ken: Þat tyme þat þis chaunce fel, Lyuede þe prophete SAMUEL. Gwyndolene was þen stout, Scheo dide þe folk vntil hire lout: Ten &yogh;er wiþ Lokeryn had scheo ben, & siþen fiftene wynter, quen. When Madan couthe kepe his þyng, In hure lyue was he mad kyng. To Cornewaille sche turnede eft, To kepe þat hure fader left. Madan gat vpon his wyf Two sones þat ay lyued þat lyued. in strif; Malyn highte þe eldest broþer, Membrice men calde þat oþer. Madan regned fourty &yogh;er, & left his sones þat lond in wer. wehere. Þyse brethere were euere wrothe, ffor þe lond þey striuen boþe. Membrice for trewes to Malyn sent, In pes to holde a Parlement; Bot Membrice to treson drow, His broþer Malyn priuely he slow; Þorow slaughter & þorow treson & treson. Membrice hadde þe region. Þys Membrice wax he wex. vnkynde, ffordede god men þat he myght þe gude men, we. fynde, Reften oþer Reft þam ouþer. land or lyf, Or forsok & forsoke. his wedded wyf, & haunted synne þe syn. of Sodome: Vnkyndely to bestes he com. Twenty &yogh;er þen had &yogh;ere had. he space, & als he went in to. wode to chace, Many With. wolues alone he mette; Also þeues abouten hym þey set, As deueles þai about hym sette. Lym fro lym hym al to-rent; & so Membrice to deþe dede. went. Þen Saul regned in Iudea, And Eristeus in Lacudemonia. Dunc estoit Samüel prophètes , Et Homer ert prisez poëtes. MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé. Wace , I. 73, note ( b ). Ebrauk his sone was of age, Had þis lond in heritage. He was a ful noble knyght, A gret nauye he dide hym he gert. dight; He was þe first man of þys lond þat robbed by se oþer by sond. bi see & sond. Wiþ Cornewaleys he stod to chaunce, Þey & he robbed al ffraunce; Þey robbed tresor & vitaille; Hom in to Bretaigne þen Home to Bretayn. gan þey saille. When he hadde y-now tresour & fe, had tresore & fee&yogh;. In þe North he made a cite; Kaer Ebrak he calde þat toun; Anoþer, Aclud, vpon Brutoun. Kaer Ebrak first men spak, Syþen men caldyt Eborak; ffor frankysche speche ys nought so lyk, not so like. ffor Eborak þey caldit Euerwyk. Aclud he calde Maidenes toun, Carlauerok es now þe renoun; Maydeneskastel by þat day, Wiþ maydenes had he þer his play. Mais j'o n'en sai por quel raison Li castiax ot nom de Pucèles Plus que de dames, ne d'ancèles Ne me fu dit, ne jo nel di; Ne jo n'ai mie tot oï , Ne jo n'ai mie tot véu , Ne demandé, ne retenu. Mult estourait à home entendre Qui de tot volroit raison rendre. Wace, I. 75, 76, l. 1566-74. Alle were þey dight, þyse madenes gent, & in-to Lombardye war sent To þe Kyng Syluy, Latynes Latyn. sone, To brynge þem at bring þam. to warisone. Þe twenty bretheren, als hit seys, To purchasen hem þey purchace þam. wente þer weys; þey dide þem intil Alemaygne, & alle þe lande was þer wayne.
text.29: ¶ Brutus Grenescheld Rex. ¶ Brutus Grenescheld, his þe. eldeste sone, In þys lond he lefte to wone; Twelue wynter he regnede here Al in þes & gode manere. Rex leylus. ¶ He hadde a sone þat hyghte Leyl, He made a toun wiþ his conseil: Caerlel hit hatte, as men hit seye. Bot Leyl ageyn þat he schold deye, Preyed faste in his elde, ffor his lond he mought nought & his lond couth not. welde. Ilkon on oþer werre sought; ffor doute of hym left þey ryght nought, Ne he couþe be no couth no bettir. iustyser: He regned fyue & twenty &yogh;er.
text.30: . ¶ Nomina prophetarum tempore isto. In his tyme was þe prophete Amos; And Hyen and Aggos, Hien & Aggeos. And þe prophete Sakarye, From Geoff. Mon. Wace (I. 79, l. 1660-4) puts "Solemons, Amos, "Aggéus et Johel" in Rehudybras's reign, after l. 2238 here. In þat tyme preched prophecie. He lys Leyl lygges. at Karlel, as þe stori spak, & Brutes Brutus lygges. at &yogh;ork biside Eborak
text.31: ¶ Rehudybras Rex fecit Wyntonium & Canter|burium & Schefton. & Schefton in another hand. After Lleyl regned Rehudybras; Rudhudibras. To iustice þe folk, fol wys folk noble. he was; He acorded al his barons Pees to holde, & he. made hem somons; He made Wyncestre & Canterbyre, & þe castel of Chestebury; Chestirschire. (Cestebire , Wace.) Awhileon egle inserted by a later hand. spak þanne, & prophesied, Bot som men seide þat he lyed. One spak þer & prophecied Aquile: men sais he lied. P. Uns aigles , MS. du Roi, 27. un ange , MS. de Ste.-Genev. Y. fol. 10. Wace , I. 79. note a. ¶ Aquila Septonie. Rehudybras, in his power, He regned nyne & fourty &yogh;er. Qarante ans, un mains, réna cil. Wace, I. 79, l. 1657.
text.32: ¶ Bladutus Rex fecit Balneum. In another hand. ¶ After þe Kyng Rehudybras, Bladut his sone corowned was. Bladut dide many maystri, He gaf hym al to nygromaunci; Hote þe hate. bathe he dide make, ffor mikel god to mannes sake; He dide leye þerin þer it. springes, Tonnes of bras wiþ queynte bras quante. þynges Þat make þe water euere hot; What ys þerynne, noman wel wot; Bathe, for baþyng, þe name hight; Byside þe baþe a MS. &. P. has a. temple he dight,— Þe temple name was Mynerue,— Þe folk to receyue & to serue; A fire ? MS. After. A fire , P. he dide make þer-inne, Euere to brenne & neuere to blynne. Bladut wrought many meruaille, Many god þyng þat &yogh;it wyl vaylle; many a gude þat &yogh;it'auaile. Atte laste he wolde fleye, ffeþer-hames he made hym sleye; At London he tok his flyght, & fley as fer as he myght Vpon a temple sire þe temple of. Appolyn, Þeron he fel, & m[a]de his fyn; Sire Appolyn so doun hym cast, Þat body & bon hit al to-barst: to brast. Twenty wynter was he kyng, At London he mad his endyng.
text.33: ¶ Leyr Rex fecit Leycestre. After hym þen regned Leyr, Þat was his sone & his eyr; ffourty wynter þen regned he; Vpon Sore he made a cite, Kaer Leyr he dide hit calle, Leycestre þe name ys now wiþ alle. Þre doughtres hadde sire Leyr, Mighte he haue non oþer eir, Þe eldeste highte Gonorille, Þat oþer Ragaw, Ragau (but Ragawe l. 2297, &c. below.) Wace has Ragau. þe þrydde Gordylle, Gordille. (Gordéille, Wace.) Bot Gordille, Gordille. (Gordéille, Wace.) was &yogh;engest, & hure louede þe fader best. Leyr, when he was in elde, His lond fol wel myght he nought welde; He þoughte his doughtres gyue hosebandes, & twyxten hem parten his landes; Bot of hem first he þoughte wald he. here Which of hem had hym most dere; He assaied asked of. ilk by þeym self one, Þe eldest first of ylkone. ¶ He com & spak to Gonorylle, " Doughter, sey me new þy wylle, " How mykel woldest þou me loue " &yogh;yf þou were lady me aboue?" Whan swylk a whan þat. word scheo herde neuene, Scheo swor by þe Godhed of heuene, Wheþer scheo were mayden or wyf, Scheo wolde loue scho wild luf. hym as hure lyf. " Doughter," he seyde, "graunt mercy! " Of me þou getes gret curtesy." ¶ He com & spak vnto Ragawe: " Doughter, sey me þe soþe sawe: " How mykel louestou me wyþ wylle?" & Ragaw þoughte on thouht of. Gonorylle, Scheo seide: "ffader, y loue þe more " Þan al þat in þys werld euere wore!" " Doughter, þat ys loue ynow; " Þat louyng schal be þi lufyng sall falle. for þy prow." ¶ He com to Gordylle þat was &yogh;ongest; Of boþe þe oþer he loued hure best. Scheo wyste how þat hure systres seyde, Of a gyle hit was a-breyde. " Doughter, how mikel louest lufes. þou me?" " ffader," scheo seyde, "y schal sey þe: " Als my fader y haue þe loued, " And euere more schal to be proued." & euer sall to be reproued. " Ne louest þou Loues þou. me namore, mi dere?" " &yogh;ys, fader, þou lyst listen. & here: " Ryght als þou has, so artow worþy, " So mykel loue to þe owe y." Þat word tok he yuel til ill to. herte, He vnderstod hit al ouerþwerte; Scheo seyd nought glosyng til glosand to. his wille, Als Ragaw dide, & Gonorille; Þerfore he answerd þus a-geyn: " Of me þe þynkes þink. gret desdeyn, " & hast has. myn elde in despit; " Of myn for euere þou art quyt; " Þou seist nought as þy sistren seis, " Þyn answere his nought of þin ansuere. so curteys; " Þerfore y schal sall. myn heritage " Gyue þy sistres in mariage; " Þey schol sall. depart hit þeym by-twene, " & þou þer-fro [go] quit & clene: " Of þem alle y loued þe mest, chirest þe maste. " & now y se þou loues me lest!" Gordille wolde namore no more wild. seye, Ne striue ageyn, bot &yogh;ede hure weye; Ne he ne saide namore til hire, Bot wente fro hure al in he went away full of. ire. In þys tyme þat þey were wrothe, He mariede þe oþere doughtres boþe; Þe kyng of Scotland þat on dide wedde; Hennieis Hennis. of Cornewaille, Ragaw hom ledde; Þey acorded alle at her pay To parte þe lond al by his day. Dame Gordylle wiþ wraþthe sche went, Of many men mikel was by-ment, was ment. Þat sche hadde no warisoun Neyþer of rente, lond, rent of lond. ne toun; & he forbed hire lord to take In his lond, for warison sake; Þerfore he schamede hure þerfor aschamed hir so. sore; & hure ouer-þoughte hir forþouht. mykel more Þe wraþthe of hure fader þe kyng Wel more þan any oþer þyng. þan þe tynsell (loss) of oþer thyng. ¶ Aganyppus, þe kyng of ffraunce, Herde speken of Gordylles Gordille. chaunce,— Alle men leyde on hure how men said of hir. gret pris Þat sche was fair, curteys, & wys,— & þoughte &yogh;yf he þouht if. he myght hure haue, Al his honur schold sche saue. ? MS. haue. P. reads suld scho saue. He sente messegers to Leyr, To wedde his doughter he was in speyr; Bot Leyr had nought &yogh;it forgeten How lyghtly sche had of hym of him had. leten: Leyr sent hym ageyn to seye, " His land was gyuen to his he had gyfen his lond to. doughtres tweye; " Hure body on hym he vouched saue; " Wiþ hure nought elles myghte he haue." To Leyr he sente &yogh;ut eft ageyn, & seyde Leyr & teld hym. for certeyn " Þat he ne askede non oþer þyng, " Bot onlike his doughter &yogh;yng." Leyr þen graunted þem also sone; þam alsone. Wiþ hure to wende þey made hem bone; To schip þey wente, & vp þe sayl, Þey askede namore asked þei non. apparayl. Now ys hure falle þe fairest chaunce, Gordylle ys mad her is mad. quene of ffraunce. Þenne þe Lo þo. men þat kyng Leyr Had ordeyned to ben his eyr, þey nolde soffre hym nought to take, Hys owen propre awen propir. for to make. When Hewyn. þe Duk of Cornewaille, Al þe souþ tyl hym gan taylle; Manglanus, Meglan. þe kyng of Scotlond, Þe north he tok hit til north toke to. his hond; Leyr was al at þer baundoun, & þey sette hym to lyuersoun; liuerison. Þey sette hym honurable to be, Wiþ fourty knyghtes à cinquante chevaliers , Wace. of meygne. Leyr held hym payed of þat coueinaunt; was payed of þat conant. To holde hym þat, þey swore þe graunt. ¶ Wyþ Menglanus was Leyr þe kyng fful wel serued atte þe comyng; gynnyng. Sone afterward þey fillede of þei filled. Leyre, & dide his liuere for to apeire. After þe peirement After apeyrment. of his liuere, Were abated of his meyne; Þe quene, his doughter Gonorille, Hure þoughte most scorn & ille Of þe meyne hure fader held; Gret outrage scheo hit held. Sche seyde vntil Manglanus, " ffolyly fouly (? for fonly , foolishly). hold we þis meyne þus, " Þat mykel þyng al day notes; " & my fader in elde dotes " To halde hold. swylk a squierye, " & gret costage in ryotrye. " Þerfore y rede, doþ als y seye, " Lat somme of hem go som of þise go forth. þer weye." Þen was ordeyned to lesse þer men; Of fourty knyghtes abated MS. abyde þe. abatid , P. (30 are left, see. l. 2428.) ten. Þen was sire Leyres rente abated; He auaunsed first hure þat hym hated; Scheo was first maried of alle, And first dide scheo his honur falle. Alas! to fewe Allas fo. childre men fynde, Þat ben to fader & moder kynde! Nota.
text.34: De ingratitudine filiarum, & planctu patris eorum, Leyr. Now gynnes Leyr to myslyke; " Sone," he seyde, "þey gynne me swyke " ffro myn aboue MS. alone. aboue , P. y am put lowe, " & &yogh;it scha[l] more &yogh;it more. wyþynne a þrowe. " Myn oþer doughter wyl y proue, " Þey scheo be what scho is worth. wroþ to my byhoue;" & dight hym wyþ his apparaille To wende & went him. in to Corne-waille. He dwelt nought þer fullyk had not bene þer fully. a &yogh;er, Þat þey ne made hym gret daunger, & lessede his knyghtes & his. oþer men: Of þritty þey abated ten, And &yogh;it of twenty abated fyue; Þen wold Leyr han ben of lyue; De trente homes l'ont mis à dix, Puis le misrent de dix à cinc. Wace , p. 91, l. 1946-7. " Alas!" he seyde, "y hider cam! " ffro wycke vntil wors y nam." To Gonorille a-gayn he &yogh;ede, He wend sche wold heue mended wald amend. his nede, Haue gyuen hym als scheo hadde as he had. byforn, Sche swor by god þat hure leet suore þat god lete hir. be born, Þat scheo ne wolde, day ne nyght, Halde bot hym & a knyght.
text.35: ¶ Lamentacio Regis Leyr. Þenne bygan Leyr to sorewe, & ment his mone euen & morwe; Þe grete richesse he hadde byforn, Al was a-weye & y-lorn: " To longe a lyue haue y be, Now ouer long o lyue haf .I. bene. " Þat euere scholdy þys day se! " Ensample of fforbisen bi. me men may take, " & warnyng of sibbe, & warned be. for my sake! " Y hadde richesse; now haue y non! " My wyt & al myn help & my happe. P. omits the next fourteen lines, which are, how|ever, in Wace (p. 92-3), and are taken more or less from Boethius, de Consolatione. ys gon! " Lady ffortune, þou art chaungable; " O day art þou neuere stable; " No man may of þe affye, " Þou turnes hym doun þat er was heye; " Þat now ys doun, vpward þou turnes; " Wyþ þe, nys non þat he ne mournes; " Bot þere þou gyuest þy loue lokyng/, " He ys worschiped als a kyng; " & whom þou turnest þy lokyng fro, " Sone ys he doune yn sorewe & wo; " Þe vnkynde þou wilt vp reyse, " Þe kynde þou puttest to meseysey; " Wyþ kyng & erl, when þe myslikes, " Þer welþe a-wey to wo þou strykes. " When y had god gold. & welþe ynow, " Þen fondy frende þat to me drow; my frendes vnto me fast drouh. " Now pouerte ys put me byforn, " Þat al þer sight fro of. me ys lorn; " Þer loue schold lange to me suld longe to. þorow ryght, " Þat schewe me of loue þei mak of luf. semblaunt ne syght. " Dame fortune, þy louely lok " & þy gode wille fro me þou tok, " When y blamed my doughter &yogh;yng, " & gaf no kepe til hure kennyng/, " Þat seyde me soþ apertely: " 'Als y had, so was y worthy, " 'And also mykel scheo loued me:' " Scheo seide bettere þan y couþ se; " Hure word noþyng y ne vndestod, " But mad me wroþ: y couþe no god, " Y parceyued nought what was hure tent, " Bot now fele y wel what scheo ment; " Y fele hit we[l] þe soþe hit endes; " Whyder may y now to seke my may I to seke me. frendes? " &yogh;yf y seke hure for any frame, " Þey sche me weyue, scheo nys & scho me weyue scho nes. to blame, " ffor y defended hure my lond, " Ne nought hure gaf, ne hure Ne nouht I gaf hir. ne fond: " Naþeles, hure wol y seke, " Y fond hure euere god and meke; " Wisdam sche has me ytaught, " Wysdam schal make hure wiþ me saught; " &yogh;yf y may nought bryng hure þerto, " Wors þan þe oþere may sche nought do; " Scheo seyde He said. a þyng y scha[l] now proue, " 'Als hure ffader scheo wolde me loue;' " & als scheo seyde, proue schal y " Hire kyndenesse & hure curtesy." When Leyr had longe sore syked, Hys mone ment, & myslyked; He dighte hym, als of chaunce, Right ouer þe se forþ into & ouer þe se he ferde to. ffraunce. Vp at Calays Chaus , MS. du Roi, 27; Kaleis , MS. Cot. Vitel. A. x.; Chain , MS. de Ste. Gen. Y. fo. 10; Wace, p. 95. he hauene At kaleis vp heuen he. hent, To þe quene priuely he sent; At a cite he abod, Whyle a man his till a man þe. message rod, & telde þe quene al hys cas, And how he vp aryued was; How hys doughtres had wyþ hym wrought, Al his meschef, furgat [he] mischefe forgate he. nought.
text.36: ¶ De gratitudine Gordylle. Gordille, when sche wyste þe pleynt, Hure faire colour gan wex al gan all to. feynt Al þat scheo had yn hure power, Scheo bitaught hit þe messeger, & bad hym go hym forte atyre Wyþ honur, to come & speke wiþ hire; " Bot byforn sendes biforhand send. my lord þe kyng, " & warne hym of his comyng." Þe messager spedde hym swyþe, & broughte Leyr tydyng blyue; Vntyl anoþer cyte he &yogh;ede, & dight hym al þat hym was nede. When he was dight at hys wylle, To þe kyng he sent, & to Gordylle, Þat he was ryued y þat contre, To speken þe kyng, & his doughter se. ¶ When he wyst þat Leyr schold come, Agaynes hym ful faire þey nome, & fair receyues hym aforn for. þe quen Als a man he hadde nought seen: He comaunded yn hys kynedam To worschipe hym where þat he cam. When he had dwelled longe space, & telde how his doughtres dide him chace, Sire Aganyppus was curteys; He samned an ost of his ffraunceys, & comen wyþ Leyr ouer þe se To helpe to wynne a-gayn his fe. Cordille wiþ hure fader went, Wyþ leue of hure lord his host had sent. Þe dukes sone byforn hem þey fond, Þey slowe þem boþe, & wonne þe lond. Þre &yogh;er after was he kyng, In ful seysyne made plenere seisen. hys endyng; Dame Gordylle he made his heyr; In Leycestre sche leyde hure fader Leyr, In a temple solempnely; Þe temple highte temple Iany. Sone after fel þe chaunce þat chance fell. þus, Deide hure lord Aganyppus. In hure wydewehod sche had þe honur ffyue &yogh;er als conquerrour. Not in MS. du Roi, 27; but four other French MSS. have "Puis a "cinq ans tenu l'onor." Wace , p. 98. Hire two sistres had two sones; How þey dide, þe story mones: Gonorilles sone highte Mongan, Gonorill son hight Morgan. Þat oþer Condage, a noble man. When þys Morgan and þys Condage Cinedagius, Wace , p. 98, l. 2108. Waxen were, & of age, To Gordylle þey gaf bataille. & scheo ageyn dyde hem trauaille. ffirst were þey boþe ouercomen, & at þe laste Gordille was þei. nomen, And held hire longe in þer prison, ffor hure hir. myght go no raunson. When no raunson myght for hure hir. go, Hure hir. self for sorewe dide sche slo.
text.37: ¶ Exe fratres diuiderunt regnum. Wha[n] þat Condage & Morgan Margan (like Wace and Geof|frey, and henceforth to line 2599.) Of Gordylle þus þe land wan, Condage tok (als hym þoughte best) Ouer Humber þe Northwest. Þenne Morgan þe South ches, & bot. two &yogh;er þey helde þe lond yn pes; Bot Couetyse þat neuere restes, Venym amonges men hit kestes. Morgan hadde enuiouse felawes, Þat wyckedly seyde til hym sawes; Þem were leuere werre þan pes. He lystned hem, & þat he ches. Þus þey seyde vntil Morgan, " Þat þat left out. þow art eldest, & baldest man, " & hast has. bot half, & &yogh;it þe leste; " & he ys &yogh;ongest, & haþ he &yogh;ongere & has. þe meste, " And þat ys al þyn owen gylt. " Þou may haue hit al &yogh;yf þat þou wilt; " To ride, &yogh;yf þat þou wile bygynne, " & al all. þe lond[e] myght þou wynne; " Þou getest getis. folk wyþoute noumbre " To sese þe londe by-&yogh;onde Humbre. " &yogh;yf þou bygynne forto ryde, " Condage schal nought þe abyde." Morgan dide atte her did after. conseille & wroughte hym self to wroþer haylle; He passed Humber, destruyed þe lond, Brente & robbed al þat he fond. ¶ Condage herde hit sone seye; He dighte his host to stoppe hys weye Morgan herd telle þat Condage Com wiþ gret host & outrage; He turned bak, & gan to fle South, fro contre to contre. ffer yn to Walys fled Morgan; & Condage folewed, & hym ouer-ran.
text.38: ¶ De morte Morgan per contumeliam. And þer yn Walys Morgan slow. Þorow hit haþ þat þe name now, Nota. " Clow Morgan" Fr. Marge ; that is, Margate in Kent! says de Lincy. Wace. i. 100. ys now þe name, ffor Morgan deide in þat same.
text.39: ¶ Condageus Rex. Þen had al, sire Condage, Þe lond holyk holy. in heritage; Þrytty wynter was he kyng, In pes he made his endyng.
text.40: ¶ De prophetis & Romulo. Ysayas. ¶ In his tyme was Isaye, & preched þenne þe prophecie; & þe prophete Osee, Y þat tyme þan þat tyme. lyuede he; And þe Emperour Romulus & his broþer sire Remus, Þyse two brethere made Rome, Þer holy chirche gyueþ þe kirk gifes his. dome; Þre hundred &yogh;er & foure score & seuentene, þus fer fell. [Not in Geoffrey.] byfore Regned kynges y þis landes Ar Rome wer set þer hit now standes.
text.41: ¶ Ryual Rex. After þe kynges tyme þis hyng. Condage, Ryual his sone tok held. þe heritage. Þre dayes in his [tyme] reyned blod— Y ne wot why, ne vndestod,— & wox so mykel mynde of flyes, Men deide by gates bi strete. & by styes: Alle men hadde þerof gret drede Tyl hit sesede & ouer &yogh;ede.
text.42: ¶ Gargustius Rex. After þe kynges tyme Ryual, Gargustius Gurgustius , P. and Wace. his sone had al; After þis þis, P. his sone , Lam. Cargustius, Regned his sone CYCYLLIUS; Rex & after þe kyng Cycilly, Was Lago kyng, his cosyn ney; kyng cosyn gurgusti. Rex After Lago was Kynmar Rimar , Wace, p. 102, l. 2184: Kinmarcus , Geoffrey. kyng, Rex Cysillies sone, & had þe þynge. After Kynmare regned þan Hys sone, þat highte Garbodian. Gorbodian ( Gorbodiabo , Wace.) Rex Garbodyan Gorbodian ( Gorbodiabo , Wace.) had two sones, fful enemys, þat &yogh;it men of. mones; Þe eldest he hight sire fferreus, Þat oþer men calde Porreus; Might þer neuere pes be þeym bytwene In non acord, bot euere tene. Þe while towhils. þer fader was on lyue, ffor þe royalme gon þey to stryue; 2 Al þus þey ferde wiþ gret enuye, Whilk scholde haue þe seignurie. 2 2-2 not in P. Porrex was &yogh;ongest, eldest (wrongly; see line 2642.) & most felon, His þought was ay vpon treson Where-þorow he moughte þer þorh he thouht. his broþer slo. Þat oþer herd þat, dide hym to go En France oltre mer s'enfui. Wace , p. 103. fforþ in to ffraunce, for doute of gyle. Þe king Syward he serued a while, & gadered þer god a. party; Wiþ schipes com ouer baldely, & til his broþer gaf bataille, And deyde sone, hit myght nought vaille, Bot at þe firste was he slayn, & al his folk, knyght & swayn. Iudon, þer his. (Luclon lor mere, Wace: Widen, Geoffrey. ) moder, herde wel how Þat þe ton þat oþe[r] þe toþer. slow; Scheo louede mykel þe slayn broþer, & dedlyk dedely. hated sche þat oþer; ffor als vnkyndely as þey wrought, Þerfore vnkyndenesse an vnkynes. sche þought. A nyght hure sone to bedde was gon, On hym com his moder Iudon; Ilk of hure maydones, a knyf she bar, Porrex þrote a two sche schar, And on peces hym al to-hewe; MS. alto hewe. P. better, all to hewe. Swylk a vengaunce noman knewe: Longe was spoken of þis men spak of þat. chaunce, Of Iudon Luclon , Wace, p. 104. & of hure vengaunce. ¶ When þyse breþer þus werre bygon, were gon. Eyr of blod was þer non Þat oughte haue myght haf. þe heritage, Was þer non left of ryght lynage; Bot to ffyue kynges þey lefte till fyue kynges. þe lond, Þat fourty wynter þe werre fond; Ilk of þem þat most was of myght, mast myght. Bynam þat oþer of his right; þe powere of his myght. Mesure ne lawe, ne held no man, Bot whoso myghte, of oþer wan; Þat rycchest were, most bar þem stout, In loue ne in lawe In lawe ne luf. wold non of hem lout.
text.43: ¶ Diuisio regni. Þat tyme in Scotlond regned Stater; In Logers was þe kyng Pyncer; Piguer , Wace, l. 2250, p. 105. Rudak was kyng of Walsche men; & Cornewaille had þe duk Cloten. Cloten of kynde was next of alle To wham þe heritage sholde falle; Bot for þe oþer were most of myght, Þey gaf nought of al his ryght. Þys duk Cloten hadde a child, A doughti bacheler & a wyld; Þat tyme was he man most worþy, & ffayr waxen, & wel an hey; " Donwal doughti" Donvalomolinus , Wace; Done|walmolus , MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3 , Colb. ib. Dunwallo Molmutius , Geof|frey. was his name, Of curtesey had he þe fame, Ouer þeym alle passed his power; ffor first he slow þe kyng Pyncer, & seysed þe lond til his byhoue. Vpon Stater &yogh;it wolde he proue; Wyþ force of armes he gan to ride, Stater & Rudak he þought to byde. Rudak & Stater herde so son. seye, Þey swore to-gydere on hym to deye.
text.44: ¶ Respice Donwalem Conquestorem. Ageyn Donwal þey broughte þer host, In to halues, tuo parties. by diuerse cost; Rudak of Walys had þat o þe to. syde; Toward þe northe Stater gan ride; Þey brente & slowe, nought wolde þey spare, Of castel & toun þey made bare. Donwal Donvale, Wace. herde his lond þey wasted, He dighte his host, & to þem hasted; He mette wiþ hem, and dide hem stande,— Þey were in feld þritty þousande; Gret noise at her samny[n]g was, P. omits these lines. Wiþ trompe & taber, & horn of bras, P. omits these lines. & grete strokes, & sore sette, Wer gyuen when þey to-gedere mette, Helm þorow smyten, & many a scheld, P. omits these lines. Many a knyght was feld in feld, P. omits these lines. Of many hauberks was hewen þe maille. P. omits these lines. Longe þey stode, & gaf bataille; P. omits these lines. Non wyste ho scholde haue wist who suld haf. þe maystri, Þe parties were boþe so doughti. Donewal was werreour god, Hym ouerþoughte forþouht. þey so wel stod; Sex hundred of hyse he colede weled he. ( Cole , cull, L. colligere; wele , Old Icel. velga; O. H. Germ. wellen , choose: Stratmann.) out Þat proued were, hardy & stout; He dide þer armes al doun leye Pryuely biside þe weye, & armed þem on alle manere Als here enemis armes were, Þer scheldes toke, helm & gleyue, Þeyr enemyes forto deseyue. Þey diden alle at his auys, & toke þe armes of þere enemis of armes of his. Þat leyen dede, wyþ here & all þer. queyntise, & dight hem on her enemys wyse. Donewal saide, "comes alle wyþ me, " & þider as y go, so schol sall. &yogh;e." Þey &yogh;ede spiande her & þer In what bataille þe kynges wer; When þay wyste alle at ones, Trauersed þem for þe nones Als þey had ben of on. þeyr party, & syde by side ryden hym by; þam bie. Þe kynges to þem gaue no tent, Bot forþ in here bataille went. " Haue at!" seyd Donwal, "now ys leyser!" Puis s'escria: férés, férés [strike]. Wace , p. 107. & seysede Rudak & Stater, & boþe at ones þeym lyghtly slow, & of þat pres þem smartly drow, & caste þer armes of, þe vnknowen, vnknawen . . . . . awen. And armede hem eft wyþ here owen. When þey hadde þer armes nomen, And to þer host ageyn were comen, ffaste þey fullen opo þem folowed on þam. alle, Þat sone þer force gan doun falle; Þat oþer side stod nought stoute (bad reading). in stour, ffor þey had lost tynt. þer gouernour; Þey fledde to wode & to mountaynes, ffor slayn were þeyr cheuentaynes. Whan Donewal hadde þe maistrie, Hys pes he dide hit sette & crye, Þat so god pes was neuere or, Ne þerafter schal namor. neuer more. A coroune of gold he dyde hym make, Swylk on neuere for kynges sake Was in Bretaigne wrought byforn, Ne on kynges heued set ne born. He stabled swylk pes & gryth, & wyþ his sel confermed confermed it. wyþ, Þat ylka temple & ilk cite Schold haue & holde suld haf & hald. þys dignite, Þat &yogh;if a man had don trespas, Robbed, or slayn, or oþer cas, &yogh;yf he tyl a temple cam Er men hym wiþ handes nam, MS. nan. Or to a cite go þan his weye, Non yuel scholde men til hym eft seye; of ill suld no man to him say. & also to hem þat to þat (qui as carues, Wace ). at plowes &yogh;ede, &yogh;yf any man dede hem yuel dede, did ille dede. — Oþer til or to. market &yogh;yf on schold go, &yogh;yf men dide hem any wo, Hit was teld told. for felonye, & worþy was were. þer-fore to deye. ffourty wynter was he kyng; At London he made his endyng; A temple þere dide he make ffor þe pes & concordes sake; In þat temple mad for þat pes Was he leyd, & þere he ches. Of hym were two noble sones, Als þe story of þem mones: Belyn þe eldest, þat oþer Brenne; Donewal þer fader, God y bykenne.
text.45: ¶ Diuisio Regni inter Belynum & Brennum. Belyn and Brenne parted þe lond On þys manere, als y hit fond: Brenne schold of Belyn holde His lond, fro Humber northward he tolde; Ilk del in-tyl Katenesse Belyn lete brenne of him holde fro humber north his lond he tolde Ilk a dele vnto Cathenesse. Held Brenne of Belyn, more ne lesse; Seruise schold he do þer fore, He & hyse for euere more. Belyn held til his partie, Logers, Londres, Wace. Wales, & Cornubye. So þey helden hit held it. fyue &yogh;er In pes & in faire maner; Bot contek & couetyse Out of þe north wyl alwey will algate. ryse, ffor þus men seide by elde be olde. dawe, & &yogh;it hit ys a comun sawe: " Souþerne sothron. der gos Northward, " & Norþerne northren. werre to þe south ys hard; " Bot norþern sothron. der & souþern northren. werre, " Non dredeþ, oþer þey come nought nerre; " Bot norþerne [werre] northern were. þat ys þe doute, " & southern souhren. der þe norþ dos loute." In Brennes tyme, als &yogh;e may here, Hit ferde in þys ilke manere; Abouten Brenne were lozengeours, Bakbiteres & werreours: On was þer þat ful euele spak To whette Brenne to reyse contak; One þer was þat wikly spake bituex þe breþer raised contake. Þus he spak al wiþ tresoun:— Y gyue swyche gyf suylk. Crystes malisoun!—
text.46: ¶ Respice verba detractorys. " We haue merueille in oure þought— " Bot non to þe dar sey ryght nought— " Þat of so gret an heritage, " Þat long & brod ys in passage, " Þat þy fader hadde in his baillye, " & hast þerof so litel partie! " And &yogh;it, als litel as þow has, " Þou schalt sall. hym serue at alle cas! " Wiltow holde longe will þou hald. þat wyse, " To serue þy broþer in alle seruise? " Artow þral or bastard, " Or more vyl or more coward, cuhard. " Þat þou schalt sall. do hym þer-fore homage, " & art of þe same parage? " Þe ffader hym gat, he gat þe, " & of o moder born ar er. &yogh;e. " Sythen &yogh;e boþe breþere are, " & of o ffader & moder ware, " Wherfore has Belyn, & why, " Of þe & þyne swych seygnury? suylk sengnori. " Brest a two þat ilke Brist it þat þou with þe. bond, " Do hym no seruise for þy lond! " ffor no lord holdeþ ffor lord ne holdes. þe, Belyn, " Namore schaltow holde no more sall þou hald. hym for þyn. " Trowe til vs & oure consayl! " To þy worschipe hit wole auayl! " To non of þy vasselage " Ne seye we neuere do suche outrage! " Þorow whas whos. queyntyse, & þorow whas whos. art, " Ches Belyn hym þe beste part? " Þer falles non oþer chesyng to; " Bot most schal haue, þat most Mast sall haf þat mast. may do. " More artow worth, & more hardy! " Þat haue we sen fol certeynly " When þou slowe þe Duk Cenflo Césio . . . . Moriane, Wace. " Þat al Morine langede longed. to, " Þat al Scotland wolde haue wasted; " Þy doughtinesse to deþe hym hasted. " I trowe of þys þou þoughte byforn, " Bot priuely þou hast hit boren, " Þat we ne scholde mynge suld nempe it. for drede. " Now [we] rede, þow we þe. do hit in dede, " And forto fond to. wynne hit ilkadel. " Doute þe nought, þou may ful wel, " ffor we ne schulle sall. þe neuere faille, " Þe while we lyue & mowe vntill we lyf & may. trauaylle, " &yogh;yf þou ne trowest trowe. þat we þe seye, " Do þe ouer vntil Norweye, " And þe kynges doughter þou take; " Þy party may þou þe bettere make. " Haue þou Norweye & Scotland, " & vs alle vnto þyn hand; " Agaynes no land schuldestow wende, suld þou wend. " Þat þou ne gete þe fairere ende; " Ne Belyn durste þe nought neuer. abide " &yogh;yf þou ageyn hym woldest wille. ride. " &yogh;yf þou haue y-þought þouht. make þy bone, " Go by tyme, & come right sone, " Al by þe syde of Myrreyue, " Þat Belyn no þyng aparseyue. " Perauenture he wolde hym greue " &yogh;yf þou wyf toke wyþoute leue, " Or oþer wyse men wold wald. hym seye " Þat þou haddest had. of hym non eye." On þis wyse conseilled þey hym so, & Brenne tristed triste. þer conceille to: He passed in Norweye, he gan aryue, passed ouer in Norway gan ryue. & asked þe kynges doughter to wyue. Þe kynges name was Alfynges, He graunted Brenne al his askynges, Holyk holy. Bretaygne for to wynne, When he wolde his werre bygynne. Often tydyng to Belyn was brought, Whider Brenne &yogh;ede, & what he sought; Belyn had þanne suspecion Þat for felonye was hit don, & þoughte he scholde suld. wyþynne a whyle His owen deseite hym self bygile: He seyde, "on stelþe he sekes hym pray; " Hit schal nought helpe, &yogh;yf þat y may; " Ne schal nought Brenne bede me trypet treget (from trans and jactare ). " Þat y ne schal turne hym wiþ a forset." Belyn seysede Northhumberland, Boþe castel & toun tok in-to his hand; Alle þat were Brennes byforn, ffor werre he storede stroyed. þem wyþ corn, & folk ynow to þeym dide sende, to þam he send. Agaynes Brenne þem forto defende. Hym seluen &yogh;ede wiþ an ost, & rengede by þe se seis. cost; Hauen to aryue Hauen & lond. þey hym wyþsette, Bot þorow bataille oþer barette. ¶ Tyl Brenne men broughte brod broth (1. hasty, fierce; 2. direful). tydyng Þat Belyn had sesed his þyng/. He hadde his wyf, & was al &yogh;are Wyþ fair folk in flod to fare. Lyþerly lyked þat lady gent; Sche wepede scho wepe. weddyng, & mykel hit ment, ffor scheo had loued longe byfore Þe kyng of Denmark, er Bren com þore; or brenne com þore. & þe kyng had loued hyre, Longe scheo was of his desire. Þe kyng of Denmark highte Goodlak, Gutlake (Gurlac, Wace ). Scheo sent hym a lettre þat þus spak/: " Longe haue y loued þe kyng of Denmark/; " Þat loue is loken & leyd in ark; " An vncouþ on of fer schal fonge MS. fonde. P. has sall fong. " Þy loue þat þou hast loued so longe; " & bot þou come, rescours to make, " Neuere in armes schalt þou sall. me take." Whan Goodlak wyste, his herte gan was. drede Þat Brenne a-wey his lef schold wyf suld. lede. He dide samne al his flet, & Brenne & he in se þey see gan. met. When boþe fflutes come at a frosche, at frusse. Þe fyrste hortlyng hurtyng. gaf a gret crusche; Ende til ende, syde by to. side; Þe heyest of bord, best fel burde best fell. his tyde. ffaste þey foughte boþe fflutes, Persed schipes wiþ arblast schutes; Wyþ ax & swerd ilk oþer on hew, In to þe water ouer bord þey þrew; On boþe parties were þey goode, Bote þe Daneys best þey stode, Speres & darts þykke þay schote, & persed þorow-out Brennes fflote. Brenne fledde, als & was. desconfit, & Goodlak seysede a schip fol tyt. As auenture fel, þat schip he wan Þat scheo was inne, Brennes lemman. Whan he hadde wonnen won. þat he sought, Of al þat oþer gaf he nought; & Brenne fledde wiþ sayl & ore; His wyf he les, þat playned he sore. When Goodlak hadde þat may in hande, He &yogh;erned faste to þe lande. Als he seyled his lond toward, List of a chaunce þat hym fel hard: In þe se a storm hym it. grew, Þe water rored, þe wynd vp blew, Þundred, reyned, lemed leuende. lyght, Þe sky wax blak as hit were nyght[ MS. myght. ]; Þe se gan fighte, þe wawes ros, Þe streme woxe, & þem agros; stremes wex & þam at gros. Þeir schipes alle in peril were, Ropes, borde, broste ay where; Mast & sayl, doun hit lusched, lussed. Cordes, kables, casteles, tofrusched: kastels frussed. — To knowe þer names y am al wyl, Al þat þer was was in peryl.— Þer fflute sone was al to-spred, & into diuerse londes fled; ffyue daye atte þe leste Lasted thenne þat þan þat grete. tempeste. Gutlak had þre schipes, & & no (cinq nes, Wace , p. 120). mo, Wiþ hem he skaped in peyne & wo, & aryued vp in þys londe, & fayn he was þat hap he fonde, Bot for þe loue of his lemman Þat in þe tempest wax al wan; He ne wyste what lond ne port He was aryued, for mys-confort; Bot þo þat kepte þe se side, & seye þe schipes til haue[n] glyde, to hauen ride. Godlak þey toke, wyþ þat may þei toke Gutlak þat may so. gent; Tyl Belyn of hem þey made present; & alle hyse men wyþ hym þey tok, & Belyn dede þem alle to lok, &yogh;yf he wayted, For waited. what tyme or whenne, Þat he myght here tydyng of Brenne. Þo þat were take wyþ þe mayden, Vnto Belyn þe soþe sayden, Ilka del how Brenne had wrought, & þe kyng of Norwey sought, & how þat Godlak had hym met Vpon þe se wyþ strong baret.
text.47: ¶ De applicacione Brenne, & de bello inter fratres. Brenne wolde nought longe abide, His fflute he gadered on ilka side, Aryued vp in Albanye Wyþ gret force of god & gode. nauye; He sente to Belyn messegers, Of worthy Men of gode. knyghtes & squiers, Preynge Praied him. forto deliuere his wyf & his casteles, & bate alle st[r]yf; And bot he wolde &yogh;elde þeym on haste, More of his he wolde waste. Belyn gaf nought of his manace, Bot þoughte he scholde &yogh;it don suld &yogh;it. him chace, & sent hym bode by his men bolde, " Þat he had taken, þat wolde he holde; " ffor his praieres prayng. noþyng wolde do, " Ne for his loue namore þan so." Hys folk were al redy & folk redied & all. dight Agaynes Brenne for to fyght: Bysyde a wode at hate. Kalenters Mette þe breþere wyþ here baners; Eyþer oþer mykel þey þe tone þe toþer mykell. hated, Þe felonloker Fersliere. þey hem abated; Dartes til oþer þey schotte ful faste, Grete stones wyþ slynges caste, Scharpe launces þorow scheldes smot, & brighte swerdes þorow helmes bot; Sone Som. by nekkes þey sesede sore Wyþ knyues smyten to deþ smyte togidere. ay-whore, Þorow heued & þrote, breste & bak, ffruschte to-gidere, þat nekkes brak/. Þe Bretons bolded styfly to stande, & nought þe norþerne, bot were fleande; þe norþeren nouhted ay fleand. To flyght flote. þey fledde, ilk bataille seer, & Belyn folewede, & neyghed hem ner; Two þousand fleyng he þer slow, Thousandz hundrethes fleand he slough. Als þey vntil þer schipes drow. Brenne, þat made most þat wo, Wyþ peyne he skaped þe slaughtre fro; Vneþes he skaped, þe vneþis a schip in hauen. hauene he hent; His twelfte tuelf. & he, to se þey went; Alle he les bote þo twelue, To ffraunce he wente wyþ hem hym selue. ffyftene þousand slayn were told, MS. cold. P. were þor told. Wyþoute prisoners þat were in hold. of men slayn without in hold. Whan al þis wo was brought til ende, & Brenne in-til ffraunce gan wende, lende. Belyn vntil &yogh;ork he went, & þere he held his parlement. He askede his barons, and spak, " What scholde be don of sire Guthlak?" Gutlak byforn sent to Belyn, sent Belyn. Out of prison þer he lay was. yn, " Þat of Belyn he wolde wild he. holde " Al his honur, &yogh;if þat he wolde, " Denmark his lond, quyt & cler, " And gyuen gyf. hym truwage ilka &yogh;er; " Syker þerof he wolde hym make, " Wyþ bond, treuh. & god ostage to take; " Wyþy with þi (with that, so that). he myghte lede safly " His lemman, wyþouten vyleny." Belyn had fol gret desyr To haue truwage of his enpir. Þorough leue of þe parlement, Gutlak & his lemman went, When he had sworn & don omage, & bondes mad, Whan had don his homage othe suorn. & gyuen hostage, To Belyn to halde þer couenaunt, conant. fforto wende he hadde þe graunt. Gutlak, to go, sone he was &yogh;are, Wyþ schip vntil his lond to fare. Manning should have translated Wace's Sa mie en a à soi menée, Quc par sa paine acatée. i. 125, l. 2643-4. Belyn held wel þenne his honour, & wysly was god governour; He louede pes wyþ al pes at. hys myght, & pesyble men held he to ryght. Hys lond Bretayne he went &yogh;ode. þorow-out, & ilka countre biheld about; Byheld þe wodes, watres, & fen, & no passage fond he mad no passage was maked. for men, Ne heye strete þorow no contre, Neyþer to burgh ne to cyte. Þorow myres, hylles, & vales, He made brugges & causes, cauceiz. Heye stretes for comun passage, Brugges ouer watres dide he stage: Þe firste he made, he cald hyt "ffosse;" Þorow-out þys londe hit goþ til Scosse; Hit bygynnes atte Toteneys, & endeþ þenne at Cateneys. endes vnto catheneis. An oþer strete þan ordeyned he: ffro Souþ-haumpton opon at Southampton vpon. þe se, To Mene yn Walys, (Seint Dauies now hight,) Ikenyldestrete reches ful ryght: & gos to Weles to seynt dauy þe toun hight Menne þat tyme redy. Two causes ouer þe lond in lengþe & brede, tuo kaucez ouer þe lond o brede. Þat men ouerthwert in passage &yogh;ede. When þey were maked als he ches, He comaunded till alle haue pees; Alle schold haue suld haf. pees & fredam Þat in his stretes &yogh;ede or cam; & &yogh;yf hit were any of hyse Þat for-dyde his ffraunchise, fforfeted schold ben al his þyng, & hym self His body. taken til þe kyng. Brenne þat was gon in to ffraunce, Hym schamed sore of his chaunce Þat hit MS. his. P. has it. was so wyde yspred Þat his lemman was a-wey led. Hym self & his twelf felawes Serued þe kyng &yogh;eres & dawes; Knyght he was, curteys & wys, Oueral he hadde los & pris; What ony knyght hadde to þer Whan any knyght toke his. lyuere, His was largest, for he was fre; Mykel was he preysed of prowesse, & ful wel loued for his largesse; He couþe mykel couth Inouh. of curtesy, & faire hym bar, as man worþy. When his los was þorow ronnen, & in þe lond his pris hadde wonnen, Wiþ wham he made any soiour, He preyed for help & for socour ffor to conquere his heritage, Þat Belyn reftym held. wiþ outrage; & he. &yogh;ede to Burgoyne, to Duk Segwyn, Bysought hym of help ageyns Belyn. Þe Duk louede his compaignie, & gaf hym of his tresorie. Brenne was yn speche curteys, & konnynge a konand knyght on. knyght by many weys; He couþe of chas wod. & of ryuere, Inow of game of here gamen on oþer. manere; Gentil of body, wyþ fair visage, He semed a man of hey parage, & was plesaunt & seruisable. Þe Duk was riche wyþoute fable, he was meke to serve and briche & þe duke was noble riche. & of his body had non heyr Bot a mayde ferly feyr. Inough sche hadde þat tyme of elde, Þat scheo myght take a lord to welde; He spak louely, wysly, & stille. & serued þe Duk at al his wylle, & wel hym payed alle his dedes, & oueral wel he spedde his nedes. Þe Duk his doughter gaf hym to wyue, To haue þe Duche after his lyue. Þen þoughte þe Duk, þat hym fel feir Þat God had sent hym suche on til heyr. saue þis he had þe speire þat god gaf him a son till heire. Brenne obeysed hym curteysly, & seide "Sire Duk, graunt mercy!" Al men þei. hym louede, & held hym dere, Ech man hym payed wel his & he þam paied on all. manere. ffel þanne wyþynne þe twelf-monþ not was it siþen a tuelmoth. ende, Swyche a grace God gan hym sende, Þat he deyde, þe Duk Segwyn. Of al þe Duche, Brenne tok seysyn; Hys barons þat louede hym wel byfore, After louede hym mykel more; Wel louede hym ilka Burgyloun, & knyghtes of þeyr oþer. nacioun; He hadde þe lond wyþ al þe lond Inouh &. rente, And a &yogh;ong lady & &yogh;eng lemman. fair & gente. In al his welþe þis weth. forgat he nought How Belyn hadde wyþ hym wrought, & held þe londes þat his schold be; Bot whan he sey his tyme eyse, He sent for knyghtes & squiers, ffrendes he soughte, & waged hired. souders; Wyþ gret ost cam til Normandie, & purueyde þer a gret nauye. Whan hit was he sawe. tyme, had wynd at wille He passed þe se wyþouten ylle. Belyn herde wel þat he cam; Wyþ folk ynogh ageyns hym nam; Þer bataylles assembled wyþynne a lite, & redy were almost to fyghte.
text.48: ¶ De Humilitate Tonewenne, matris Belyni & Brenni. So com þeyr moder, dame Tonewenne, Þat bar boþe Belyn & Brenne, Bytwyxt þer hostes, tremblyng trembland . . . . . haltand. for drede; ffol old scheo was, haltyng scheo &yogh;ede; Ouer al scheo asked where was Brenne. Atte þe laste, men gan hure kenne; & Brenne herd seye þat hit was sche; He saide "Moder, welcome be &yogh;e!" Hure armes aboute his nekke sche hals [neck] scho. cast,— Boþe ostes wondred þer-ate þe ostes biheld þam. fast,— Vntil hure girdel hure cloþes sche rent; Naked byfore þe host sche went; Ses mamèles li mostra nues, Flestres, et vielles, et pelues. Wace, i. 132, l. 2769-70. Vntil Brenne gretynge gretand. sche spak, Hur fyngres sche wrast, þe blod out brak, Sche tremblede & sykede inderly, sighed inerly. Handes & face brest handes face breste. al blody: Mistaken translation of Wace's " Car ele soglotoit [sobbed] forment ," i. 132. l. 2773. " Dere child!" scheo seid, Dere son. "wher hastow ben? " Now þanky God y haue þe sen! " Sone," sche seide, "list now to me, " & do als y schal conceille þe. " Lo, here þe pappes þat þou on sok! " Þyse armes hit arn armes ere. þat þe bylok! " Here ys þe wombe &yogh;e boþe ynne ware! " Þys body &yogh;ow bar wiþ wo & kare! " Y am sche þat for &yogh;ow kneled! " Now þenk o þat sorwe þat y þenne feled! " Ley now Schew. no sorewe me more byforn, " ffor hym þat let &yogh;ow of me be born! " Ley doun þyn armes, me forto saue! " Wylle nought þat y for þe deþ dede. haue! " Þou mysdost, þat þou now fandes fondes. " To brynge straungers of outlandes aliens of vnkouth londes. " Vs forto robben & to vs forto. slo! " Rest þe! let þy mod ouer go! þin owen demeyns to wirke wo. " Þou hast namo breþere in wold; " Þy fader ys ded, dede is þi fadere. þy moder ys old; " Suffre, for no þyng in lyue, " Þy pore frendes a-way to dryue! " Þou scholdest vs presente & gyue, " & helpe vs alle in pes to lyue; " Bot now þou comest to reue vs our [socour], socoure. " Þat scholdest ben oure mayntenour. " Lef folye! & y vndertake, do þis foly now to slake. " &yogh;yf þou on hym wilt pleynte make, " And y fynde he haue þe gylt, " He schal amenden right als þou wilt; " Bot &yogh;yf þou seist he dide þe fle, " I seye nay; witnesse on þe! þe wrong is in þe. " ffyrst þou bygonne al yn wrong; " So al þe folye ys on þe longe, " Þe firste folye & yuele in alle. dedes. " When þou intil Norwey &yogh;edes, " Wyf to take, wyþouten leue, his leue. " Þat schewede þou mentest hym to þou wild him. greue, " & broughtest Norn men hym tasaille: brouht þe north him to assaile. " Þerfore þou lostest þy þou sped nouht at þat. bataille; " Þy blame ys now &yogh;yt fol grym, " Þat swiche suylk. . . . . . bringes. an host bryngest on hym " & schapest þat is till. oure desherytysoun, " & þys londes & to þi lond. destruccioun!
