" So mykel yuel wold he nought þe, ill wild he not þe. " Al-þey his power so mykel if his powere so wele. myght be. " Brenne, sone! what þenkest þou? " Com til acord now for þy prow! " Ley doun þy swerd, do wey þy scheld, " Wyþdraw þy folk out of þe feld; " & sek þe pes, for & seke pe pour. charite! " Þe same schal he do to þe." Brenne hure preyere vnderstod; ffor loue of hure changed his mod; His helm, his hauberk, he dide vnlace; Al bar-heued, wyþ open face, Cam he wiþ his moder Tonewenne, & also dide þe same did. Belyn to Brenne: Þeyr moder dide hem to-gedere kysse. ffor þat saughtlyng was mykel blisse; More of wrath was þer nought spoken; ffor with. loue in armes ilk oþer þey loken. Al þus þen ended þusgate endid. þe breþere wrathe, Þer tene turned to game & glathe. ffro þeþen þien. to Londone þey went, & þer þey helde a parlement; Of þeyr parlement was þe ende, To wynne ffraunce wolde þey wende. Belyn dide somone his Bretons, & Brenne haþ P. omits haþ. alle his Burgylons. By tyme & terme þat þey had set, Boþe ostes atte hauene met, & schiped ouer into ffraunce; To wynne hit, þey hoped was her chaunce. þe lond to wyn awnterd þer chance. By-twyxt hem was þen a batille don: Þe force of ffraunce fel ful son, Þey durede nought to fighte in feld; Þe breþere dide hem to þeym &yogh;eld; Casteles þey sesede fer & ner, & wonne alle ffraunce wan þam all. wyþynne a &yogh;er. When al þe folk were atter was at þer. dome, Þey seide þey wolde wende to Rome, And leue non þat þey fond, Bot &yogh;yf þey helde of þeym þer lond. Þey sente aboute to diuerse costes, Of doughti folk þey gadered hostes ffor to wynne pris & prow; Þey passed þe Mountaynes of Moungow; Mon Giu, Wace. "Mons Jovis, " montagne qui separe la Savoie de " l'Italie: le grand Saint-Bernard. " De Lincy's Wace , i. 138. Taurynus þey toke, & Iuerye, & alle þe Cytes of Lombardye, Vrceles, Pauye, & Tremoygne, Vécialz . . Crémone. Wace , i. 188. Melan, Plesence, & grete Boloyne; Þey passed þe water of Tauron, & þe hul of Mount Bardon; þey robbed þorow al Tuskane, & al ouer rod, & þorow ran. Als þey ryfled robbed. landes ay whore, Rome þey neighed ay þe more. Romayns dredden hem for to deye, ffor þo tydynges þat þey herd seye; Al day of passande men þey herd, Þe two breþere wonnen al þe werd. Þey of Rome had chosen þat &yogh;er Two noble men of gret power, Þat þey scholde, when þey had nede, Þer folk vntil bataille lede, & saue þer landes, holde þem to ryght, ffor doughtiest þey were in fyght: Sire Procenna, þat on hight so, Þat oþer men calde sire Galbao; Gabao. Gabius, Wace , l. 2930. Þyse to tuo. were þeyr conseillours, & speke vnto þe senatours " What þey wolde, how hadde þey tight, " Þeyr cite &yogh;elde, or stande to fyght." Þe Sene seide þey were affrayed, Non hem wyþstod, bot þorow alle strayed: " Wiþ swilk to fighte, we haue non host, " ffor þey han folk wyþ þe most; " & &yogh;yf we myghte oure pes haue, " Þorough mekenesse oure gode godes. saue, " & oure seluen at here pes lyue, " Gold & seluer we wolde þem gyue. " Ouer þat, þey schul haue truage, " To passe & do vs non vtrage; " ffor strong hit were for oure cite " To be destruyed, & al þe contre." In al þer drede, & al þer dome, Þe breþere come & byseget seged. Rome. Þorow comun assent of þe senatours, Þey presented present. þe breþere gret tresours; & to be in here auowery, þer auowri. Truage þey graunted hem for þy. Þe breþere tok of þem hostage; Twenty childre of þe beste lynage & of þe richest of al þe toun, Þey presented present. hem as for raunson: Þus was þe pes bytwixt hem graunted, Bot lytel þrowe while. þey hit haunted. Belyn & Brenne remued remoued. þer host, By Lombardye þey wente þe cost, To werren opon þe Alemauntz, The m has 4 strokes in the MS. & take truage of þe remenauntz. heue trewage at Remanans. Þey were letted by þe destorbled þorgh. Romayns, Þat couenaunt breke; rise þeym a-geyns; & proue þey wolde þeir hardinesse, And seide þey wolde do more pruesse. Þey send for knyghtes oueral aboute, & gaderet MS. gaderest. P. reads gadred. ost gret & stoute, Wel armed in ilke a conreye; armed were in all conrey. After þe breþere þey tok þeir weye; On þem þey þowte to smyte al fresse, Ithe Mountaingnes to holdem at destresse, hald þam at stresse. Þat non of hem scholde namore come Of þo breþere eft ? MS. est. oste , P. to Rome. Þey sente messages on þer partye, In to Alemayne, vnto þe almayns. þe breþere to spie, Þat ilka pas þey scholde suld. so wayte, Ithe Mountz holden hem so straite, &yogh;yf þey schold suld. passe on eyþer syde, Wyþ force þey schold suld. hem ouer ryde. Al þus on ilk a side þey ros, To haue þe breþere host in clos; & atter passyng in to þe mount, Þe Alemauntz schold suld. ben in þer frount; Þorow force of þer god ordynaunce, Þey schold suld. nought passe þorow be. no chaunce. When Belyn perseyued þe ffelonye, Þey conseilled on þer partie Þat Brenne scholde suld. turne a-gayn To wyþstande þe host Romayn, And Belyn scholde suld. on his side Agayns þe host of Alemauntz ryde; & whilk of þem best myghte spede, Schold suld. turne & helpe þe toþer at nede. When Romayns wyste Bren schold suld. come, Þey toke þe wey gate. agayn to Rome, Þat Brenne schold suld. neighe Rome no ner, & þe breþere a sondre fer. Þorow a spye Belyn herde seye, & taughte Brenne a geyner weye; To trauersen hem al ouer þere score, & passe þe Romayns wel byfore. Þey chose gyours þe contre knew, To lede þem wye trist & trew, & brynge þem wel to þat strete Þer þeym byhoued Romayns mete. Þey iourneyed Ioneyd. boþe dayes & nyght Al so stille as þey myght, Wyþoute noise, cry, or how, noyse or any crie. Vntil þe entre of Moungow. & when þey were in þe valeye, Þer ledere seide, "þys ys þeir weye! " By þys þey come, hit is certeyn; " Oþer wey haue þey non ageyn." non oþer may þei gayne. To þat passage þey come at nyght; Þe mone schon ful schane. faire & bright; Brenne bad þem ber ham [al] pryue, Wiþ-oute noyse, til tyme schold to tyme. be. Sone after cam þe Romaynes route; Of non þey hadde drede ne doute. By þe mone þat so lyght schon, þat bright schone. Þey spedde hem faste swythe to gon. Atte passage glyfte þey þer eyene; þei glift Ine. Agayns þe mone sawe þey schyne Helmes, hauberkes, scheldes vp-lyfte. Þenne were þe Romayns al a-glyfte: oglift. Þe Bretons hadde þe Romay[n]s byden; Al so swyþe þey to þem ryden; Brenne þem boldede, bad þem wel smyte, MS. snyte. " ffelleþ &yogh;our fos þat wolde &yogh;ou byte!" Oueral þe Bretons þeym þe bretons ouer all halfe þam. assailled; Þe Romayns route fel & failled; Þey nadde no tome for to fle, Ne place to huyden hem ne to tapise in stede. priue. Þe Bretons bowaylled þeym, bouweld þam. & hew; In buskes, bankes, doun þeym þrew; Þe slaughtre lasted al þat nyght, Til hit sprang þe dayes lyght; & al þat day afterward, Vntil þe nyght, was bataille hard. Þe nyght departed þem o sunder: Þat any askaped, hit was a wonder. Þat oþer day in þe morwen tyde, Toward Brenne, Belyn gan ryde;— ffer from his broþer wold he nought ne wild he. go, What chaunce so bytidde of mo;— & Brenne þat byfore nam, Abod [þer] vntil Belyn cam. When þey were to-gyder comen, Boþe vntil Rome nomen, & byseged MS. byseded. P. biseged. hit aboute,— & þey of Rome were ful stoute,— On alle sides þey sette engyns, Als Brenne ordeyned, at brenne ordenance. & belyns. Mynours þey hadde ynowe, & sleye, Þe wal to perce hole. & vndermye. Þo wyþynne deffended hem wel, At þat tyme lostey nought les not. a del; Wyþ arblastes schoten quarels vnryde, Inow men broughte, & leide by syde; Wyþ grete stones þey hem affrayed. Þe Romayns were nought desmayed, Þey launced darte, bowes drowe, ffele þey felde, & manye slowe. Þe breþere leften þer assaut al, & persed no þyng of þe wal. Longe lastede þat ilk distaunce, To þe breþere gret noyaunce; Galewes dide þe breþere renge; Of þer blod þey wol þeym venge; Þe galewes þey reysed vp ful heye,— Þe Romayns wel myght hem se wyþ eye,— & hongeden alle hanged ilkon. þer hostagers, Burgeyses sones, lordes peres. Þat kynde, y trowe, had sorewe & wo, To schames deþ þat saw hem go.
text.49: ¶ De Subuersione fratrum. Alle olyke only. þer fore were wroþ, & alle seide, & swore þer oþ, In pes ne schold þey passe quyt, Bot þey wer wroken venged. on þat despit. On þyse men tristed þe Romayns þo, On Prosenna & on sire Gabao, ffor þyse wer gon to Lumbardye To procure Rome more partye. After þeyn þam. abyden þe Romayns; A day to come þey sette certayns; Þat day was ner of þer comyng, Þe Romayns þat day mad þer samnyng, samenyng. & ber hem ful egrely & were right full egre. & stout; Þey armede hem, & isseden issued. out, & oþe breþere faste þey sought, & þey ageyn ne spared hem nought. Als þey foughten best in stour, Com her chefteyns wyþ more com þe tuo men with all þer. socour; Oþe breþere þey fullen alle on a res: Vpon þe breþer & ilkon fresse. Þan were þey boþe in hard destres; þe breþer in hard stresse. Þe Romayns vpon þe oþer partz, Þat oþer side, Poyles & Lombartz, & felde fellid. fele of þe Burgoylons, & calde þem "cowardz! hore sons! " We schol sall. &yogh;ow do drynke &yogh;our owen blod, " & spare oure water of Tyber in þe. flod! " On þys half Moungow, what do &yogh;e, " Vs to chalange of vur fe? " & þat &yogh;e henge our children heye, " Þat vilenye &yogh;e schulle sall. abye! " To &yogh;ow was hit an yuel it was a wikke. conseil; " Þat schul &yogh;e fele to &yogh;e sall se full. wroþer hayl." Wiþ suche vmbreides þey hem suylk vpbraid þei þam. missayde, & grete strokes vpon þeym leyde; Obak MS. Olak. P. obak. a-geyn [þey] dide þem go, & dide þem braye & crye for wo. Belyn & Brenne were al dysmayed Þat þe Romayns so þem affrayed; Þe Bretons sawe þer syde &yogh;ede lowe, Þey rempede runethed or rimethed. þem to reste a þrowe; In þer restyng þey gan hem mene, A parlement made þem bitwene, & gadered þer folk a-geyn to fyght, Armed hem newe, & renged hem right, In sere batailles set þeym a sondres, Boþe by þousands & by hundreds. Of þe hardiest & defensables, Made þey Mayster & þer maistres &. ont fait maistres et. Wace , i.150, l. 3168. Conestables, & bad hem in þer bataille holde, Þat non fro oþer schold flitte ne folde. 9 [beside were set to þer socoure, archers to maynten þam in stoure; þe alblasters on þe toþer side, ilkon for oþer better to bide. doun on fote þe moste gan light on fote þei renged þam to fight.] 1 9-1 Lines 3503-8 are from the Petyt MS., translating Wace, lines 3174-8, vol. i., p. 150-1 of De Lincy's ed. P. has not lines, 3509-10. Þo þat were strong, hardy, & wyght, fformest þey were set to fyght; Þey bere þe launces vp and doun, On þe manere of a scheltroun; cheltroun. & non for wele ne for wo Ne scholde byforen suld forþer þan. oþer go, Ne go swyþer þan softe a. paas, At ones to smyte, as comeþ þe cas; whan com a kas. en la grant presse, el tas [heap, mass]: Wace , i. 151, l. 3184. & non schold baldere þan oþer be, Ne noman [schold] fro oþer fle. When þey had set ilk a bataille, On what manere þey schold assaille, Trompe blewe, & greyles greilles. ronge, On boþe parties þer batailles to batale. sprong. On ilka side were strokes ynowe, Speres dide þem lances did þei. breste & bowe; After þe speres þat þey MS. sey. set, after lances þat þei sette. Syþen wiþ swerd & knyf þey met; Ilk oþer on ran ilk oþer to styke; Vpon þe dede &yogh;ede þe quyke. Al to telle hit, nought y ne can, Bot loren was þer many a man; Þe Bretons seye non oþer weye, Þey most wel fyghte, oþer elles deye; þer behoued þam lyue or deie. Oþer al to wynne, or al to lese, Þat on of þo byhoued hem chese. Þe best fyghters ber bare. forth þe brest, Archers & arblasters þem next; neste. Þe Myle[ne]rs & þe Centaynes Milleners & centeners. ffolewed faste on þo Romaynes; Sire Galbao, Gabao. þer gouernour, He bated hym o þe Bretons stour; Bot slayn was sire Galbao, Gabao. Þat al þer trist was vnto; & þat. Prosenna was brought right was born. doun, On hem þe Bretons wonne þe toun; Prosenna þey tok a[l] quyk; all quike. Þey persed þe Romayns bataille þyk, & al þer force doun þey slow, & to þe cite faste þey drow. Þe toun might þey defende namore, Þe cheftayns were slayn þat þer wore; Þe breþere come vntil þe cite, & founde þer-inne richesse plente. Belyn gaf Brenne al þe empyre, And he was Enperour & sire; Þe folk of hym þey had gret doute, His fomen þorow force dide þem aloute, did he loute. [Long he regned Emperoure From the Petyt MS. ] Þat neuere dirst Romayn stire in his stour. romeyn durst stir him stoure. Belyn to Bretayne þen gan turne, He wold no lengere þer soiourne; & when he com vntil þis lond, Þe olde cites þat he fond, He closed þem, & mad hem newe, Þe walles he reisede trist & trewe. In Walys he dide make a toun; Kaerusik kaerusk. he caldit on bretoun, ffor hit stande it standes. vpon Vsk, A water þat rennes by bank & busk; Siþen men caldit Kaer-legion: List now what was þe enchesoun. why þe encheson. Whylon whilom. Romayns had þis lond In þer demeynes, in þer hond; Whan Romayns com for þer truage, At Kaerusyk kaerusk. þey helde hostage, & þere þey made most dwellynge, ffor þer was gret ese of mikel þyng; At Kaerusyk kaerusk. in Clamorkan, clamorgan. In wynter þey dwelt þer, ilkaman; & for þey had so longe þer hold, Kaer-legion þe name was told. Com after, men of diuerse Com diuers men of þer. language, Þat schortly to speken haue in schorte to speke haf. vsage, And schorted hit wyþ name & soun, And afterward kaldyt Carlyon; brak þe word to kaerlioun. Bot legion ys noumbre of folk þat wex, Sex þousand, sex hundred, sexti & sex; Þus many alwey fro Rome com, euer fro Rome cam. Þat ay for truwage to Carlyon nom. ay vnto kaerlion nam. Whan Belyn Carlion had set, Þe walles he reysed, & folk to fet; To Londone þenne tok he þe way, And þer he dwelled many a day. Þer dide he a MS. &. P. a. gate by-gynne, Ouer þe water, þer schipes come ynne; & ouer þat gate he made a tour, Þer-inne he held [ful] long soiour. He reysed raised. alle his fader lawes, & dide þem holde by his dawes; Dom he gaf wysly & right, Trowþ held he wel wiþ at. al his myght. Mykel pleynte was in his tyme, On no mannes more may men of no man more may we. ryme; Longe he lyuede, longe þe lond. to welde, & faire he ended in his elde; ffor of þat gate þat Belyn aught, Of Belyn [þen] þe name hit laught; Longe men caldit called. til now late, After Belyn, Belynes gate; Þorow schort langage, y tolde er how Byllyngesgate men calle hit now.
text.50: ¶ Hic moriebatur nobilus Belynus. ¶ Whan he was ded, sire Belyn, Þe people for hym hadde sorwe & pyn; ffor manye a man fol sore gret Þat day þat he ys lyf for-let. Þey dide make for his honur A barel of gold of his tresour, & brente his body, flesche & bon, Iþe barel of gold þey leid ilkon; More worschip þem þought hit so, Þan his body in erthe to do. When þe barel was al dight, & wel y-burnuscht fair & barred all & burnessid. bryght, Vp yþe Tour þey made a stage, & heye it henge bifore & hang it befor. þe passage, Þat alle þat passed, more & lasse, Schold preyse Praised. Belyn for his prowesse.
text.51: ¶ Gurgoynt Rex. After Belyn, Gurgoint his sone Hadde þe heritage þorow be. resone. Gurgoynt Beretruk, þus was his name; Of gret godnesse he bar þe a man of gode þer of had. fame; Pes to loke, & ryght to holde, He lyknede his ffader, Belyn þe bolde. Þat Belyn left, he heldit wel; Noiaunce had he neuere a del, Bot þe Daneys, MS. Dameys. P. has danes. þey forsok To gyue truage þat Belyn tok. Gurgoynt þoughte he hadde ryght þer-ynne, His truwage he wolde al gate wynne; His host he gadered, & schipes he gadred schippes. did come; Þey set vp sail, & forþ þey nome. To bataille þey samnde, boþe partys, Bot Gurgoynt wan þer sone þe pris; P. wrongly transposes this line and the one above it. Hym self yn bataille slow þe kynge, & tok homage of ilka lordynge; & his truwage dide restore, Als his fader had hit byfore. When he had take of hem ostage, Gurgoynt forþ went on his viage: He passed forþ by Orkeneye; Þritty schipes he mette in weye, Charged wyþ folk Charged full. & wyþ vitaille, Bot þey ne wyste whider to saille; Pantalius, þer maister hight, Þat mayntende hem, & held to ryght. Gurgoynt asked what men þey were, & what þey soughte, & why come þere. Pantalius spak ful curteysly. " We ar men of pes, sekyng auowery, " Wey-farende men þat wolde haue gryþ; " We aske þe leue to speke þe wyþ." Þe kyng ne wolde no pes Pes wild nouht þe kyng. breke, Wyþ loue he gaf hem leue to speke. He saide, " We ar men of diuerse lynage, " Exiled of Spayne, comen by þys ryuage, " &yogh;yf þat we any stede fond, " On to reste, a certeyn lond. " ffor oþer half &yogh;er a &yogh;ere & half. An et demie, Wace i. 159, l. 3337. þus haue we went; " Hunger, þurst, cold, haþ vs schent; " Many a cost haue we þorow sought; " Lond on to lende, ne fond we nought; " & we ar alle onoyed þer fore, " ffor oure trauaille & grete lore. " Bot, lord, &yogh;yf hit were &yogh;our wylle, " Suffre vs to reste on þy londe stille! " Seruise þer fore we wole þe do; " Þy men bycome, &yogh;yf þou wilt so." Bot Gorgoynt wolde þem nought graunt Of his to haue a remenaunt; Nought for þy he gaf hem conseil Toward Irlond to sette þer sayl; & of his schipes he lente þem tweye, To techen hem þe ryghte weye.— ¶ Irlond þat tyme was bygged no þynge Wyþ hous londes. ne toun, ne man wonynge.— So longe þey sailled, þe se þorow ronne, Þat algate to Irlond þey wonne; Þey stryken sayl, & anker cast, Vp to lande þey &yogh;ede ryght fast; Al þey founde wast all fond þei wildernes. & wylde. Þey spredde hem aboute in ilkan ylde; Sone þey maden eryed mad ardawe. feld, Þey logged hem, & tymber timbred. teld; Þer folk wax faste, & fostred more, & tyled þe lond aboute ay whore.
text.52: ¶ Pantalyus primus Rex Hibernie. Pantalius, þey maden hym kyng; In Irlond þen made he ireland mad he. first wonyng. When Gurgoynt had þem þider ysent, Hom vntil his lond he went; Þritty &yogh;er in þys lyf gan lende; At Kerlyoun he made hys ende.
text.53: ¶ Gwyntelyn Rex, cuius vxor Marciena Sapiens fuit. Whan Gurgoynt hadde don his fyn, Regned after him com. his sone Gwyntelyn; A god man was for þe maystrie, & his wyf highte dame Marcye. Dame Marcye was mikel of in. pris; Of landes lawe scheo was ful wys; Scheo studyed faste to make þe lawe. ffor hure þey caldyt by þat dawe, In Bretons tyme, als y wene, Þey calde þat lawe Marcyene. ffro kyng to kyng þat lawe men wrot, & Englysche kynges &yogh;it hit wot; Marchenlage, þe Englisch hit calde; In eyghte auht. schires þat lawe &yogh;it men halde, Gloucestre, Chestre, Warewyk, Oxenford, Hereforde, Wynchestre, The Petyt MS. rightly substi|tutes Wircester for this:— Gloucester. Wircester. Herford. Werwik. Oxenford. Schropschire. Chester. staford. Schropschire, Stafford. And Gwyntelyn & Marcyen, A knaue child hadden þem bytwen.
text.54: ¶ Syluyus Rex. ¶ Syluius his name þey told, & er he were seuen &yogh;er old, Deyde his fader: þat tyme here He regned namore bot ten &yogh;ere. After Gwyntelyns deces, Kepte Marcyen þe lond yn pes; & when þat he was wel of elde, Þat he couþe þe londes welde, Scheo hym dide coroune kynge;— Y telde &yogh;ow his regne in alle & he regned in all þe. þynge;— Stalworth he was, yn armes was till. bone; Bot after his fader he deyde die. sone.
text.55: ¶ Kynmar Rex. Þenne com his heir, Kynmar, her, Kymare his sonne his heire was here. & regned he lyued. on & twenty &yogh;er. DANEUS his broþer þen hadde siþen had. þe lond; Rex. Ten &yogh;er he regned, wyþ werre he fond.
text.56: ¶ De Morpydeo Rege Bastardo. Þys Daneus hadde on bastardie bascardie. The second scribe of P. writes from here to l. 3965. See qwen , l. 3881, note. A sone þat wan hit wyþ maistrie; Morpydus, Morwidus. Morbidus in l. 3755; Morpidus in l. 3758, 3763, &c. hit seys he hight; He was a merueillous Ouer mesure was he. mody knyght. Þorow hardynesse wan hit of chaunce; Egreliche Irouslik. he tok vengeaunce, Hys ire, when hit on hym ran, ffor nought wold wild. he slo no man a man. ; ffor loue wold wild. he noman spare, Þe To. whyles þat his wrathe ware. In al þe regne ne was þer non So fair of vertues als he on. Hys body was gent, & fair of vis; Til alle he gaf gyftes of pris; Out of mesure þen was he large, Tresour to holde ne made he charge. Þe To. while his ire was a-weye, Al wold wild. he do þat men wold wild. seye, & also meke was as a child, Tyl þat his wraþ wax Bot whan his wrathe was. on hym wyld. In Morpidus tyme þat was so stout, Þe duk of Morreue robbed a-bout; Northumberland gan he waste; & MOrpydus til hym gan haste, And angerly egrelike. gan hym assaille, & þer hym slow in pleyn bataille. Þus seide men, & &yogh;it mes seys, & &yogh;it sais. Þat hit was proued (y not what weys) Þat Morpidus slow mo men, sleu me. alone, Þan alle his host[e] dide ilkone. When he had slayn al þat he myght, & was al wery more to fyght, Þe bodies "All alive," says Wace, l. 3463. he dide brenne of þo, Er his grete ire myght ouer go. Þe Be. tyme þat he was best in elde, & stalwordest hym self to welde, A best com out of þe Irysche se & destruyed al þe contre; An hydous best was hit by sight, ' Monstre Maryne' men seide hit hight; & som men caldit 'Marebellew,' marine bélue, Wace , i. 166. Lat. belua maritima, De Lincy , ib. So wonderful best no man þer knew. (Swylk calle men 'Monstre,' als y fynde, Þat lymes hauen has. out of kynde; Þat hauen has. lymes more or lesse, 'Monstre' men seis þat swilkon ysse.) es. 'Marebellow' Mare Bellu. ys þe se hound: I not wheþer hit suiymmes ? MS. smymmes. suimmes, P. or is atte ground. Was non þat wonede by þe se syde, Þat durste for þat best abyde; Man & best he swelwed & et ete . . leet. ; Þat he ouertok, on of. lyue ne let. ¶ Morpidus herde þerof gret cry; Hys herte was bold & euere ouer. hardy, On himself he affyed so, Allone, þe best he &yogh;ede hym to, & faught wyþ hym,—hit was folye On hym self so mykel forto affie; mikil affie. — Hym self alone Al on him self. þe best assailled, Gret hardynesse hym non Hardines of hert. ne failled; Wyþ spere first he til hym schet; launce first he to him scet. & wounded hym þat was so gret. Whan he had schoten, & til hym cast, Þenne wyþ swerd hew on hym fast. Ouer neygh he cam in þat fyghtyng: He gaped wyde, & swelwed opind his mouth & sualhid. þe kyng. 5 [þus gate deid sir Morpidus; So did þe best þat swalud him thus.] 5 5-5 From the Petyt MS. ffor þe kyng men made gret mone, Þe bestes deþ conforted ilkone.
text.57: ¶ Gorbodyan rex. Morpydus hadde sones fyue, & alle þey leftym byhinde alyue. all left be-hind him on liue. Gorbodyan, fairest of flour, & Argayl, & sire Elydour, Iugenes, Vigenius, Galf. Mon. i. 18. & sire Perodour, Alle fyue were kynges of honur. Gorbodian was flour & pris, He was trewe, feyghtful, rihtfull. & wys; Neuere kyng wyþ so mykel loue Ouer no lond regned Ouer lond ne folk ne was. aboue, Neuere louede he no lye, witand he ne leih. No dide men wrong, lowe ne heye. dide wronge to man þat deith. He was kyng ful mesurable, To don alle right he was ful stable; P. wrongly omits this line. Loue & pes his tyme was ryf; Ten &yogh;er he lyuede þer inne his lyf. In Trenouante þer he lys, His broþer hym leyde at his deuis.
text.58: ¶ Argayl Rex. Argayl, þat next hym was born, Was kyng as he had be byforn. Wykkedly þen gan hym falle, ffor he discorded wyþ hem alle; Þe godmen he abesed abeissed . . aueanced. mykel, & auaunsed þo þat were swykel; Þe tresor þey hadden, he it hem reft; He loued wel lyes; Bleþely wild lie. þe soþes he left; Trowe men ne louede he nought; Glad was he whan wo was wrought. þe barons conseilled þeym bytwene; Þe lond þey refte hym quyt & clene.
text.59: ¶ Elydourus Rex. Þenne corouned þey sire Elydour, Man of pite & of socour. Argail, þat was dryuen out, He &yogh;ede to prynces ouer al about ffor help to haue his regne ageyn; Bot his trauaille was al in veyn, Non wolde helpe restore his perd; Þen lyued he ffyue &yogh;er in pouert. Sone afte[r] þe ffyue &yogh;eres ende, Elydour þorow a wode schold wende, ffor to pleye by o ryuer; Þat wode, men caldit Calduter. kalamiter. Galatère, Wace , l. 3570, where Brenne fought Belin, p. 107, l. 3025 above. Argail þer sire Elydour mette; On knes sire Elydour he grette, & asked hym grace & mercy; & he hym graunted al redy; On hym he hadde gret pyte, Þat in pouerte schold hym se. His armes abute his nekke he kast, His grete pouerte he pleyned fast; Whan he had longe ment his mone, Tyl Aclud þey wente ilkone; In his chaumbre he dide hym be, Þat non hym wiste bot in pryuete. Hereþ now of sire Elydour, How he dide his broþer gret honur.
text.60: ¶ De pietate Elydory. ¶ Elydour feyned hym sik to lye, & seide he hopede hopid , expected. forto deye. After his barons þenne he sent, And þey alle til hym went; A day was ordeyned for to be, Þat þey schold visiten suld viset. hym, & se; Wyþoute noyse til hym schold suld. go, On alone, wyþouten mo, & speke softe & priuely, ffor he ne moughte suffre no cri. Ilkon dide þe kynges wille, As þey come yn, þey held hem stille; & als þey comen, þe kyng hem tok, & dide þem sweren on þe bok ffor to don Argail homage; Were he neuere of so hey parage, Wold he, ne wolde, wild he ne wild. þat scholde suld. he do, Oþer þe deþ schold he Or ye dede be suld. go to. Þus sonderlypes sunder leps (separately). he dide þem swere, Tyl Argayl schulde þey faiþ To Argaill suld þei feche þe bere. bere.
text.61: ¶ Deposito Elidoro, Argayl iterum factus est Rex. When Qwen. þey had alle sworen an oþ Tyl Argail, wer hem lef or loþ, Elydour & þey alle went To &yogh;ork, & helde a Parlement. Elydour þer þe coroune leued, And set hit vpon Argailes heued, & seide, "here gyue y þe Argayl " Þe coroune of Bretayne holyke al." Þan seide men of sire Elydour, Þat he of pite was fruyt & flour, Þat forsok þe regalte, regaunte. & gaf hit his broþer for pite; þerfore in ilka lordes lordyng. hous Was he cald Elydour Pytous. ¶ Argail amended his maners, & louede his barons, & m[a]de þem pers; his pes. Was non of hem so mesurable, Ne of his word so wys & stable; Alle his wykked tecches he left tecchis left. When [he] had take þe corown whan ke tohe ye croune. eft; Alle hym louede þat hym er hated, ffor alle his vices were abated. Ten &yogh;er he regned in honour, & syþen syn. fel in a langour, & ended his lif fair & wel: Þey byried hym at Karlel.
text.62: ¶ Iterum elegerunt Elyodorum. Sire Eliadour eft þey ches, Þat loued so mikel pite & pes. Bot Iugens & Perodours Agayn hym gonne be him were. werreours; Pryuely gadered þey partye, & tok hym al wyþ tricherie; At Londone þey dide hym in hold, In a prison hard & cold.
text.63: ¶ De falsitate fratrum. Perodour & Iugenes, Þey parted al þis lond, & ches: Iugenes tok, as hym þought best, By northen Humber, Est & West. Perodour hadde þat oþer partie, & in a þrowe al þe seignurye; ffor Iugenes lyued bot seuen &yogh;er, Wythouten heyr, quyt & cler. ¶ Perodour gan hit þenne vnderfonge; Rex. Bot he reioysed hit nought ne ioyed it neuer. longe, ffor þe ffeuerynges ferynges. deþ hym tok; Wyþ synne hit wan, wiþ sorewe hit fursok. schame for soke. ¶ Þen brought þey forthe sire Elydour, Rex. & corouned hym wyþ honur. When he had take þris had he takyn. þe coroun, He dide þat tyme þe folk somoun To se þe skaþes his breþere had don, & amended hem al so son. Of folyes was he god iustice, He refte nere man his fraunchise; He gaf ensample of alle wysdam, Þat helden þe lond, or after hym cam; Large of herte, of wylle fre, He hight Elydour of pyte; In al his tyme hit was hende, all ende , and leaves out the next line. In alle godnesse his lyf gan ende; In Aldeburghe castel was he leyd, 'Klud' Glud. þat tyme þe name was seyd. After Elydour of pite, His cosyn hadde þe regalte, Þe eldest sone of Gorbodian, Rex. Syþen Argailes sone, MS. Argailessone. þat hight Morgan. Rex. Þys Morgan was god & meke, His gode wyl was nought to seke; He was god lord Lord till all. wyþouten ylle, And alle hym louede wyþ gode wylle. After Morgan, Argailles sone, MS. Argailessone. ¶ Ermaneus Emmanius , or Ennuanius. En|niaunus, Geoff. Mon. hadde þe regyone. Rex. Eumaneus Emmanius , or Ennuanius. En|niaunus, Geoff. Mon. was Morganes broþer, Bot his maners were alle oþer, He couþe hym neuere ffrendes gete; Tyl al he hadde ire & hate, niht and hete. & alle hated hym right sore, ffor he dide ylle to alle þat wore; Ilkon þey found hym vengaunce ful, Wyþ schrewes he dide hem many yl pul. with yuel men did him manie a pull. Six wynter he regned in his lyf, In felonye & in stryf: Alle þe comune seide right þus, " We haten hym, so doþ he vs." Þer-opon conseillede þey, & dryue hym out of þe lond awey; Þus þey reftym reft him. þe kynedam, & noman wyste whe[re] where. he bycam. Þenne made þey a parlement, & chosen a kyng þorow alle assent, [þe comon of þe region] From P. Iugeneus sone, sire Yualon. Vigenius ..Idrovallo, Geoff. M. Rex. Yualon gaf hym to trauaille, Al to gode þat myghte auaille; He dide make many estres, And lykned muche his gode auncestres; Bot his lyf lasted bot lif was. no stounde, Ouer sone had deþ cast hym to grounde. When Yualo had mad his endyng, Perodours his sone þey chose kyng. Rex. After Perodours sone deces, Was Elydours sone Gerunces; Rex. After Gerunces was Catillus; Rex. After Catillus was Coyllus; Rex. Þenne was Porrex; & þenne Cheryn, Reges. He þat was a drynkere of wyn; Ouer mykel drynke he ches; Hys &yogh;ougthe al þer-inne he les, In drynke & in dronkenesse, Dide he neuere oþer prowesse. By his wyf had he þre sones, & alle were kynges (þe story mones) Ilkon were after oþer: ffulgenius was þe eldest broþer; Rex. Eldadus, & Androcheus, Reges. Þis oþer breþere men caldem þe toþer breþer called men. þus; Lytel while was ilkon kyng, Alle made þey sone þer endyng. Androcheus sone highte Vryan, Rex. He regned a &yogh;er, & deide þan. After Vrian, Elyud men ches; Rex. He hadde his tyme þe lond yn pes. After Elyud, Endacius; Cledamus, Geoff. M. Clédan|tius, Wace , l. 3737. Rex. After þan, Doten Cletonus, Geoff. M. Cloten, Wace , l. 3738. ; syþen Gurguttus; Reges. Syþen was Merian, fayr in chere, Rex. He couþe of wode & of ryuere; In alle manere venurye, Hym lyked best swylke maystrie. Ladies bed hym of loue ynow, Bot to non of hem wolde his loue bow, Bot onlyke til his owen wyf; So ended Merian his lyf. After Meryan was Bleludo Rex. His sone, & couthe of wode also; Large he was, & gaf bleþely, He spared to of. non þat was worþy; Alle men hym loued, for he was fre, Erl, baron, & knyght, & oþer meyne. After þys noble Bleludo Cam Capes,—hys name was so;— Rex. After Capes, Oeneus; Rex. After Oeneus cam Sysillius; Rex. After Sysilly com Glegabret, Blegabret. Rex. A syngere of þe beste get; þat was a syngere of þe get. Of song & of mynstrecye Alle men gaf hym þe maystrie; Þe note he couþe of alle layes, Of mynstrecye al þer assayes; & mynstralcie all þe saies. He couþe so mykel musyk & thume Þat þe people [saide said. ] in his tyme He was þe best was god. of ffythelers, Of iogelours & of sangesters, ffor he was euere glad & ? for in or to. gamen, ffele in seruise held he samen. Of ioye & song was his spel; Was he neyþer irous ne not irous no. fel, Bot led his lyf in melodye Ynto þe tyme þat he schold deye. After hym was Archyuaul, Archmaul , or Archiuaul. Rex. Pesable he was,—God haue ys saul!— After hym was his sone Eldol; Rex. Hit seys he hadde a folted pol, ffor he was euere lecherous, Of women ouer coueytous. A gentil womman, where he myght if he mot. fynde, Were scheo neuere so noble of kynde, Wheþer scheo were wedded or nought, His lecherie he wolde haue y-wrought; & for þencheson of his folye, Men hated hym, as was worthie. After Eldolf, þys folted fon, Cam his sone hight Redyon. Rex. Redyon hadde þe kynedam, & after Redyon, Redryk cam; Rex. Syþen was ffamour, & kyng Myssel; & Famur & Missel , for which Geoff. Mon. has "Samuelpenissel," and Wace "rois Phanupenisel," l. 3799. Reges. And after hym com kyng Pyrchel: Rex. Pyrchel had fair heued wiþ her, Þorow gift of kynde þat was er; heire. Som what was hit fair out of kynde, Þat &yogh;ut of his her heire. write men fynde. After hym cam Caporus; Rex. Syþen, his sone Elignellus. Cligueillus, Geoff.; Elignellius, Wace. MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3 Colb. De Lincy, i. 181, note a . Rex. Þys Elygnellus, fol wys was he, Man of mesure wel auyse; After hym regned his sone Ely Rex. ffully to-gidere &yogh;eres fourty; A noble man was he, & a wys; ffaire he deyd, & at Castre lys.
text.64: ¶ Lud Rex. Helye had þre sones wyghte: Þe eldest sone, Lud he highte; Þat oþer was Cassibalan; Þe þrydde, Nemny, Nenny (Nennius, Geoff. and Wace , l. 3812). a doughti man. Lud was eldest, most of age, Hym fel to haue þe heritage; Knyght was he fol god in stour, & lyberal man, & vyaundour; & metegift man viandoure. Cites & casteles newe dide set; Of þe olde mad he god recet; gude rescette. He louede London best of alle, Þerfore vmb-closedit wyþ a he closed it about with. walle; Manye ar þe clos me men. se &yogh;it stande, Þat Lud dude make, hym whils he was. lyuande. ffor barons & for burgeys sake, Grete stedes til hem dide he make; Þerfore men seye, & &yogh;it men may, Þat neuere bifore vnto þat day Made kyng byforn so fele cites, Ne castels, ne clos, þat &yogh;ut men ses. ¶ Tyl Luddes tyme men held þat haunt, To calle London Trenouant; ffor þe loue of Lud ylk del, Þat woned þer longe, & closed hit wel, & was of hym so gret renoun; Kaer Lud þer fore men calde þe toun. Þenne come oþere men were straunge; ffor þe Lud, London dide hit chaunge, Þenne come Saxoyns, men of Angle, Als þey couþe on þer speche iangle, ffor Kaer-lud caldyt Ludden, Þat couþe þey best com on & ken; Þenne come þe Normaunz & þe Frankisch, Couþe nought com on to calle hit þis; ffor London, Londres þey hit calde; &yogh;it Frensche men þat name on frankis &yogh;it þat name men. halde. ffor regnynge be remouyng. of kynges straunge, ffor diuerse speche, langage men chaunge, Þat han þis lond often ywonnen, & þorow riden & þorow ronnen, & Ere. þe names chaunget þer fore; Som names ar lasse, & som ar more; I hope fo MS. þe. P. reads fo. tounes þat now are Hold þer names þat first ware. When sire Lud, þe gode kyng, Was ded, & don was & mad. his endynge, Byside his gate þey hym leyd, Þat, for his name, Ludgate ys seyd: He yt made, & he yt aughte, Lodgate for hym þe name laughte. Of Lud were left two childre &yogh;yng; Lond to kepe couþe þey no þyng: Þe eldest hight Androcheus, Þat oþer men calde Tenuacius. Tenuantius, Geoff. Tenuenci|us, Wace. Cassibolon was þer em, Þe nexte sibbe of þat tem, He kepte þe childre & þat lond; Men held hym kyng, faire he þem fond; He mayntende þe lond to ryght, He was curteys & doughty knyght; Þe folke he couþe wel iustise, Of hem he hadde fair seruise. When þe childre were of elde Þat þey couþe lordschip welde, In to tuo. erldomes he dide þem seyse, Worschipfoly, al atter ayse. Androcheus hadde, þorow assent, Londoñ, & þe erldom MS. Erldon. of Kent; Þat oþer broþer had þe baylle Of þe erldom of Cornewaille. When ilk was sesed in his erldam, Þey were cald Erles, whare þey cam. To whyle þe kyng & his cosyns In loue loken ar þer lynes, Richesse þey hadde ynow to wylle, & of no lond dredde þey non ylle, Ne neuere þurt hem haue thorte haf. drad no tyde. Bot ouerwenyng of herte pride Ros a discord hem bytwene, Þat longe in þys londe was sene; ffour hundred &yogh;er hit lasted, & nyne, In þis lond þat firste pyne; Hit bigan, as &yogh;e may se, Of Cassibolon & Androche, Þorow whilk sorewe þe Romayns wan Truage of Cassibolan, Þat myghte nere be wonne mot neuer wyn it. byforn, Tyl þer loue þorow pride was lorn; P. omits the next four lines. Whyle þer loue to-gedere held, Might neuere no Romayn bide þem in feld, Þat þey ne chased, þorow force of fight, Cesar of Rome, & al his myght. How hit bygan bytwyxt þem bale, Listeþ, & y schal rede þe tale.
text.65: ¶ Exe de Iulio Cesare, Romanorum Inperatore. In þe tyme of Gassybolan, Iulius Cesar, a myghty man, Þat tyme was Emperour of Rome. Of alle knyghtes of knyghthede. he bar þe blome, Of alle þo þat men of tyme were. herd, ffor he conquered al þe werd; Als he was doughti knygt, & god, In clergie wel he hym vnderstod, Of conseil he was man ful wys, & of manhod he bar þe pris; Hys gyftes he gaf largely, He wyste to wham hit whom &. was worthi; ffals & felon he couþe wel knowe; Þe ouer proude, he held þem lowe. Þe Romayns were þan of pride, ffor þey hadde wonne on ilka side; Þe londes oueral þem aboute, & gauen þeym truage for doute. When Iulyus had wonne þus þere, ffurþer he þoughte to conquere; Long nold he soiourne ne wald he soioure. ne rest, Tyl he had wonnen toward þe west. Hardy Iulius, knyght war & wys, Preysed of prowesse, of poer had pruesse powere &. pris; He gadered hym of knyghte &yogh;onge, Of alle nacions þat speke wyþ tonge, & tok his leue at [þe] Romayns, To wende fro þem for longe teymes; to wyne londes lungeteyns (les lontains, Wace , i. 186, l, 3922). West, he seide he wolde wende, To wynnen to þe wordles ende. werldis end. Whan Iulyus was wel dight ynow, He passed Burgoyne & Moungow. Fr. Mon Gius. Lat. Mons Jovis. ffyrst he wan al Burgoyne, ffraunce, Nawuarre, & Gascoigne, Peytowe, Normandye, þe lesse Bretayne; Syþen went agayn til Alemayne; Alle he wan hit ar he þeþen þien. nam, Siþen to Boloyne & to fflaundres he cam, & al conquered vnto þe se, Al gaf truage to Rome in fe. Whan al was wonne, wel heldyn held him. payd, By þe se a day he &yogh;ede & playd; Toward þe se his eye egh. gan kest, & faste byheld toward þe west: " What ys &yogh;one lond y &yogh;onder se, " & what [folk] folk /. euere þer may be?" Men hym tolde hit was a lond þat folk of Troye first[e] fond; Brutus highte þer firste cheftayn, & after hym hit hatte Bretayn; þe heires þat of hym ar comen, In heritage þey haue hit nomen.
text.66: ¶ Dicta Iulii Inperatoris. Iulyus answered & seide right þus: " Wel han y herd of sire Brutus; " He saide he com of Eneas kynde, " Bot ryghtly born nought we fynde; " He com of Eneas, þat held þo landes " Þer Rome our cite now yn standes; " &yogh;yf he were born of Eneas kyn, " Þorow kynde y sette chalange þer-yn; " Chalange y wole þat lond þorow ryght, " Þat Eneas kynde gete þorow had of. myght. " Ys þat lond — loke Es &yogh;on þat Ilde þat. &yogh;e me kenne— " Þat bolde Belym was of, & Brenne, " Þat oure cite of Rome wan, " Oure se[n]e, & our seene (senate). destruyed ilkaman? " Wel schal þey wite, whyle witte till. y am her, " Þat Rome ys now of more power! " & right hit were, & reson hit welde, " Þat þey til vs truage schold &yogh;elde: " &yogh;one ilde was Belynes, & Rome was his; " Gret skil haue y þenne þorow þys, " ffor to sette chalange þer-inne, " Þat his lond was, þorow right to wynne. " By letteres woly hem first somoune, " To here þer wyl, what þey respoune; " Nought ne woly passe þe se " Til y wyte how þey answere me. " &yogh;yf þey to my pes wille hem chese, " & &yogh;eld hit me, þey schol nought lese; " &yogh;yf þey ne wol nought bot wyþ stour, " y dereyne þe lond for our." Þay dide Iulyus write a bref, & schewed hem how he was chef, & how his kynde fyrst hit wan: Of Eneas com Brutus, þat man, & syþen was Belynes heritage; He wold hit wynnen, or take truage. Þe lettere com to Cassibolan, Þat he schold bycome sire Iulyus suld com Iulius þat man. man. Cassibolan brak þe seal o sunder; Of truage askyng he had wonder; Anoþer lettere dede he wryte þare, & sent hit ageyn vntil Cesar Al in ire & in tene, & þe lettere writte. þus mykel wol mene:
text.67: ¶ Rescripcio Cassibolany ad Inperatorem. ¶ "Cesar," he saide, "we haue meruaille " & gret desdeyn, wyþouten faille, " Þat of &yogh;ow Romayns rennes silk los,— " & to longe hit lastes after hit & fer it. gos,— " Þat ar of so gret couetyse " Þat non bot &yogh;e may haue fraunchise; " And al þe syluer & al þe gold, " & alle lynage þat lyuen on mold, " Til &yogh;oure dom wil &yogh;e þem drawe; " Wy[þ]oute reson, wyþoute lawe, " Al þe tresor &yogh;e drawe &yogh;ow to: " What wil &yogh;e þer-wyþ al do? " & we þat are atte wor[l]des ende, " & in an ylde lyue lif. & lende, " &yogh;yt &yogh;e ne wil will &yogh;e nouht. passe vs forby " Wyþoute truage askyng bot &yogh;orgh treuage. greuously! " & we MS. were. þat schal & ben we þat suld be. &yogh;our peres, " &yogh;it wolde &yogh;e make vs truagers! " Þerfore, Iulius, &yogh;yf þou wilt assay, " & of þy comynge to com till vs &. sette vs a day, " Y trowe þou schalt fol euele suld litell. spede. " Com on, & proue hit in If þou wild proue it with. dede! " ffor euere &yogh;it haue we lyued fre " Y þis lond, bot now for þe, " & schul we lyue als we suld life also. frely " As &yogh;e Romayns; & reson whi: " Syn we ar comen alle of o for &yogh;e & we ere all a. kynde, " & of o rote & of o rynde, comen of a rute & a rynde. Fr. orine (origin), Wace , i. 190, l. 4010. " Þat ys to seyn, for we ere comen. of Eneas, " As frely born as euere þou was. " Þerfore, &yogh;yf þou þe byþoughtest " In skil & reson as þou oughtest, & after skill & reson wrouhtis. " Þou scholde nought put vs to þou suld not sette vs in. seruage, " Syn we ben of þyn owen þat ere of þin awen. lynage; " We schul be peres to &yogh;ow of Rome, " In alle fredam haue euenly dome. " Vs wondreþ at &yogh;owre nurture of Als þou ert Ientill & of grete. pris, " Þat swylke vilenie in þe now lys, " In seruage to put vs to! " & we wot nought how we scholde do, " We neuere lered, ne nought wil lere, " &yogh;yf þat we may, in none manere. " Of alle oure kynde, y ne wyste no man " Þat couþe of seruage, seruise. ne &yogh;ut ne can; " Ne we knowe nought on what wyse " We scholde serue seruage seruise. " ffre we ar, so schol we be; " & &yogh;yf God wyl, we schul Cesar. for þe! " Wite þou wel by oure answe[re], " While till. we may oure seluen were, " & fende oure lond & oure fraunchise, " Of vs getestow neuere seruise! " Ne neuere truage schol we þe gyue; ne treuage I gyf þe a gyue. " Þat ys to seye, whiles þat we lyue, " We wol be fre, & holde honurs, " As dide byforn our auncessours." To Iulius swylk a lettere þey sent; & when Iulius wiste þat entent, Þat &yogh;if he wold haue any truage, Nede byhoued nedeli borde. hym make passage, Þenne dide he make schipes & barges, ffoure score wyþ grete charges,— So grete byfore were neuere for were, Ne non þat so gret heuy. charge myght bere,— Wyþouten oþer schipes smale, Þat we nought telde byforn in were not telde of in þat. tale.
text.68: ¶ De nauigio Cesaris. ¶ When Iulius Cesar was al redy, To go to schipe þey made a cry; His folk com in-to schipe right fast, & drowe þer saylles vp heye on did drawe þe saile on þe. mast; Þen blew þe wynd, and gan hem dryue, At an heuen þey gon vp aryue, ryue. Þer Temese & þe se to-gydere comen. Bot er Cesar hadde vp lond ynomen, þe land had nomen. Þer was sprad by þe se side ffair folk to fighte, Cesar tabyde: to bide. Cassibola[n] Cassibelan. was redy at Douere, & renged his men by þe ouere; him bi þe ses ouere. (A.-Sax. ofer shore). Hys styward highte sire Belyn, Of conseil was he god & fyn; He hadde do comen þorow don com þorgh. somons On alle ilk. half, erles & barons. Þe kynges neuews com wyþ gret neuoz þe to. partie,— To hem he myghte hym well on þo tuo he myght. affye,— 7 Þe eldest highte Androcheus, Þat oþer broþer Temuacius; Androcheus & his Loundreneys, 7 7-7 Androcheus & his lordynges, londreis. Tenuacius wiþ his Cornwaleys, Sire Nemnius, sire of Kanterbire, Þe noblest of al þe empire: Þe kynges broþer was Sire Nemny, Androcheus was in his compaigny, & oþer folk [ful] gret plente. Wyþ ostes were þer kynges þre: Erudyonus, þere þe. Scottes kynge, Britalles wyþ al þe Walsche garderynge; Of South Walys com kyng Ignarcet; Þyse þre were in [o] a. bataille set, Wyþ here frewille þyse þre cam ffor to defende þe[r] þar. fredam. Ilkon gaf conseil to go Er þe Romayns were logged mo;
text.69: ¶ Bellum inter Romanos & Cassibolanum. ¶ Er þey hadde ony recet taken, Þey þoughte þey wolde hem a-wake[n]. or þei wild hald þam waken. When alle were set in ylka bataille, & schept ho scholde formest assaille, whilk of þam suld formast saile. Toward þe Romayns faste þey nomen. Whan Cesar sey þat þey scholde comen, He cried to hys men "armes &yogh;ow! " Þe Bretons ar redy, & come right now." Sone were þer bataille ostes. to-gedere met, & to bataille renget & set: The next six lines are from P. [þe parties smert smyten togidre, With scharp suerdes on helmes gan glidre. þer schaftes þorgh schoten body & schelde; Many on fell, & many vphelde; Many tome sadill & hors ostray, Many douhti knyght doun þer lay;] Many on wounded lay þer to blede, & manyon stode, som fledde for drede; Knyghte knyghtes. iustede, archers drowe, On boþe parties fol manie þey slowe, Þei come so þikke & so smert, & perced brunyes, hauberk. brest & hert; Wyþ wyfles (A.-S. wifel , arrow, dart, jave|lin.) stanes , P. strike, wyþ axes hewe, Schuldres, schankes, & hedes, doun hewe; þe schuldres þe schankes doun threwe. Alle was strewed þe grene gras Wyþ blod & bowaille bowes. & heuedes fresch. fful hard was þer, & moste no ferly was it behoued. nede; Þe quiyke vpon þe dede &yogh;ede; Vpon þe dede þey stode to fight, & eueryche alle. slow þat he slo myght. Cesar hadde in his bataille Knyghte þat couþe boþe fende & saille; He peyned hym to do þeym wo, & faste he folewede hem for to slo; Was þer no man was it non. þat he smot, Þat ful sore on hym ne þat ne þe dede sone him bote. bot; Mighte þer noman lyue no stounde, Þat of his swerd[e] laughte toke any. wounde. Androcheus com wyþ þo of Kent, & Nemnyus, to-gedere þey went, Þey set o þe Romayns a gret þei gadred þam a gode. partie, & beot hem doun batailed þam. as men hardie, & seide "Turne we vpon Sezar!" & als þey rod, þey were hym of him. war. Nemmyus fyrst ferde in þe stour, & bated hym opon abatid him on. þe emperour, And ful glad was þat he myght Wiþ so noble grete. a lordyng fyght. Cesar perseyued þat he cam, A-geyn his scheld a strok his stroke his scheld. vp nam; Cesars swerd Cesar suerde. was out ful sone; Nemny to smyte he was al bone, & Nemny on þe heued he smot; Hit was trenchaunt, ouer fer hit bot, Bot Nemny bar vp his scheld, His heued a party lowe hit held; lowe a parti helde. &yogh;it þe strok sank so doun, Þorow þe helm he schelde &. brak his croun; Lite failled þat he ne had Clouen þe hed, þe Clouen þe borde. dynt was sad; Bot Nemny bar þe scheld o sker, & Iulius smot his swerd ouer fer, Þat he ne myghte drawe hyt ageyn; Naþeles he dide þerto his peyn, He drow þe swerd, Nempny þe scheld, Ilkon wel his owen held; Nemny wilde haue turnd & went, Bot Iulius wiþ þe draught hym hent; I hope Iulyus had drawen hit out, Bot Nemnyus fol[k] folk. were egre & stout. Androcheus, Nemnyus neuew, neuow. Wyþ hem of Kent dide gret prow; On ilka side þey slowe aboute, & Cesar saw hym self in doute, & fro þem fledde in to þe feld, & lefte his swerd in Nemnyus scheld. Nemny saw of help ynow, He turned þe scheld, þe swerd out drow, & wiþ þat swerd forþ he faught; Bot þo þat þer-wyþ woundes laught, Myghte þey neuere haue medecyne, Bot to þe deþ by-houed hem þe dede bod þam. labennius. (Labienus, Geoff. and Wace. ) pyne. Als he þus faught, þys Nemmyus, He ouer-tok sire Labemnius, constablie. (conestablie, Wace , i. 198, l. 4177.) — A lord he was of gret baillye, In Rome he hadde a constablerye, 6 — Nemnius swilk a strok hym lent, Þat by þe schuldres þe hed of went. How manye þer deide, y may nought ame; Of alle þe fighters y knowe no name; Bot þer was manyon doun leyd, Wel mo þan any man wrot or seyd, & wel mo scholde &yogh;it þat nyght, Had þey nought sondred for faute of lyght. had ne sondred þam & left þer fight.
text.70: ¶ De fuga Romanorum. Þen com þe nyght, gon was þe day, & ilka party &yogh;ede þer way. Þe Romayns syde was nought payd, Logges non hadde, þey were dismayed; Wery þey were, & yuel lykande, ill likand. ffor wiþ þe Brutons þey myght One stroke too many in the m. nout stande. Þey toke conseil a-wey to wende, No lenger in þys lond to lende; ffor þe contre knew þey nought, Logge ne recet had þey non wrought; To schipe þey wente þat ilke nyght, Vntil fflaundres þey fley þer flyght. Þe Bretons made blisse, ilkon, Þat þe Romayns were so gon; Bot þe kyng made sorewe ynow ffor Nemnyus, þat to deþe drow; Nennius to dede drouh. Medicyne myghte non be founde Þat myghte hele Nemnyus wounde. Of sire Nemny nought elles to seye, Bot þe fiftenþe day Nemny gan deye. he died on þe fiftend day. Þey buryed hym in a temple gate, In London, atte Northe gate, Honurabloker Honorable more. þan an oþer, ffor he was þe kynges broþer. Þat swerd he wan of sire Cesar, De gladio Cesaris. By hym in graue þey leide hit þar, ffor he was of gret honur, & he haddyt wonnen y þat stour. Þe swerd was of swylk metal, Þat who þat wounded were wyþ-al, He ne scholde nought longe lyue ffor medicine men myghte hym gyue. Why of deþ hit hadde þe gylt, Hit was writen on þe hilt Wyþ lettres of gold, burnusched bryght, Þat "Crucia mors" þat swerd hight: P. has, for the next three lines, on & &yogh;it men say as sais þe romance. Hit myghte wel hote "Crucia mors;" Wham hit wounded, hit was ded cors; & &yogh;it hit ys seyd y þe Romaunce, Þe enperours swerd was al vengaunce. Til þeym of ffraunce cam tidyng tyt, How þe Romayns were desconfit Þorow þe Bretons in pleyn bataille. Þanne mysliked þeym saunz faille, And for cowardes þem selue ches, ffor þey were at [þe] þe. Romayns pes. Þey conseilled þem a day certeyn, Vpon Cesar to turne a-geyn; In þer conseil þei seide þus: " Als þe Bretons chased Iulyus, " &yogh;ut schul &yogh;it sall. we fonde so to spede, " To do sire Iulius fle for drede. " Þe Bretons be nought &yogh;it so bolde " As we haue ben, [ne] men of tolde, als we ere ne men of tolde. " & so lyghtly dide þem lout! " &yogh;it schul &yogh;it sall. we fonde to chace hem out. " Hit are ynowe þat first han grace " ffor to wynne, & robbe, & chace, " & siþen turnes þer praye til pyne; " Lyghtli þey wynne, lightly þey tyne: " Þer lordschip &yogh;it schul we abate, " ffor alle þe world þey wynne wyþ hate." Þus þey seyde þat þey wold do; & &yogh;it alday men telle þem so, teld þam to. Þat þe Bretons MS. frensche. bretons , P. Que li Breton mer passeroient, Wace , l. 4249 (after Geoffrey ). wolde fonde a flyght ffor to felle þe Romayns myght. france to help þe romeyns to fight. Þat sawe made mad. þeym wylde & wod, & reysed þem more vp in þer mod: Bot sone þer bost was al in griþ, Whan sire Iulius had spoken hem wyþ. Sire Iulius Cesar was ful queynte, Wisdam he couþe, & wordes feynte; A folet couþe he wel adaunte, a felon [ Wace , félon] couþ he full wele daunte. To proude men þer wylle graunte.
text.71: ¶ De blandiscione Cesarys. Wel couþe he paye þe couetous, & wynne He wan. þe wille of þe enuyous; & ful wel couþe bere hym meke When his strength force. was for to seke. He wiste þat þe frenche men wist þe frankis men. were fykel, & how þey forcedem forced þem. agayn hym mykel; & his men were yuel ille. dight, Wery & wounded al & weri for-fouhten. in fight; Leuer hym were in loue þem loute, luf to loute. Þan in bataille to ben com to bataile & be. in doute; Þe Bretons hadden hasted hem had þam hasted. so, Þat tyme in dede myghte þey nought do. Wyþ faire wordes hem to hym drow; & gaf hem giftes & richesse giftes riche; and leaves out the next two lines. ynow,— ffor of his giftes he was ful large, ffor schame þey moughte hym namore charge;— & more he byhet, þan gyue hette þam if þat. he myght, Þe Bretons to wynne wiþ force & fight. To pore men he gaf fraunchise, & cleymed þeym quit clamé quite, Wace. Eng. "quit|claim." of þer seruise; Þo men he hadde flemed þat he had fled. [ Wace , escil|lié]. þe contre, To comen ageyn he gaf hem fre, & to haue þer heritage, & restored þeym of here þam þer. damage. Þerfore when þis grete lordynges Seyen Cesar ofre sawe Cesar offer. þem swylke þynges— Gold & syluer atter at þer. wille— In pes þey held hem alle stille. Mikel ys richesse of power! ffor sone had he bated wo & wer, wheere; and leaves out the next two lines, and transposes the two next to them. Sone had he turned wrong to right, Sone had he blent þe coueytous sight, Sone made he frend þat er were wroþe, Of Cesar & þe ffrankysche boþe; ffor þo þat hym byforen hated, Wiþ for. hys gyftes were alle abated; Þat schopen hym yuel compassid foly. & outrage, Þey diden mad. hym fewte & homage, At his conseil for to lende, Ageyn þe Bretons &yogh;yf he wold wende. Whan sire Cesar, Iulius. lord & sire, Had pesed & swaged al þer ire, He conseilled hym wyþ an engynour, & dide hym make a merueyllous tour In Boloygne: "Ordre" ys þe name. So wrought ys non bot þat same; By-neþen hit is in strange compas; Brod & þykke þe gynnynge was, & euere hit nareweþ nerewes. rysande on heyght, & semeþ griller grelere (rougher, sharper). & more streight. Selcouþe stages ar þer-ynne, Wyndowes cast, coruen wiþ gynne. His tresor he leyde þer inne to lok, Onlyke þer al þat he toke; & hym self lay in þe tour, When he dred hym of for [de traïson, Wace ]. his tresour. Two &yogh;er he dwelled þer in ffraunce, & dight hit for werre in alle dighted it for were o. chaunce; He sente to baillifs to gadere hym his. fees, & reisede his truwage of his citees. Whan al was gadered on ylk party, In Ordre þey leide hit in tresory. In two &yogh;er he dide hym dight, & made hym to Brutayne right, vppon þe bretons eftsons to fight. & dide hym dighte a fflute on flode, Sex hundred gret schipes & gode, schipes grete & gode. & seide, "&yogh;it wyly make will mak. assay " Vpon þe Bretons, spede how if. y may; " Bot &yogh;if y may conquere Cassibolan, " Y preise nought elles al þat y er wan; " Al my conqueste preise y nought, " Bot þe Bretons to trewe be brought."
text.72: ¶ De subuersione nauigii Cesaris in Tamysia. Whan hit was dight, al his flet, Wyþ god folk & vitailles set, Þe schipes seyled day & nyght Til þey come in to Temese right. þei sette vp saile þe schippes kemse þe wynde þam drofe in to temse. Þus þey wend, þat atte firste tyde Þer nauye to Londone holy schold suld. ryde; Alle at ones þe scholde suld. vp saille, & to þe Bretons gyue bataille. Þe Bretons wist hit wel ynow, Bot of þer sleigþe lystneþ now; bot what þei did listen how. Longe pyles peeles. [peus ferrés, Wace , 4437.] & grete dide þey make; ffaste yn Temese dide þey hem stake, Euerylkon wyþ iren schod; Ageyn þe schipes stod ilkon ilk an. od, fful wel set, & sykerly; Þer myght non wel ascape scape. forby.
text.73: ¶ De bello inter Cesarem & Brutones in Tamysia. ¶ Right atte fulle se at a folle flowe. of flod Com alle six hundred schipes god; Sykerly þey wend haue nomen, & into Londone at ones comen. Þey ne were wyþynne bot a lite, Or on þe pyles gon þey are on þe peles þai gan. smyte. Þer myght men se þat stod on brynke, Schipes in-to þe water synke; Þat on vn-to þe toþer hurte, hurtle. (hurter, Wace , 1. 4347.) Þe mastes faste falle. to-gidere burte, & somme ouer-terned, & lay on syde; Bordes ryuen out holes wyde, Ropes ryuereled, & swerued reueld suarled. in lyne, Ilkon dered oþer, & dide pyne; Lond ne hauene myght þey non taken, So faste on pyles gan þey staken: pelis gon þei stake. In yuel ille . . nome. tyme out þey nomen, Yuel þey ryued þat þider comen! Ille þei sailed & þidire come. Cesar saw þat grete vnhap, Þat in þe water was swylk a trap; Iren-schod was ilka peel, & he. þoughte þat so was ilka del; Many of þem turned a-geyn, & seyde þat wendyng was in veyn. He dide þem alle gon vp to londe, Man & hors, þer þey best fonde; By bankes vp aboute þey wente, & pyght piked. þeym pauylons & tente. Right als þey picched piked. þer pauylons, Cam Cassibolan wyþ þe Bretons, Erles, barons, knyghte, squiers, suaynes. Asperly folle on þe Romayners: fellid on þe romayns. — His neuew & oþere of his neuoz & his oþer. kynde, Wyþ alle þe oþere þat he myghte help þat he mot. fynde, Þe kynge asemblede in noble ascried þam on his. wyse, ffor wiþ þe Bretons was no feyntise:— & at þer logges þer as. þey hem set, Þe Bretons wyþ hem þer þey met. For the next two lines the Petyt MS. has, on leaf 28, back,— ferweis at þer first comyng. þer armour herd ye crusse & ryng. At þer loges þe romeyns biden. agayn þe bretons stifly riden. of which the first two represent the "Dont véissiés armes croissir" of Wace , l. 4366, vol. i. p. 206. Þeyr egre comyng þe Romayns a-boden, A-geyn þe Brutons stifly þey stoden; Als a wal þe scheltrom held, þer hardynes helde. (Lor hardi|ment orent por mur, Wace , l. 4369.) & ruysed þe Brutons abak did þe bretons go bak. in feld. ffirst þe Romayns ful wel stoden, Agayn þe Bretons in bataille &yogh;oden, felde &yogh;od. & fer bakward dide hem go, & manyon slowe, & wroughte wo. Þenne was wroþ Cassibolan; ffor tene byfore þem alle he nam, wan. & bar þe breste on þem by-fore, & after hym þe Bretons gaf gan. bore, & euere was fresche folk comande, And dide þe Romayns ageyn stande. So wyþynne a litel þrowe Men amed þem, & wel hit sowe, Two so many Bretons þare As hadde þer Iulius Cesare, Bien se sunt esmé as trois rans De chevalier, tos combatans, Que César n'i ot amené. Wace , i. 206, l. 4377-9. Britones vero, omni hora affluen|tia suorum augmentati, triplo major|em numerum habebant. Galf. Mon. iv. 7 (p. 62, ed. Giles). & dide þe Romayns a-geyn to fle, & slowe þem, schame was hit to se!
text.74: ¶ De probitate Brutonum. ¶ Hardy Cesar, noble kyng, Þat neuere so bayscht was neuer abaist. for no þyng, He sey þe force of þe Brutons, & hyse to þem hadde no fuysons. fosons (defence, p. 56, l. 1591, note 17, above. Þe Bretons, as wode, rengede route; Of dynt ne deþ dede ne dynt. had þey no doute; Þey slowe, & felde, & made þem weye; Þey made no force to lyue ne deye. or deie. Cesar perceyued þat ful wel, He dide turne hys folk ylk del A-geyn, & to þer schipes wende; Bot hym self lefte til was in. þe last ende, A-gayn þe Bretons for to þe bretons. to fyght, Þe whyles to whils. his folk to schipe þem dight. By þe lond þe schypes did ryde, To kepe his folk at ilka tyde; When alle were ynne, & sayl on mast, Cesar com yn alder last; & alle þat were of his conrey, Hyed þem faste, & wente vp with saile & forth. þer wey. Euene as lyne als lyn. þe wynd gan dryue; At Ordre, his tour, gon þey aryue. did vp ryue. The three lines following are in the MS. du Roi 73, and the Arsenal 71 ( Wace , i. 207), though not in the MS. du Roi 27 that De Lincy printed. Cesar soiourned þer ful longe, To hele þem þat hele þat. were wounded stronge, & man & hors for to rest, And ordeyned for hym what was best. Þe kyng of þys lond, kyng douhti kyng. Cassibalan, & þe Bretons ilka man, Made ioye for þe mykel pris Þat þey had wonnen won. of Cesar twys. Þe Romayns, mykel sorewe þey made Þat þe Bretons were so all : and leaves out the next four lines of verse. glade; Cesar & hyse were dismayed, Bot þe Bretons were wol payed.
text.75: ¶ Pro Victoria eorum optulerunt solempnem sacrificium Diane diis suis. ffor ioie þey hadden þo batalle wonnen, & Cesar twyes had ouer-ronnen, To God þey highte to make a feste Wyþ alle þe comme[n]s lest & meste. comune of þer geste. Þe day he set of þe sacrifise, Hys vow to holde wyþ fair seruise. Cassibalon sende his messegers ffor þe barons, for barons. knyghtes, & squiers, Of his demeynes alle þe pytaille peddile (foot-soldiers). Þat hadde hym serued in bataille, Þat þey scholde suld. alle to London come, Vp peyne of forfeture of &. dome, Wyf & child wiþ hem schold suld. lede, Þo þat halp hym in his nede, & alle all þei. come wiþ herte glad, In riche atyr, ryght as he bad. Man & wyf, & children &yogh;onge Þat couþe go, & speke wyþ tonge, Alle þey comen to þe cyte: ffairer folk myght no man se; & ilkaman after his auenaunt Made offrynge, as was his þer. haunt.
text.76: ¶ Exe Sacrificium. ¶ Þys feste day þat was so hey, Were offred ffifty was of fourti. (quarante mil, Wace , i. 209, l. 4431.) þousand ky, &, þer-to, þre þer þritti (trente-millers, Wace. ) þousand hyndes, Wylde walkande by wode lyndes; & an hundred þousand schep; Þe noumbre of tale af. foules gaf noman kep, So fele þer were, myght non þem no man. ame, What of wilde, what of tame. When don was þat sacrefyse, & feste holde in þer beste wyse, P. leaves out this line. Mynstrals bygon to blowe glewe. & ryme, Als þer custume was þat tyme; Knyghtes, squiers, made bourdys, & hem desgysede in pourpre in þer quantise of purpure. & bys; & oþer bachelers skirmede faste, Wrastlede, lepen, wristled skipped. stones caste; In feld, in toun, in at. ilka weye, Ilkon pleide þat he couþe pleye. When þey hadde alle pleyd at wille, & schold haue ended, & & suld haf. ben al stille, Two wolde skyrmen, as fel þe skirme þat com of. cas, Sire Huwelyn & Irelgas. hereglas ( Ireglas in rubric and next line).
text.77: ¶ De Infortunio inter Huwelynum & Irelgas. Irelgas was þe kynges cosyn; Androcheus neuew was Huwelyn. nouowc was Heulyn. Þyse to-gedere wolde skyrme al gate; Þorow pride of herte son com þer hate, Þorow hate þen gan þer þorgh þan gan. wordes ryse Of boþe parties of yuel ill. assise. When ilk had seyd til oþer wough, Wyþ wraþe to smyte, þe egge edge. drough: Þorow a meschaunce, y wot hit was, Huwelyn slow þer Irelgas. When þe kyng þys chaunce herd seye, Þe feste was sturbled & turbled & mirth. aweye. ffor þe kyng was ful feloun, & hastyf, vntil vengaunce boun, Þe kyng seid vntil Androche, & bad hym vp peyne of alle his fe, Huwelyn, his cosyn, hym heulyn him. for to sende, Þat felonie for to amende, & in his court haue iugement Þorow þe comunes, er þat þey þorgh comon or þei. went. Androcheus þoughte þouh. wyþ herte ful wo: " &yogh;if y hym sende, he schal hym slo." Androcheus sende ageyn ful tyt, & of his court asked respit: " A lord y am, & a. court y haue; " Þorow þat wyl y whilk .I. may. hym dampne or saue. " &yogh;yf þer be eyþer it be ouþer. baron or knyght, " Pleyneþ hym þer, he schal haue right; " & þe souereynte þou takest þe þe courte þat þou bides me. to, " Hit schold be myn, & schal suld . . & sall. be so; " Þou wost hit wote it. ys myn heritage; " Þou bedes me mys & outrage!"
text.78: ¶ Rex irascatur versus Androcheum nepotem suum. When þe kyng herde his answere, He swor he scholde suld. on hym were; & þat he had, he scholde suld. hym reue, Heritage ne nought, hym byleue; & Huwelyn schold suld. he slo, ffor þat outrage þat [he] had do. for Ireglas suld he go. On þis manere parted departed. þer feste; Wiþ loue bygan, endede wiþ cheste. Cassibolan was Androcheus eem, Luddes broþer of þat teem. 7 Androcheus was Luddesone, & Temnace, As y forn telde in oþer place. 7 7-7 Androche & Tenuace lud sons boþe .I. told or space. Whan Lud deyde, þey ne couþe Kepe þe lond for þer for ouer. &yogh;ouþe; Cassibolan þerfore vndertok Þe lond, & hem to kepe & lok; & þorow þe wroþe of þis þynge Made Makis. Androche a chalangyng. Now ilka day Cassibolan fandes fondes . . . . . londes. To brenne & struye brenne. Androcheus landes.
text.79: ¶ Hic peciit concordiam. ¶ Androcheus saw his felon wille, Þat þe kyng þoughte hym to wild him. spille; He sente til hym his messeger, & preyed þe kyng in fair maner, Namore destruye his landes so, Bot make acord bytwyxt hem to; & preied hym "þat he wolde if he wild it. mone " Þat he ha. was his broþer sone, " & heir of al þat heritage " Þat þou me reuest wyþ outrage." reues als outerage. Þe kyng was of so felon rees, He ne wolde here of preyere ne he not here his praiere no. pes, Bot vengaunce take for any þyng; Þat falles ful yuel vmwhile ill. for a kyng. Androcheus saw no bettere bot: " Suffren," he saide, "nede y mot." Hys pleyn londes he let hym haue, Bot his forteletes he dide & his forceletes did. saue: Wiþ hym to holde he fond noman, So cruel was Cassybalan. ffle ne wold he neuer a del, Ne lese þat he myghte holde wel. Androcheus asked: "What ys to rede? said what is to spede. " Syn no man dar me helpe for drede, " & help me byhoues haue algate, bos haf alle gate. " Nede me dryueþ vntil chaces vnto: and then leaves out the next four lines. þe &yogh;ate; " ffor þe kyng assent wil nought " Þat y haue þes, als y haue sought. " Siþen y ne may haue no rest, " On oþer halue y schal do my best; " fful mykel anguisse woldy byde, " ffor to felle þe kynges pryde. " A folye to do, & fle a wel & slek a. more, " Men haldes þat wysdam hold it wisdom. & lore; " To do a folye, &yogh;ut were hit skyl, " ffort[o] lyuere to delyuer. a man fro more peryl; " & god hit wele it. were to suffre a wo, " ffor to venge hym of hys fo. " Wel y wot, & haue in hert, " Þat hit schal vs boþe smert; " Bot &yogh;it me lykes þat greuaunce, " &yogh;if y may take on hym vengaunce. " What so schal me bytide algate, " Þe kynges pride y wyl abate; " Y may nought elles wyþ hym dele." A lettere he wrot, & dide hit sele, & sent hit priuely to Cesar, Tyl Ordre his tour, for he was þar. What he wrot, & þyder sent, Y vnderstonde þus þentent:
text.80: ¶ Epistola Androchii ad Cesarem. ¶ "To Cesar, hardy, war, & wys, " Whas pruwesse men preise whos pruesse men praises. in pris! " Of Bretaigne, Androche þe Bretoun, " Sire of Kent, lord of London, " Sendeþ þe gretynge, wyþ his god red, " Þat whilom wylned to þe ded. to send þe gretyng is my rede, whilom to whom .I. desired dede. " Cesar! often haue men seen, " Þer to han tuo haf. hated, & fomen ben, " Þat syþen han loued to-gedre wel, " Tristiloker þan ony stel; tristeliere þen any. " After hate, loue wyl be, " & after schame, worschip & after wirschip. men se: " Þus hit bytides many gate, " Of somme þer longe has ben þat long haf bene in. hate. " Ilk soughte oþer deþ, we souht our dede. al þat we myght, " When we met vs we fondid. in feld to fight; " Bot so hit fel, to boþe oure prow, " Þat neyþer am y slayn, ne þow. " The lines following, down to l. 4915, are not in De Lincy's MS. du Roi 27, but are in MS. 73, Cangé. Wace , i. 214-15. A-geynes vs bataille hastow nomen, " & twyes we haue þe ouercomen; " Bot lef þou wel þis bot witte þou now. for certeyn, " Þat &yogh;if þou wilt come If þou will com. eft ageyn, " Of Kent ne þertestow thurte þe. fle þat cost, " Þaw þof. y were þere wyþ al myn host; " & þey þof. þe kyng þat tyme com þare, " Ne þart þe thurte þe. fle for al his fare; here. " ffor þorow myn help, & þorow me, " Has þe kyng do þe twyes fle; The Petyt MS. adds,— & þorgh þe dyntes of my honde , defended þe kyng his londe. " ffor by me þe land þou lees, " & for me fledde þy mykel pres. " Þerof now y repente me sore, " Þat y so dide ageyn þe þore; " Þerfore by me þou schalt be brought " To wynne þe lond, als þou had þought; " Now me forþynkes þat y þe noyed, " & þat þe kyng þe so destruyed; of þe destroied. " ffor syn he haþ boren hym in to proud wyse for he has born proude þerfore. " Til his barons, & to alle hyse, to his barons out of score. " And syþen hadde he neuere siþen with me ne had he. wille " In pes me suffre a day be stille; " My lond to waste he goþ wendes. aboute, " My frendes to slo, & dryue þem oute; " My self he wolde wald. exile & chace, " & slo, als hit ys his manace; " My God y take witnesse vnto, " Y serued neuere he scholde so do! " My neuew to deþ he wolde haue wild haf. demed; " ffor y wyþstodit, he haþ for þat encheson am I now. me flemed, " & for y wolde wald. nought do his wylle, " To suffre hym myn neuew spille. " Y schal þe telle how hit bygan " Bytwixt me & Cassibolan: " ffor [þe] þe. honur & for þe pris " Þat we hadde ouer-come þe twys, " Þe kyng dide þe folk somoun " Þorow-out þe lond of ilka toun. From the Petyt MS., lf. 30 which gives a different version of the first part of Androcheus's letter, up to line 4942 here. It follows the Wace MS. du Roi 73, Cangé, to l. 4915, and then the MS. du Roi 27, that De Lincy printed; while Robert of Brunne repeats the account given on page 167, from l. 4753 to l. 4776 above. [" Þat alle of valow, moste & leste, " Suld com to London to his feste, " Grace till our God [to] &yogh;elde " With sacrifise, as lawe wilde. " Graces &yogh;olden with sacrifise, " Whan we had don our seruise, " Diuerse folk in stedes did samen, " & diuersly plaied þei gamen.] The Petyt MS. continues,— My neuow was þer Heulyn , & þe kyng had þer a cosyn: with skirmyng þei bigan to play , & ilk oþer with word missay. þe kynges cosyn manaced fast , & drouh his suerde at him in hast. My neuow saw þat, & on him stirte , held his suerde for doute of hirte: of trewe men þus .I. it herd , bituex þam tuo þus it misferd , þat þorgh a wond þat he lauht þore , vp ne ras he neuer more ; oþer wais no man ne wote whedire he felle, or he him smote. þe kyng of þis apechid me , & comandid on all my fe , ' þat .I. his body to him sent , ' & at his courte take Iugement. ' I. hoped wele he wild him slo ; þe ton suld for þat oþer go ; þerfore .I. douted him to sende , I. said .I. had a courte, .I. wende , & lordeschip, as a man of myght ; com pleyne him þer, & tak his right.
text.81: ¶ De infortunio inter Huwelinum & Irelgas. " Irelgas was þe kynges cosyn; " Huwelyn, he was neuew myn: " Þyse to-gydere wolde skirme algate; " Þorow proude hertes þer wax hate; " Þorow hate þer gon wordes ryse " On boþe partys, on yuel assise. " Whan ilk had seid oþer wow, " Wiþ wraþe to smyte, þe egge drow; " Þorow a meschaunce, y wot hit was, " Huwelyn slow þer Irelgas. " When þe kyng herde þys seye, " Þe feste was trobled, & myrþe a-weye. " ffor þe kyng was ful felon, " & hastif, vntil vengaunce boun, " Þen seid þe kyng vntil me, " Comaundynge, vp peyne of al my fe, " Huwelyn hym for to sende, " Þat ffelonye for to amende, " And in his court have iugement " Þorow þe comunes, ar þat þey went. " Þan þought y wyþ herte ful wo, " &yogh;if y hym sende, he scholde hym slo. " y sende hym ageyn ful tyt, " & of his court asked respit: " ' A lord y am, a court y haue, " ' Þorow þat wold y hym dampne or saue; " ' &yogh;if hit be eyþer baron or knyght " ' Þat pleyneþ hym þere, he shal haue right. " ' Þe court þat þou bedes me to, " ' Hit schold be myn, & schal be so; " ' Þou wost hit is myn heritage; " ' Þou beodes me mys & outrage.' " & for y þus agayn-seide hym, " He ys to me þus wroþ broþe. & brym, " & me manaceþ day by day " To brenne & slo, &yogh;yf þat he may. " Wher-fore, Cesar, y schewe hit þe, " Þat þou my socour ageyn hym be, " & help me in my wo so harde, " And com hyder in god forewarde, " And þorow me schaltow haue þorh me sall þou haf. Brutayne, " & y þorow þe brought out of & .I. for þe be brouht of. payne. " Ne haue þou non suspecioun " Þat y hit seye for any tresoun: " Y wolde nought swylk a þyng bygynne, " Al for. þys reame for to wynne; " Bot com, & make no dwellynge, " & rescowe me a-geyn þe kynge. " ffor þou myshappedest y If þou spede not in. þe first ende, " Now schaltow spede er þat þou wende." ¶ Cesar herde what he bysought, & streitly turnde hit in his þought, & schewed hit his barons aboute, Wheþer þey heldit certeyn or doute. Þer-on þey conseild, þat þer war, Þat atte laste seyde Cesar, " Þat he ne wolde, for sonde ne sawe, " Put hym in peril ne in awe; " Ne for no a. byheste of bost " Wold he so sone sampne sone eft samen. his host; " ffor y haue herd seye fele syþe, " Þat faire byhestes makeþ hotes makes. foles blithe." Cesar sent hym bode ageyn, &yogh;yf he wold hald wild holde. his word certayn, Sende he scholde hym hostagers, Men of gode, barons, pers, Oþer elles wolde he nought com þere Vntil his tyme bettere were. ¶ Androcheus dred hym of treson, Þat þe kyng Cassibolan. wolde bysege þe toun. His sone Senna til Cesar sent, & þritty oþer wyþ hym þey went, Of þe beste þat he might fynde, Next born of his owen kynde. Cesar receiued þem wyþ honur, & dide þem alle in Ordre, did þam Odre. his tour. Syn, als sone as he myghte hye, He dighte his host, & god nauye, & priuely aryued vp at Douer, & logged hem by þe cost al ouer. bi banke & ouere (shore). Androcheus com til Cesar þyder, & conseiled þem boþe to-gyder, How þey schuld wyrke, & on what wyse, Ageyn þe kyng in bataille to rise. Tydynges ronne, þat ouer al Renoun ran þat ouer. reches; Ilk man til oþer made þer to ilk a man mad þei. speches, Til speche. men tolde þe kyng tydant, Þat Romayns were aryue on land. Þe kyng þeron conseilled sone; On hem to renne, mad hym bone; & in herte had gret meruaille Þat þey so so sone broughte hym þei rose so sone eft in. bataille.— He wende of þeym haue hed no warde, Bot hym fel þer a chek ful harde; chek hasarde (far better). — & al so sone as he myght, Toward Douere his host he dight. To Cesar was hit told in hast Þat þe kyng was comande fast: Cesar conseilled conseild. wiþ Androche, Þat he wolde come out he wald out. of þe cite, And turne a sidenhand o turne sidenen in a. valeye, &, all. armed, biden hem in þe weye; & arraied þem in renges & renge þam redy in ordire. ryght, & assigned whiche bataille first schold whilk aschelle suld formast. fight. Whan Cesar had arrayed al set all. his host, O A. þyng he comaunded most: " Þat non scholde, for wele ne wo, " On fro oþer, of renge go; " Ne non prese to styrte ne stirte. byfore, " Ne holde byhynde in coward score; " Bot passe forþ sadlyk, renge þam sadly syde by syde, ' Til þey com þer þey schold vntill þei com þei suld. abide, ' & stoutly hem þanne o þe bretons auaunce, & þan baldely auentour his chance. ' & felle þem doun resceyue him. wiþ swerd & launce.' Androcheus enbusched bussed. hym pryuely Wyþ fif hundred cinq mil, Wace , i. 220, l. 4699. men armed, redy On þe kyng assaut to make, By-twyxt hem &yogh;yf he myghte bituex þam if þei mot. hym take. Cassibolan on his wey gan spede; Of non enbuschement bussement. tok he hede; Þeyr hostes boþe neighed boþe he neihed. &yogh;erne; & whan þey were he was. nought fro þem ferne, Ouer an hil þen lay his weye; & als he com in to þe valeye, He saw þe Romayns fresche y spred in. þe feld, Redy enbatailled wiþ spere renged with helme. & scheld. Als sone mad he hym redy, & loude ascried þem on har & discried þam with a. cry, & sone þey schoten & to schot. arewes & dartz fful felonlyk on boþe partz. Androcheus, atte firste comynge, Of his enbuschement gan he springe; Al freschely he com on hem fresly on him he com. ful hot, & bacward vpon þe Bretons smot: " Ey!" seid þe kyng, "here ys deseit! " Bytwixt þem to þey holde vs streit!" .I. am holden streite. He ne myghte nought perce þe host Romeyn, Ne he ne myghte turne ageyn; Byhynde, biforn, he saw peryl. O side he trauersed vnto a hil, So nede hym byhoued, or be in clos. On boþe sides he saw his foos, He seide hym self þo, he was bitraischt; betraist . . . . . obaist. Þen were þe Bretons alle abaischt.
text.82: ¶ Hic Cassibolanus se retraxit. Ilk þat þer myght Ilkon þer mot. (The next line, after l. 4723, is left out in De Lincy's Wace , i. 224, without notice by the editor.) fle, þey fledde; Þat best myght renne, best he þam. spedde; Bettere was fle, þan worse abide, es fle þan foly bide. ffor socour þer cam on none whan socour comes on no. syde. Vntil a hey hil þey drowe hem to, þei fleih. Bettere wistey nought what for to do; he wist no bettere þat þan deih. & er þey myghte þat heye hil take, Many a croune men myght se crake. Whan þey hadde þe hil al nomen, Þeym þoughte þey were til castel comen; Non of þe nomore. Romayns durst com hem ney, Bot held þem fro þe hil a drey. nehi . . . . . drehi. Þe hil was strong round. busked aboute, Þat þe Bretons of Cesar hadde no had of no man. doute; ffor eche man tok a tre to stal, As tristi as trostere þan. a castel wal. Cesa[r] byheld to þe hilles of þe hill þe. heyght, Þat wyþ non assaut ne wyþ no sleight Mighte he wynne þat forcelet; Þerfore a sege abute hit set, Þat þey ne myghte no-wer noure. aboute, Bot þorow hym, haue issue þorh þam all passe. oute. He dide sette in wardes stedes. seers, Knyghte to wachem, waite. & squiers; & also he dide hewe trees, Þe styes to stoppe, & þe entres, & furgat nought ful lyghtly How þey had chased hym wyþ maistri; & ofte þey telde in þer auys vys. How þey bifore had chased hem twys: " Now schal y &yogh;elde hit, &yogh;if þat y may, " Er &yogh;e departe fro me away!" Alas, hit schold euer so suld so gate. bytyde, So bolde Bretons myght non abide! ffor þey had chased twyes þat man Þat al þe werld þorow bataille wan; & &yogh;it þey stode stifly, ilkon, Whan þey wiste socur of of socour. non, &yogh;it suffrede þei nought for to be nome Of hym þat þey had er ouercome; But Dame ffortune had turned her whel Donward til wo, þat er was wel; ffor þo þat abouen were wond vp were wont. to be, Donward þeym now turneþ sche.
text.83: ¶ Qualiter Brutones iam deuicti sunt per famem. Þyse Bretons þat were in-clos & byseged wiþ her fos, Had þey neyþer drynke ne mete, Ne non myght hem purchace ne gete. Þey dredde no saut sauht. of bataille; Bot what may þat help or a-vaille, When of mete ys defaut? Honger wynnes hit atte firste saut. Þer ys no castel so strong idight, It is . . . . . stalworth dight. Þat honger ne wynneþ wyþouten fight; Wyþouten wepen or armour, Honger &yogh;eldeþ castel & tour. God castel dredes no power, Emperour, kyng, ne kayser, Ne oþer help me haue men haf. at nede; Bot of honger ys al þe drede. Þer force haþ mad manye assayes, has mad of assais. Honger hit wynnes byn fewe in fo. dayes. Þre dayes þey were in þat turment, Þat honger had þeym ner al schent.
text.84: ¶ Rex misit Androchio pro Misericordia & Auxilio. Cassibolan had sorewe in wold, How he mighte ascape þat hold: On alle halue he saw Romayns Redy for to do þeym payns; He hadde no force wyþ hem to fyght, & honger hadde ouer nere (ses homes mate, Wace , i. 224, l. 4789). reft þer myght; Mykel he dredde Iulius Cesar, & more þe honger þat þey had þar. He moste chese on of tweye: of þe tuo þan had he weie. &yogh;elde hym to Cesar, or for honger deye. Two dayes & two nyghtes til ende Wold he noman biseke ne sende; ¶ Þe þrydde, he þoughte how best myght be, & sende his sonde til Androche:— I ne wot ho dide þe message, Wheþer knyght, squier, or page:— " Androcheus, y sende þe him. to seye, " Suffre me nought he suffire me not. schamely to deye. " Þaw y mystok me .I. haf not serued it. greuously, " I prey þe of me haue þou bot .I. pray him of. mercy. " Þaw i dide an hastynesse, þof .I. did him a hastifesse. " Y schal hit amende, as if. his wylle esse. " A man schold nought his owen kynde " Dampne for o defaute, we fynde; " ffor hit haþ ofte be wyst & sen, " Þat wraþe bytwyxte kynde haþ ben; " Bot whan þer [wraþe] wraþ. was brought til ende, " Syn han þey ben ful feyþful frende. has bene full hende. " I preie þe now, &yogh;if þy say him if his. wille be, " Þat þou he. be now curteys to me; " Y biseke þe, bid him. þenk on no mysdede, " Bot schew me þy schew now. kyndenesse in þys nede, " & saue me now byfore Cesar, " & euere more eft wol y be war. " To þe may neuere falle honur " &yogh;yf me bytide a misauentur."
text.85: ¶ Responcio e contrario. Androcheus herde þe kynges pleint, Þat ner was recreaunt & teynt; & answered hym al at reburs: robours. " Haþ now þe kyng nede of my socurs? " What, haþ my lord herd ought or seen? " Seue nyght &yogh;it ne haþ hit ben, " Þat he wolde me exile, & reue " Al my lond, & no þyng leue, " & þerto þrette me to slo, " Whare he haue now laten þat mod ouer go. " My lord þat bar hym so ouer are so. stout, " ffor no preiere to loue wolde lout, " I wiste hit wolde nought it suld not. falle hym wel, " Þat was so fers, & þat he bare him. ouer cruel. " Wyþouten skil were we wroþe, " & þat schal now repente vs boþe; " Bot alder meste skaþe wil falle " On hym seluen self. for vs alle; " Hit falleþ no kyng to it fals no kyng do. felon res, " As lyon in þe tyme of pees, " Ne in tyme of werre for to dare, " Ne ne omitted. to fle for drede, as doþ þe hare. " Þat he fled, sire, nought so, fled .I. say not so. " Bot his cruelte wil hym fordo; " He auaunted hym til vs auanced him till his. ilkone, " He venquised þe enperour alone; " Bot he alone neuere hym ne wan, " Namore þan dide an oþer man; " Bot þorow me & þorow my knyghtes " Þat wounded were in many fightes, " And oþer þat were al so doughty, " & wel bettere þan he oþer y, " Þorow þeir dede & oure trauaille " Wan Cassibolan þe bataille. " ffor swylk he made his noble fest, " & seid hit was his owen conquest.
