" His barons þat were his peres, " Of his conqueste were parceners; " ffor he þat stande wel in stour, " He aughte haue part awe haf partie. of þe honur. " Þe kyng may wel hym seluen wyte, " By hym alone schal hit nought byte; wite. " Þo þat halpe hym hit for to wynne, " Wel oughte þey be parceners partinere. þer-ynne.
text.86: ¶ De gratitudine Androchii. " Bot wel am y now venged on hym; " Þat now ys meke, þat er was grym. " Now, siþen þat he bisekeþ sekes. me " On hym to haue mercy & pite; " & y schal certes, &yogh;if y may spede, " Help hym now in his gret nede. " I may nought elles for no þyng; " He ys myn eem, my lord, my kyng/; " I ne may nought faille hym, ne y ne wil! " Syn he hym mekeþ, y wol He mekes him .I. will. do skil: " I am venged on hym y-now; " Now wol y fonde to don his prow."
text.87: ¶ Dixit Androcheus Cesary pro pace Cassibolani. Androcheus, wys knyght & war, Anon on one. he &yogh;ede vntil Cesar, And on knes byfore hym MS. injured. P., him sette. sette. Iulyus Cesar ful faire he grette: " Sire Iulius, þou art a myghti man, " Conquered þou hast Cassibolan! " Vnto þy mercy wol he now come, " & &yogh;elde his truage vntil Rome; " Tak of hym now þat truage, " Of þe to holde his heritage; " Wiþ loue let hym now come to þe. " Þou askes nought elles of al his fe, " Bot onlike of þe to holde; " He hit graunteþ, & y hit wolde. " Iulius, haue of hym mercy! " Þy wille to do we ar redy." Bot Iulius Cesar wold hym nought here; fful deflike herde he defly he herde. his preyere, & passed forþ as he nought herde; Til Androche nought he answerde. Androcheus had þer-of disdeyn, Þat Cesar tok his preyer in veyn; He stirt vp wiþ yuel wylle, & bad Cesar stonde a whyle abide Cesar & stand right. stille: " Þis londe ys &yogh;olden to þy baillye; " Þorow me hastow þe seignurie; " Þat y þe hight, y holde couenaunt, " & more getes þou nought of graunt. " Þe seignurye of al þenpyre, " Þat may þou haue, as lorde & sire; " Þat þow hast; what wiltow more? " Nolde God god will not. þat oþer weys wore, " Þat þou myn eem schost prisone or slo! " Nay, Cesar, so schal hit nought go, " Þat he schol He sall not. be so lyghtly slayn, " While þat y haue till .I. haf. þat myght & mayn " Þat hym for deþ fro dede. y may rescuwe! " He is myn eem, & y his neuewe; " He noriced me, he ys me dere! " &yogh;if þou ne wilt my biddyng If þou ne will my praiere. here, " Y parte fro þe, & haue god day: " Do now til do þan to. hym al þat þou may!" Þen cam Cesar forþ, & stod, Þoughte he was of kynde blod, & þat he seide, hit was skyl, & he dide his wit þer-til. Whan he hadde al cast & þought, He graunted al þat he had sought; bisouht. Hostages asked þe partys, & þey wer graunted at here auis, And truage þey graunted so, As þe lond was taxed to: Þre þousand pound ylka &yogh;er, At termes so sette. to paye plener; Of alle þe lond gadered & tan. Þen brought þey forþ Cassibolan, & diden Cesar & hym kysse: ffor þat acord was mykel blisse. Byfore þis tyme, neuere y ne fond Þat any man conquered þis lond. ¶ Þenne returned Cesar wiþ hye To Romeward after his victorie. Bot &yogh;e schul here a wonder þyng This ' wonder þyng ' in Roman history—an expansion at will of two lines in Geoffrey of Monmouth, lib. iv. § 10, p. 67, ed. Giles—is neither in Wace (i. 230, ed. De Lincy) nor our Petyt MS., though this last (almost like Wace) substitutes for it and lines 5279-80 above, the following lines,— till Cesar com & mad conqueste as &yogh;e haf herd in þis geste. euen sexty &yogh;ere þis was beforn þat Ihesu Criste was born: here with all acordes saynt bede; þe gestes of Ingland first &yogh;e rede. Whan all þis was brouht till ende , & fele went to se þer frende , The next four lines are not in De Lincy's MS. du Roi 27, but are in the Arsenal MS. 171, B.-L.; and the Ste. Genev. MS. Y., leaf 10. Wace , i. 230. þus say þei þat know þe estre , þat Iulius funded first Excestre. Excestre it hate, þis skill is whi , þe water hate ex þat rennes þerbi. till wynter were gon, Cesar gan bide , & went home in þe somers tide. for grete luf & specialle he toke with him sir Androche , & led with þam men of ostages , of þis lond þe best lynages. [for the continuation, see note to line 5334]. Þat fel in Rome after his wendynge: He had þer mad chef of þe cite Sire Crassus & sire Pompee; When þey had so al þe maistry þer, & he nought returned þe fyfte &yogh;er, Þey racoillede þe Romayns til her wylle, Ageyn Cesar. þat fel hem ylle; ffor Iulius destruyde Rome þan, & slow þer lord & gentilman; & Crassus he slow in a tour hey, Bot Pompeus skaped, & faste fley. fforþ in to Poylle he chased hym wel; Þer he byseged hym in a castel,— Braundys hit highte, as men tolde;— Bot þat myghte he nought longe holde, Bot in-to Egipte þen schiped he, ffor wel wend he þer siker haue be. Bot Cesar hym suwed yn-to þat contre, & spak to þe kyng, sire Tholome. Wiþ him was sire Pompe y-take; Bot for drede of Iulius sake He nolde meyntene hym namore, Bot his hed dide smyte of þore, & sentyt Iulius til present; & þer-wyþ he to Romward went In al his moste nobleye. in Rome Right yuele þey schope for hym ful sone: His barons wiþ treson dide hym deye, Bot Greffes hym mordred for enuye. Twey neuews he hadde, bot sone non, Þe eldest was cald Octouyon; Þe Romayns corouned hym saunz faille; Þen sesed he Braundys & Itaill, Of Poylle & Grece he tok þauow, & of alle þe reomes by-&yogh;onde Moungow. And al þe Oryent, þat oþer sesed, & tok tys part þat þe oþer leued; Of þritty reomes euery kynge Were enclinaunt til his coronyng. Such wraþe bytwixte þe neuews ros sone, Þat wiþ batailles to feld þey come. Octouion þat oþer slow anon, & his men desconfyted echon. Þen hadde Rome suche renoun Þat al þyng was in here baundon; Þen gaf þey til þe enperrour A newe name for gret honour, 'Augustus Cesar' þe calde hym þere, ffor þei ouer alle oþere were; & after þat he þat name had, Þe Romayns were þe more y-drad, ffor þemperour had þen vnder hand Al þe werld, boþe se & land. For the next 20 lines (5335-5354) the Petyt MS. follows Wace, and has this passage: [ Seuen &yogh;ere lyued Cassibalan siþen Cesar þis lond wan. to &yogh;elde þe treuage he was full mylde, ne he had noþer wife no childe. In &yogh;orke, far soth, he did his end|yng, & biried [ was ] þer as a kyng. Comes Cornubie factus est rex. Tenuacius was erle of Cornwaile , had þe regne all in his waile: he was Androcheus broþer; Androche was went , þer was non oþer; bot he regned full litell space; he died sone, king Tenuace. Kimbelinus cepit regnare. After sir Tenuace fyne , þei crouned his sone Kymbelyn. he was norissed at þe courte of Rome , he was gode knyght, wiseman in dome. At Rome, till Kymbelyn was þare , he mad him knygh[t], Augustus Cesar. ten &yogh;ere he reyned kyng , & in þat &yogh;ere he mad endyng. ] Ihesus Christus natus est. Ihesus Criste þat &yogh;ere was born , so had a prophete tald beforn. Bot Cassibolan was ful ioyous Þat þis werre was ended þus. ffyftene [&yogh;er] after he regned in pes, Bot no child ne lefte at his deses; Þerfore þe corounede sire Tenmace; To gouerne þe reome he hadde grace. Cassibolan was ded, as was pite, & buryed at &yogh;ork, þe gode cite. Wiþ Iulyus went forþ sire Androche, & his broþer reioisede þe regalte. After cam Kymbely, Tenmace sone, Þat had ful gret grace of Rome; Of alle his truage þey relesed hym þer, While he scholde regne & lyuen her, So þat he neuere ne payed non Wace and Geoffrey say that Kimbalius did pay it. To Rome ne to Octouyon. He meyntend euere his lond in pes, & leftyt his sones after his deces.
text.88: De natiuitate Christi. In his tyme was here þis lond þan was. (This Ta|liessin invention is not Geoffrey of Monmouth's. It is not in De Lincy's MS. du Roi 27, but is in the 'MSS. du Roi, 73, Cangé; de l'Ars. '171, B.-L.; de Ste. Genev. Y., fol. '10.' Wace , i. 232). a deuin, His name was called Telesyn; He telde þe Bretons many selcouþ, (Al fond þey trewe he seide wyþ mouþ;) He bad þem "lyue leue. wyþouten errour, " ffor now ys born our saueour! " Now ys vs toward ioye & blys, " Þat of a mayde þis Of a maiden a. child born ys! " Al mankynde schal he saue! " Ihesus, þat name schal he haue." Þis word þat þilk prophete seyde, Þe Bretons in herte ful wel hit leyde; Many a day þat word þey held; þey fondyt soþ al þat he teld. Þer was no folk in al þe werd Þat trowed so sone, when þey ought herd Prechen ought of Iesu lawe, Ne to þe feyþ so sone gon wild. drawe. Þen was þer a þowsand &yogh;er gon Þat Brutes aryued in Albyon, & þerto two hundred &yogh;er & tuo hundreth sais it. mo Er Kymbelyn to deþ gan go. As longe as he regned her, Wyþ þe Romayns was he dere; Þey asked hym neuere no þer. truage, Neyþer in his &yogh;ougþe ne in age. neuerþeles at terme & stage. He &yogh;alde it curtasly & hende. in pes till his lyues ende.
text.89: ¶ Christus natus est in tempore Kymbelyny. Of Kymbelyn to tuo. childre left, Þat þe Romayns þer truage reft. Wyder, hight þe eldeste broþer; Arwygar, men calde þat oþer. Sire Wyder hadde þe heritage. A man he was of gret corage, a douhty knyght in vassalage. Proud he was, & ouer stout; Þe Romayns nolde he loue romeyns ne wild he luf. ne lout, Bot whare so euere he hem fond, He dide hem sone alle. voyde þe lond. Claudeus was þan emperour, Of Rome maister gouernour: Scorn hym þought, & swor his heued son cief jura, Wace , l. 5013. Þer truage schold suld. nought so be leued; He scholde suld. haue hit a-geyn ful wel, Deserite Wyder of ylka del. Of Romayns he gadered an host, & hyed fast til Bretaigne suyth vnto þis. cost. Hauene he tok at Porcestre— ' Kaer Perys' karepers. hight þan þat estre,— He wende haue taken þe toun in hast, Bot he failled of his [t]ast. tast (attempt). Þan tened Claudius [w]iþal, Lamb. MS. perished. P. has with all. Byfore þe &yogh;ate dide make a wal, Þat no vitaille schuld come til toun: To enfamyn hem famen þam. was þencheson. Bot Wyder & Arwygarus Wyþ twenty ten. þousand mad hem rescus. Sire Claudius & his partie ffledde faste to þer nauye; Þe beste Romayns in batailles seer Stoden somme ageyn Wyder, & foughte wyþ hym longe stounde; Of boþe side ley ded on grounde. ¶ A Romayn þer was, a noble baroun, His name þey calde sire Hamoun, He was þemperores conseillour, A noble knyght he was in stour; He houed, & byheld sire Wyders, How he bar hym stout & fers, Romayns to felle, Romayns to slo,— Vnneþe ascaped hym any mot any ascape him. fro,— How wysly his folk he ledde, & how in batailles to bataile. he þem spredde, Wyþouten los slow þe tinsell [loss] slouh. Romayns, & syn relied his men eft alied þam wele. agayns. He saw wel—weel he mought till he mot lyue. hit leue,— Þat oþer truage wold he no geue, 6 Ne þe Romayns schuldit neuere wynne Whyle Wyder rengned kyng þer-ynne; 6 6_6 Lines 5449-50 omitted in P. He þoughte þorow He þouh. what manere þyng He myght best slo Wyder þe kyng/. Þat ylke noble Hamon Romayn, Dispoilled a Breton þat he fond spoiled a Breton þat was. slayn; Wyþ þe armes of þat Brutoun He armed hym seluen Hamoun, & went þen o þe Bretons syde: Als þey rod, so gan he ryde. P. adds here,— & þer langage to þam he spak. toward þe kyng þe bataile brak. [Þe] MS. perished. P., þe. armes deseyued hem ylkadel, & of þer langage he spak ful wel,— He had lered at our He lerid it at þer. hostagers Þat were at Rome truagers.— He calde þe Breton by þer name, & þey answered agayn þe same, P. transposes these lines. Til he cam to þe kyng Wyder, P. transposes these lines. Alwey he neyghed hym ner & ner; Þys Hamon rod ay side by side, & þidere he sawe þe kyng ride. þus Hamon rode ay side bi side. To sle þe kyng his tyme tabide. Þe kyng til hym gaf no tent; Þat saw Hamoun, a knyf out hent, Vnder þarmure þe kyng he styked, Priuely fro þem alle he pryked.
text.90: ¶ De sapiencia & prudencia Arwygary. ¶ Arwygarus, his owen broþer, Parseyued þat er any oþer, & þoughte hit were gret folye Þere to grede or for to crie. He tok þe kynges conisaunce, ffor non scholde perseyue MS. perseyme. þat chaunce, An bad his priues primes. euer-ylkon, " Nought so hardy make no mon; to mak mone. " ffor wyst our folk we were þus trayscht, " Hit scholde make þem alle abayscht; traist . . . . . obaist. " Wyste þe Romayns þys chaunce wore, " Hit scholde enforce hem wel þe suld aforce þam wele. more. " &yogh;yf we were bold, now be we baldere, &yogh;e were bolde bes now boldere. " & y schal vndertake sall maynten forþe. þys were." He was wel armed, & on his stede Toward þe to gyf. bataille he gan hym spede. Waster was þer. non þat wolde hym feyne Whan þey sey þe kynges seigne. sawe þe kynge seyne. So wel he bar hym, & so auster, Þey wende hit were kyng Wyder. Þan myghte men se knyghtes stoute, Þat perced þorow þe Romayns Route; Þe Romayns ne moughte to-gedere holde, So were þe bretons egre & bolde; Syre Claudius wyþ his partie To þe water fledde wyþ his meynye; to þer nauie. Þat myghte nought to þe water fle, Vntil a wode þen fledde he. wod fledden he. Hamoun, þat þe host al ledde, To þer schypes faste he fledde; He spirde after þer enperour, Whider-ward he made his retour; Men ynowe til hym gon seye, Þat to þe water he tok hys weye. Þe kynges broþer Arwygare, Whider how. Hamon fledde, he was wel war. Atte water Hamon doun lyght, Intil a bot Hamon had him. tyght; Byforn cam Arwygar atte bot; Sire Hamones hed þer of he smot. ffor Hamon lefte þere his heued, Þe name of hym þer ys bileued; is leued. & for þencheson of þulke þat. Hamoun, ffor hym þe calde þe toun HAMPTOUN: ffor swylke chaunces þat han bytid, for chances þat haf ben tid. Ar names of tounes cald & kyd. Whan he was fled, þenperour, & Hamon slayn atte retour, & alle wer dryuen to þat cost, Þe kyng to Wynchestre lad his host. When Arwygar till Arwigarus. þiderward nam, Claudius ef[t] eft. to londe cam, & com a-geyn to Porchestre, & brak þe walles, & brente þe estre: Al he brente, vp & doun, & chaced men exilde þe men. out of þe toun. Byforen hit was a god noble. cite; Syn cam hit neuere to þat bounte. When he had destruyed þus Porchestre, Syþen þan. he wente to Wynchestre; Þer-inne he seged Arwygare, & alle þat euere wyþ hym ware. Gode engyns dide he make, Þe walles to breke, houses to schake. Arwygar heldyt a vylte, So seged in a toun to be, & seide 'he wolde nought þrynne lye, ' To wham-euere happede who so fell to wyn. þe maistrie; ' Eyþer wold ouþer wild. he wynne or lese los, ' Er he scholde more be halde inclos.' suld more be holden clos. He went out in-to þe feld, & alle his knyghtes wyþ spere helm. & scheld; He batailled hem vnto þe fight, Wyþ archers gode, wel adight; Þe mene folk alle y fere Were wysly set in god wele sette on gode. manere. Bytwyxte þe partys was þer bot lyte Þat þey ne scholde to-gedere smyte.
text.91: ¶ De consilio Sapientum Ciuitatis. Þe wyseste men of þat cite Conseilled hem how best if better. myght be. Mykel þey dredde þer god to tyne, & slaughtre of þe folk, þe &. pyne; Þey saide, "þe pes were better to haue, " Our toun & oure godes to saue, " þen for to lyue in werre & stryf, " & lese oure godes, & tyne our lyf." Þey toke a man of honour, & sent hym to þe Emperour, To wite at hym wheþer þat he ches To haue þe werre oþer þe pees. Þenperour seide, als he þought, " Werre to haue wylny wild .I. nought, " Ne y ne &yogh;erne nought of &yogh;oure, " Bot þat Rome haue his honoure; " 2 Ne y ne wilne wyþ no man fight, " So þat Rome mot haue his right." 2 2-2 P. omits these lines. Þey graunted alle at his auis, And sworen þe pees in boþe partys.
text.92: ¶ Concordati sunt Inperator & Rex. Þe Emperour honured mykel þe kyng, & profred hym a ful fair þynge: " Sire kyng," he seide, "a doughter y haue, " & on þe y vouche hure saue " &yogh;yf þou wilt myn owen will myn ow. bycome, " & &yogh;eld þy & &yogh;elde. truage vntil Rome." Arwygar graunted þer-to, & to þe true to treuage. &yogh;eldyng al-so. In Wynchestre were þey hosteld were ostiled. boþe, & frendes, þat er weren wroþe. Þemperour to Rome sent ffor Genwys, þat maiden gent. In dwellyng of þis messagers, Þey sampned knygtes & squyers; Wyþ gret host þey wente þer weye, & wonne þe ilde of wan to Rome all. Orkeneye, & oþer ildes þat þer ware, Wyþ help of him was. sire Arwygare. Þis Claudyus regned y þat tyme— As seint Bede seys in his ryme— Syn Ihesu was born of oure leuedy, Þer fel &yogh;eres þer fele &yogh;ers. sixe & fourty. Þis messegers þat went to Rome, Y þe somer a-geyn in þe somores tide. þey come, & broughte þat maiden Genwys, Gentyl of body & fair of vis. Þen cam hom þemperour; þat tyme com þe emperour home. Þan mad þey myrthe in halle & bour. mirth þei mad at þer tocome. To wedde þat may in place auenaunt, Þe couenaunt to holde, siker þey & sikere. graunt, Vpon Seuerne, in o vale Þat riche was & ful ese, asasée (ensemencé, fertilisé), Wace , l. 5191. Bytwyxten Ingelond & Wales,— To telle &yogh;ow þe soþe for to mene of þo. tales— Þat for þe worschip of þat may, A toun þey sette þer þat day. P. inserts here ,— Gloucestre first hight it þus. for þe emperour sir Claudius. Þys Emperour gat þer a sone; Of þat child þe name we mone; Gloy he hight y hight born in. (Wace gives a prior alternative: because Claudius built Gloucester.) þat estre; ¶ And for þat Gloy, hat hit GLOUCESTRE Arwygar wedded þer Genwys, In Gloucestre, wyþ mykel pris; Þer was he corouned, & sche, Noblely wiþ solempnete; & when þe feste was brought til ende, Claudius to Rome ageyn gan wende.
text.93: ¶ De aduentu Sancti Petry Apostoly. I fynde writen, &yogh;ow to teche, Þat in Nero tyme seint Peter gan þat tyme &yogh;ede saynt Petir to. (A cel terme, Wace , l. 5214.) preche. ffro Antyoche þat tyme he cam, Þorow prechyng brought hit to Cristendam, And was comen right in to late to. Rome, And preched þere of Cristes dome. ¶ Whan gon was sire Claudyus, In Bretayne regned Arwygarus; Of hym self he let right mykel, Bot proud he was, & a party a partie. fykel; Þe true treuage. to Rome gyue he nolde, ffor he dedeyned he deyned not. of hem to holde; Þe Romayns þoughte an outrage So for to lese þer truage; ¶ Þey senten hyder after. VASPASYAN, Maister of Rome was he þan. At Douere wolde he vp a-ryue; Þe kyng hit herde, & þyder gan dryue,— As hit ys founden in þe Latyn sais .I. wene. Ebru, Douere þen highte Reptupu, Ritipu. — Þer fended he defended. Vaspasian þe lond. Þer sailles ageyn on mast þey wond, & seyled by þe landes syde Tyl Toteneys, þer gon þey ride. ffor þy now hit dide hem fond þei non þat did þam. (Ne trova qui li desfandist, Wace , i. 243, l. 5239. qued Þat þey hem so þat þam þe. lond furbed. Til Oxenford Essecestre, Wace , l. 5240; Exe|ter, Geoffrey , iv. 16. þey gon alle ride, To take þe toun y þe euentyde: 'Karphuelgoit' vpon Karpenhuelgoit opon. (In Geoffrey, not Wace). Bretoun, On Englische, 'Oxenford' þe toun. Þe toun of þeym hadde no doute, Seuenyght þe seged hit wyþoute. Þe kyng, als sone as he myght, Oste gadred, & þider hym dight; Raþer ne myghte sonere ne mot he. þider wende; Bote atte seue nyghtes at þe seuen daies. ende, He com in a morwe tyde. Sone þey assembled on boþe & smyte togidere on ilk. syde, ffro morn til euen bataille þey nomen, Þat neyþer side was ouercomen; At euen þey &yogh;eden alle asonder; Al were þey wery, hit was no wonder. On þe morn, þo þat were lefte, Þey armed hem to bataille efte.
text.94: ¶ Concordati sunt per Reginam. Bot þe quene, dame Genwys, Sche scho. acorded boþe partys; Scheo scho. peyned hure acord to make, ffor loue of þe Romayns sake; Algate scheo peyned hure so, Til þat. acord sche scho. brought þem to. Al þe wynter scheo scho. dide þem byde, Til hit was toward þe. somertyde; Þe pes was take, þe pes þe granted. þe partys swore, Bot Vaspasian swor first byfore. & Vespasian to Rome fore. (Puis est à Rome repairiés, Wace , l. 5266.) Þe kyng, fro þat ylke day, Al his lyue &yogh;ald Rome þer pay; P. leaves out the next four lines. Their subject is in Wace and Geoffrey. Hys oþ ne let he neuere falle, Bot ay worschiped Romayns alle, And wyþ help of Vaspasian Al Irlonde he wan; Geoffrey implies this: iv. 16. Þe folk, þe lond, he couþe wel loke; At Colchestre he lis, gode kyng he was. we fynde in boke. A bok, men calleþ hit Iuuenal, Geoffrey of Monmouth (iv. xvi.) notices Juvenal's mention of the famed Arviragus, Sat. iv. 26. Of stories hit spekeþ al, At Gloucestre, þer hit lys, it sais he lies. And þe quene, dam Genwys. Marius his sone, of Genewys born, Was kyng as his fader byforn. A myghtful wilfull. man was Maryus, Of fair speche merueillous; Marius Rex. His ffader tyme he was atte Rome Wiþ þe kynde his moder of come. Wel he contened hym in his londe, Þer blessed hym boþ fre & bonde. þe folk serued him at hand. In Maryus tyme fel þis ferlyk: In Scotlond aryued vpryued. a Peyt, Rodryk. King Peyt cam out of þe se, fre Cice. (Sice, Wace , l. 5286; Scythia, Geoffrey. ) Þat neuere had mercy ne pite; a man he was full of malice. Mykel he loued to robbe & reue, Scotland to waste wold he nought leue. Als he wente &yogh;ed. & robbede faste, Maryus mette hym atte laste; Marius had god folk ynow, & Peyt Rodryk smertly he slow. ffor þat Maryus slow þe Peyht, He dide þer set a ston þorow sleight, ffor to schewe his prowesse, & forto make þe menyng fresse; ffor in þe ston he dide be wryte, Whar-þorow euery & for þat writyng. man may wyte; Hit wytnesseþ þe & testemons þat. auenture, & telles þe disconfiture, How Marius slow þe Peyt Rodrik; Þe ston was set for þat ferlyk: Þo men þat weren, & &yogh;it þat þer woned &. are, Þey calle þat ston &yogh;it 'Westmare;' Þat contre folk seyen þe men of þat cuntre say. ilkon Þat te countre þat it. is cald after þe ston; ¶ ffor þe ston Westmare, WESTMORLAND; Þus in þe Latyn Geoffrey of Monmouth, book iv. chap. xvii. writen y fand. When þat Rodrik þe Peiht was ded, Men gaf þe kyng Marius to red, ' To take þe Peihtes more & lesse, ' Deliuere hem a party of Catenesse ' To tyle & haue in heritage, ' ffor hit was bot wast & sauage.' Þey herborwed þe herberd. þem þer euery where, In stedes ese, þat best were. Wymen of Bretayne wolde þey haue, Bot þe Bretons vouched nought non. saue; Þey dide hem in til Irland, & tok þer wyues at her at þer. hand; Of two of þo tu. kyndes, Iris & Peiht, Sorewe & tene hit broughte ire & tene es wele. on height. Marius þe kyng, in his lyf her, Lyuede nyne & fourty &yogh;er; régna longement, Wace , i. 247, l. 5322. Buried he was in Salesbury, Þat standes on a playne ful mury. After Marius þan lyuede longe, Coyl Rex. Coyl his sone þat land gan fonge; He was norysed y þe toun courte. of Rome; In of. alle lawes he gaf right dome; Þey of Rome louede hym wel, ffor þey hym founde as trewe as stel. Coyl couþe of many queintise, And manie artes of seer on sere. wyse; He was neuere nygon ne nyce, Ne neuere vsed yuel vice; non ill vyce. Ten &yogh;er he regned her al fully; wele & riche. At Norwiche byried ful worþyly. he ligges biried at Norwiche.
text.95: Lucius primus Rex Christianus. After þis gode kyng Coylus, Regned his sone sire Lucius; He was large & curteys, And firste Cristen kynge, men seis. Al þis land so fair and fre, re Lucius Bretannie. Þorow hym was brought to Cristiente. Whan he herde þe lawe of Crist, How in his name [men] in his men. were baptist, Of his miracles men spake ryf, & of þapostles holy lyf, & als how God for þeym wrought Þat to Cristendam wer brought, He sent þe Pope Eluthere, Papa Euleutherius. ( In a later hand. ) Bysoughte hym as his fader dere To sende hym a man myght hym baptyze, Of Cristes lawe lere hym þe wyse. When þe Pope herde þat tydynge, He þanked Iesu, heuene kynge, Þat in his tyme he wolde so wyrche, Brytaigne to brynge to holy chirche. Two clerkes he sente hider to preche— Bisschopes þe were, þe lawe to teche,— Þat o þe to. clerk highte sire Duman, Þat oþer men calde Bisschop ffagan, Matan, MS. du Roi 27; Fagan, MS. du Roi 7515 3.3. Colb.; Wace , i. 248. l. 5349. Faganus, Geoffrey. Þyse to bisschopes baptized þe kynge & alle his men meigne. at her comynge. Þorow þe kyng & his kyng had. grauntise Þey ordeyned þe lawe in as þe lawe is &. right assise; Þei ordeigned ilka MS. illa. bischop þer se, Ordeyned þei Archbisshop see. (Lamb. MS. follows Wace.) & Erchebischopes abouen hem to be. & bisshopes vndere þam to be. In hys tyme þis lond. were temples olde, The eight and twenty flamens are in Geoffrey (chap. xix.) but not the next line. Eyght & twenty flamins grete. men tolde,— Þe Latyn calleþ sais þe. temple 'flamins,'— Somme of Mahoun, & somme of Appoll[i]ns, Somme of Dyane, somme & of Berit.— Two Geoffrey makes three: the third at the City of Legions, chap. xix. arche flaminus were þey þer. &yogh;it; At Londone was þer chef flamee, þe archeflame. & at &yogh;ork þat oþer se; Þe oþere flamins in londe ware Als þe bischopes sees now are. Þyse temples of Maumetries Þey turned alle fro þer eresyes, & halewode þem halowed þam. to Cristes werk, & ordeyned kirkes, prest, with preste. & clerk, Landes, rentes, lyght & catel, Þat to þo temples langed or longed &. fel, & al oþer aportynaunce, He gaf hit to þer sustenaunce: To a dyocise langed a cite, & ordened paroschens parisches. (parosces, Wace , l. 5365.) for to be. To parsones & to vicaries Was graunted grete seignuryes. When Bretayne was Cristen al, & þe newe lawe was brought to stal, Ioyful was sire Lucyus, Þat sey þe folk al turne sawe þe folk turned. þus. In Cristene lawe, als he hym ches, Þer-inne he ended in god godes. pes; At Gloucestre he deide, & þer [he] lys, London he died & þer he lies. & his soule wente to Paradis. Þe date of Crist, men seid þo told so. her, Was an hundred & fyue sex. (sis, Wace , l. 5387.) & fifty &yogh;er. Wyþouten heyr Lucyus ys ded. Þen couþe þe Bretons þer-of no red: Wo was hem he hadde non heyr! To haue a lord þey were in speyr; to be þer lord had þei no speire. [þe were bigan omang þam alle, to whom þe seignorie suld falle.] From the Petyt MS. ffro lond to. la[n]d, fro man to man, ¶ Of þat to Rome tydynge ran, Þat ded was sire Lucyus, & þat we werreyed amonge vs. MS. he werreyed ageyns. P. reads, we wered amang. Þey chose Sauer, a senatour,:emperour: & made hym maister & gouernour; Sauerus Inperator. He broughte hider two Legions. Þe Bretons to þeym were felons; Sauer werreyed on þem faste, Manye he conquered & caste, & ffele oþere hadde disdeyn ffor to halde of any Romayn; Vmwhile þey faught, vmwhile fleand; Sauer þey[m] Seuere þam. chaced to Scotland. Þen chose þe Bretons þeym a kynge: ffulgencius Rex. ¶ ffulgence he highte, a gret lordyng; He felawed hym & folowed þam. wyþ þe Peytes, As Pis se sont acompagnié, Si se sunt ensamble aloié. Wace , i. 251, l. 5412-13. Þat euere were ful of deseites; lefe to fehtes. Outlandeis þat were ffledde, Alle swilk wyþ þeym þey ledde; In a conrtre þey dide cuntre men did. gret schame; Dene Deire. was þenne þer-of þe name. ffro Scotland in to Þurlewal, vnt Thrilwall. Peytes landes þey telde hit al. Peihtlond þei told it all. ffulgence southewarde hym hasted, Þe lond al aboute was wasted; Sauer fledde southeward ageyn; Þe Peites robbed & made al pleyn. ffulgence wyþ Peytes on hem þey whan Seuere had folk on þam eft. ran, Bot þe Peyte fledde ilk a man;— Som tyme wolde þey bataille abide, & som tyme fledde on ilka syde; Bot ofte dide þey Sauer tene, ffulgence wiþ þe Peytes kene. Longe dured þat reuery, robberie. Þat Sauer mought neuere come þem by, Til he dide make an ouerthwert dik, Bitwyxte to sees a ful gret strik; & þer-on a pale wel y-poynt, palis with poynt (palis, Wace ). Þykke & hey, ful wel y-ioynt, & closed þat side of þe lond; Ouerthwert, Est & West hit bond. Syn þat tyme hit was in-clos, Neuere non of alle his foos Durste non of þeym ferþer fele, Ne by þat side robbe ne stele. ffulgence tok conseil at wyse, & of Peytes at þe Peihtes. & oþere of hyse, To werre &yogh;it more vpon Sauer, & hym to chace fer & ner. & robbe & reue hym full nere. Til Peytes he gaf gyftes grete, & preied hem þey scholde nought þam þei wild not. lete To gadere bot gadred. a god compaygnie Toward on. þe se in his nauie. When þey hadde gadered þer host, & schipes by þe se in his schippes bi þe sees cost, Þe host was schiped, & went to se, in stedes þer þei sawe ese. & aryued vp y þe beste contre, & byseged &yogh;ork al aboute. Al þe contre til hym gan loute; He sente to grete lordynges, & het & gaf hem riche þynges. ffor fair hot, & giftes þat þey tok, Þemperour Sauer þey forsok. Sauer tok hise oþer Bretons, & asembled gadred togidere. his legions; Toward &yogh;ork faste þem dight, To remue remoue; and omits the next two lines. hem he hadde tyght. When þey were comen wyþynne a lyte, Þe batailles gonne to-gedere smyte; ffellyk þey foughte, for þer was slayn On eyþer syde þeir cheftayn; ffulgence was first feld to grounde, & Sauer was slayn on a stounde. Þe Romayns for Sauer bysought, So þat his body to &yogh;ork was brought, & biried þer solempnely, & his oþer frendes hym by. Not in Geoffrey either. Þis ilke enperour Sauer Regned her seuentene &yogh;er: Syn Crist cam was born. of þe vyrgyne, Nyne score &yogh;er euene, & nyne, Of þys Sauer þat deide þere, Tweye knaue childre were; Þat on men calde Bassian, Þat oþer had to name Cetan. Gelan. Cetan Gelan. moder was a Romayn, Comen of men; and after l. 5881 re|peats lines 5878-9 on of gode knyght & swayn. Bassan was born of a Brette; Þe Bretons of hym þe bettere lette. Þe Romayns toke þis ilke Cetan, Gettan. & corouned hym, & bycome com. hys man. Þe Bretons wiþ Bassan helde, & of þe roeme highte hym þe schelde. Þen ilkon in þer party Held wyþ his kynde doughtyly: Al þus wyþ megge þus gate with mengyng. (ensi ot por l'eslection, Wace, i. 255, l. 5486.) & wiþ monge Bytwixt hem wax þer werre stronge; Ilkon ouer oþer so lange þey algate ilk oþer so long ouer. ran, Þat atte laste slayn was Cetan. Getan. ¶ Þe Bretons, eft sones þey ches Bassan kyng, & hadde þer pes. Bassan Rex. ¶ A ladde was y þys londe, of fame, Karaucyus Charais, Wace. Cp. 'Karas,' below. þen was his name; Karaucius Hardy he was, & ful connynge, & conand. Maledictus. Stalworthe of body, & wel fightynge; fightand. In many nedes assayed he was; Of prowesse men preised þys Karas; Born he was of pouere pure. lynage, & litel he hadde of heritage. Gretter & fairer fairer & better. stat he held, Þan wolde his rentes, þan he rent had. or land in feld; Grete emprises he durst vndertake; More louede he þe werre þan þes to make. I þe se to wende, þenne was doute, Maryners robbed þe ildes aboute; Mighte atte hauenes reste ne duelle no. be, ffor outlandesmen þat come by se. Karaucius þenne hym by-þought, Þe senaturs of Rome he MS. þey , but þ altered to h. he , P. sought, & tolde hem þat outlandes flet Bretaygne alle aboute biset, & seide "&yogh;if &yogh;e wil gyue me leue " Þe robbours o þe se to greue, " & gyue chartre of a-vowerye, chartire & auourie. " Þe se to loke wyþ myn nauie, " I scholde &yogh;ow warante &yogh;oure I sall þam warant þorgh. truage, " Þat non outlandeys scholde make passage." Þey graunted hym þen leue to haue, So þat he schulde þer truage saue; Chartre þey gaf hym wiþ her sel, So þat he scholde to þeym beo leel. þat he suld to þam be leale. Karres his leue atte Romayns MS. Romayms. nam, & schewed [þe] þe. chartre þer he cam; Sone quicly. gat he hym mariners, Wiþ schipes, barges, & balyngers. schippes gode busses coggers. He desired disherited. men þat were fledde, Þeues & robbours, swylk he ledde, Yuel dedy ill dedy. men þat were wight, Of Outlandes al þo. þat he myght; Of swylk he gadered compaignies, Born & norysched in felonyes. Whan þis Karraus had gadered him geten him. ost, Of manye a land he serched þe cost; ffro on ilde til oþer he &yogh;ede, Of no þynge ne hadde þey was it non þat þei ne had. drede; Men he robbed, & landes wasted, ffrom o stede til oþer fro a stede till anoþer. he hasted; To ney neygheburs, & ferþer neihburs nere & fer. fro, Til alle he dide skaþe & w[o]; Al he tok þat he myght take, He nolde mesure to mesure wild he. no man make; Þat Outlandeys byforn had left, De fide ffracta. He spared non, bot alle he reft. To saue þe folk, Carrays was sworn, Bot he was worse þan oþer byforn; fful mykel he wan, &yogh;it &yogh;ernde he more, ffor his folk woxe & spredde ay whore; Casteles & tounes doun he þrew; ffor lord, he wolde þat alle hym knew. So fer he sayled farde. to wynne hym wayne, Atte laste he aryued in in þis. Bretaigne; Pryuely wiþ þe Bretons he spak, & seide, "&yogh;e se nought &yogh;oure lak! " &yogh;our kyng can nought hym seluen were! " Bot &yogh;yf &yogh;e wyl me god feiþ bere, " Y scholde deliuere &yogh;ow out of peynes, I. suld delyuere &yogh;ow of þe Romeyns. " And al &yogh;our land of &yogh;our Romaynes. all þis lond of þar dimeyns. " He &yogh;ede to þe Peytes, & seide hem þe same; &yogh;if þey wolde alle wyþ o name Make hym kynge of þempyres, He wolde þem make lordes & syres. þo were þe Peytes wyþ þe kyng pryue, & in þys lond gret plente; And Karays wyste þat þey were fykel, Þerfore he glosed hem, & gaf hem mykel, & þey hight hette. hym wyþouten faille, &yogh;yf he wyþ þe kynge tok bataille, Tyl Kareys party schold þey go, And þe kyng desconfite & slo.
text.96: ¶ Decepcio Pyctorum. Whan þey had alle Karays y-highte, Bretons & Peytes help at her myghte, Bassian he gan defye, & wiþ foule wordes hym descrie. wordes ascrie. So longe lasted þer manace, To bataille þey comen in to were þei brouht in. place: The Petyt MS. inserts— Karais partie dred not þe kyng. ne Bassian Karais no þing. Bassan affied hym o þe Peytes, In bataille þey knewe many Inouh of bataile þei couth. sleightes, Þer-fore his trist was on þeym more Þan on alle þo þat þer wore. ffor he god trist to þem hadde, Richely often þeym he cladde; & als þe partys gaf bataille, Iusted & chased, & gon assaille, Þys ilke Peytes were traytours, Ageyn þe kynge turned y þe stours, & wyþ Karays partye held, & traysched þe kyng right in þe feld, And slowe þe kyng, sire Bassian, & alle his folk, ylk a man. Þus þey traisched hym in nede, Sire Bassian þat dide þem fede; & Karays lyghtli wan þe lond; Agayns hym no party he ne fond. Karays gaf hem, for þer seruise, Among þe Scottes gret ffraunchise; So þat Pictes & þe Scottes kynde Ar now al on, as men fynde.
text.97: Allectus & Walwus, Romany, venerunt. Whan þey of Rome tydyng herde Þat Karays wiþ Bretaygne þus ferde, with þis lond misferd. Þey sente hider þre tuo. trois, Wace , i. 260. legions, Wyþ to of þer bolde barons; Allectus & Walwes þer name Allet & Gallus þer names. hyght, Wysemen of werre, & hardy in fight. hardy & wight. Þey come pryuely com vp ryuand. out of þe se, Bot Karays wolde haue reft hem þeir entre; Bot maugre Karreys, on hym þey wan, And slowe Karreys þe false man, þat falsnes gan. & alle þat weren of his kynde, Destruyed hem stroyed þam. by rote & rynde, & alle þo þat þe Romayns forsok, And til Kareys party tok.
text.98: ¶ De electione Regis Asclypidot in parliamento. Þe Bretons seye þe Romayns aboue, And Romayns myghte þey neuere loue; ffayn wold þey þer fredam fende, P. transposes this line and the next. Truage to Rome wold þey non sende; After þe barons þo þey sent, To chesen at þat Parlement A kyng þat myghte ageyn þeym vaille, Asclipedot, Erl of Cornewaille. Whan he was chosen, he dide somoune Alle þe Bretons fro toune to toune, 1 Þat alle þat myghte wepene welde, To bataille schold come, þat were of elde, 1 1-1 all suld com þat were of elde. to bataile go or wapen welde. To Londone ageyn Allectus, & his felawe sire Walwus. Gallus.
text.99: ¶ De Bello inter Romanos & Regem apud Londonium. A day þe Romayns made sacrifise I þe temple, as was [þer] gyse. þer wise. Right in þeire solempnete, Byseged þe Bretons þeir cite; Þe Romayns herde noise & cry, & cried "as armes!" on hy, on hy, has armes all on hy. And dide þem out in to þe felde, & baldely on þem self gon belde, & foughten wyþ þe Bretons faste. Bot þe Romayns route to-braste; ffor Alectus dide side. ; & his mene &yogh;ede al doun, & moughte nought fle; Alle þat were on þat party, Ascaped þer non by stret ne sty. Sire Walwes sey Gallus sawe. þeir side &yogh;ed doun; By tyme he fledde in to þe toun, & þe gates after þem sperde. To karnels & to þe walle [t]hey ferde, & to þe toures cop toure vp. on hey, & dide þe Brutons holde þem a dreigh. o drie. Asclipedot þat was wyþoute, Saw þe Romayns hadde no doute; His lettres brefis. he dide write & sende After mo bretons fer & hende, Þat þey scholde come & sege make Aboute Londone, Romayns to take. ffor þe sonde of sire Asclipidot, Come Walschemen & many a Scot; On ilka syde alle þey cam, Þat langed vnto þe kynedam. Engyns dide barfreis did. þe Bretons reyse, & mangenels ful gode to preyse, & ffruscht þe wal of þe cite; Wyþ strengþe on þeym þey had entre. Þen myghte men se þe Romayns deye, & on hepes leye by ligge in. ilka weye; Neuere byfore swylk slaughter was Of [þe] þe. Romayns at no pas. Þe Romayns þat were so schent, To priue fortelets forceletes. þey went, ffro þe Bretons for to hyde, Þer lif to lengþe ay byside; be tide. Bot þe Bretons helden hem þam so. streyt, Þey ascaped nought for no deseyt. Sory was Walwes, & vnglad was Gallus he. made his mone, & preyed vn-to said vnto. þe Bretons ilkone, " Lordynges, wol &yogh;e let me go " Vnto Rome þer y cam fro, " & my men for to saue? " O legion, & namo, wold y craue. a legion no mo we haue. " Þo þat mystaken haue, more or lesse, a legion mo ne lesse. " ffor þeym ask y forgyuenesse, " & let vs senglely a-wey with lyfe & lymme away to. fare " Out of þys lond for euere mare." Þe Bretons graunted þem þer bone, & þe Romayns &yogh;olde þem sone. Out of þe tours þey come al doun, To þe pes in-to þe toun; & als þe Romayns &yogh;olden were, Þe Wa[l]ssche & Scottes þe scote þe walsh. wyþ al þer here Comen wyþ gret noise & hew; hu. Tok þey no tent to pes ne trew; toke þe no tent of pes ne tru. Of the Romayns þey smyten ilkan heued, Lord ne ladde was þer non leued. bileued. Walwes Gallus. þey tok, al his vnthank, & leddym to Atyngal, a him till a. brokes bank; Þer left he his heued, his hede gird of. he was þe last; His body in to Atyngal cast. in to þe broke kast. & for he in þat water lay, Þe riueres name was turnd þat þe broke men call to þis. day; On Englische tonge hit hat Walbrok, on Inglis Gualebroke. ffor þat Walwes his deþ þer tok. ¶ Þenne regned Asclipedot; Neyþer was he nouþer he lufed. schrewe ne sot. Gret feste he held at hys coronynge, & ten &yogh;er he regned kynge.
text.100: ¶ De Dioclisiano Inperatore. maximo persecutore Christianorum. ( In a later hand. ) In his tyme was an Emperour Dioclisian, a werreour, He sente hider Maximian; & struyde & slow ilk Cristenman. Þat he on þys half Moungow mon Giu, Wace; Mons Jovis. See p. 116, note or in. . fond, Til he come vntil þys lond, Al he destruyed, & broughte to schame, Þat cristned were in Iesu name. Dioclisien, on his partie, To Cristenmen dyde felonye; Vnder hym & Maxymian Þey slowe at Verolame Written over an erasure. seint her was slayn sayn. Alban, & seint Iue & seint Aroon. Þo were in ware at in Wales in Kaerlion. Kerlyon, Þe byschop wyþ alle þe clergie Þat leued in Iesu or or in. Marie, Alle þey slowe þat þey fond, fful fewe ascaped fro þer hond; bot if any ascapid þe lond. So fele were neuere slayn in stour Of corseyntz corsayntes. vnder emperour. Þat &yogh;er þe date of Iesu wex, ¶ . Two hundred &yogh;er, four score & sex.
text.101: ¶ De Rege Coele, Patre Sancte Elene. In Colchestre Wace says 'Hoël . . . . . de Gloe|'cestre;' but R. Brunne is right by Geoffrey of Monmouth. waster was. a lordyng, Of wham þe toun hadde gynnynge; S[i]re Coel his name hight, Of noble lynage, a man of myght; He werreyed wered. on Asclipedot, ffor he had born hym as a sot, & suffred to mykel suffred mykell. Maximian, Þat he þorow þe lond so ran, Þe Cristene blod for to slo; Þer-fore were þe Bretons þe Bretons were wroþe. wo. ffor Asclipedot bar hym nought wel, P. transposes these lines. Þer-fore corouned þei sire Coel. P. transposes these lines. When Maximien was gon to Rome, On Asclipedot toke þey dome; Sire Coel hym in bataille slow, ffor he fro Maximien hym yuel wyþdrow. him drouh. Þis Coel hadde a doughter fair, Of clergie [sc]he couþe, of clergie couth. (A.-Sax. heo , she.) & was his ayr; Sone ne doughter had he namo Þat þe heritage myghte to go, Scheo was to hure fader ferly dere; He dide maistres hure for to lere, Þat scheo moughte bettere scho couth. þe lond &yogh;eme, & lord to take, as hure wolde byseme; þat hir wild queme. Þys ilke mayden highte ELEYNE, A ful god woman, & a certeyne. Þe Romayns herde, & were fayn, Þat Asclipedot was so slayn; Þey sente hider a man of pris, Constancius, þat was noble Constancius both ware. (Cos|tans, Wace , i. 266.) & wys; Al Spayne he had wonnen to Rome, Þorow truage al at her dome; Was noman þanne of his bounte, Þat men wiste, so mikel as he. Þys Constant þat þus wan Spayne, He aryued her in Brutaigne. Choel, þat wiste his comyng, He dredde Costant Constant. ouer alle þyng; Coel sent til hym messegers, & seide 'he wolde on faire maners ' Holde of hym, &yogh;if þat he wylde, ' & redyly his truage &yogh;elde.' Costant Constant. seide he wolde skyl, & consented til consentid to. his wyl; Þe Romayns seyde sawe. þey were aboue, & fayn þey were of pees & loue. Was hit nought a monþe long, Sire Coel tok an yuel strong; Eyghte aght. dayes lay he, & namo, & deide, & wente þer we schal go. siþen died as we sall do (not in Wace or Geoffrey). Constant saw þys ilke Eleyne,— Þis lond was al of hure demayne,— Saw þat scheo was ferly wys, And of beute bar þe prys; Hym þoughte he myghte wel be he þouht him self wele. byset To wedde þat mayde, & bate baret. Þen was he kyng, & scheo quene. A knaue child com þer hem was þam. bytwene; CONSTANTYN was his name ytold; & when he was enleuen &yogh;er old, His fader fel in a seknesse, Þat to þe deþ ded. hit made hym stresse. When Constant MS. Constantyn. had y-mad Constant had don: and leaves out the next four lines. his fyn, In Euerwyk toun þey byried hym fful ryaliche wiþ gret honur, ffor he was a worþy emperour. When þenterement was done, Constantyn his sone þey coronede sone; þei crouned his sone Constantyn. & þe more he wax in whan he was wele of. age, Þe bettere loued hym ys wele lufed him his. baronage; God chiualrie til hym he Gode knyghtes to him. drow, ffor he was large, & gaf ynow; &yogh;if his fader were of bounte, &yogh;it was þe sone wel more þan he. Þis Constantyn was man of queyntise, Þer-wyþ he was a noble iustise; P. puts this line two lower. In his &yogh;outhe he was als wys As elder were y þer moste pris. ffor his moder, he loued Bretons; ffor his ffader, of Rome al þe barons; Of þyse two kyndes he was born, And of þe noblest men byforn.
text.102: ¶ De Constantino, filio Constanty & sancte Elene. At Rome was þenne an Emperour Þat dide þe Romayns gret desonour; His name was Maxencius, Proud, & fers, proude. stoute. & malicious; He wasted þe honur of þe toun, Þe noble men he brought þem doun, Þe ordre of þer sene abated he, & reft hem þeir dignite. Somme þat hated hym of þo, Left þer fes, feez. dide hem to go Hider to Bretaygne, til Constantyn. ffor he was born of þeyr lyn, Þey preied hym he wolde make defens, & abate þe pruyde of Maxens, Bysoughte as he was, worþy knyght, Of þer sene to holde vp þe ryght. Þe Bretons alle preied hym so, Wyþ hym þey wolde concente þer to. Longe þey preied, bot at þe bisouht & he at. ende He graunted þeym þider to wende; He tok wyþ hym he dight his folk. knyghtes & squiers, Men wiþ bowes & arblasters, with alblastes & oþer archers. & his moder ful wys his moder eames wys men. of dome; Wyþ hym wente þey alle vntil Rome. ffor þey were men of honurs, He dide hem y þe ordre of senaturs; Þat on highte sire Huwelyn, Leonyn. (Lohélius, Wace. ) Þat oþer Iohern, 'þat oþer' is dotted under, as if for omission, in the Lambeth MS. The Petyt reads þe toþer Trahern (L'altre Trahens, Wace ). (See Tra|herne here, lines 6259-64,&c., below.) Geoffrey (v. 8) gives only Leolin, Trahern, and Marius, three uncles of Helena. Eroert, & þe þrid. Maryn; Wardeyns he ordeined gode & left gode. certeyn, Þis lond to kepe til he com ageyn, When Constantyn to Rome cam, Þe maistrie fro Maxcence he nam, And was hym selue emperour, & Maxcence doun wiþ deshonur. R. Brunne leaves out Wace's seven lines (i. 270) on the finding of the Cross by Helena. Til sire Huelyn Leonyn. he gaf a wyf, Of noble kynde was sche ryf: Of þat wyf, sire Huelyn Leonyn. wan A child men calde Ma[x]imian. Maximian.
text.103: ¶ De Rege Octauo. This heading is two lines lower in the MS. I þe wardeyns tyme this wardeyns. þat Constantyn tok Þe Bretons for to lok, Com Octauus, an erl of Walys, & sesed þys lond, boþe dounes & dales. Þy[s] erl of Walys þis Octauus. was man of myght, In Bretayne he cleymed ryght; Wardeyns & schirreues he slow, Baillifs, bedeles, dide schame ynow. Bot Constantyn to Rome was went, Til gretter nedes he gaf his tent; He ne myghte þenne on none wyse Hyder come to make iustise; He sende sent. hider sire Traherne, Þe lond to kepe & to gouerne. Two legions wiþ hym he ladde, P. omits these lines. Toward Bretayne þey hem spedde; P. omits these lines. At an hauen þat þey fond, Sire Traherne tok þys þe. lond. To Wynchestre Porcestre, Wace , l. 5866, who makes another march on Winches|ter, l. 5870. R. Brunne follows Geoffrey. wente þis sir. Trahere, Two dayes he soiourned þere, & to hym he dide hem to him þe toun he did. &yogh;elde; By þer willes þey ne wolde; Maugre þeires, þey &yogh;olde þe &yogh;ald þat. estre. Syþen he &yogh;ede &yogh;ode. to Wynchestre; Sire Octauus wiþ many a scheld Was byforn hym in þe feld, & gaf til hym bataille stout. Þe Romayns ofte perced þe rout; Romeyns perced þorghoute. Octauus grettere force hadde, So þat þe Romayns route to-schadde, alto schad. & dide hem to þe hauene fle, Vntil þer schipes on þe se. Þey sette vp sail heye on mast, Toward þe northe þey seyled fast; In Scotlond aryued, he ryued in Scotland. & logged his ost, & pylede & robbed robbed & reft. at ilka cost. Til Octauus sone com tydand Þat Trahern robbed in Scotland. Octauus gadered host ay whare, & hyed hym faste þat he were þare; Oft he seyde wyþ grete pryde Þat Trahern schold nought dur abide; Bot his ouerwenyng ouerhope. gan faille; Trahern stod, & bod stode vnto. bataille, & dide Octauus for to fle; In to Norweye ouer þe se. Octauus þenne fledde for ferd; He spak vntil þe [kinge] Comperd, vnto kyng Comperde. ffor help & socour he preyde socour for. &yogh;erne, To wynne þe lond of sire Traherne. Pryuely he sent to þis lond ageyn, To þo þat were til hym certeyn, Þat þey scholde fonde on alle wyse To sle Traherne wiþ som queyntise. Þat tyme spedde Traherne wel ynow; Rex Tra|hernus. ¶ Ageyn to þe southe Traherne drow, & dide hym coroune kyng to be, & regned wiþ solempnete. A day to of. Londone he scholde out ryde; His ffomen a-spied wel what tyde; Enbusched þeym by þat strete Þer þey hoped þe kyng to mete. Sire Traherne of non hym dredde, Þer-fore no folk wyþ hym ne ledde; At a passage as he went, Þey breken of þeyr enbuschement; put þam of þer bussement. Þo þat hym hated for Octauus Slowen slouh. þer sire Trahernus. ffor Octauus þey sende sent. þer sonde, & sesed hym eft in to þe londe, & corouned hym als he was er; & alle þat comen wyþ Traher, Euerilkon he þei. dide þem slo; Ascaped non bot wyþ wo; Syþen in pes þe lond gan welde, & longe lyuede til gret to right gode. elde.
text.104: ¶ De consilio Octaui per Karadukum. Whan he had regned regned in. þis lond her, Þe tyme of to & þritty MS. &yogh;ritty. P. þritty. &yogh;er, He sey þat of hym cam sawe of him was. non eyr Bot a maiden child right feir; He asked who moughte his doughter haue, Þis lond for to loke & saue. ffele of his frendes seid his gaf. reson, To sende to Rome for a baron, His doughter for to gyue to wyue; So myghte þey pes haue in þer lyue. Oþer þer were þat loued Conan, Þe kynges cosyn, a noble man; Þey conseilled to make hym ys eyr, He myghte best, in þeir espeir. þis was þer speire. Þen spak þe Erl of Cornewaille, Sire Karaduk: he seide, 'saunz faille ' He ne wolde nought conseille þer-to, ' ffor ne. hit were nought wel to do, ' To make his eir sire heir to mak his cosyn. Conan; " Bot sende after Maxymian, " Þe eldest sone of Huelyn, leonyn. " Eleynes Heleyn. cosyn, & Constantyn: " His fader ys Breton, þat þis. is certayn, " & on his moder side Romayn; " Gif hym þy doughter in mariage; " Wys man he is, & wel of age. " &yogh;if þou gaf hit vntil Conan, " & maried þy doughter to anoþer man, " He scholde fonde, when he myght suld fond whan he mot. wel, " Þe lond of hym to wynne ilk del; " He scholde þenke, & ful wel myght, " Þat hit scholde þe lond suld. be his þorow ryght; " Bot &yogh;yf &yogh;e do as y &yogh;ow seye, " Of pes ys þer non oþer weye." Þe kyng held hym to þat conseil; Þer-fore bygan þer a tyrpeyl tirpeile. (Fr. trepel, Wace , l. 5967.) Bytwyxt Conan & Karaduk; ffor Conan gan þat oþer þe [ on ] to þe toþer. rebuk, & reuiled Conan stouted. hym wyþ wordes þore; & &yogh;if he had durst, he wolde more. Sire Karaduk held ful litel had litell. awe Of his manace or of his sawe. Þe kyng bisoughte sire Karaduk To sende to Rome his sone Maurik/, & preye hym vpon alle þynge Maxymian to Bretaigne brynge. Whan Mauryk was to Rome y-comen, He saw þat gret party was nomen Bytwixten þis Maximian & Valentyn & Gracian: Þey stryue to haue þe empire; Þe breþere hadde þer partie most seure. þe breþer þe better partie. Sire Maurik þer Maximian fond, & teldym told him. he was of þys lond; Anon he bad him, "take leue bad him leue all þat. of Rome, " & vntil Bretaygne smertly come, " Þe kynges doughter for to take; " Þou may þy party þe better make."
text.105: ¶ De Maximiano Rege. When Maximian þis tydynges herde, Wiþ ioye to Bretayne wyþ Maurik [he] he. ferde: Was non abyd ne no dwellynge Til Maximian com to þe kynge. Maximian at Southaumptoun gan ryue, & asked þe kynges doughter to wyue. Þan was Octauus al at ese; Of his doughter he dide hym sese, Wiþ al þe reome & alle rengne. ilkadel, & bad hym richely regne, & wel. ¶ Conan was wroþ, & made gret bost, He alyed hym to þe Scottes cost; Octauus, his em, he gan manace, & Maximien wiþ to. werre dide chace; Bot Maximian gaf nought of hym; He stod ageyn Conan ful grym. fful often Conan of hym wan, So dide of hym Maximian:— Hit ys þer chaunce þat werre bygynne, Vmwhile to lese, vmwhile som tyme to lose som tyme. to wynne.— Whan þei to-gedere had werreyed longe, Men of gode &yogh;ede þeym amonge, Dide þem acorde in loue & pes, So þat Maximian nought ne les; He highte hym, for his emes he het him þan for his eam. sake, A riche man he scholde hym make. Þre 'five' says Geoffrey. &yogh;er in pes, wyþouten fight, He drow to tresour þat he myght; He seide he wolde assaye þe wild stande to. chaunce, Ouer se to wende, & wynne ffraunce, & fro þenne wende to fro þien vnto. Rome, Of his enemys to make dome, And of alle þat wyþ hem helde, Ageins hym fyghtynge in [þe] agayn him fightand in þe. felde.
text.106: ¶ De nauigacione Maximiani versus Armoricham. When he had folk, & was redy, To schipe þey wente hastily. Toward south-west þey passed þe se, Aryued vp in a contre; Armoriche was þenne þe name, Bot now hit haþ an oþer fame. Humbald was þer-in lord & sire, Of Armoriche he held þenpire; He dide somoune alle his barons, A-wey to chace, & felle to chace away. þe Bretons. Þe Bretons were of wel more myght; Humbaldes men þey slowe doun right, Þey nadde had. no force to turne agein; Alle þey fledde, knyght & swayn; Bot fiftene þousand wer þer slayn. & Maximien gan turne MS. turned. ageyn, & ioyful was þat he so spedde:— Þat lond held women, þe men were fledde:— had wonnen þe folk was fled. He tok sire Conan by þe hond, hande. & on hym low wyþ god semblaunt/; louh with faire semblande. " Conan," he seide, "þou art doughti; " To manne Armoriche to haf a reume. þou were worthi. " Sestow now þis faire contre, " fful plentyuous & ful ayse; wele ese. " Þe lond to tyle, god ys to wynne; " Wodes, watres, ynowe þer-ynne, " fforestes fulle of ful fayr dere, " ffresche ryuers ese & ner; " Y ne sey nere in al I. sawe neuer in. my lyue " A fairer lond, ne more so faire a lond ne so. plentyue. " On þe, Conan, y vouche hit saue, " Þat þou hit welde wyþ ioye, & haue. " Bretaygne þe grete was þe het, " & on þe hit were ful wel byset; " Bot for me þou hast hit lorn, " Þer-fore to me yuel hastow ill will to me þerfor has. born; " ffor-gyue me now ilk a del, " & haue þis lond, & brouk hit wel. " Þis ys þe heste hete. (see l.6405-6.) þat y þe hight; " & bettere y wolde, &yogh;yf þat y & better sall whan .I. haf. One stroke too many in the MS. m. myght; " Þys lond we scholle sall. clense of þyse, " Þen schulle sall. þe Bretons þe lond iustise; " Non oþer folk schulle sall. dwelle þer-ynne; " Þen may þou weldit al weld þe lond. wyþ wynne." Conan of hym receyued þe gyfte, & Maximian to kyng hym lyfte; And Conan made hym þer fewte, Of hym to holde hit euere yn fe. hold all his fe.
text.107: ¶ Brytannia Mynor conquesta est per Maximianum. ¶ Maximian spak to þe kyng: " Þis lond is Bretones wynnyng, " & for þat ilke encheson " Þat hit is conquered þorow conquest þorgh. Bretoun, " Hit schal hote þe Lesse it sall hate lesse. Bretayne, " And we Bretons to be cheuentayne; cheiftayn. " And y comaunde &yogh;ow alle oliche, onlyche. " Þat noman calle hit Armoriche." ffro þat day vntil þis same, Of Armoriche hit loste þe name; & now ys hit cald Bretaigne wyþ alle; I trowe þat name schal neuere falle. Maximien, til his demeynes He sesed þe faire cite of Reynes. Þat were þer-ynne, þe toun þenne left, Durste neuere non of þeym ryse efte. Maximian þe þat þe. lond tok, Tounes & casteles dide he lok; constables castels did loke. ffaire countres ouer al he fond, Bot þer were none myghte tyle þe lond; He þoughte he wolde to Bretaigne sende After men, boþe sibbe & fremde, Þe lond to multeplie & to tyle, & forto puplise þe lond & tile. Þat oþer þer-to ne scholde haue skyle. He dide come of pore pedaille An hundred þousand þat myghte trauaille, 2 To laboure & to tyle þer fode; Wyþ þritty þousand men of armes gode, Þe londe fro enemis to fende & were, Þat Vtlandeys scholde þem nought dere. 2 2-2 & þritty þousand of knyghted gode. to fende þam to tile þer fode. Þenne was Conan corouned kyng, & hadde þe regne al in kepynge, Þer-ynne þer for. to lyue & to deye, And Maximian wente forþ his weye. Als he wente, Maximian, ffraunce & al Lorreyne lorenge. he wan. Hym þoughte hit was nought &yogh;it ynow; To Rome he þoughte, & þider he drow; He þoughte to venge hym þenne of þo Þat greued hym at Rome, when he scholde go, whan he Rome first &yogh;ede fro. & þo breþere to brynge to yuel ille. fyn, Boþe Gracien & sire Valentyn. He com to Rome ful hastely; austerly. Þat o broþer tok he par þe tuo breþer toke par. maystry; Þat oþer he dide wyþ force fle, & held þempire in dignite. Þen was he þe fourtenþe fourtend. Emperour Syþen Augustus, þat bar þe flour: Þe date of Crist þen was þus euene, Þre hundred &yogh;er, seuenty & seuene.
text.108: ¶ De Dynoto, Custode siue Rege, & de Vrsula, filia eiusdem, & .xj. Ml virginum, tam per tempesta|tem quam apud Coloniam, occisis per Sarasenos. When Maximian ferde fro Bretaigne, Of Dynotis mad he cheftayne, ceiftayn. To kepe & kept. þe lond til his bihoue; ffor trewe & feyþful he dide for a lele man did. hym proue. Sire Karaduk, þat y spak of Karaduk broþer .I. spak. byforn, Was Dynotis broþer, & &yogh;onge was Dinotus & &yogh;ongere. born; Bot ded þat tyme was Karaduk; & his sone, þat highte sire Mauryk,— Þat &yogh;ede to Rome in Octauus message— Wyþ Dyanot he kepte with Dianoth had. his heritage. A doughter had Dianot, & no ma; Hure name was cald dame þat maiden hight. Vrsula. Þo þat were dryuen fro Armoriche, Þe Frensche & þey felawed o-liche, frankis & þei fleand olike. & rysen ros. ageyn Conan to fight; Bot Conan meyntende wel his right; ffor þeym ne loste he þem he les. neuere nought Whan þey on hym bataille sought. Þen was Conan meued of skyle to do his folk be more þorgh skill. Hys lond to edefie & to tyle; & þe lond herberw & till. & þat þey moughte þe sikerere lyue, Wyues he þoughte hem for to gyue. ffrensche wymen wolde frankis women wild. þey non take, Þat þer blod no monge scholde monge suld. make, To haue cleym þorow heritage, Ne dowarye þorow mariage. Vntil no blod wolde þey hem bynde, Bot only to þer owene kynde; Þerfore Conan sente his sonde To Dianot, þat kepte þis londe, " To sende hym his doughter Vrsele— " Wiþ non oþer wolde he dele,— " And gentil damysels vngyuen, Ientill douhtres vngyuen. " Þat able to mennes companye were þat were of waxdam & wele. þryuen,— " Squyers sergeanz. doughtres, & frankelayns, " To gyue hem to knyghtes & to swayns, " Oþer maidens comen of þralles, " To be maried as þem falles; " Alle þat he myghte, he schold suld. him sende, " Wiþ waryson he schold suld. þem mende." Dynot graunted to sende hym hyre, & richely þen dide hure atyre; Alle þo þat he gete myght, Lordynges lordes. doughtres wel adight: ¶ Enleuen þousand elleuen. þey were by tale, Of gentil blod, women. grete & smale; Oþer þat were of lower kynde, Þe auenauntest þey myghte auenant þat þei mot. fynde, Sexty þousand, quarante mil, Wace , i. 285, l. 6169. so many þer ware, Redy to schipen ouer schip ouer se. to fare, Wel dight ilkon for þe nones. At Londone þey schiped at ones, P. inserts,— whan þei had all þat þam fell nede. & were bitaght þo þam suld lede. & drowe þer sail heye vpon mast; Bytaughte þem God, & seyled fast. ¶ When þey were com. in deppest flod, & wenden han had passage wende haf sauf passage &. god, Ros a tempest, rorande loude, One stroke too many for the u in the MS. & reyned al doun wyþ a blak myrk was þe skie grete was þe. cloude. Derk was þe skye, gret was þe reyn, Þe wynd was wod [&] þem & þam. ageyn; Þe sky ferd as hit scholde doun falle; Wonder wawes agaste þem alle, So þey arysen on so grete risand one. ouer anoþer, Þat þeym nauaillede auailed nouht. mast ne roþer; Þe wynd, þe water, so faste þey faught, Þem to saue was non þat þought. nouht to saue nouht ne douht. Þrytty schipes scippes. þer were nomo, Þo sexti þousand to deþe &yogh;ede þo, Þe oþere enleuene ful þe elleuen fer. fer were dryuen, In Barbarie þey vp aryuen: Two Sarasyns were kynges of pris, Þat on highte Melga, þat oþer Gwanis. Gwanis Ivains, Wace , i. 287, l. 6218. was kyng of Huneys; Melga, of Peyghtes was kynge, hit seis. Þyse Sarasynes wolde han leyn hem by, Bot þey nolde of no vileny, Leuere þem were deye wyþ drede, Þan to lecherye þer bodies bede. Wiþ martirdom þey dide hem deye; At Coloyne now, men sais, þei lye. Þenne herde þise to Sarsyns seye Þat þe force of Bretaigne was aweye, How gret host wyþ Maximian went, & to Conan þritty þousand sent; What wyþ þat on, what wyþ þat oþer, Þer lefte no force agayns non oþer. What dide Melga & Guaneis, Bot gadred ost of Outlandeys. Wiþ gret nauye o þe se þey with a grete flete on flode to. ryde, & comen in alle by Scotlande syde; Wyþ werre & wo þey dide gret noye, ffor Westmorland al gon þey struye; Al þe northe contre þey wasted. Þey passed Humber, & southe hem hasted; Non encountre in no countre. þey ne fond, Bot husbonde-men þat tyled lond, & werkmen, & oþer pedaille Þat couþe nought werre ne of bataille; &yogh;if any swyche stod ought ony of swik stode. agayn, Wyþ armed men sone were þey slayn. Ilk man fro his owen gan fle, & þo þat ne myghte, slayn was he: How scholde þat londe kepe hym fro harmes, How suld a lond be dredede. Þat naked ys of men of armes? þat of knigthes es al nakyd. A lond hedles heuedles. in tyme of nede, Ouer al þanne ys sorewe & drede; & so was þenne bot cry & kare, Of socour & help þey were al bare; Bot to. while þey hadde þer bolde barons, Sauelike Sauely. held þey þer castels & touns; Ouer alle landes þey schewed þer þei mustird. myghtes, Þe whyles to whyle. þey hadde þer noble knyghtes. Þen chose þey of most bolde þei ches þat were baldest. & fers, & sent hem to Rome as messegers ffor help vnto Maximian; And he þem sende sire Gracian; Wyþ hym come two legyons Þat wel socoured þe Bretouns; Þise Sarsynes þis Saxins. (les hulagues, Wace , i. 289, l. 6253.) þeues þey drof awey, In til Irland ilkon fled þey. ¶ In þys tyme at Rome ros Valentyn Wyþ al hys kynde, em & cosyn; Wyþ hym com kynges a kyng. of þe Est, Mo þan twenty, as seyþ Theodosius, so sais. (O Théo|sien d'Orient, Wace , i. 289, l. 6258.) þe Gest; Bot þorow treson, y ne wot how, Algate Maximian þey slow. Þe Bretons þat Maximian ledde, Summe þey slowe, somme were fledde; Þan sesed Valentyn Rome Valentyn seised all eft. al efte, Al þat Maximian hym refte.
text.109: ¶ De Rege Graciano Romano. Þys tydyng com to Gracian, How Valentyn slow þat he was dede. Maxymian; & saw he was here cheuentayne, he saw him self cheftan. P. transposes this line and l. 6666. & dide hym coroune kyng of Bretayne, And bar hym heye as a Tyraunt, ffor þis was his custume & his haunt, Pouere men to do þem wo; Out of þer right he put þem fro, & ful manye of þeym he slow; Þe riche he louede wel ynow. What dide þe mene folk & þe pedaille? poueraile. Samned þem a gret bataille; To pryue conseille þey gon þem renge, On of. Gracian þey wolde hem venge. Þey byseded hym sodeynly, þe biseged him priuely. & token hym syþen par maistri, & his body al to-hewe, Þe peces vntil houndes þrewe. Þe Romayns þat were wyþ him comen, Smertly a-geyn to Rome þey nomen.
text.110: ¶ De captiuitate Brytannie. Melga Guaneys Melga Guanis. (Ganis et Ma|gan, Wace. ) herde wel how Þat þe poraille poueraile. (vilain, Wace , l. 6281.) Gracian slow; ffro Irlond þey come, ful & were. fayn Þat sire Gracian was so slayn; Þey gadered alle þe outlandeys Of Norwey men, wyþ þe Daneys, & of. þe Scottes wyþ men of Irland, & ouer-sette alle Northumberlande; Þey passed Humber, pylede robbed. & brent. Þen sawe þe Bretons þer lond al schent, P. puts here, for the next line, & þer folk so schamly deie. . & þey hadde no myght to stoppe þer weye, myght stop weie. ffor nought þat þey couþe don or seye; No þrowe in pes ne myghte þey reste; Þer-opon þey conseilled what was þe beste.
text.111: ¶ Hic miserunt Britones ad Romanos pro defencione eorum. ¶ Þey sente vnto þe senatours Of Rome for help & socours, As men þat þey most on affied, & in seruage to þem alyed, To helpe hem on haste now in þer nede, ffor ay þey lyue wyþ pylours with robbours lyued all day. in drede; & þey ne scholde neuere, for wele ne wo, More out of þer conseil do, go. (n'istront, Wace , l. 6294.) Bot &yogh;elde hem þat þeym oughte to haue, &yogh;yf þey if &yogh;ei. wolde helpe now þeym to saue. Bot þe Romayns forgete nought What schame byforn MS. byform. þey had hem what to þam befor þei. wrought So often & so fele syþe Whan þey moughte þer felonye kyþe; Natheles, twoo legions neuerþeles agayn. (Une légion solement, Wace , i. 291, l. 6299.) þey sent, Þat sone come, as hap þem lent, & deliuered þem of þer enemys: To Scotland fledden Melga Gwanis.
text.112: ¶ Iam Romany venerunt, & fiery fecerunt Murum de Thurlwal. Þys Romayns dide þem conseyl take, A wal vpon a dik to did. make ffro þe est se vnto est vnto. þe west, Agayns þer foos to saue þem best. Ston þey dide gadere & graue, & masons alle þat þey myghte haue; Ouer-þwert þe lond, þat ys, þe brede, Þey made þe wal ar þat þey &yogh;ede, ¶ ffor by þe northe ende come alle þo Þat to þe lond broughte werre or wo. Þat contre hight þat tyme Deyre, Of þis half þe wal in &yogh;ork-schire; On þat oþer half, y vnderstande, Men caldit þenne þe Peytes lande. cald it þan Peihtlond. When þys land wall. (tot, Wace , l. 6314.) was al dight, & wardeyns set boþe bi. day & nyght þat wal for to defende & lok, Þat þey namore scaþe ne tok, Toward þe southe gan þey wende Whan þe wal was brought to þe ende. At Londone þey sette a Parlement; Þe heye folk of alle, þyder þey went, Þorwout þe lond ilka lordynge; And þus þey seyde at þer sampninge: " We wole wende fro &yogh;ow to Rome, " & neuere hider sende ne come. " Be &yogh;e doughty, & lereþ lere. of armes, " & quykly defende &yogh;ow fro defend &yogh;our. harmes, " ffor we ne mowe come so fer viage, " Ne endure þe grete costage." ffor we ne may suffre þe costage, so often com so fer viage. Þe Bretons seyde alle þer geynes. Þenne stirte vp on of þe Romayns, A wys man & a wel spekande, & seyde, "Lordynges of þys land, " Lystneþ listens. now til y haue seyd; " Þe Romayns reson on me ys leyd.
text.113: ¶ Hic Romany trugam renuerunt pro toto tempore, sic dixerunt. " Lordes," he seide, "mani a many tyme. lore Nota. " Haue we suffred þis lond fore; " & byfore [vs], befor vs. oure auncessours " ffor &yogh;ow han had ful harde stours. " Truage &yogh;e gaf, & vmwhile som tyme. nought; " When we hit hadde, dere was we. hit bought; " Litel þerof were we amended, " ffor ay for &yogh;ow wel more we spended. more for &yogh;ow we haf dispendid. " &yogh;yf o &yogh;er til vs we &yogh;e hit &yogh;olde, " Two &yogh;er after &yogh;e ne wolde; " &yogh;yf o kynges tyme &yogh;e were vs trwe, " To so mykel after tuys als mykell. &yogh;our wrong was newe,— " Til whan &yogh;e mighte onst stonde to while &yogh;e myght ouht stand. ageyn— " Ne louede &yogh;e neuere man Romayn; " Ay when we come to þys lond, " To lese oure right som cheson &yogh;e fond, " And oþer wronges til vs y-nowe; " An[d] alderworst, aldermast. oure men &yogh;e slowe. " Now &yogh;e haue nede, &yogh;e vs byseke, " And het vs þanne to ben vs meke. " Whan we han holpen &yogh;ow in cas, " Þen do &yogh;e wors, & more trespas; " Til vs &yogh;e bere &yogh;ow as lyouns, " & waytes waite. vs wyþ sum tresons " ffor to wyþ-halden vs oure right, " Oþer yuel hit gyuen, ouer wikly gif. & þat wiþ fyght. " Wel bettere were hit al for-sake, " Þan suffre þe wo we þer-fore take; " Our costes ar grete, & [we] wone It is grete coste we. fer heþen, " & &yogh;e haue ay nede, & ar byneþen; " & we ne mowe nought we may not all way. come al day. " Doþ now &yogh;our self as &yogh;e best may! " May we ones take til Rome, " ffor no man eft schol we here come. " To saue &yogh;our self, bygynneþ bigynnes. now, " ffor we namore wil mayntene &yogh;ow. " Wyteþ wel, wittes wele. &yogh;our auncessours: " Were bolde & hardy conquerrours, " ¶ Belyn/ Constantyn/ & Maxymian/, Nota. Brytonum Inperatores. " Alle londes to Rome þey wan; " Þey mayntend hem self, & dide prowesse. " Bot now of &yogh;ow, oþer weis hit esse! ways is. " Y ne wot wher-on hit ys long, where it is long. " On &yogh;ow þer ne comeþ non oft comes non ofte. so strong " Þat &yogh;e ne myghte &yogh;ow self defende, " &yogh;yf any grace on &yogh;ow myghte desende. of &yogh;ow descend. " Bot &yogh;e [are] ere. al gon out of kynde; " &yogh;our wikkednesse now &yogh;e fynde! " Turneþ ageyn, & wexeþ Turnes agayn & waxes. bolde, " & þenkes thynk. on &yogh;our auncestres olde, " Þat riche regions conquered! " ffor fyght ne fondyng were þey ferd. " fful late schul &yogh;e now conquere, " Syn þat. route of rascaille may &yogh;ow ay fere. " Now schal bi sene what hit schal be sene what it may. vaille " When Outlandeys comen &yogh;ow to will &yogh;ow. assaille? " We haue &yogh;ow closed þer most nede was; " & &yogh;yf &yogh;e defende wel þat pas " Wyþ archers & wyþ mangeneles, " & wel kepe þe carneles, kirnels. " Þer-on &yogh;e may boþe scheote & kaste. " Wexeþ bolde, & fendeþ waxes bold & fende. &yogh;ow faste! " Þer Outlandeys aryues & rydes, P. omits the next four lines. " Makeþ þer hauenes to kepe þo sydes, " & at oþer recettes fele, " Þat non alien on &yogh;ow stele. " Þenk, &yogh;our fadres wonne fraunchise! þinkes &yogh;our fadres wan fran|chise. " Be &yogh;e namore in oþeres seruise, " Bot frely lyues lyf to. &yogh;our lyues ende! " We taken now leue, fro &yogh;ow to we will fro &yogh;ow for euer. wende." At þat word was mikel cry, ffor manion wep ful delfully. doelfulli. Was þer nought elles for to seye; Þe Romayns þem keste, kissed & went away. & wente þer weye, And seyden hem þere for certeyn Þey ne wolde her neuere come eft ageyn. Gwanyus Melga Guanius Melga. (Ganis et Magan, Wace , i. 296, l. 6399.) hadde þer spyes, Waytyng ay waitand. by stretes & styes How longe þe Romayns scholde suld. soiourne, & whan þey scholde suld. to Rome-ward tourne; & al so sone as þey forþ nam, Melga Gwaneys Melga Guanis. to þys lond cam, Robbed & brente Northumberland; Ageyns hem non encountre þei no cuntre ne. ne fand; Made þey neuere stynt ne stal Tyl þey come to þe Romayns wal. Þe Bretons were redy þeron aboute, To gyue bataille to þeym wyþoute: Þer myghte men se on boþe partys A scharp schour by-twyxten enemys; schaftes schoten bituex enmyes. Arewes, quareles, þykkely fleye, þikli flie. Wiþ slynges casten stones heye. Þo þat on þe wal faught, fful mykel scaþe sone þey so mykell skaþe non. laught; Þo þat were newe dobbed knyghtes, Þey couþe bot litel þo þei ne couth not &yogh;it. of fightes; The Petyt MS. adds, þei couth not þe querels scurne ne no quantise in bataile turne. Þe arewes come so þykke so als þik as. reyn, Þey couþe nought coeuere þer eye not couer þam. þer ageyn; & also þykkely come þe stones, Wiþ schot of dartes, with þe dartes &. al at ones; Vneþes myghte non kepe his eye, Þat he nas y poynt bakward to flye; Was þer non so hardy Bretoun, Þat hym ne þought long til he were doun. Þey wyþoute were mynynge myand. alle; Þe wal þey holede, & dide hit falle, & fulde filled. in fele stedes þe dyke, Þat wal & wey was euene y-like, & made þer-þorow pleyn passage Wyþ cart & wayn, wiþ to. hors & page. Þey robbed & slowen slouh. al aboute, ffor þey fond non þey hadde of doute; Byforn þat tyme befor or þat. no man fonde So manye at ones slayn in þys lond Wiþ so delful deþ & vyl, Of &yogh;onge knyghte, & so gentil. Whylom Bretons bere som tyme bretons bare, þe pris, Now al þer prowesse doun hit lys, & þorow hem schal hit neuere a-ryse, Bot þorow grace of oþer þer. queyntyse. Þen sent þey to Rome, to þe senatours, & preyed hem &yogh;ut of more socours. Þe Romayns saiden, 'þey ne wolde; ' To Bretayne þey neuere come ne scholde; ' On oþer halue þey hadde to do; ' Þey wolde namore be trauailled so, ' Bot gete þem help where þey myghte haue, ' Þey wolde þem neyþer slo ne saue.' Whan þe Romayns þus vs forsok, Þe date birth. of Cryst was wryten in bok, ¶ ffour hundred &yogh;er, & nyne, were gon Syn Iesu of Marye tok flesche & bon.
text.114: ¶ Hic miserunt Guncelinum Archiepiscopum ad Regem Minoris Brytannie. ¶ Al þe clergie of þe contrees, & lordynges of londes & fees, At Londone þey toke þer conseil, com all to a comon conseile. What myght hem helpe in þer turpeyl: how þei mot turne þat tirpeile. " Þys þei said. aliens al day vs noyes, " & þe Cristen blod destruyes. " Bot Iesu Crist visite vs sone, " We Cristen men schul be fordone." Þen was at Londone þe bischopes se, When Cristendam com gan. first to be. Þe Erchebischop highte Guncelyns, A ful holy clerk was a holy man clerk. in deuynes; Þys Erchebischop his conseil tok At þo þat þis lond schulden lok, Þat he wolde wende to þe Lasse Bretayne, Þer Conan vmwhile som tyme. was cheftayne. Aldroan highte Adroel hight. þe kyng was þan, Þe ferþe kyng after Conan. Þe bischop wente in to þe lond, Sire Aldroel þer kyng he fond; Þe kyng receyued hym curteysly— His fame was god, his stat was hey,— He asked what he so fer had sought, & what tydynge he hadde brought. " Lord," he seyde, "&yogh;ow þar nought wene, " Why y am comen &yogh;e may wel mene, " & what encheson me hider led, " Þat y to &yogh;ow so hastely hasty. sped; " ffor &yogh;e nar nought &yogh;e ne ere not. born so late, " Ne bytwyxt vs so fer gate, " Þat &yogh;e naue haf. herd tydynge seye, " How alyens don vs schamely deye. " Syþen Maximien went vs fro, " We han y-lyued in sorewe & wo. " Þat þys lond þorow conqueste wan, " & gaf hit þyn auncestre, sire Conan, " Oure doughti folk al wyþ hym went, " & siþen were we neuere bot schent. " Donward syþen haue we gon; " ffrendes fond we fewe or non " Þat euere vs wolde socoure or were; " Bot to fele we fynde þat wolde Inouh we fynd þat will. vs dere. " Whylom, som tyme. Bretons landes wonnen, " Þe renoun of þeym þorow lande ronne; remes ronen. " Now ar þey nought so mykel of myght " Þat þer lond may halde londes may hold. to ryght. " Þey of Rome halp vs whylom; " Now haue þey for-sake vs alle & sum, " ffor fer þer. wonyng & gret costage, " Þat often mys-spedde misferd. in þer passage. " Of folk we are ynowe &yogh;yt leued, " Bot kepere non, ne kyng, to heued, " Þat can oure folk to bataille lede, " Ne oure enemis to haue of no drede. " Bot we haue help by tyme One stroke too many in the MS. m. P. at þis tyme. now " Of oþer landes, oþer of &yogh;ow, " We kenne neuere cone not. oure cursed kare, " So fer doun byneþe we are. " I ne may nought telle, for sor of for sore. herte, " Al oure sorewe þat ys so how it is. smerte, " Þat we han had, & &yogh;it haue; " Bot God wyle, nought may vs saue. " Here-fore am y to &yogh;ow comen, " As to kyþ of oure kynde & our kyn. nomen, " ffor &yogh;e ar Brutes, ere brettis. & we Breton; " & for þat skyle & þat reson, " Help vs now to venge our foo, " As we wolde &yogh;ow & for an , if. P. if. &yogh;e were wo. " Þorow right lawe write men fynde, writen we fynd. " Þat men oughte to helpen auh to help; and leaves out the next two lines. þer kynde; " & hit ys also worldes honur, " At nede þer frendes for to socour. " Þey no sybrede of kynde cam, " Helpe &yogh;e scholde Crystendam." Whan Aldroel herde so Gwyncelyn speke, ffor sorewe hym þoughte his herte wolde breke; Þe teres ronnen out of his eyne, ffor þat þey were in so gret pyne, Gretand ageyn he hym answered, " ffor þe doel þat y haue herd, " Y schal do al my trauaille " Þat y to &yogh;ow may helpe or vaille. 1 " &yogh;yf y myghte my self, y wolde my self wald. fayn, " Bot Frensche men frankis men. me chace ageyn; 1 1-1 Wace gives these two lines after the sailing of Constantine, l. 6569-70 ( Wace. ) " Þey werre on me al þat þey may, " My self am þer a[t] ylka fray; at ilk assay. " I wol nought leue my litel þynge, " Myn heritage, for more wynnynge; MS. wymnynge. " I haue a broþer, sire Constaunt, MS. Constantyn. P. has Con|stant. " God werrour, & man valliaunt; " Wyþ two þousand trois mil armés, Wace , l. 6553. y schal hym sende, " Wyþ gode knyghtes, &yogh;our lond to fende; " Hym to Bretaigne schaltow lede, " Þorow gode grace for godes grace wele. to spede." He sente þenne for Constantyn, & bytaughte hym sire Gwyncelyn. Whan Guncelyn byheld þe knyght/, Þe hand he lyfte þat was þe ryght, & gaf Constant þe benisoun: Þe knyght byfore hym kneled doun, Þe bisschop foure wordes seyde; Þe wordes arn, o ere of. Latyn leyde, " Christus vincit, Christus rengnat! " Christus vincit, Christus inperat! imperat. " Þe kyng þen bitaughtym four þousand bitauht him knyghtes tuo þousand. (trois milliers, Wace , l. 6564.) Of men of armes wel tuo þousand squiers þam. seruand, & þre þousand men of fote. Þe kyng þan seyde, "Þys kyng said þise. may do bote " To saue &yogh;our lond ilka del. " My kynde þer-inne, gret þem wel." Syre Guncelyn aryued at Toteneys, & sire Constant wyþ his harneys. Þat herde þe Bretons alle aboute, Þo þat er skulked for drede & doute. Out of wodes & out of mountaynes (Þat durste nought er þat durst not are. come to þe playnes,) To Constant come þen men ynowe, Þat þer enemys ouer al slowe. He dide hym vntil Westmorland; Þe countre al wasted he fand; Al þe lond, leye hit lay, Þe folk for fere wer for pouerte. fled away; Hadde þey nought vn-to þe þer. fode, Bot bestes wylde, & fische on in. flode. Þeyr enemys þer þey broughte of lyue, Þe remenaunt out of lond gon dryue.
text.115: ¶ Apud Cirencestriam coronatus est Rex Constantinus. To Circestre Constant wente, & held þer a parlymente. Sire Guncelyn þer gaf hym þe coroun; Þer-of was fayn ilka Bretoun. Þenn tok he wyf auenaunt & god, Sib þe bischop, of Romayns blod. Þ[r]e childre on hure he gat auenaunt, Þe eldest, highte his name Constant; He dide hym norice norish. at Wynchestre, And &yogh;ald mad. hym monk in þat same estre; Þat oþer sone highte Aurelyus, His to-name was Ambrosius; Þe þridde child, Vter he hight, Þat lyuede lengest, & best was knyght. Þe bischop, þorow leue of þe kynge, Hadde þe two in his kepynge. &yogh;yf Constant had lyued ani sel, any seele. He schuld haue mended þe lond ful wel; Two ten. &yogh;er he regned, & namo; Lyst how a traitour dide hym slo: ¶ On ffortyger, of Walsche blod, One Vortiger of Wales blode. Þat neuere in truþe no stude stod, while stode. He &yogh;erned mikel þe kyndam. Lyst how þe treson fro hym listes how þis treson for him. cam:
text.116: ¶ De quodam Pycto traditore. Y þe kynges court serued a Peyght, Þat was þorow ffortegers deseit; þorgh Vortigers sleiht. — Þis Peit, longe wiþ þe kyng had ben; Of treson he þoughte ay by-twen; Þys Peyt &yogh;ede wyþ þe kynge a day Vntil In to. an herber alone to play; Bot hit was perceyued of non Whider þe kyng & þe Peyt was gon. Þe kyng of treson wende nought, Bot þe Peyt þeron he þought; As þey boþe to-gyder sat, & speken þer of many what, Þe kyng til hym gaf no tent. Þat saw þe Peyt, & his knyf out hent, & smot þe kyng vntil to. þe hert, & fledde awey also smert. Pryuely þat fame &yogh;ede Þat fforteger had don Vortiger gart do. þat dede. fforteger was of þe Walscherye, an erle þat lufed tricherie. Þat euere louede trycherye; 4 . Queynte he was, & fer couþe þenke To compasse a wykked blenke; 4 4-4 Wace, lines 6638-40. ffaire he spak þer he wolde gyle; & þer he hated, þer wolde he smyle; Wel couþe he preyse & lakke somdel, & treson couþe he teche wel:— & somme þat arn at þis tyme here, Þat craft of hym nought nedeþ þat of him þar no thyng. lere.—
text.117: ¶ De electione Constanti Monachi in Regem. ¶ Þe clergie for þis dide make asemble, Whilk of þe children best kyng myght childre kyng mot. be; Bot þey were so lytel & &yogh;onge, Reson couþe þey non wiþ tonge. Constant was eldest & mere, & was a monk, a man of lere. Þey seide atones, alle & som, it myght not be don. Þem noughte nout (=ne oughte not.) P. ne oughte not. reue hym fro religion; to take him fro religion. Ne lawe nolde hit by no weye, of no right we se no way. A monk to take fro his abbeye: To take an oþer, þe take on þe tuo þer. Conseil ches. Þen stirte vp Forteger in al þe pres, & seide, "Hit is to drede no þyng, " Of þe monk to make a kynge. " He ys eldest;—of þe habite no tale!— " Þe oþere arn &yogh;onge, & ouer smale. " Y graunte non oþer kyng to be. " ffor al þe synne, y take on me." Non oþer assented to þat dome, Þat þe monk scholde a kynge bycome; Þey dredden dred. swylk a þyng bygynne; Bot fforteger dredde dred. nought þat synne: What he wold do, non durste hym werne, To Wynchestre he hyed hym &yogh;erne, He asked leue atte priour To speke wyþ Constant y þe parlour: ¶ " Constant," he seide, "þy lord ys ded; " Þy breþere ar &yogh;onge; what ys þy red? " Y wolde þou haddest I. wild þou had. þe herytage, " ffor þou art man most of age. " Wiltow will. auaunce my rente, my fe, " & loue me wel, & triste on me. " Þy blake cloþes schalt sall. þou loþe, " & y þe richest y schal sall. þe cloþe; " Þy monkhod þow schalt sall. al weyue, " Þe heritage of þe reome reseyue." Þys monk was blent wyþ veyn glorye; monke &yogh;erned seignorie. Abyte & ordre he let al flye, ffor he &yogh;erned more pryde þan prow, & wel more vice þan vertu. Þat fforteger asked, he hym hight, & þer-to his trouþe he dide hym plyght. Out of his abite he hym schok, Syþen out of þe abbeye hym tok; In faire cloþes he hym cledde, Wyþ hym to Londone Constant he ledde. London he him led. Was noman wyþ-seyde hym o no man þat said him. nay; Þey seye hit was þe monkes sawe it was þe mokes [so in MS.]. pay. To somone þe folk anon þey bed; non ne beed. Bot þerchebischop þat tyme was ded P. adds (wrongly) line 7086 again:— with him to London Constant he led.
