Þat felle to make þe corounement; Þer-to non oþer durste consent; Bot fforteger þe coroune forþ fet, And on Constantes heued hit set; 5 [was þer non oþer benyson, bot Vortiger set on þe croun,] 5 5-5 These two lines are from the Petyt MS., representing lines 6677-8 of Wace, i. 308. & Constant þe coroune tok, & ordre & habite al forsok; Þus to worschipe gan he lende, Wiþ schame he parted schame departid. at his ende.
text.118: ¶ Hic ffortygernus traditor factus est custos Regny sub Monacho Rege. Þenne ffortyger hadde alle þe maystrie, Þe kyng at wille, & þe marchalsye; marchaucie. (senescaucie, Wace , i. 308, l. 6695.) Al to-gedere þe kyng he ledde, & al he dide þat he hym redde; Þe kyng dide al as fforteger wylde, & al his conseil he fulfylde. He saw þe kyng couþe no god, Ne kynde skile nought vnderstod; 8 [on clostire skill couth he maste, & his breþer with þe leste.] 8 8-8 These two lines are from P., leaf 42 back, column 2, and represent Wace's lines 6701-2, vol. i. p. 309. He sey þe force of þe barons falle, & saw his stat heyest of alle, 1 [þe folk discord nouht in a will; þan he þouht in hert full still,] 1 1-1 These two lines are from P., and represent Wace's lines 6705-6, vol. i. p. 309. & þoughte þe regne haue in to haf þe regne on. his syde; Her whuche a deseyte here a desceite. he spak þat tyde: ¶ "Of o þyng, sires, sir. y wot right wel, " þer-of &yogh;e owen to wyte auh to witte. som del, " Þat þe Daneys, wyþ men of Northweye, with þe Norweíe. " On &yogh;ow wyl þey lyue & deye; " & for þou art no knyght ert no kyng. of armes, " Þe more þey wayte þis lond wyþ harmes; " On vs þey wyle þis somer þe soner. haste, " Þy casteles take, þy lond to-waste; " Here-of y rede þou nyme take. &yogh;eme, " Þy lond to fende, þy folk to queme." In casteles he sette garnysons castels set þi warnisours. ffor þe drede of oþer traysons; traitours. " To þo þat castels couþe loke, " To swylke y wolde þat þou hem toke." Þan seyde þe kyng to ffortyger, " Tak þou þe lokyng take þe kepyng. in þy power; " As þou wilt, hit schal be so; " Ouer þe wol y þat noman do; " Þe castelles alle y þe bykenne, biken . . . . . bren. " Now loke þat noman slo ne brenne. " In þy conseil onlyk am conseile þan. y, " Loke to me þou do truely. " Of cites & of tresor al; " Right as þou wilt, so be hit schal." ¶ Þenne was ffortyger at ese, ffor alle þe strengþes he gan to sese. þe forcelettes he did him seise. When he had alle þys forceresses, now has Vortiger þe forcelesse. Wyþ cites, tounes, & alle richesses, richesse. &yogh;yt he þoughte on oþer on oþer. wyse To contreoue a fals queyntyse: " Sire," he seyde, " &yogh;yf þou wilt do " Þat y schal conseille þe to, " Þy lond schaltow ful wel saue, " & do þyn enemys of þe stond awe. & of þin enmys no drede haue. " Sent for knyghtes þat conne of sleytes. Sende . . . . . can of sleghtes. " & þat ar bolde men in feyghtes; quante men ere alle þe peihtes. (Des Pis d'Escoce soldiers, Wace , i. 310, l. 6742.) " Lat þeym be alle þy souders, " ffor of alle kyndes þey knowe þe maners; " ffor &yogh;yf þey be y þy court wyþynne, " On whilk side þat what tyme so any. werre bygynne, " Þen may þou sende hem aboute, " To serche of wham þer ys most of whom is moste. doute, 10 " Þaw þe Peytes & þeir kendes, " Þat ofte han schewed þey were oure frendes." 10 10-10 þorgh þe peihtes & þer frendes. may men witte how mykell wendes.
text.119: ¶ Exe iam tradicio falsy ffortygerny. Þe kyng to fforteger þus seyd: " My purueaunce purueiance. ys on þe leyd; " Do ryght als þy seluen wyle; " Tak & lef as þou sest sees . . . . . has . . . . . wote. skyle, " Als manye as þou hast sees . . . . . has . . . . . wote. of nede; " Bettere þan y þou wost sees . . . . . has . . . . . wote. þe dede." Þen fforteger had his wille ynow; An hundred Peyghtes to þe court he drow. Of castles, tounes, & tresorye, Of al he hadde þe maystrie; He gaf þe Peytes what þey wyld, Al þer askyng he fulfyld, He honured hem swyþe mykel, ffor wel he wyste þey were ful fykel; Wyþ metes & drynkes he made þem glade, & often dronken he þem made; He preised hem faste in his sawe, & oueral dide þem forþ drawe; fforby alle oþere bifor oþer. he þem honured; Þat mester hadde, he þem socourred; Þer-fore comunly ylka Peight, Byfore alle þey seyde on heyght, " Þat fforteger was more curteys " Þan þe kyng was ony weys, " & bettere semed to bere þe honur " Þan þe kyng or his auncessour." In ilka stede whare als. þey ferde, Þus þey seyde; þey ne roughte ho herde. & for þe Peytes on hym seyde þis, fforteger þer-of had gret blys; & þe more þat þey hym preysed, Þe more he þem vp areysed.
text.120: ¶ De Adulacione ffortygerny. A day hit was, to þeym he drank ffor to gete of hem more þank; & right as þey dronke als þei sat drunken. & songe, Com fforteger þeym alle among, & to þem seyde, "God glade &yogh;ow here!" Bot yuel he let, wyþ sory chere. " Knyghtes," he seide, "mykel y &yogh;ow loue, " I haue &yogh;ow holpen to &yogh;oure aboue, " & more y wolde, &yogh;yf y hadde ought; " Þys [lond] lond. (ceste tere, Wace , i. 312, l. 6780.) ys þe kynges, & myn ys nought; " Here hauy nought þat ought amountes; " Þat y spend of, y &yogh;elde acountes, " ffor y þys contre lond. (ceste tere, Wace , i. 312, l. 6780.) haue y nought; " ffro fer hit comeþ þat me ys brought. " To serue þe kyng y do my tent; " Of hym hauy no lond ne rent, " So þat y may nought holde to me " ffourty squiers sergeanz. (sergans, Wace , i. 312, l. 6788.) on al my fe; " &yogh;yf y more hadde, hit were &yogh;our prow, " Þer-fore nede y mot parte bot nedes .I. mot. fro &yogh;ow; " & þat ouer-þynkes forþenkes. me ful sore, " ffor pouere y am, & may namore. " Bot &yogh;yf &yogh;e se þat y ought mende, " Boldely comeþ to me, or sende, " And y schal fonde, at al &yogh;our nede, " Boþe forto cloþe & [to] fede."
text.121: ¶ Exe iam falcitas ffortygerny. Fortyger þenne turned his bak; Fals he was, & feyntyse spak; And þo þat hadden dronke wel, Trowed his sawes falsnes. P. leaves out the next two lines. ylkadel; His word to truþe al þey hit turned, Þat he to falsnesse had perforned; Þey seide til oþer, "what haue &yogh;e mynt? " Þys curteys knyght man. now haue we tynt. " Þys folted king, he gyueþ kyng serues. vs lytel, " ffor a monk can nought bot his chapitel. " To slo þat folt, wel were to it. done; " A bettere myghte we haue ful sone; " Go we now, & sle þat vnþrift/, " & ffortyger to kyng we lyft, " ffor he ys worþy to haue he were worþi to haf. empyre, " & bettere hym he. semed lord & syre " Þan þis monk þat nought ne can; " Go we & sle þis folted þat foltid. man! " He haþ no kynde þat vs þarf þar. drede, " Þat myghte may[n]tene host ne lede; " Ne hym self schal neuere be nought; " Go we & do þat we haue þought!" Þe whyles to while. þer wylle was þus hot, Þey stirte tys chaumbre to his chambire. ; his hed of smot. Wyþ þe heued als swyþe þey went, To ffortyger þey made a present, Þey gon to crie, "here may þow se " Þat we wyl auaunce þe! " Þis monk ys ded! now do þy wylle! " Tak þe coroune, & hold vs stylle!" ffortyger, þat saw þe kynges heued, Glad he was þey haddyt hym reued; Naþeles he couerede hym queyntely; Semblaunt he made he was sory, & for þat dide þo Peytes deye, & more to did his felonys. And at Londone he dide crye, þerfor in London did he crie. 'Þat al þe Peyghtes þat men myght wyte, 'Þer heuedes scholde al of be þer hedes of suld men. smyte.' Manyon were þat trowed & seyd, Þat 'non of þeym hadde handes leyd ' On þe kyng wyþ yuel ill. manere ' Wyþoute þe conseyl of ffortygere;' & þe Peyghtes seyde þe same, Þat þey dide hit for his frame. Þo þat þe children had in kepyng, Aurelius & Vter, boþe &yogh;yng, Dredde þat þorow þe conseil of þo Þat slowen þe kyng, þem wolde þey slouh þe kyng þam wild. slo; Þer-fore þis conseil þey tok, To Bretayne þey sentem, hem to lok, To þe kyng Budice of þer kynde, Þat ful nobly dide hem fynde, And honured hem þorow al the lond; When tyme was, armes hem fond.
text.122: ¶ Hic cepit Regnare ffortygernus. Fortiger had al in kepynge þe land, Casteles, & cites, al in hys hand; & at his wylle þe folk he ledde; ffor his power, noman he dredde; He sey fortune toward hym he sauh his chance wele wild. falle, And regned þen kyng ouer þeym alle. Of two þynges wakned hys wough; Of þe Peytes þat he slough; Þey cald hym traitour wyþ manace, & to meschaunce þey scholde mischefe þei suld. hym chace; An oþer þyng men hym telde, Þat whan þe childre were of elde, Þey scholde venge Constant her broþer; War were . . . . . no noþer. hym wel, & hope non oþer.
text.123: In tempore ffortygerny venerunt Saxones primo in Anglia. This heading is at the top of the front page of of the Lambeth MS., as a head-line. Whyle þat fforteger þus In tyme þat Vortiger. regnede riche, Þre schypes aryued at Sandwiche Wyþ fair folk & wel y-dight,— Hengist & Hors þer maistres hight;— Of fair stature wyþouten lak, & a selcouþ speche þey spak. Þis ffortyger þat held þonour, At Caunterbury he made soiour; To þe kyng men tydynge tolde, ' Þat a fair folk, wyþ faces bolde, ' At Sandwyche late gonne aryue; ' So faire y-schape were non alyue.' so gentill of schap is hon of lyue. Þen seyde þe kyng, "&yogh;yf swylk be comen, " & peysibly þe hauene han & in pes haf hauen. nomen, " In pes lat þem take þer rest, " & wyþ my pes to do þer best, " And &yogh;yf þey speke wyþ me in pes, " & right & in þat. so wende als þey ches."
text.124: ¶ Hengistus, & Horsus frater eius, cepunt portum apud Sandwycum. ¶ When þyse breþere Hengist & Hors Had leue of þe kyng & of þe ports, He greyþed his feres þei dight þer fers. to fare al myry To speke wyþ þe kyng at Caunterbyri. When þey come, þe kyng þey grette, & alle þat were by hym sette. Þe kyng byheld þyse bachelers Were faire of schap, & face clers, How þey were mad so gentilly, ffayrest of al þer compaigny: Þen seyde þe kyng, "of whenne what lond. be &yogh;e? What haue &yogh;e sought to þis contre?" Þen was Hengist eldest & more; ffor alle his feres onswered he þore: " In Saxoyne sessoyne. were we born & fed; " ffro þennes þien (no fro ). hyder our God vs led. " &yogh;yf ye wil wite al þe manere, " Whi & for what we ar com here; " To telle &yogh;ow, sire, gyues þe sir gif þou. me leue, " Þat &yogh;e ne &yogh;oure þou ne þin. wyþ me ne greue." Þe kyng gaf hym þe grauntyse, & Hengist teldym þen in tellis on. his wyse: " Sire kyng," he seyde, "&yogh;yf þou euere herde, " So waxynge waxand. folk in al þys werde, " Ne so gendryng, genderand. ne so plentyue, " Ne so gracious kynde þrod (? for þeod (A.-S. þeod ) peo|ple; or A.-S. þreot, þreat , a crowd). to þryue, " Als we arn of oure kynde, " In no lond scholde men fynde, " Ne selcouþloker so ne so selcouþly. to gendre, " Ne haue so manye childre tendre, " & wexen boþe men & women y-nowe, " Þat alle þer dwelle þey ne mowe. duelle ne mouh. " ffor whan þe folk ar woxen & larged, is waxen & largid. " & þe lond ys ouer-charged, " Oure Prynces perceyue þer ar so fele, " Þe &yogh;onge dur þey nought out wele, þe &yogh;enge þorgh þei do wele. ( wele = choose: see page 98, note what lond. .) " Bot þulke of twenty þat ere of fiften. (qui de quinze ans sunt, et de plus, Wace , i. 319, l. 6911.) wynter elde " Or more, þat con þem kepe & welde, " On strong[e] stronge. men, lotes þey kest, " & byddem bid þam. go purchace þem best, " To seke oþer lond & lede, " ffor so. mykel people may hit nought fede. " Mo childre þer are of oure gendrure " Þan bestes are in oure pasture; " & for we so multeplye, " We ar of þe kynde of Germenie. " At þis tyme fel on vs þe lot, " Þer-fore, nede, of lande of ond nede. we mot, " To seke vs oþer on to lende; " & hidere oure Godes dide vs wende; 6 " Mercurius, þat vs saues & schildes, " Haþ vs brought vnto þys yldes." 6 6-6 P. leaves out these two lines. When þe kyng herde hym nemne a God, herd þam neuen. He asked þenne how þey trowd, trod (see next note). & what þer Godes name hight, On wham þey trowed whilk þei trowed. had most myght. He seide, "We haue Godes seeres sere. " ffor whos wyrschip we make auteres; to whom we mak autere. " Mars, Iubiter, & Saturnus, " Dyane, & Mercuryus: " Þis ar Godes of oure paen lay, " Þat we worschipe wirschip. at þer day. " & mo Godes &yogh;yt we holde, " As oure auncestres by-forn vs tolde; " Bot on ouer alle wyrschipe wirschip. we mest, " Sire Mercurius, & holde his fest. Nota de die Mercurii & Veneris. " Mercury ys on oure langage " 'Woden,' louerd, ys oure vsage,— " Oure auncessour set hit so,— " Þe ferþe day we halewe hym to. " ffor we þat day worschipen hym alle, " 'Wodenesday' þat day we calle. " Wyþouten hym an oþer we haue, " A Godesse þat we for help to craue; " On oure speche we calle hure ffre; " Þe sixte day, hure worschipe we; " ffor 'ffre' we calle hit ffryday, it freaday. (Freedai, Wace , i. 321, l. 6950.) " & worschipe hure on payen lay." ¶ Þen seide þe kyng, "&yogh;e leue al wronge; " Wyþ false Godes &yogh;e make monge; " On swylk ar nought for to leue, " Hit ar ffendes þat schol &yogh;ow greue; " & þat sore ouer-þynkes forþinkes. me; " Naþeles," he seyde, "welcome ar welcom ere. &yogh;e! " ffayre men &yogh;e are, & stalworthe seme. " And &yogh;e wyl serue me to queme, " Euerilkon y wyl &yogh;ow take, " & riche men y schal &yogh;ow make. " Þe Peytes wayten me wyþ wo, " Þe Scottes also vs brenne robbe. & slo; " &yogh;yf hit be so, &yogh;e may me vaille " To vencuse venquis. þem in pleyn bataille; " Gyftes schol &yogh;e haue ful gode " Til &yogh;oure cloþynge & &yogh;our fode; " & kepes wel ay þe Northe cost; þe north kepis ay wele þat cost. A fresh hand writes a page here in the Petyt MS., (leaf 44, back) and the initial qw - for wh - comes in: see notes 9 , 10 , p. 261, below. " ffro þennes comen ouer al þeyr þine comys euere all oþer. ost. " Loke y fynde in &yogh;ow no feyntyse; " &yogh;e schul me serue of swylk seruise." On þys manere come þe Saxouns sessouns. Þorow ffortyger among þe Bretouns. Hengist tok leue at þe kynge, To Londone lond. for to brynge his þyng; & sone com to þe court agayn Wyþ manye faire knyght & swayn.
text.125: ¶ De Bello inter Saxones & Pyctos. Wel sone after þat was it not long sethen. þey were come, Þe Scottes & Peytes bataille nome, And comen faste in-til þys lond, Pylede robbid. & brente al þat þey fond; Right reght. to Humber water þey cam. Þe kyng wyþ Saxons sessons. ageyn þem nam. Þe Saxons sessons. were þer-of ful blyþe, Þey arrayed hem wel, & þydeward swyþe, dyght þem wele & þidir swiþe. Þey smyte to-gedere bataille smert; Þe Peytes were euere ful egre of hert, Þey stode wel furst & hardyly; ffor þey were wond to haue þe wer won haue. maistri. Þey wende haue had þer elde custume, Þe lenger ageyn þe Bretons þey nome. Þer wenyng þat day þey tynt, ffor þe Saxons sessons. did þem bakward stynt, 9 [& were discounfet at þat dai; þe Sessons bare þe prise a-wai.] 9 9-9 From P., representing lines 6995-6 of Wace (i. 323). Þen was þe kyng a ioly ioiefull. man Þat he þe bataille of þem so wan; Þen let he mykel þe king lete mikill. of þe Saxons, sessons. & dide hem amende þer liuersons. did amend þer liueresons. Þe kyng gaf Hengist faire of his. maners In Kent, & fele oþere stedes seers: In Lindesai in stedis sers. (In Londesìa regione, Galf. Mon. , vi. 11; Lindesée, MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3. Colb.; Lindesie, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé, Wace , i. 323.) Þys loue lested bytwyxt þem longe, ffeyþfullike, wel & strong. Hengist sey til hym þe word wold schape, saw þe werld wild skape. His nedes to spede þen had he rape; for to spede & rape. He sey oþ er do MS. to. P. has do. (Wace's comment 'Comme cascuns faire 'devroit,' (i. 323, l. 7006), on Hen|gist's 'D'avancir soi s'entremetoit,' is not translated.) þer queyntyse, Wher-of auauntage myghte aryse, qwere-of auauntige mote rise. & also þoughte he þan seye som þynge ffor to plese wyþ-al þe kyng. On a day by þe kyng he sat, To-gydere spekynge of many what; spekin of mani qwat. He sey þe kyng was mury wele. at ese, Wyþ his conseil he gan hym plese: " Sire," he seis, "&yogh;e han do Sir king þou has done. me honour, " & mykel y haue y-take had. of &yogh;our. " &yogh;yf y haue serued þe to wille, " &yogh;yt bettere wol y forward fulfylle; " & mikel haue y herd & seen " Syþen y haue y þy court y-ben; Alls I haue in þi court bien. " ffor þou hast neyþer baron ne knyght, " Þat alle ne hate þe wyþ her all þe hate at þer. myght. " Of two childre y here þem speke, " Þat on þe harde schul of þe ful herd þei sall. þem wreke; " Þer lige lordes þey scholden suld. ben, " Þorow heritage of þer faderes fe; " & bynne schort terme In scort time. schul suld. þey come, " & of vs boþe take harde dome: " & þis ys þe comune sawe of alle, " Þat yuel An iuell ('ill' was the first scribe's word). endyng on þe schal suld. falle. " Þus þey þrete wyþ Þei þe with ill. manace, " & ful yuel þey And to. procure & purchace. " When y here þem þus &yogh;elpe, " Þen þenky þink .I. how y myght &yogh;ow helpe; " Þer-fore to Saxoyne woldy sende, in to sesson wild .I. send. " ffor my sib kynde, & oþer freinde; " & &yogh;if y her hadde childre or &. wyf, " Þen were y holden, on lymes & lyf, " Þe forto socoure & to saue " Wyþ al þe strengþe On all þe purtenaunce. y myghte haue; " Þe sikerer mightest þow mote þou. be for me, " & y scholde deserue more loue of i suld be loued bettir for. þe; " ffor alle þyn enemis, þaw þey wild enmis þou ne. fond, " Ne durste nought reue þe a fot of lond. " ffor y þe serue & loue truely, " Haue y on me many enemy; " & y lyg euere so naked syde, " & oure fomen spred ful wyde; " &yogh;yf y had ony fforcelet, " To haue þer-inne som haue on. syker recet, " Þen myghte we þe more be syker, " What tyme our enemis wold giue vs byker. " Þer-fore wer hit prow to þe " Þat y hadde som oiþer in the first scribe's hand again]. castel or cite " Where-inne y mighte sauely slepe, " Þat none enemis on vs lepe; " [wele more þan, þei wild me doute] From the Petyt MS. " Þan þey do now y lygge þer-oute." Þenne seide þe kyng vnto Hengist, " Þorow sonde y wolde þy folk hit wist, " Þat þey were her when we had nede; " Inow þey scholden haue sall haf. to mede. " To gyue þe a toun, y ne may, " ffor þou art of þe Payen lay; " ffolye hit were, more þan resoun, " To gyue a Payen a Cristen toun; " Of oþer þyng þe entermet, " ffor of toun getestow no recet."
text.126: ¶ De cordys Corey Taury. 3 " Syn þou," seide Hengist, " wyþseyst þat me, " A skylful preiere þou graunte me: " Of þy maners þat y mot haue— " Wher-inne þat y may my lif saue— 3 3-3 Said Hengist, if þou will nouht. ne dar not gif .I. þe of souht. on of þi maners þat . I. haue. grante it me myself to saue. " Namore lond, ne no more lond. wyd ne syd, " Þan y may sprede a boles hyd." Þat graunted anon kyng ffortygerne. Þen Hengist of sente his frende &yogh;erne; A boles hyde, he broughte hit þyder; On þonges he carf hit al thuonges he karue it all. to-gyder, And knytte hem alle þen on o þonge; & al so fer as hit was long, & euenlik al so mykel in brede, Þe lond he tok hit ouer &yogh;ede. Þe lond aboute he dide hit stake, A fforcelet þer-on þan dide he make, & on his wyse langage. he gaf hit name, ' Þe Castel of Þonges,' Vancastre ( Wace , i. 327), MS. du Roi, 27; Gancastre, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé; Tuancastre, MS. de l'Ars., 171, B.-L. þe firste fame; Syn, als schorter speche fel, Hit was called 'þong castel;' thuangcastell. Bot Frenschemen couþe nought so seye, & caldit 'Castel de Correye;' Þat vse uses. men by&yogh;onde þe se, & Bretons caldit 'Kaer Karre.' Wace adds that many now call it 'Lancastre' who don't know the cause of its first name, l. 7082-4.
text.127: ¶ Exe Castellum factum est, cui dedit nomen Þongcastre. When Þongcastre thuang castell. was al closed, Þe name y-gyuen, giffen. oueral alosed, Of þo þat Hengyst sente his sonde, Þer comen sexten schipe xiij. schippis. (dix huit nés, Wace , i. 327, l. 7087; decem et octo naues, Galf. Mon. vi. 12.) to londe, Wyþ mikel folk, knyghtes, swaynes, & oþere þat were of his demaynes. ¶ In a schip wyþ gentil geentill . The second scribe wrote this column and the next two: see his q, -it, -is, -in , in the notes 10 , p. 266; 13 , p. 264; 11 , p. 266; 1 , 12 , p. 265. men Com Hengiste doughter þat hight Ronewen, Roven, Wace , i. 328, l. 7091. A &yogh;ong woman & louely, a fair woman & a loueli. Auenaunt, & fair & semly; auenaunt gret & fair was hi. Bot þis lewed men sey & synge, & telle þat hit was mayden Inge. and tellit it was a may din &yogh;inge. Wryten of Inge, writin of Ingge. Robert Man|ning poohpoohs this Inge notion again, when writing of King Engel, near the end of the first part of his Stori. no clerk may kenne, Nota de nomi|ne Engelond. ( In a later hand. ) Bot of Hengiste doughter, Ronewenne. Al þe folk Hengist fore sent; To Þoncastre thuang castell. P. leaves out the next four lines, 7539-42. ilkon þey went. (ffro Angle, a contre in Saxonye, Comen alle Hengistes compaynie; So þat for Angle, y vnderstond, Bretayne was cald Engelond.) Þen Hengiste faste hym purueyd, A day Hengest him purueid. & sente unto þe kyng, & seyd, ' Preyenge, Praid him. as he loued his griþ, ' Þat he wolde ony night herberwe A night herber. him wyþ, ' A day to ete a sop, & drynke, ' & se his werk, how þat hym þynke; ' & of his folk, how þat hym þought, ' & wyþholden & held. þo þat to hym dought.' Hengystes þe king his. werk fayn wolde he se; He &yogh;ede þider al in pryuete. Whan he hit saw, wel he hit preised, & þat þer myght be folk wel aysed; þat þus myght folk be wele asaied. & þo knyghte knightes. þat late cam, ffor þer sonde wyþ hym þey nam. Hengist þat day dide his myght Þat al was wer. glad, kyng & knyght; & als þey were best in gladyng, & wel cuppe-schoten, cop schotin. (enivré, Wace , i. 239, l. 7108.) knyght & kyng,
text.128: ¶ Exe Ronewenna, pulcra puella, quam Rex fforty|gerus desponsauit secundum legem Paganorum. ffro chaumbre cam Ronewenne so gent, Byfore þe kyng in halle scheo went; A coupe wyþ wyn sche hadde in hande, And hure atyr hir hatir. was wel farande; Byfore þe kyng o knes sche hir sette, In hure langage ful faire him grette: " Wassayl, my lord! wassail!" Lauerid king/ wassaill. seyd sche. Wassail. Þen asked þe kyng what þat myght þe king askid what suld. be: On þat langage þe kyng ne couþe, Bot a knygh[t] þat speche had lered langage lerid. in &yogh;ouþe— Breyþ Bre&yogh;. highte þat knyght, y-born Bretoun, Þat wel spak langage of Saxoun. þat lerid þe langage of sessoun. Þys Breþ was þe kynges latynier; Bre&yogh; was þe latinier. — & what scheo seyde, teldyt ffortyger: told Vortager. " Sire," Breþ seyde, " Ronewenne &yogh;ow gretes, " And kyng calles, & lord &yogh;ow letes; " Þys ys þer custume & þer gest, " Whan they arn at þer [ale or] are at þe ale or. fest, " Ilk man þat loues, þer hym best þynk louis qware him þink. " Schal sey 'wassail,' & to hym drynk; " He þat haldes schal sey bidis sall say. 'wassayl,' " Þat oþer schal seye ageyn 'drynk hayl'; " Þat seys [wassayl] drynkes sais wosseill drinkis. of þe coppe; " Kissing his felawe, he gyueþ Kissand his felaw he giues. hit vppe; " 'Drynk hail,' he seyþ, & drynkeþ drinks. þer-of, " Kyssyng kissand. hym in bourde & scof." Þe kyng seide as þe knight gan kenne, " Drynk hayl," smylynge Drinkheill smiland. on Ronewenne. Ronewenne drank right as hure lyst, & gaf þe kyng, & syn hym gaue þe king sine him. kist.— Þat was þe firste wassail in dede, Þat now & euere þe & þat first of. fame &yogh;ede. Of þat wassail men tolde gret tale, & vsed 'wassail' when þey were at þale, & 'drynkhail' to þem þat drank; Þus was wassail take tane. to þank.— 5 . fful often þus þys ffele sithes þat. mayden &yogh;yng Wassailed & kyste þer þe kyng; 5 5-5 These lines are in the MS. de Ste. Gen. Y. of Wace, fol. 10. Wace , i. 332, note b. Of body sche was ful auenaunt, Of fair colour, wyþ swet semblaunt. Hure atir, ful wel hit bysemed; Hir hatire full wele it semid. Merueillyke þe kyng scheo Meruelike þe king sche. quemed; Out of mesure was he glad, Opon ffor of. þat mayden he wax al mad. Þe ffend & dronkenesse hit wrought; Drunkenes þe feend. On Of. þat Payen was al his þought. As meschaunce þat tyme One stroke too many in the MS. m. hym spedde, A meschaunche þat time him led. He asked þat Payen for to wedde; & Hengist wernde hym bot Hengist wild noght draw o. lyte, Bot graunted hure hym al so tyt; & Hors his broþer consented sone; Hire frendes seyd alle, hit was Hir frendis said it were. to done; Þey askede þe kyng to gyue gife. hure Kent, In dowarye, to take of rent. Vpon þat mayde his herte so kast, What-so þey asked, þat þei askid. þe kyng mad fast. I wene þe kyng tok hure þat day, & wedded hure on Payens lay. Of prest was þer no benisoun, Ne messe songen, ne orysoun; In sesyn þe kyng had hure seisine he had hir. (si l'ot, Wace , l. 7183.) þat nyght; Of Kent he gaf Hengist þe ryght. Þe Erl þat tyme þat Kent Erell . . . . . Kent all. held, Sire Gorogon, þat bar had. þe scheld, Of þat gyft no þyng he ne wyste Til he was dryuen out To he was cast oute. wyþ Hengist. Þe Payens conseil þe kyng vnderstod, & despised þe Cristene blod; & alle þe Cristene hym forsok, ffor he hym to þe Payens tok; His owen kynde hated hym mest, kin hotid him. His children loued hym alder lest. childir loued him alle lost. Byfore tyme he hadde a wyf, But deþ hadde departed Bot dede had depart. þer lyf; Wyþ þat wyf he had þre sones Þat helde ageyn hym for þe Bretons; Þe eldest highte sire Vortymer, Þat oþer, Patens, and Catyger. þe toþer Passence & Katiger.
text.129: ¶ De blandicione Hengisty. Hengist wente wyþ þe kyng aboute, To be syker for drede & doute, & seyde, "y se hit on many gate " Þat þou for me of summe hast has. hate; " & y am—syker mot &yogh;e be— " Hated for þe loue of þe. " Þou art my sone, for þys skyle, " Þou hast has. my doughter; as lawe hit wyle, " Y am þy fader, als in honour " To be þe a god conseillour; " ¶ &yogh;yf þou wilt regne, trist on me wel, " & help on my partie som del. " &yogh;yf þou wilt greue þyn enemis, " Y schal þe conseille by god auis, I. sall þe counseill a gode vis. " Send after my sone, sire Octa, " & ffor his cosyn Ebsa, Ebissa (in Wace, and Geoff. too). " & ffor a noble knyght man. The first scribe begins again. Kerdyk; " in al Saxoyne nar sessone ere. non þem lyk; " Þey ar fighters, & noble iustours, þise ere feihters nobill in stours. " & queynte men & werreyour[s]; " Gyf hem lond y þe norþ to lende,— " Þy werre comeþ euere in by þat ende, See p. 235, l. 6703-4; p. 259, l. 7399, 7400, &c. — " ffro þyn enemis þey schul sall. þe were, " þat nought of þyn schulle þey sall robbe ne. dere; " So myght þou haue, til þy deses, may þou haf to þi decese. " O þys half Humber þy lond in pes." ¶ Þen seyde þe kyng, " send after þo, " & of þe beste, &yogh;yf þer be mo." Hengist hadde his sonde had his sondes. sone; Þem to brynge þey were al bone; Wyþ hem cam a fflute of fflode, Þritty schipes à trois cent nès, Wace , i. 335, l. 7231; cum trecentis navibus, Galf. Mon. vi. 13. alle gode; Knyghtes þat wolde wende for wages, Wyþ Octa wenten to þe ryuages. After þat fflute, com ouer þe se Schipes vmwhile by two or bi. þre, 2 By foure & fyue, by six & seuene, By eyghte & nyne, by ten & enleuene; 2 2-2 P. leaves out these two lines, though Wace begins at four ships and goes up to ten, i. 335, l. 7237-8. In a þrowe were mo Payen men, Or al so manie, as were Cristen. Þis seye þe Bretons, & were onoyed, noied. & seide þe kyng þe lond destruyed; To þe kyng þey pleyned in curteys sawe; þei praied him he suld not drauh. " Payens ageyn þe Cristen lawe " Bygynneþ gretly vs to greue; " To wende a-wey, sire, gyue þem MS. vs. P. gif þam. (Départe les, Wace , i. 336, l. 7249; ut ipsos expelleret, Galf. Mon. vi. 13.) leue, " Alle, or þe moste partye, " ffor to Cristendom &yogh;e do vylenye." Þe kyng answered, & seyde, "nay, " Y sente for þem; þey serue to pay."
text.130: ¶ Vortimerus, filius ffortigerni, factus est Rex. Whan þe Bretons herde þat þe kynge Wolde nought leue for no þynge, At Londone þey sette a Parlement, & Vortymer to kyng þey hent, Þe eldest sone of ffortyger, Þat was a doughti bacheler. Þis Vortymer dide crie a cry, ' Þat no Saxon . . . . . krie a kri þat no sessone. were so hardy, ' In his demeynes dwelle ne be, ' Neyþer in burgh ne in cite.' Anon alle out he dide hem keste; smertli all did þam out kest. Among þe Bretons myghter non reste. non mot rest. Þe kyng, for loue of his wyf, Held wyþ þe Saxons, & meyntend strif. held þe sessons mantende stryfe.
text.131: De infortuniis Saxonum. Hys sone hadde þer-wyþ enuye, & sey his ffader meyntende folye; He spied þe Saxoyns, sessons. whar þey ware, & chased hem as hound doþ þe þam als hunde dos. hare; His folk was god, hym-self doughti, & meyntende wel his party. Baldely bolded on hym þe Bretons Ageyns his fader & þe Saxons; sessons. De exilis Saxonum. ffoure tymes þey bataille nomen, & euere þe Saxoyns sessons. were ouer-comen; Þe firste bataille was vpon Derewent, Þer were þe Saxons sessons. alle y-schent; Þat oþer at Berforde, att a brok, Breford at a broke. (Epifor, Wace , l. 7273; Episford, Galf. Mon. ) Þer þe Saxons eft bataille tok, þer eftsons bataile þei toke. Þer was Hors & manye anoþer Ageyn Catyger, Vortymeres broþer; Gretly þey &yogh;ernde ilk oþer tasayle, & boþe were slayn at þat bataille. Þe þridde tyme in Kent, at an hauen; To þer schipes þer as. P. transposes the next two lines. þey were drawen; Þer wer þey so harde byset, Þey fledde to þe yle of Tanet; ffro by&yogh;onde Humber, vnto þat ylde, Was no Saxon sessons. so bold ne wylde, Þat he ne dide hym þyder chace, ffor in ffortiger for all þe kyng. þey fond no grace. Þe Bretons folewed þem & slowe; Þo þat ascaped, to þe hil Ilde. þey drowe. I þe yle þey assailled þem þer-ynne Wiþ botes, as þey myghte þem to þam. wynne; By þe se syde on þem þey carf; O þe oþer syde for hunger þey starf. Þan sey Saxons þe sessons sauh. on ilk syde wo, & þoughte best þare best it. were to wende þer-fro; Þey sente her sonde to ffortyger, ' Þat he wolde so sende to wild praie sir. Vortymer, ' To gyue hem leue a-wey to wende ' Wyþouten slaughter, scaþe. P. leaves out the next two lines. as he was hende; ' ffor þey ne leften nyght ne day ' Þem tasaille wyþ strong afray: ' His trewes, þer-fore, fond vs In þis treus leue. to gete.' Þen drowe þe Saxons þe sessons drouh þam. alle to a fflete, & dight þer schipes, & sette vp sayl, Left wyf & childre, & oþer porayl: childe & oþer apparaille. On þis manere a-wey þey scaped, Ouer se til oþer land þeym Into þer awen lond þam. raped.
text.132: ¶ De Restauracione ecclesiarum per Vortimerum. Vortymer dide þanne restore Þat for þem hadde any lore. He dide kirkes reyse & make,— Þo þat Hengist dide doun schake,— & dide Godes seruise be songe & seyd, Þat for þe Payens longe was leyd. He sente to Rome, to seint Romeyn, & he sente hider þe byschop Germeyn. Þen com wyþ hym seint Lowys, An holy bischop & a wys,— Þey were sent þe londe to assoille,— He kepte þe sege of the apostoylle. see of þe apostole. Þyse two turned þe folk ageyn, To Crist & to his lawe ageyn; to leue þe cristen lawe certayn. & manion þorow hem saued was Þat er wer gyuen to Satanas. Þorow hem schewed God many vertu, Þat in þis lond dide gret pru.
text.133: ¶ De Maledicta Ronewenna. When þey had stabled Godes lawe Þorow miracle & þorow þer sawe, Anoþer sorewe com vp ryf, Þorow Ronewenne, ffortygeres wyf: Scheo made a drynke þorow treson, & Vortymer sche dide poyson; Scheo poysend hym þat louede Crist, ffor þe payen, hure ffader Hengist. Whan Vortymer wyste he scholde deye— Leches to lyue couþe hym non seye, not seie. — Þen sent he after his barons bolde, Bytaught hem alle his tresor to holde, & seide, "takeþ conseil & red,— " Of me nys non, for y am ded, .I. am bot dede. — " Men of armes swyþe knyghtes of sonde .I. rede. &yogh;e take, " By alle þe costes bi þe se side. quykly to wake " Þat no Saxoyn sesson. on &yogh;ow aryue, " Ne receyueþ non for þyng alyue; " Holdeþ þe stat þat y &yogh;ow wan, " And trauailleþ forþ as y began; " And &yogh;yf &yogh;e do als y schal rede, " On &yogh;ow to come þey schul drede. " By þe se side, byrieþ me þere, " Þe sight of me &yogh;yt schal hem fere; sall þam afere. " & doþ make a toumbe þat longe may last, " Þe sight þerof schal þem agast; " On alle manere &yogh;e make hit heye, " Þat y be euere ageyn þer eye; " Þat wey of me þan schul þey scurne, " Ne neuere haue grace on me to turne." Þus he þem taughte, þus he þem seyd, & þenne byforn þem alle he deyd. Bot þei dide nought his comandement; Heu promorte Vor|timery! Þe dedes conseyl dede conseile. ys sone ouer-went,— Nota. To Londone his body þey bar, & in þe cite biried hym þar. Þen wax ffortiger ful stout; Als he fore dide, he he are was. regned þorowout. Ronewenne þenne hure lord bysought Þat Hengist myghte a-geyn be brought. Anon tys till his. [ went =turned] wif, his wille he went, & after Hengist his lettre sent: To come sleightly he scholde com slily he suld. fonde, & litel folk wyþ hym brynge bot bring not mykell folk. to londe, 7 So þe barons þem nought mispaye, Ne þe comun folk affraye; 7 7-7 P. leaves out these two lines. " Hit nedeþ no þyng gret folk to haue, " ffor Vortymer lygges ded MS. dred. P. dede. in graue."
text.134: ¶ Hengistus reconsiliatus est. When Hengist herde þo tydinges, His God he þanked, he þankid his godes. & made offrynges; He dight hym folk, an hundred þre hundreth. (trois cent mil|liers, Wace , i. 343, l. 7380; trecenta millia, Galf. Mon. vi. 15.) þousand Of armed men, brought þem to land. Many a Breton þen dredde hym sore, & so schold oþer þat þenne [ne] þan ne. wore. When þe kyng herde Hengist was comen, & wiþ mykel folk þe lond hauen. had nomen, He dredde hym sore, & mente his mone. Þe Bretons were greued ones euer. ilkone, & seide 'þey wolde do þei suld fond. þer myght ' To sle þem doun wyþ force & & do him flie þorgh force of. fight.' Bot Hengist herde, what loud, what stille, Þe Bretons to hym hadde yuel had wikked. wille. Hym self was euere ful feloun; He sente to þe kyng al in tresoun, ' Þat he wolde speke wyþ alle in pees, ' & simplely scmpely. A fresh scribe (? not the second) writes this page of P. and has -in, -is, -id , &c. wyþouten pres; ' Pes he asked, pes wolde he seke, ' Til hym in pes he wolde be wild him. meke, ' & he wolde nought þe Bretons greue, ' Ne dwelle wiþ force ageyn þer leue, ' Bot chese þem-seluen, as þey wol say, ' Wheþer we schul dwelle, or go our way.' or at þer will go home þer weie. On þat couenaunt & þat deuis Þey hadde trewes on boþe partys. When þe partys to trewe treus. wer brought, Hengist of treson hym byþought; who wild haue wend of treson þoght. Þorow trist of trues, of treist & treus on. on assent Þey sette a day of Parlement Opon þe Playne of Salesbury, Byside the Merueille of Aumbresbyry, Nunnis of Ammesberi. (l'abeic, Wace , i. 344, l. 7410; cœnobium, Galf. Mon. vi. 15.) Þey bede Hengist no gret folk lede, Bot senglely come, & noman simpli no man suld. drede, & what lordyng he gan mete, Als he þem dredde he scholde so suld he. lete. Hengist sent hym bode a-geyn, Þat he wolde comen to þe Playn Wyþoute armure on any wyght, ffor drede of contek & of fight.
text.135: ¶ De tradicione Hengisti, & occisione Britonum cum Sexis. To þat playne þey come þat day, Of Salesbury, þe firste of May, Many a man (wyþoute þoru. somons) Of þe Saxons sessons. & of þe Bretons: Hereþ now how Hengist þought, heres now hov . . . . . wroght. What treson he schop to be wrought. þis treson who wild haue þoght. " ffelawes," he seyde, "what so bytydes, " Get &yogh;ow knyues egged on puruey &yogh;ou kniues egid. boþe sydes, " & ber þem priuely, þat non ne se, " In &yogh;oure hoses harde by &yogh;our kne. In &yogh;oure bosums be &yogh;our the. " When we haue þem, & þey vs gret, " & ilkon of vs by a Breton Ilkone be sidyn oþer. set,— " On alle manere fondes how, " Ay on of hem, anoþer & on. of &yogh;ow,— " Nymeþ out takis oute. &yogh;our sexes when y so say, " & handes on &yogh;our felawes lay, " On ilka Breton þat sittes &yogh;ou nest, " & strykeþ hem ded þorow bak & & smyte with knife þrou bak or. After, brest P. adds, all gate þat &yogh;ee him slo. no poer haue ferer to go. brest." When Hengist to þem þus had yseyd, whan þis treson to þem was said. Ilka Saxon man. a sex purueyd, & com to þe Playne of Salesbury, ffair felawschip, felichip. & ful mury. When þey were alle set in fere, Als he had seid hem þe said on þat. manere, " Nymeþ out takis oute. &yogh;our sexes," seide Hengist; Bot what hit mente þe Bretons nyst. ne wist. Þe Saxons sessons. anon þer sexes drowe; drohe . . . . . slohe. His felawe next, þe Saxons sessons. slowe. Þe kyng sey þat, anon vp stirt, Bot Hengist laughtym toke him. by þe skirt, & he held hym as stille as ston, Þat he mighte helpe to saue non. Þe Bretons seye þey were by-traischt, be traist. fful deolfuly were þey þenne abayscht. So sodenly þei were o beist. Þat so sodeynly had þer lyues & þer liues so sone. reft/, & so fewe lordes as þer were left; ffor þer wer slayn of knyghtes barons. bolde Þre hundred quatre cens, Wace , i. 346, l. 7438; quadringentos, Galf. Mon. vi. 15. & sexti Bretons tolde; Alle were þey lordes all riche men. euerilkone, ffor whilk þe lond made mykel mone; & þo þat ascaped out of þe place, Wyþ stones foughte as wit stonis fauht wen. þey had space; ffyghtyng þey fledde, þey hadde al ffehtand þei fled as þei had. nede. Þe Erl Erell. of Gloucestre was in þat drede; A tre he laughte, & þer-wyþ smot, & his dint on þe Saxons Sessons. bot; Sire Eldok, þe noble Erl so þis erill sir Eldok he. hight, His dint wyþ-stonde, no Saxon to stond his dint non ne. myght, ffor he slow þer of Hengistes þe Hengist. men, Als hit telles, twenty seuenti. (soixante dis, Wace , l. 7449; septuaginta, Galf. Mon. , vi. 16.) & ten. He bar hym so in þat pres Þat of wounde he was wem-les, Þey seye he scaped so þei sau he wus schapid. wyþ þe lyf, & kesten after hym many a knyf; Þer his hors was, þider he gan þer his hors was þidir him. spede, & to Gloucestre on þat hors he &yogh;ede; on him to gloucestre he fled. And so he warnyscht al þat toun Þat þey ne dredde no Saxoun. sessoun. (These readings will not be given again.) Þen Saxoyns Sessons. (These readings will not be given again.) wolde han slayn þe kyng, Bot Hengist wold nought for no þyng; He bad hem "leue, do him bot god, " ffor he haþ auaunced mykel my blod: " Als in lawe he ys my sone, " Elles he scholde oþer weys mone." Þey ledde hym þenne to London, & þer þey dide hym in prison. London was þeirs, to Lincolne þey hasted, Wynchestre & &yogh;ork þey toke & wasted. ffortyger saw how þat hit foor; fore . . . . . suore. What þey hym asked, he þem swor. ffor to ben out of þer prisoun, & quit of alle manere raunsoun, He graunted þem þanne to haue Southsex, Oxenfordschire, & estsex. (Essexe, Wace , i. 348, l. 7474, from MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé.) & Middelsex, ffor þey marchen vpon merched opon. Kent Þat he gaf Ronewenne to rent. & forto mene &yogh;yt of þe tresons Of þe sexes & of þe Saxons, Þo countres haue þer-of þe haf þo cuntres þerfor to. name, Sexes, fo[r] þe Saxons schame. 5 Sire ffortiger þe kyng þankede God þo, Þat so quit & sker had lat hym go. 5 5-5 Whan þe kyng sir Vortiger. was laten go quyte & clere. Toward Walys þen fledde he &yogh;erne, ffer awey by&yogh;onde Seuerne; Þere he dwelled & made soiour: Now hereþ how he þer made his tour.
text.136: ¶ De castello ffortygerny in Wallia. He dide sende after þe clergye, Þe wysest men of astronomye; At hem alle, conseil he took, ' How he myghtym safliest lok sauely loke. ' A-geyn his enemis for to fende, ' &yogh;yf host byseged hym as he wende.' Þus redde hym þenne his conseillours: ' To make a strong castel wiþ tours ' Þat non wyþ force mighte hit take, ' Ne wyþ engyns hit perebrake; non engine perbrake. ' & when hit [was] whan it were. dight at his auys, ' To warnyschit warnissed. ageyn his enemis.' In fele stedes þenne ches he Where was best & most ese. On an hil hight Mount de Tyre, Mont de Rir, Wace , i. 349, l. 7510; ad Erir montem, Galf. Mon. , vi. 17. Þer-on was his moste desire; Masons brought he þenne slie he brouht. þer-tille, Bygonne þat castelwerk o began a kastell opon. þat hille; Morter þey made, & ston dide fet, & spedde hem faste þer-on to set. Alle þat þey made a day vpright, ffallen was doun vpon þat nyght; Often þey les al þeyr iornes, Þat what [þei] þat þei. made, lay doun on knes. Þat saw þe kyng hit misferde þe kyng sauh it misfare. so; Þe maistres he dide eft com hym to, & preide þem telle 'what þyng hit deres ' Þat þe erþe þys werk ne beres; ' & &yogh;if þey mighte, þey scholde fonde ' To wyte what myghte don hit stonde.' Þys wyse maistres þer bokes kest, maistres lotes caste. (ont de|viné et sortoi, Wace , i. 351, l. 7529.) Why þat werk ne wolde nought lest; Þey fondyt þenne in þer musyng, fond in þer lotes kestyng. A gret selcouþ, & telde þe kyng: " &yogh;yf ani man myghte a child fynde " Þat hadde no fader of mankynde, " &yogh;yf he were taken & slayn sone, on one. " & menged his blod wyþ morter & stone, " Vpon þat morter þat blod wer inne, " Þat werk men mygh[t] safly bygynne." Þe kyng als sone his sonde sent, ffro toun to toun þorow Walys went; In ilka contre, þorow euery þorgh ilk a. schire, He hadde spyes for to spyre; & in oþer landes seeres Sente þe kyng his messegers: Two to-gyder, aboute þey &yogh;ede, Þe bettere for to spirre & spede. Two of þyse wente þorow Walys, Of swylk a child &yogh;if þey herde tales. So fer in to þe lond þey nam, Atte last to Kermerdyn þey cam: By-fore þe &yogh;ates y þe way Sawe þey manye childre play; Bytwyxt to þer a stryf þey herde, Of grete reprefs vpbreide. ilk oþer onswerde; Þey wyþ-stode, & gon abyde ffor to here þe children childir. chide. When wraþe bygynneþ, þen comeþ vmbreyd; wrath comes þan is vpbreid. Al þat men wot, ys þen forþ seyd; So dide þey þat weren wroþe,— Dynabus, Merlyn, (þus hight þey boþe,)— ¶ Dynabus seyde, "Let be, Merlyn! " &yogh;yf þou me vmbreyde, þou vpbreid. þe schame ys þyn. Merlinus. " Y am born of heyer kynde " Þan any man of þe may fynde. " Hit aughte þe schame in al þy lyue " Þat þou, Merlyn, wyþ me wilt stryue; " ffor y am come of kynges blod, " & þou, Merlyn, art nought so god; " Þy kynde & myn ys no þyng euen, " Ne þy fader canstow nought neuen, " Ne neuere hym seye, ne hym ne knew, " Ne of what kynde þat he grew! " Þer wot no man of wham þart come, ne no man of þe may kone. " Þer-fore y halde þe no mannes sone!" Þe messegers lystned, & þought Þat swylk a child hadde þey sought; Þey spird þe spired. at men of þat cite, Þat Dynabus seyde, &yogh;yf hit myght be, Þat ffader wystey hym haue wist þei him haf. non. Þey of þe cite seyde ylkon, " His moder we knowe, þat hym bare; " Of his fader ne wyte we whare; " Hys moder kynde alle we knawe, knowe . . . . . sowe. " Bot his ffader we neuere sawe. " Scheo was þe kynges doughter, Dymenice, demetie. " Of Walys he hadde half partye; " Scho ys nonne of relygion " At Seint Petres kirke of þis toun." Þey &yogh;ede to þe Meyre of Kermerdyn, O þe kynges halue asked Merlyn Þat neuere &yogh;it no fader had; His moder also wyþ hym þey lad. Þe Meyre þen wolde þem nought werne, Bot sped þem on þer wey ful &yogh;erne. Þey come to þe kyng ffortyger, & he welcomed hem on faire maner: ¶ "Dame," seyde þe kyng, "welcome be þou! " Nedlike at þe y mot wyse how, Dicta Matris Merlyny. " Who þan gat þy sone Merlyne, " & on what manere was he þyne." His moder stod a þrowe, & þought, Er sche to þe kyng onswered ought. When scheo had stande standen. a litel wyght, Sche seyde, "by Marye bright, bi ihesu in Mari liht. " Þat y ne sey, ne neuere knew, " Hym þat þis child on me sew; knaue on me sewe. " Y ne wiste neuere, ne y ne herde, " What maner wyght schap. wyþ me so ferde; " Bot þis þyng am y wel of graunt, " Whon y was of elde auenaunt, " On com þer to my bed, y wyst, " & wyþ force me clipte he me halsed. & kyst; " Als a man y hym felt, " & als a man he me welt, " And als a man he spak to me, " Bot what he was myght y nought se. " So often to my bed he cam, " & ofte me kyste, in armes nam, " & knew me als a man schold do, " Byfore ne syþen did neuere non so: " Al þus þusgaiel conseyued y þys knaue, " & als y wiste, told-y &yogh;ow haue." Þen dide þe kyng a maister calle, Magait Magaunt. (Malgant, Wace , i. 356, l. 7623.) he highte, wysest of alle; He asked &yogh;yf hit myghte be so, Þat þyng þat scheo als scho. telde þem to. " &yogh;e," &yogh;a. seyde þe Maistere to þe kyng, " Hit may bityde, swylka of suilk a . þyng. " ffor we fynde writen in our scrytes " Of swylk manere of spyrites; " Bytwyxte þe mone & þe erþe þei wone— " So telleþ vs our bokes þat we kone;— " Som what tak þey of mannes kynde, " & mengyt wyþ angles, as we fynde; " ffor þeyr wonyng ys in þe eyr, " Vmwhile to þe erþe þey make repeir. " Mykel skaþe do þey nought; " Drecchynge by tymes haue poyntes haf. þey wrought. " Mannes nature vmwhile þey take; " Þat ys þer myght þey may so make, " Whan hit ys tyme of here powere, " To haue lyknesse of bodyes here. sere. " What tyme þey tak hit, wot noman " Bot he þat al may wyte & kan. " Þise spyrites do women schame; " Incuby / demones, ys cald þer name, " ffendes-in-bedde, as our bokes so þei. sayn, " Þat many woman han forlayn. " On þis manere myghte Merlyn " Be geten & born, by in. oure deuyn." ¶ Þen seide Merlyn: "Sire kyng! þou has " Sent after me; sey me þy what. cas! Dicta Merlyny. " What þou wilt, sey me þy wille, " Wheþer hit is for god oþer ylle!" Þen seid þe kyng, "þou schalt here; " ffor þe y sente, at þe to lere. " A castel y haue bygonne, begunnen. " & lore þer-on þat y haue wonne; & lost þerfor þat .I. haf wunnen. " Al þat þey make þer on a day, " O nyght alone holy. stand hit ne may; " & eft when þey gynne begyn. þe walles, " Eyþer hit synkes, or cleues, or falles; " & ffayn y wolde þe werk haue hasted, " & mykel of myn þer-fore ys wasted, " Bot þus seide alle my dyuinours, " Þat þer ne schal stande wal ne tours " Bot þy blod þer-on be schad, " Þow þat neuere no fader had." Þenne seide Merlyn, "þat wold nought God, " Þat swylk a fals schold be bytrowd, suilk fals worde so suld be trod. " Þat þorow þe mengynge of my blod " Þy tour schold stande strong & god. " Y schal proue þem fals fur-sworn " &yogh;yf þou brynge þem me byforn: " Þo þat on me lotes cast, " & seyde my blod myght makyt mot. fast, " Y schal þem þroue for lyeres olde, " Þylke þo ilk. maistres þat þe so tolde." Þe kyng dide þem come ilkone, Ageyn Merlyn hym self alone. " Maistres," he seyde, "what haue &yogh;e seyd, " What lotes haue &yogh;e on me leyd, " ffor þys þyng ys þus ffarand, " Þe kynges werk hit may nought stande? " Con &yogh;e sey non oþer enchesoun cheson. " Whi þat þis castel þus falles doun? " & &yogh;yf &yogh;e can non oþer sey " Why þat hit falles som certeyn wey, " How couþe &yogh;e wyte þat þorow my blod " Þis tour myght stande stark & god? " Seys what þyng ys on in. þe ground " Þat hit ne may stande hol ne may not be hole &. sound, " & seyþ what þyng hit helpe myght, " Þat þys castel myght stande vpright. " & &yogh;yf &yogh;e ne conne nought do hym wyte " What þe fallyng may wyþ-syt, with site. " Þat &yogh;e haue seyd, hit ys bot fable, " Þat my blod schold make hit stable! " Seys now hym al þe desturblaunce, disturbance. " & where-of comeþ þat wonder chaunce!" Þise maistres of astronomie & of deuyn þat said þat devyne. Onswered ansuerd . . . . . ansurd. nought o word to Merlyn. When Merlyn sey þey ne onswered ansuerd . . . . . ansurd. nought, Right to þe kyng he sayde his þought:
text.137: ¶ Dicta Merliny ad Regem. " Syre kyng," he saide, "gyf now entent! þi tent. " By-neþe þe erþe, atte ffundement, " Is a water rennyng dep, rynnand depe. " Þat makes þy werk slyden o slep. to slide o slepe. (Par quoi ta tor en terre font, Wace , i. 359, l. 7694.) " & serteyn þer-of [þat] þou be, " Do graue þe erþe al vp, & se." Þe kyng dide come mynours grauers. ynowe, Þat þe erþe vp caste & drowe. As Merlyn seyde, þe water þey fond. " &yogh;e maistres," seid Merlyn, "of þys lond, " &yogh;yf &yogh;e con telle vs now here " What merueille ys in þys ryuere, " Seyeþ now þe righte certeynete, " &yogh;e þat diuined þe deþ of me!" Þe maistres alle stille þey stod, Þey seyden neyþer yuel seid noiþer ill. ne god. Þen to-ward þe kyng Merlyn gan turne: " Do scope þis water, & turn þe borne. burne. " Sykes do &yogh;e graue & groupe, MS. groupes. P. groupe. " Þe water þer-inne in þam. men schal scoupe." Þe kyng dide come folk ynowe, Þat þe water wiþ scopes vp drowe.
text.138: ¶ De diuersitate duorum Draconum. When þe water was oute clene, Merlyn schewed what hit wold mene: He telde þe folk alle atones, Þat "y þe ground leye two hole tuo holle. (hole-y, Fr. chaves. Wace, i. 360, l. 7712.) stones; " By-twyxte þe stones were to dragons, " Þat dide hym make al þe þis. somons. " Do þat þo stones weren a twynne, " Þe dragons schul &yogh;e fynde wyþynne." þer Inne. Þey brast þe stones vp al so tyt, & founde a red dragon & a whyt. The explanation and dragon|fight are not in Geoffrey of Mon|mouth. Þis rede dragon was grym to se; ffel to fyghte þen semed he; Þe white was nought so grym of grimly in. sight, Ne so fel semyng semand. to fyght. " Sire kyng," seid Merlyn, "to me þou herk! " Þyse two dragons fordede þy werk! " ffor whan þy werk on heyght[e] larged, " Þen schok þe ground, þe grounde satled. & þeym ouer charged; " Þen meued þey hem, þe water al quok, " & þe werk abouen al schok; to schoke. " Of þat y seyde, nought y ne ley." say nouht .I. leih. Vp in to þe eyr þe dragons þen fley, & foughte so þat hit was selcouþ; fflaumes as fyr fley fro of fire com of. þer mouþ. Al þe folk seide comunly, Þey hoped þe rede schold haue þe maistri. When þey hadde longe to-gyder smyten, Spatled, spouted, belewed, spouted sperkes bolned. & byten, Wyppyng wyþ wenges, ouer-wepen wipped . . . . . ouerwarpen. & went, Cracchyng wiþ clawes, rubbed, & brent; kracchid with clawes rombed & rent. Þe bataille lasted day & nyght, Vntil þat oþer day was lyght. Þe folk wondred þat þe white dragoun To þe rede had any foysoun. At þe ende, þe white a fflaume out cast, Þat þe rede bolnede & brast. When he was ded, þe rede dragoun, Þe white &yogh;ede & leyde hym doun; Þre daye þen lyued he, & na mo, Þe ferþe he deyde, y trowe, for wo. ¶ Vortyger sey þanne þis chaunce; He askede Merlyn þe signifiaunce, & preyed hym telle what hit wild mene, Wheþer hit tokned ioye or tene. Þenne seyde Merlyn many thynges, What y þis lond schuld tide of kynges, Þat are in Blase bokes write, See Geoffrey of Monmouth's "Liber septimus, qui est de Pro|"phetiis Merlini." Wace leaves it out too: Ne voil son livre tranlater, Quant jo n'elsai entepréter: Nule rien dire ne volroie Qu'issi ne fu com jo diroie. Wace , i. 361 ll. 7733-6. — Þey þat hauyt, mowe hit wyte, þo þat it haf þei it witen. — And in Tolomer & sire Amytayn; (?) Auntayn. Þyse hadde Merlynes bokes playn, ffor þyse þre write his prophecyes, And were his maistres in ser were maistres at sere. partyes. Som men haue þem mykel in hande, Þat con nought þem wel vndestande. Y sey for me, y naue no wyt To open þe knottes þat Merlyn knyt. Men may sey more þan he haþ seyd, Þat noþyng þer-to may be leyd. Merlyn spak on swylk a manere, Þat til hit be gon, non may hit lere.
text.139: ¶ De interpretacione draconum per Merlynum. Þe kyng held Merlyn in mikel pris, ffor his seynge was god & wys. (In ffortiger tyme, men hit Merlin men. told, He was þat tyme bot twolf &yogh;er old.) Þe kyng bisoughtym þat he wold seye What manere deþ þat he schold deye. dede he suld dye. " Sire kyng, to wyte hastow haues þou. desir: " Al way war þe war þe wer þe. (Garde-toi, dist|il, garde-toi, Wace , i. 361, l. 7742.) wel fro fyr " ffro Constantes childre, Constant Childir. þat ar comand, " Þat sone schul aryuen here on land. " Þou signefiest signifise. þe rede dragoun, " Þat ffader & broþer slowe wyþ tresoun; " & hit menes, þer bataille strong, " Þat þou hast halde þou haues. þer lond wyþ wrong. " Þe white dragon ys syngnefiaunce " Þat þey schul take of þe vengaunce: " fful yuel þou slowe þer ffader & broþer, An euell þou didis þou slou þer broþer. (The second scribe began again in P. at line 8229.) " & madest þe kyng, þat was anoþer. " Þe þridde combraunce þat &yogh;it þe mones, " Þou receyuedest þe Payens Saxones. " On alle halue comes þy wo: " Þe Saxoyns wyl waite þe to slo; " I þat oþer halue þe eyres schul come, " & aske þer lond of þe þorow dome; " Þey ar now saylynge sailand. in þe se; " Awey by tyme y rede þow fle. " Þey schul sall. aryue vp at Toteneys " To morn, wyþ hors & wyþ harneys; " To renne on þe [þey] schul sall. þem renge; " ffader & broþer þey schul sall. þan venge. " Þer þou wenst best recet wote best refute. to haue, " ffle now faste, suyth. þy self to saue. " &yogh;yt schal y warne þe of þys þynge, " Aurelius schal sall. first be kyng; " & he schal sall. lyue nought bot a stounde; " Þorow poyson schal sall. he be brought to grounde. " Vter, his broþer, after hym schal sall. be " Kyng, & regne als dide he. " Vter sone schal com fro Cornewaille, " As a fyghtyng bor als a feihtand bore. in bataille; " Þe traiturs of þyne þat he may fynde, " He schal furdo, and al þer kynde; " Of prowesse he schal haue þe pris, " & destruye alle his enemis." Merlyn stynte, left. & spak namore. Þen fforteger tok his at Vorliger he toke. (Et Vor|tiger d'iloc torna, Wace , i. 363, l. 7778.) leue þore; ffo[r] þes tydynges dwelt he ne Vortiger duellid. nought, On Merlynes wordes was al his þought.
text.140: ¶ Hic de Aurelyo Rege. Þat oþer day, as Merlyn seyd, Totenesse was vmbyleyd be layd. Wyþ schipes wyþ þe children childir. host, & spred aboute by al þe cost. Bretons þat herde, & weren blyþe; Þey gadered þem, & þyder swyþe; Þo þat were a-sondred ful or sundird. wyde, Com to Toteneys on ilka syde; Lordes riden, & fotmen ran, Bretons were bliþe ilka man. Hengist byforn had don hem skulke In wodes, in hilles, to crepe in hulke, to krepe & hulk. & had ney slayn al þer barons Wyþ þe sexes of þe Saxons. Wace, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé. De Lincy's No. 27 has 'Des castiax ot la signorie,' Wace , i. 364, l. 7790.) Þen were þey bolde of þe cominge; Þey tok Aurelius, & made hym kyng. Wyþ þe Bretons was blisse ynough, eneughe. & þretten Hengist to wake hys wough. wakin his wouh. ¶ þys tidyng com to ffortiger, Þat Aurelius & sire Vter Were comen, & hadde seysed þe lond, Þeym to venge, &yogh;yf þey hym fond. ffor þo tydynges & þo tales He fledde & warnyschet hem wanisid him. in Wales;— Genoyre hight þe castel name, (I not &yogh;yf hit haue &yogh;it þe same;) Þe hil hight Cloart, þer men hit kennes, & byside þe water of Weye be side wye a water þat. rennes; Þe contre þat hit standes yn, Þe name þer-of hight Dergryn; Hergrin. — Þider gadered his folk & þaire vitaille, & warnyschet warnisid it. hem, &yogh;yf ought myght vaille. ¶ Þe &yogh;onge kyng & his broþer, Wyþ mania Breton, on & oþer, De Morte ffortygerny. & folk wyþ hym þat he brought, In Walys fforteger þey sought. Þey byseced straite his castel; besegid his castell Genoire. ffele arewes þey schotten, & quarel & fondit &yogh;if þei might it peire. Þey caste þer-to, on manie a gate, ffor þey had þer-to ful gret hate. I þe ost was þe erl erell (still in the second scribe's hand). of Gloucestre,— In Walys he knew al þe estre,— Eldok he highte, man of honur, And hardy knyght & god werrour. Þe kyng Aurelius asked hym red ffor to venge his fader ded, & seyde, "Sire Erl, erell (still in the second scribe's hand). þou furgetest ylk del " Þat my fader feffed þe wel, " & gaf þe armes, & made þe knyght; " Syþen my broþer, in al his myght; " & &yogh;if þou louedest louedis. hym feyþfuly, " Help me to venge his enemy! " Let now no god wille be wane, " Bot help to venge my fader bane! 5 ."Þenk o þe Payens þat sexes drow, " & at þe Parlement þe lordes slow!" 5 5-5 & þink hov he ye paiens droughe þat Hengist at þe parlement slouh. (leaf 50, where the first scribe begins again.) When Eldok herde, he made swilk mone, Þey cried "as Has. armes" euerylkone, To gyue mak. assaut to þem wyþynne; Bot þe castel was yuel ill. to wynne. Þey comaunded to al men lyk, þat all olike. Wiþ brusch to come, brusche suld com. & fylle þe dyk. When hit was ful, fir þey set, & on a lowe at ones hit set; Þe lowe was mikel, & vp-ward stey, So þat hit in to þe castel fley, & vp in to þe tour hit went, Þat alle þe houses aboute brent; Castel, houses, wyþ al þer atyr, Man & best, al was on fyr; Til al was brent, woldit nought lynne. wald it not blynne. Þe kyng hym self was brent þer-ynne, & alle his folk euerylkone, Brente to deþe, body & bone. Of ilka traytour swilk ys þe ende! Last of his lyue wyþ wo schal ill sall. wende! Of a traitour ys al of spoken; Of Hengist wolde þe kyng be wroken. When Aurelius & sire Vter Were venged on sire ffortyger, Al þe land, ouer al aboute, Wyþ loue he did hit til hym loute. Whan he wyste þat al þe land Was til his wille bowand, He seide, ' he wolde no lenger abide; ' Agayn þe Saxons wold he ryde, ' Deliuere þe land of þem al klene; ' Þey han vs do ful haf vs wrouht. mykel tene.' Hengist herde þo tydynges seye, Toward Scotland he nam toke. his weye; Þe souþ contre al he fursok, & ouer Humber þe way he tok; Of at. Scottes & of Peytes þere He hoped of help, &yogh;yf nede we[re]. Þe kyng hym spedde, spied. when he hit wiste, Toward þe northe after Hengyste. When Bretons herde þe kyng passed Humbre, So fele to hym come, men myghtem nowt noumbre. Towards þe northe al ways[te] þey waste he. (Mult trova li rois pais gaste, Wace , i. 368, l. 7867.) fonde, Were þere non left myght tyle þe londe, Casteles broken, tounes MS. þey breken tounes þey. P. wisely leaves out the two þeys. brent, Holy kirke was broke & schent; Þyse Payens Saxoyns al had reft. Þen sey þe kyng nought waster was there. P. has was only. left: Al he highte to restore, &yogh;yf he myght lyue, & eft come if he had life eft to com. þore, ¶ Whan Hengist wyste þat herd. þe kyng cam, ffor drede he ne wyste what for him he wist þe. wey he nam; ffor to fle myght hit nought vaille, Bot ned he mest byde nede bord him stand to. bataille. He calde his felawes, called his folk. & bad þem rest, & seide, " felawes, what ys þe best? " Þis Bretons folewe vs faste & ney; " Vs by-houes be queynte & sley. " In bataille now þey we. wil vs frayst, " Lok þat &yogh;e be trewe & traist; " Dredeþ nought þer gret compaignye; " &yogh;yf we wel stande, sone schul þey flye. " Wel wot &yogh;e what Bretons are; " Þey feynte ful sone &yogh;yf non þem spare. " Standeþ styf & truely standes stifly a þrow. ageyn, " We schul þen of hem make feldes pleyn. þan gif þei bak & þe felde all playn. " Wyþ fewe, we han seyn many with litill folk many a. tyme, " We haue þeym sondred & smyten in swyme. " Tak &yogh;e non hede Mak &yogh;e no force. of þeyr grete host, " ffor wel &yogh;e wot þei ar bot bost, " & fals folk, wyþ feble heuede; Nota. " ffor þem our wed schal nought be leued. " He ys a child þat hem ledes! " He can nought &yogh;it on swylk[e] dedes! of suilk dedis. " & we ar noble werreours " Þat han be & has ben. proued in many stours! " Standes now wel ageyn &yogh;our fo! " Raunsom for vs non may go. " Defende oure lyues, best is to chese, " Now al to wynne or al to lese!" When Hengist had conforted hem þus, Þey armed þeym alle att o frusch, at a frusse. & riden fol softe & semly Ageyn þe Bretons wyþouten cri. Þey hoped vnarmed þe Bretons mete, & al vnwarned on þem schete; Bot þe Bretons, ilka conrey, Were as wel armed as þey; Þey hadden of þe Payens drede, Night & day armed þey &yogh;ede. Þe kyng herde seye þey come þat syde, And to bataille þey wolde abide; A feld he ches, fair & brod, He wente þyder, & þere abod.
text.141: De Bello inter Aurelium Regem & Hengystum. Þre hundred þousand. (mil, Wace , i. 370, l. 7915.) knyghtes of his meyne Þat wyþ hym comen ouer þe se, Alle doughty knyghte, fro ferne he fet. ferne fette. Boþe batailles þen sone wer set; bi þe to side all were selte. Of þe Walsche he tok to toke tuo. companies, Paþes to waite, & stretes, & styes, Þat Payens schulde for no nede Þe hylles take, &yogh;yf þeym fel drede. & þe wodes he dide so loke Al so wel þat non þem toke, Þat &yogh;yf ony þider drowe, Þe Walsche men sone þem slowe, Þe star-worþest stalworthest. to fyght & fende, & his owen bataille þen schulde his awen bataile suld. be hende. When his batailles barons. wer set & dight, Renged & redy for renged all redi to. to fyght, Þe men of kuythe kith. (Od ses homes fu naturax, Wace , i. 370, l. 7931.) þat he wel knewe, Þat he wyste were gode treist. & trewe, Þem dide he bere his baner, & fro þo was he nought fer; Sire Eldok was euere hym by, & oþer barons also were ney. " Lord," seide Eldok, "had y þat grace, " Hengist for to mete in place! " Wel oughte Wele burd. Þorow castel þen wold he nought be rescowed: Hit was bot pyne, wel hadde he herd, Wyþoute socour in castel be sperd; Leuere hym were holde hym wyþoute; Þat held he betere, & lasse an enture him he was in. doute, Þan yn castel be closed yn, ffor he nyste ho hym out schude wyn. he ne wist who suld him out wynne. &yogh;it þoughtym best myght hym he sauh no þing mygh [ t ] more. a-uaille, To relye his folk, & gyue þan for to stand to. bataille. text.142: ¶ De Pungna inter Eldok & Hengystum. As þey were boldest in þer baret, Eldok & Hengist to-gedere met; Sire Eldok, Hengist ful wel knew, His herte a-geyns hym gros & grew: Þey hit if it. so dide, ful wel hit aughte, Gret encheson mad þeym vnsaughte; He preied to God his desir He þanked god he hoped. fulfil, Þat he of Hengist might haue his wyl. Wyþ scharpe swerdes to-gyder þey with scharp spere till him he. ran, & Hengist kepte hym as a man; Eldokes strok ful wel he sat, Hengist ageyn anoþer smat; Þer myg[h]te men se fighteres bolde; se tuo Iuste & turne. ffor dynt of deþ spare þey ne wolde; for doute of dede non wild scurne. One stroke too many in the MS. m. Wyþ swerdes of werre double with scharp suerdes þei dubled. dyntes, Þe sparkles fleye as fir of flyntes; &yogh;yf Eldokes help ne hadde be ney, Hengist had had MS. (haltered) hed. P. has had. þe better party; Bot þe Erl Corlyeus erle Gorleus. of Cornewaille, Cam right y com in alle. þe moste trauaille. Whan Eldok sey þat þe Erl cam, More hardynesse in herte he nam, fful egrely þanne til Hengist he for belde of him to Hengist. went, & by þe vyser nasell. (nasal, Wace , l. 8012.) he hym hent, & heldit til he had sesed his nekke:— Þe Payens wer al mat were mate. wyþ þat chekke:— " Þanked be Merci. Iesu, þat þou hit wylde! " Þat y haue &yogh;erned, now ys fulfilde! " Now hauy take oure moste fo, " Þat haþ vs wakned many wo! " Þis ys þe hound—wo mot hym be!— " Þat neuere of vs hadde pyte! 9 ." Þis hound y soughte, now y hym fond, " He was heued to struye þis lond! 9 9-9 Not in the Petyt MS. " Sire Erl, þys hound, þys comelyng, " O myn half present hym to þe kyng, " & sey his enemy ys ouer-comen " Now þys hound Hengist ys nomen!"
text.143: ¶ De capcione Hengisti per Comitem Gloucestrie. Þan was Hengist ful-like fouly. schent, Þat ffetered to þe kyng was sent. Þen dide þe kyng kep hym ful streit In cheynes bounden for deseit. fo desceite. Hengistes sone þat highte Octa, & his cosyn sire Ebbesa, Wyþ gret pyne þey boþe ascaped, & &yogh;ork to take þey hem raped. Bot whan þey hadde þe toun taken, Warly wayted, & held þem waken, Þoþer þat lefte, fled her & þer, By dounes & dales, by in. wodes ay-wher. Þe kyng was ioyful þat he so spedde, Hengist was taken, & his folk fledde; To Conyngesburghe þe kyng gan turne, & þere þre dayes mad he soiourne, Þe wounded for to hele & reste, Þe Payens fro þe Cristen keste. In þat tyme þat þey þer lay, Þe Bretons barons. alle, þat oþer day To conseil þe kyng cald hem to, Þe beste to wite Of Hengist. what were to do: Wheþer Hengist þey redden MS. reddem. hym whedir þei red him for. to slo, Or hym enprisone, Hold him in prison. or lete hym go. A byschop onswered,—sire Eldadus, Sire Eldokes broþer,—& seide right þus: " I deme Hengist þe same wys " As in þe bible Samuel seys. " Samuel did Agag to þe ded— " Kyng of Amalek was þat qued,— " A ful fers proude. kyng, riche & kene, " To Godes folk he wroughte al tene, till godes folk he did ay tene. at all his myght wo þam wrouht. & euer werre on þam souht. " He robbed here godes, þer tounes brent, " & alle he slow þat he myght hent. " Swylk sorewe suilk mischefe. myght nought longe dure; " He was taken at a desconfyture, " & brought byfore Saul þe kyng, " ffor his mysdedes to haue demyng. How he had don to here endyng. " Saul asked what iugement " Schuld Agag haue, er þat he went. " Þan ros þe prophete Samuel, ¶ Exemplum de Iudicio Hengisti. " Keper of þe folk of Israel, " And vpon Agag handes he leyd; " Tyl hym & alle, þise wordes he seyd: " 'Agag, þou has manion trauailled, " 'Manion slayn, manyon assayled; essillié, Wace , l. 8082, from MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3. Colb. " 'Many lond mad wast & wylde, " 'Many wydewe, many faderles childe; " 'Þorow þe haue [many] ben lorn & slawen, " 'Many soule & bodies brought of dawe. many saule of body drawen. " 'Þe same wyse schal þy body sall þi soule. be refte! " 'Childles for þe þy moder ys left!' " Agag siþen he al to-hew, " Thorow out þe contres þe peces þrew, " & seide, 'oueral þou hast don wo, " 'Of þe oueral schal wonder sall wondryng. go.' " As þe prophete gaf dom þorow lawe, " So schal &yogh;e do Hengist to-drawe." so suld &yogh;e do Hengist of dawe. When sire Eldok herd hym so say, & þat holy wryt schewed þat euene way, Smertly wyþ þe dom al hot, Hengistes heued of he smot. Þen dide þe kyng þe body graue I þe manere of Payen lawe. on þat maner þat paien sall haue. Syþen quikly þe kyng hym spedde, He &yogh;ared Dight. his host, to &yogh;ork þem ledde, Þe toun & his enemys for to wynne; P. leaves out this line. ffor Hengistes sone was þer-ynne, 1 & oþer manye lordynges þer ware, & somme y þe contre in mykel kare. 1 1-1 & many lordes of his kynd. & som in þe cuntre myght men fynd. Þen Octa studied in his þought: To stonde to fens auailled nought; Socour to sende he wyste of non, Þer socour was for euere gon; He couþe se no bettere bote, Bot auntre, & bot for to. falle þe kyng to fote; ffel hit to wysdom or to foly, He schulde auntre hym mercy to cry: & alle his men red hym þer-tyl, Naþeles hit was his owen wyl. Out of þe tour toun. ilkon cam; As prisoners, barfot als prisons bare fote. þey nam. Octa had don, in stede of streng, Aboute his nekke a chayne heng, & on his knes fel mekely, full myldely. & seide, "Sire kyng! Mercy! Mercy! " Alle oure Godes ar vs failled; " Þat we on trowe, haue vs nought vailled; " &yogh;our God ys of wel more myght; " Þat we in leue, ar nought so right; " He scheweþ miracle for þy loue; " We ar byneþe, & &yogh;e MS. we. P. has þou. aboue; " We ar ouer-comen, þer-fore we .I. com; " Mercy to craue, haf. to þe we nom. " Haue here þys cheyne, & do þy wylle, " Wheþer þat &yogh;e wil whedir þou will. vs saue or spille! " We ar payed, wheþer þou wylt; " We arn aknowe we haue agilt. I am oknowe .I. haf þe gilt. " To haue oure lyues, &yogh;yf þou wilt graunt, " What so þou saist, we holde couenaunt sais we hold conant. " To serue [þe] þe. til oure lyues ende, " Ne neuere more ageyn þe wende." Þe kyng was of ful gret pite; He saide: "lordynges, what sey &yogh;e? " What conseil wil &yogh;e me gyue?" & seide, "rede &yogh;e þat þey lyue?" Þenne spak þe Byschop Eldadus Vnto þe kyng Aurelius: " Wel ys worþy, mercy to haue, " Þat mekely mercy wyl craue. " Agayn mercy who-so ys grym, " God wyl haue no mercy of god has not mercy on. hym. " To þy mercy þey made asay, " Mercy þey seke haue, &yogh;yf þe[y] þei. may. " ffor Bretaigne ys large & long, " & many stedes wast among, " Deliuere þeym lond þer þay &yogh;e. se skil, " Let þem trauaille þer-on to tyl. " Bot y rede, hostages &yogh;e take; " Sykernesse þey schul sall. &yogh;ow make, " In alle seruise to be trewe; " & &yogh;our mercy schal hem be newe.
text.144: ¶ Exemplum Byblie. " In þe bible ensample bygan: " Þe folk of Gabaot, þat wyþ wrong wan " Of þe Iewes, & syþen hit les; " At þe Iewes þey bysoughte pes, " Of þer wrong bysoughte asked. mercy, " & þey graunted hem al redy. " Syn þey had mercy & pyte, " Wirse þan þey, schul nought do we. suld we not be. " At þe Iewes, ensample nymes, " Graunt hem mercy, lyf & lymes." Þe kyng graunted þem þanne his pes As þe bischop Eldade ches. Bysyde Scotlond he gaf hem londes; Þey tylede, & were grete husebondes; gode hosbondes. Er þey wente, þey geue hostage, he toke ostages. Children of þeyres, of best lynage. childere of þer best lynages. ffiftene dayes his court gan ly, Þen dide he somone al þe clergy,— & gaf þem landes, rentes, & fees, P. transposes these lines. — Bischopes, abbotes, of þe contres. P. transposes these lines. Schirreues, baillifs, he sente sett. ay-whore, His rentes to gadere & to restore; Masons, whrightes, kyrkes dide make, Þat þe Payens dide doun schake; Þat fordon were þorow Hengist, Were wrought a-geyn to serue Crist. ffro þenne þiþen. to Londone euene he went: Þe toun he fond peyred & schent; Kyrkes, houses, were beten doun; To þe kyng þey mente hem of þe toun, Þat many of þe beste burgeys Were fled, euery man his weys. & ilk man &yogh;ede his weis. He bigged eft þat er was playn,— Clerkes, burgeys, dide come agayn,— & gaf ilkon ageyn þer estre. Syþen he wente turned. to Wyncestre, & bygged kirkes & houses MS. housed. P. houses. þere, Als he had don elles where. Syþen he &yogh;ede to Salesbury, & til þe abbey of Aumbresbury; & til þat stede he tok his waye ? MS. a altered to e , or first e to a. Þere Hengist dide þe Bretons deye. Þeyr buryels he þoughte for to honure Wyþ som þyng þat ay myght dure, & ffryþe þe frithe þat. ( frithe , preserve.) stede þer þey lay, Þat hit myght laste til Domesday. He dide masons diuise a cast What werk myghte lengest last.
text.145: ¶ De consilio Tremorii Episcopi. Wyþ þe kyng a clerk was þore, His name MS. mame. was sire Tremore, Was Erchebischop of Kerlyon; He seyde the kyng a god he did þe king in. reson: " &yogh;yf he wolde make a werk fyn, if he wild mak a werk of fyne. " Do send &yogh;our sonde after Merlyn. " To make þis werk, may no man " Gyue swylk conseil als he can; " He can þe telle what schal bityde: " After hym, y rede, &yogh;our werk abyde."
text.146: ¶ Rex mysit hic pro Merlyno. Þen seyde þe kyng, "hit scholde so be; " Mikel y desire Merlyn to se; " Of his wysdam woldy here, " He telleþ wondres sais selcouthes. on many manere." At a welles well. (a Labenes, une fontaine, Wace , l. 8217.) fer in Walys— ' Baynes' hit highte by olde tales— Þe messeger þen Merlyn fond: " Cum, spek wyþ þe kyng! he sent his sond." When he com byfore þe kyng, He made ioye for his comyng, & honured hym, for he was wys, & cherisched him ouer alle oþere of pris; He praaied hym wel wyþ louely full louand. speche, What scholde bytide, he wolde hym teche. ¶ " Syre kyng," he seyde, said Merlyn. "certes nay, Responcio Merlyny. " To opene my mouþ y ne dar ne may, " Bot hit [be] a byhouely bot if it be a behouely. þyng at nede, " Þat were warnyng or tokene of dede, " & &yogh;it wyþ gret lownesse of hert, " Þat pruyde turne hit nought ouerthwert. " ffor &yogh;yf y spak þorow pride or bost, " Oþer for scorn, ageyn my gost, " Þat ilke gost þat in me wones, " Þat al me kennes & al me mones, " Out of my mouþ hit wolde hym drawe, " Of my connyng reue me my sawe, " Þat namore myght y þen spek wyþ mouþ " Þan an oþer þat nought ne couþ. " Þer-fore of swyilk priuete " Þenk nought þer-on, but let hit be. " Þenk on þat why þou me soughtest; souhtes . . . . . brouhtes. " Bryng þat til ende whi þou me broughtest: " &yogh;yf þou wilt make a werk stedefast, " Þat fair wyl be, & euere to last, " Sent for þo send for þe. stones, þere þey stande, " Þat þe Geaunt Geantz. broughte til Irlande. " Rounde aboute, þen ar þey set; " Out of Aufryke were þey fet; " Ilkon on oþer ys set vpright, " No man in erþe haþ no myght " ffor to take doun a ston; " Ne sette þeym eft ys þer non." Þen seyde þe kyng, & on hym low: louh. " Sertes, þat were selcouþ ynow it were þan grete ferly how. " Þat þo stones þat þou of seys, " Ar so heuy, & of swylk peys, " Þat non haþ force ne fuysoun " To remue þem vp ne doun, " & ar so fer ouer þe se! " Who myghte þem þanne brynge to me?"
text.147: ¶ Prudencia superat omne Robur. Þen seide Merlyn vnto þe kynge, " Queyntise ouer-comeþ alle þynge. " Strengþe ys god wyþ vnto. trauaille; " Þer strengþe ne may, sleyght wil availle; " Sleyght & connyng doþ many a chare, Engins et ars font mainte cose, Wace , i. 386, l. 8265. " Bygynneþ þyng þat strengþe ne dar; " Wyþ sleyght myght þou þe stones wynne, " & in Bretaigne set þem inne, " Þer þou ne schalt wyþ no strengthe " Remewe hem a stones lengthe.
text.148: ¶ Exe virtus de Stonhenges. " In Aufrik were þey compassed & wrought; " Geauntz til Irland þennes hem fro þiþen þam. brought, " & sette þem on an hil ful hey " Wiþ engyns ful queyntely. " ffirst when þey ware compassed newe, " Þey dide gret god to þem þat knewe; " þo þat were seke, or had laught & lauht. skaþes, " Wasche wesch. þe stones, did hit in baþes; " Þat felde hem greued of grettere felt þam greued of grete. þynges, " Wasched þem bathed þam. of þe selue waschinges, " & warysched heled. wel of al þer pyne; " Had þey non oþer medycine." ¶ When þe kyng herde of þer vertu, Þat þey myght falle þe folk to prw, He had longyng for þem to go,— & of þat wyl wer oþer mo,— Þe stones to Bretaigne for to brynge, Þat Merlyn made of sermonynge. Þey chosen ches. Vter, þe kynges broþer, Þe kyng ofred hym self þat oþer; Of folk þey ladde fyftene þousand, Agayn þe Irische Iris (but Irisch l. 8837). for to stand; Wyþ þem wente daunz Merlyn, ffor þo stones to make engyn. When Vter wyþ his folk was &yogh;are, To schip þey went, ouer se to fare, & aryued vpon þat cost. Þe Irisch Iris (but Irisch l. 8837). kyng gadered his host; Ageyn þe Bretons þey cam right &yogh;erne, Þe lond &yogh;yf þey myghte þem werne. Þe Irisch kyng þat regned þar, His name was sire Gwylomar; When he wyste why þat he cam, whi þei kam. & so fer viage for stones nam, He scorned þem on his langage, P. leaves out this line. ' So fer for stones to make passage, P. leaves out this line. ' Ouer se til an oþer lond, ' ffor þey no stones hender ne stones hender. fond;' & seyde, "þe stones þey schold haue here, " Þey schul by hem first ful dere; " ffor &yogh;yf we may, þey schul nought spede, " Þe stones out of my land to lede." He scorned & seyde, "hit schal be nought, " Þey schul faille þat þey haue sought." Þys kyng byhig[h]t hem foul despit, P. leaves out this line. Bot wykke þey were to desconfyt. P. leaves out this line. So longe he manased & þret, Atte laste to-gydere þey met. At þeyr metyng, hit was nought lyte When þey gonne to-gyder smyte. fful wel foughte boþe partys, Bot þe Bretons wan sone þe pris; Þe Irische Iris. couþe nought so wel feight, Ne of armure þey hadde no sleight, Ne þer-of were so wel bone, Þer-fore þe Irische Iris. fledde ful sone; ffro stede to stede þey fledde to sculk, On heþ & hilles to hyde in on hii hilles to hide &. (hulk , cubile, tugurium, hovel, sty.) hulk. When Bretons hadde don þat chace, & rested þeym a gret[e] long. space, Merlyn had þem alle at ones To þe hil to se þe stones.— Kylomare highte þe hyl Þer þe geauntz broughte þem tyl.—
text.149: ¶ De asportacione lapidum de Stonhenges, de Hybernia in Brytanniam. Þys Bretons aboute renged þe feld, Þe carole of þe stones byhe[l]d. beheld. fful often &yogh;ede þey many tyme &yogh;ede þam. aboute, Byhelde wyþynne & eke within biheld. wyþoute; Alle þey seyde, so seyde þe kyng, ' Þey sey sauh. neuere so selcouþ þyng.' How þey were reysed þey had wonder, & how þey scholde be brought a-sonder. The Petyt MS. adds,— with þat worde þei þam rescued. þei ne wist how þei suld remued. Merlyn seyde, "now makeþ assay " To potte þe stones, &yogh;yf þat putte þis stones doun if. &yogh;e may; " & wyþ force fondeþ þem to bere: " Þer force ys mykel, lesse wyl þem þe lesse will. dere." Þe host atones to þe hil þey went, & ilk man tok þat he myght hent, Ropes to drawe, tres to potte, put (push). Þey schouued, þey þriste, þey stode o strot, o strut. On ilka side, byhynde, by-forn; Al for nought; þer trauail was lorn. When þey ofte hadde all þe had. put & þryst, & ilk man do what hym do lyst, & left þer pottyng puttyng. many on, &yogh;it stirede þey nought þe leste ston. Bot Merlyn wiste hit scholde nought vaille: Strengþe of body ne myght nout vaille. He bad hem alle drawe þem o drey; " Þorow strengþe come &yogh;e neuere þem ney." Al stille a litill. he stod, syþen hym bywent, & spak, but non wist what he ment; His lippes þey seye stire vp & doun, Bot non herde his coniurysoun. When he had gon alle aboute, Wyþynne þe carole, & wyþoute, & seide his coniurisouns, Ageyn he calde al þe Bretouns, And seyde, "now may &yogh;e lyghtly bere " þe stones to schip wyþouten dere. " Goþ now alle, & spedeþ &yogh;ow, " ffor &yogh;e schal welde þem wel ynow." Als Merlyn þem taughte & seyd, In MS. Im. to þe schypes þem lyghtly leyd; Þen had þey wonne þat won þei. fer had sought. To þe playne of Salesbury þem brought, Of Aumbresbyri bysyde an abbay, & hit was atte Whitemonday. & was at þe whitsonenday. (à Pentecoste, Wace , i. 391, l. 8370.) Þen dide þe kyng make somons Of bischopes, erles, & barons, & oþer lordes of þe nobleste, folk of noble geste. & dide hym coroune at þat feste. Þre dayes laste þe feste fode; sat þe feste of fode. Þe ferþe day he gaf on þe ferth day gaf he. gyftes gode— Croces [riche] to clerkes of pris, To seint Saunsom Sampson. & seint Dubris. Seint Dubrice he gaf Kaerlyon, &yogh;ork he gaf to seint Saunson; Sampson. Þys gaf he at his coronement, & many mo, þorow bi. comun assent. Byfore þe lordes þat come þyder, Merlyn sette þe stones to-gyder; Als þey were or, in þat certeyn, So stande þey now vpon þe pleyn. Wyþynne þe compas of þe stones Ar byried alle þo lordes bones Þat Hengist atte Parlement slow; Here byforn &yogh;e herde wel how.
text.150: ¶ De Pascencyo, filio ffortygerny. Of ffortyger, þat þe kyng had brent, Was left a sone þat highte Passent. ffor drede of Aurelius & of Vter, Vntil Alemayne he fledde fer, & purchaced hym folk on þe se, & aryued vp y þe northe contre, Tounes struyed, contres wasted. Þe kyng herd seye, & sone hym & þider. hasted. When Pascence herde þat þe kyng cam, Ageyn to þe se þe wey he nam; Þer he cam fro, durst he nought wende, Vpon Irland his flute flete. gan lende; He spak so wyþ þe kyng of þat land, Þat he was his wel willand Vpon Bretaigne a route to renge, & on þe Bretons for to venge. Passent calanged chalanged. his fader wones, Þe kyng for robberye of þe stones; Truþe to-gydere boþe þey plyght, To take vengaunce at þer myght. Wyþ al þe force þei myght gete, In Walsche lond & in wales. aryued þer flete. Þey spirde aboute in ilka contre; Meneue þey tok, was a toke þat. cite; Meneue ys langage on Bretoun, & now hit hatte Seint Dauy toun. In þat tyme þat þey cam þus, Syk lay oure kyng Aurelius At Wynchestre mani a day; Longe bedrede þer he lay, Þat he ne myghte neyþer couere ne deye, Bot euer MS. ouer. more languisched on euer languest one. weye. As he lay sek, bode hym was sent Þat ffortigeres sone, sire Passent, In Walys was, & þe Irische Iris. kyng, On hym to make a chalangyng; He chalanged hym of robbery, & sire Pascent passent of dede. of felony. Þe kyng seide, "Vter for me schal go, " ffor y ne may, me ys ful wo." Sire Vter seyde, "y am redy;" His folk somonde al pryuely, Wyþ hors & armes redy to ryde, & com til hym; he scholde þem byde. Longe hit was y þe somouns, & þe buschyng buskyng (preparing, getting ready). of þe barouns; P. adds these two lines, not re|presented in Wace's text, ii. 3,— dred þei were þe kyng suld die. & in to wales fer was þe weie. God whyle gude stound. hit was er he þem wan In-til Walys, ilka man.
