text.151: ¶ Appas traditor. ¶ In al þys drechyng als þey gan dwelle, Of on Appas y schal &yogh;ow telle: Appas he highte, & was a Saxon, Appas was a sesson. & well couþe contreue a treson; He ffeyned hym to be [a] fened him to be a. leche, & couþe speke diuerse speche. A day to Pascent þis Appas spak,— Treson he þoughte, & out hit brak,— " Passent," seyde Appas, "wel y wot, " Bytwixt þe kyng & þe ys hatrede hatered. hot. " What wiltow gyue me, & y schal go, " Þe kyng Aurelyus for to slo?" Passent seyde, "y schal gyue þe " A þousand pound of god mone, " Wyþy with þi (with that, so that). þy word be certayn " To sey me when þou hast hym slayn." Appas seyde "wel y graunt;" Seide Passent, "y holde couenaunt." Appas spak Latyn parfit, & clad hym in a monkes habyt; Als a monk he dide hym schaue, Contenaunce couþe he ful wel haue. Od contenance monial, Wace , ii. 5, l. 8465. Venyn Venom. for salue wyþ hym he nam, Als a monk to court he cam; ffor yueles Iuels. he couþe medicine make, Þe kyng he seyde he wolde vndertake: ' &yogh;yf he wolde do after at. his queyntise, ' Sone he scholde so he wild. do hym vp ryse.' He tasted his pous, saw his vryn, He seide he knew his medycyn. A bit from the Normandy of Wace's time.
text.152: ¶ De Morte Aurelij Regis per Appas traditorem Saxonem. Þe kyng &yogh;erned his hele mykel, 'Si com cascuns de vous vol|'droit,' adds Wace, ii. 5, l. 8476. He wende nought a monk were fykel; He dide hym in kepyng of þe feloun, & he gaf hym drynke poysoun, & happed hym warme, & bad hym slepe, ffor in his lymes hit schold al lepe. When þys Appas his nedes had sped, Al so swyþe a-wey he fled; And sone after in a þrowe Þe kyng hit wiste, & men wel sowe, knowe. Þat he scholde al-gate deye. Þen preied he men þey scholde hym leye At Stonhenges in a graue, His byriels for to mene & saue. On þys manere þe kyng was ded, & beryed als after his red.
text.153: ¶ De stella Cometa que apparuit. Vter þat tyme in Walys was Þat þe kyng was poysond wyþ Appas. Als he was ded, þen ros a sterne Þat many a man biheld ful &yogh;erne, ' Comete' ys cald in astronomye, Kynges deþ dede. wil hit signefye. ffro þat cam a bem ful bryght, Onlyke on, þat lemede lyght; Þe lemyng was boþe red & schir, Lyke a dragon þat sparkled fyr; Was þer neuere erl ne was noiþer erle no. baroun Þat þey ne lykned hit til a dragoun. Two brondes come out of his mouþ Þat lightned Est, West, & est with þe. Souþ: Vpon ffraunce lygh[t]ned lighted. þat on; Þat oþer vntil Moungow schon; Þe þridde, þat vntil þrid vnto. Irland &yogh;ede, In seuen braunches gan it MS. þey. P. has it. (see 9096.) sprede, & alle were þey schynand On þe water & on þe land. Þys ilke merueille þat þus was sene, Men wondred what hit wolde mot. mene. Sire Vter, þe kynges broþer, Hym merueilled more þan anoþer; any oþer; and leaves out the next two lines. Merueillyng, he was affrayed; Of þat affray he was nought payed; He preyed Merlyn ful specialy Þe toknyng þer-of to telle, to telle him what it ment. & why. Þen sey Merlyn þat Merlyn sauh it with sir vter. sire Vter Sore sykede, & feightit Sore sighyng he fecched it. fer, And stod as he were in dwale, No word ne seide, bot wax al pale. When his spirit was comen ageyn, & þoughte, 'þat may nought helpe, ys veyn,' Seid Merlyn, "Sorewe Ihesu he said sore. may þey mone, " Alle þat now in Bretaigne wone! " Lore þey haue þer noble kyng " Þat brought hem of Saxons yam of. encombrynge, " Out of þe false Payens þe paiens sessons. handes, " Þat manion broughte in to. bitter bandes!" When Vter herde his broþer was ded, He bycom as heuy as led: " Alas!" he seide, "now haþ Bretaygne Loren þer noble cheuentayne!" lorn hym þat was a noble chef|tayn. He syked sighed. for sorewe, deol was to se. Þen seyde Merlyn, "Vter, let be, " Þer no bote ys ouer sore ne sorewe! " Þy lyf may no man bye ne borewe; " Of deþ may non þe dede may non no. bale bete, " Þe sorewe nedly byhoueþ men sorow bos men nedes. lete; " Bot haste þe swyþe on þyn enemis! " Of þe bataille þou getest þe prys, 3 " To morewen schul þey boþe be schent, " & al þer folk boþ sleyn & hent. 3 3-3 of þe Iris kyng & passent. to morne sall þei boþe be schent. " Syþen schaltow þe coroune take, " Þe pes to menteyne & to make.
text.154: ¶ De interpretacione Comete per Merlynum. " Þe sterne þat þou seye ses. so red, " Bytokneþ euere þe kynges ded. " Þe dragon, þat semeþ P. inserts flaumand. so hey, " Þy self hit menes, þat ys so hardy; " Þe brond þat schyned out of his mouþ, " Þat spreden spredes. boþe Est & South, " Þat ys, of þe schal sall. come a sone " Doughty of dede, many on schal mone; " Alle ffraunce þen schal sall. hym loute, " Vntil Mongow men schal sall. hym doute. " Þat oþer, þat schon West so euen, " Toward þe Norþ hit spredde in seuen, " A doughter hit ys, y vnderstande, " Þat maried schal sall. be bysyde Scotlande; " Hure eyres bymene þo mene þe. seuen brondes, " Þat schullen sall. welde alle þo londes." ¶ Syre Vter listned ilka del How Merlyn conforted hym wel; He bad his host reste al þat nyght, On morn erlik arely. to bataille þem dight. Þe Irische Iris. wyste whan þey schold come, & made hem redy alle & some; þei dight þam & agayn þam nom. Stalworthly to-geder þey fought, Bot þe Irische Iris. sone were brought to nought, sone nouh ne douht. ffor þe Irische Iris. kyng & Passent Were slayn, & þer host al to-schent; MS. alto schent. P. alle schent. & þo þat wyþ þe lyf ascaped, with þe life scaped. To þer schipes faste þem raped. Of þo þat fledden & þei þam folowed in. to þe se, Þat was ouer-taken, slayn was he. Whe[n] al were slayn þey myghte hent, mot ouerhent. To Wynchestre sire Vter went. I þe weye he mette a messeger, Þat teldyt al to tald all till. sire Vter What manere þat þe kyng deyd, & byryed [was] was. þer (als he seyd) At Stonhenges so louely, þe stonhenges solemply. Wyþ þe byschopes & al þe clergy. As Vter com rydyng ridand. y þe stret, Þe folk on hym sore gon gon sore. gret, & seyde, "sire, haue mercy on vs! " Ded ys þy broþer Aurelyus " Þat mayntende vs in al his myght; " Tak þou þe coroune, hit ys þy right, " & be our heued, for we hit &yogh;ern, " & fend vs from our enemys fern."
text.155: ¶ Vter apud Wyntoniam cepit coronam. Syre Vter sey hit was to do, ffor his heritage hit was of blod al so. Hys barons þyder he dide somoune, & made a feste, & dide hym coroune. ffor Merlyn tolde þat toknyng Þat Vter scholde be doughty kynge, & of hym swylk heyres schold be, Alosed þorow-out named þourh. al Cristiante, And for þat dragon he sey in syght Bytokned hym self kyng þorow right, He dide make two dragons By conseil of hys barouns; Þat on he dide byfore hym bere, & ilka at ilk. tyme he &yogh;ede to were; Þat oþer dragon he did wyrk, & heng hit it hang. (A Piglise de l'Eves|quié, Wace , ii. 11, l. 8610.) at seinte Petres kirk. ffor þat skyl & þat enchesoun cheson. Was he cald Vter Pendragoun: Pen ys heued in Walsche langage; Dragon ys seyd on oure vsage; Pendragon was his to-name In all his lyue for þat same.
text.156: ¶ De Octa, filio Hengysty. Octa, Hengystes sone þat was, When Aurelius furgaf Forgyuen before. his trespas, & had hym gyuen, & þe kyng gaf him. & his meyne, Londes y þe norþ contre; When he wyste þat he was ded Þat þeym þe lond furst furbed, Of hym he gaf nought, þat was newe, Til hym þoughte he neuere be trewe. What dide þis schrewe, þe false Octa? Conseilled wyþ his cosyn Ebessa, Cosa. (Eossa, Wace , ii. 12, l. 8640; Eosa, Galf. Mon. viii. 18.) Wyþ alle þo of his owen kynde, & oþer Saxons þat þey myght fynde; & fele of þo wyþ hem went Þat scaped atte fro þe. slaughter of Passent; Þat fro Vter handes in weles. fled, Þey com til Octa, & he þem led. By-&yogh;onde Humber al þe land Octa tok vntil hys hand, Al til Scotland in lengþe & bred. To &yogh;ork syþen al þey &yogh;ed, Þat [toun] for to bysege þe toun for to sege. & to wyn; Þey defended hem faste wyþyn; fended it that was þer-In. Þe kyng þe sege wolde remewe, Þe toun a-geynes þeym rescuwe; He þoughte nought longe fort long to. abyde, Bot gadered folk on ilka syde. When he was comen, he abod nought, Bot on þe Payens bataille sought; & þe Payens egre & stout, Þorow þe Bretons held þem out; Payens & Cristen, many were slawen, & many a sowle fro Many saule of. body drawen.
text.157: ¶ Obsitus est Vterus Rex super collem qui vocatur Damer; et exe saluati sunt per consilium Gorleni Comitis. Þe Bretons þat tyme myght nought sped; Bak þey turnde, þey saw ned; Þe Payens after folewed fast, & many vn-to dede cast. Whider to fle þey were al wyl; Þe Payens hem chased vntil an hyl, ll. 9189-9190. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. ' Damer' Daniens, Wace , ii. 13, l. 8675; Damen, Galf. Mon. þe hil so hight. Þe Bretons tok hit þo þat nyght; Hey & streit, ful narow hiie & narow full strayte. (agus en som, Wace , ii. 13, l. 8676.) to prykke, Aboute y-busched wyþ þornes busked with hesils. þykke. When þe Bretons þe hil had taken, Wyþ sege þe Payens held þem waken, Bot hit was atte þe nyght, Þeym to saille þey ne myght; Þey logged þem stille in þe playn, & þe Bretons were y þe mountayn; Þe Payens to þer loggyng loges. gan lep; Wery þey were, & fulle on slep. Þe kyng had of hym self gret drede, & of his folk þat he schold suld. lede, How he scholde suld. a-scape þem fro; Þer weyes wer stopped þer þey schold suld. go. Þe Erl of Cornewaille was o þat hyl, Gorlens he highte, a man of skyl, Wysest he held hym of ylkon; To hym for conseil þey mente þer mon, ffor he was man of gret queyntyse, & neuere louede no cowardyse. ll. 9211-9212. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. He seide "for conseil &yogh;e com me to; " Y schal &yogh;ow conseille, &yogh;yf &yogh;e wil so. " ¶ Mercy to God, first we schal cry, " & mende vs of al oure foly, " & preye Iesu our Saueour " To schulde vs fro Wace invents this piece of piety; but puts it (ii. 15) after Geoffrey's and his advice to attack by night. mysauentour, " & gif vs grace & powere " Ageins þe Payens þat sege vs here, " Þat vs often wo han vs vs cristen wo has. wrought, " & hym for Lord ne knowe þey nought; " Þat he to day stonde vs by, " On hys enemys to haue maystri. " &yogh;yf he wyl helpe, our Lord Ihesus, " Who may þanne ageyns vs?" To his conseille þei graunted alle, & faste on Iesu þen gon þey calle, & highte to make amendement, Þat tyme to schape &yogh;yf scape. if. he þem lent. " Arme &yogh;ow," he seyde, vs he said now. "pryuely, " & go we stille, wyþouten cry; " Þey arn a ere on. slepe, y am right siker; " Þey trauailled faste to gyue vs byker, " & wene nought we dur vs abate, " ffor þey desconfit vs so late; " Þey hope to morn atte sonne rysyng " Vs to slo, or &. take our kyng. " Arme vs swyþe, & go we doun, MS. douns. " Wyþoute any more sarmoun!" ¶ Þey armed þenne þam sone. knyght & swayn, Pryuely com doun in to þe playn, & fond hem slepyng, slepand. als he sayd; Vnarmed, ilkon were þey leyd.
text.158: ¶ Occisio Paganorum. When þe Bretons were spred aboute In þer host, wyþynne MS. wyþynne & wyþynne. & wyþoute, Þen was slaughtere wyþoute pite; Was non for merci &yogh;olden fre; Þorow wombe & breste þe speres bot, Hedes, handes, fet, of smot. To arme þeym þey nadde no space, Ne to fle had þey no grace; &yogh;yf any fledde þat fle myght, Þe merknesse saued [hem] þat nyght. ll. 9253-9254. The Petyt MS. leaves out these lines; but they are in Wace, ii. 17, l. 8761-2. Octa & Ebessa cosa. o lyue þey tok, At Londone in prison he dide þem lok. ¶ When þis Payens were desconfit, Toward þe norþ þey went ful tyt; Northumberland, Scotland, þorow þey rod, Als hit was fer, [boþ] long & brod. Þo þat myghte no men non myght ore. (La gent qui estoit sans justice, Wace , ii. 17, l. 8773.) iustise, Al he drow til his seruise; Ouer al he sette swylk pees, Bettere neuere no man ches. When he was kyng kyd & couþ, He tok his gate toward þe souþ; At Londone his Pasches he held, Wyþ erl & baron, & knyght of scheld; Byschopes, abbotes, he dide somoune, & riche burgeyses, & oþer in of. toune; He dide comaunde, vpon þer lyf, Þat wedded men schold bryng þer his. wyf, 2 & oþere honeste of his meyne, Man or woman, wheþer þey be; Al he bad vntil his feste, Þat were worþy & honeste. 2 2-2 & if he wild his oþer meigne þat were auenantin courte to se. Man or woman þat were honeste all he bed vnto his feste.
text.159: ¶ De festo Vtery Regis. When alle were comen þat schold or wylde, Innes taken, ne &. fulfilde, & at þe kirke þer seruise seyd, In halles & hales bordes leyd, Þe kyng was set, & serued of mees, & at þat oþer ende was a dees; Þer set þe barons of pris, Þe Erl of Cornewaille ageyn his vys; By hym sat Igerne his wyf, Of whas fairhede was speche ryf; In al þe reome, regne. so fair was non, Ne of swylk kynde, bot scheo al on. ne of suilk was þer non. Often þe kyng had herd hure preyse, Þat sche was fair, god, & curteyse; Mikel desired he hure to se. When he hure sey, hir sawe. more louede he; Þe sight of hure hym al to-blast; all to brast. His herte on hure ageyn he cast;
text.160: ¶ De Igerna, Comitissa Cornubye. Wheþer he et or drank, spak ought or nought, Igerne was euere in his þought, Ne cam sche neuere out of his hert, To hure was his eye euere ouer-thwert. By his priues often [he] hure of he hir. grette, & his presentes byforn hure sette, Often hure lout, oft on hir luke. & on hure low, & made semblaunt of loue ynow. Hure contenaunce was, & hure semblaunt, Sche nought ne seyde, ne nought wold graunt; Þe kyng of hure nought vnderstod In contenaunce but bo. stable & god. What for laughynge & oþer tyhtes, What for presentes & oþer delites, sightes. Þe Erl perceyued & þoughte ful &yogh;erne Þe kyng louede his wyf Igerne; & þoughte þoughte=þought he. P. He þouht. no feyþ til [him] wold þat faith he ne wild him. bere, But he in pes his wyf myght were. Vp þen stirt he fro þe bord— To þe kyng ne spak he word,— His wyf by þe hand he hent, & calde his knyghtes, & þennes þien. went. Hastely þer hors were bone, & to Cornewaille þey come sone. Er he was redy for &yogh;are redy. to wende, Þe kyng comaunded, as he was hende, ' Þat he schold comen to court a-geyn, ' Or he dide vylenye els did he ville. til his souereyn; ' And &yogh;yf he ne wolde come bleþely, ' Waite hym wel as for kepe him wele he were. his enemy.' Þe kynges sonde he wolde nought here, He made no force of his preyere. When þe kyng wyste þat he wold nought Come ageyn, as he bisought, He manased hym wyþ [felle] felle. herte, & seyde he schold hit it suld him. sore smerte. ffor no all þe. manace ne wolde he byde; Bot he ne wyste what scholde bytide. Two casteles he hadde in Cornewaille, Þo he warnisched wyþ vitaille; In þe castel of Tyntagel He dide his wyf to kepe wel; Of defens hit hadde it his. gret los, Wyþ dyk & se hit see & fen it. ys in clos; Who-so kepes þat [&yogh;ate] þe &yogh;ate. (la porte, Wace , l. 8852.) See l. 9412 below. in nede, In oþer stede dar þar. hym nought drede; Þer-inne scheo was he did hir be. &yogh;emed & sperd, & he til his oþer castel ferd; Þider he ledde his souders, To kepe þe kyng at sautes sers; I þat castel was, þat he to cam, Þe force of al his erldam.
text.161: ¶ De obsisione Gorlencii Comitis per Regem. Þe kyng wyste he made purueaunce A-gayns hym to stande at stand. to chaunce. Þe kyng also sone purueyed his host; Þer þe Erl was, byseged þe cost; Þe castel þat þe Erl was in, He byseged hyt for to wyn. Al a wyke seuenyght. þe kyng þer lay, He spilte his tyme, sped of no pray; Of þe Erl nought he ne wan, Ne dide scaþe til no man, ffor þe Erl kepte euere þe comyng Hy[m] him. to socoure þe Irische kyng. Þe kyng sey þe sege was wast; Igerne to haue he wilde hym hast; He was ful gretlyk onoyed Þat his tyme so was destruyed. He calde Vlfyn, his priue baroun, To conceille hym of som resoun: " Vlfyn," he saide, "þou conseil me; " My beste conseil y take at þe. " On Igerne y am enamured anamorde. strong, " I deye &yogh;yf hit me laste long; " Y ne may slepe, wyþ wo y wake, slepe wo. I. waken. " So am y in hure loue y-take; " Ete ne drynke ne may y nought, " So lowe hure loue haþ me hir luf benethen has me so. brought; " Loue dereþ me so, to deye luf has me wonded dede. y dred; " Y aske conseil how y may sped." Seyd Vlfyn þen, "y here merueilles! " Þou louest his wyf þat þou lufes his wife & him. assailles! " Wenestow þer-wyþ to ben aboue? " Þorow werre wynne to wyn. his wyf to loue? " Hure to loue þou com to late; " Hure loue to gete, hure lord to take. ll. 9379-9380. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " At wham toke þou þis conseil, " To loue in tene & in with. turpeyl? " Conseil of þis can y non kest; " Of swylk conseil Merlyn can best; " He can ynow of swylke craftes, " Of alle vigures figures. he turnes þe schaftes. " &YOGH;yf he can kenne þe no weye, " Igerne to wynne, can no man seye." ll. 9387-9388. The Petyt MS. leave out these lines. Þorow þe conseil of sire Vlfyn Þe kyng dide sende after Merlyn. Merlyn com þe kyng byforn; He seide, "Merlyn, y am ner lorn! am forlorn. " Conseille me, syn þat þou can, " & y schal euere-more be þy man! " Y haue ner lorn wyt & lyf " ffor Igerne, þe kynges erles. wyf! " Help me now, þat y hure haue; " & what þou wilt, y vouche saue." " Syre," Sir kyng. seid Merlyn, "God furbede Dicta Merlyny. " Þat þou for hure schold be in drede, " ffor Igerne to haue þe ded! in drede for to haf þi dede. " Er schold y don anoþer red; " Þou schalt hure haue wyþoute pyne, " & &yogh;it wol y haue nought of þyne. " Bot, sire Vter, þou wost hit wel, " Strong ys þe hold of Tyntagel; " & scho ys loken þer-yn so strait, " Bot þorow queyntise or deseit " Noman ne may hure out[e] take, " Þorow non engyn þat men can make; " ffor two men þat oughtes without ( aht, oht , brave). be, " May kepe þe issue issheu. & þe entre; " & þey al hit be wykke to wynne, " fful wel schal y þe brynge .I. sall do þe. þer ynne.
text.162: ¶ De transfiguracione Merlyny. " ffor alle manere forme þat ys, " Kan y turne til oþer turne þe. lyknes: " A face to be like anoþer, " & a body vnto þat oþer; & his agayn vnto þe toþer. " Stature of body, speche & leryng, (? MS. heryng. ) ll. 9419-9422. The Petyt MS. leaves out these four lines. " & contenaunce of ylka þyng, " Y schal chaunge, what so þey are, " Ilkon schal wene þat oþer ware. " Þe Erl cherly MS. chly. P. þe erle specially. wyþ hym ledes " Two knyghtes, doughti of dedes; " Sire Bertel þen hat þat on, bretell hate þe ton. " Þat oþer heyghte sire Iordon; " Þis are his priue conseillours: " Til þeir lyknesse y schal turne oures; " Y þe Erles lyknesse y schal þe dight, " Y schal be lyke Bertil & .I. sall be bretell. his knyght, " Lyke Iordan schal sall. be Vlfyn; " Þus schal we come þe castel yn; " Alle þre at euen schol sall. we go " To þe castel, wyþouten mo, " & speke þer speche & þer facounde; " We schul sall. come in þen on a stounde. " Dred þe nought of no man, " ffor no queyntise þat any can; " And þou schalt haue hure to at. þy wylle, " Þy grete desir &yogh;ernyng. to fulfille." Al þat euere Merlyn teld, As gospel þe kyng hit held: Þen comaunded he til on certeyn, Þe host to kepe til he com ageyn. Þem charmed Merlyn þorow vertue, & colour & cloþyng dide remue, Contenaunce, speche, þe same assise; He turnde þe kyng on þe Erles wyse, & he & Vlfyn, to alle be þo. sightes, As Bertel & Iordan, þe Erles knyghtes. At euen þey come to Tyntagel, & þo þat wende haue knowe þem wel, Receyued þeym wyþ glad[e] chere, As hit were þe Erl lef & dere. What þey wilde, non wold þem werne; Þe kyng lay þat myght by Igerne, & scheo conseyued of hym þat nyght Concepcio Arthury. Arthur, þat was so mykel of myght. In þe host was told anon, ' Þat non wiste whider þe kyng was gon:' His ordynaunce þey al fursok, Þat þe kyng þe kepyng took; Þey armed hem to make asaut, ffor þat þey hadde of heued defaut, & went forþ y þe morn[e] morne. tyde; Non for oþer honour. wold oþer abyde; Of bataille sette þey no right ne bataile set ne rightly. renge, Bot ilkon forþ, þe kyng to venge. 5 Þen gon þey assaille boþ fer & hende. Þe Erl ageyn þem faste ga[n] fende: As he stod, er he lest MS. left ( lest =least). wende, He was schot to deþe, & made his ende. 5 5-5 was þer non held right aray. bot ilkone went to þe assay. on ilk a side þei gaf batayle þe erle agayn gan fast assaile. as he & his stode þam to fende. he was slayn or [þat] þei wende. When he was ded, his side gan slaken; Lightly was þen þe castel taken.
text.163: ¶ De Morte Comitis Cornubye. Þo þat askaped wyþ þe lyf, Brought tydyng to the Erles wyf, ' Hure lord was slayn y þe mornyng, ' Þe castel taken vnto þe kyng.' Þe kyng hym selue þe tydyng herd, He styrt vp, & þem answerd: " Let be &yogh;our tales to tene my wyf, þei be not trod. — " Y þank God y am her on lyf! I. am o life .I. tanke it god. — " To telle swylk tales for to greue! " Lesynges ar nought to byleue! " Y wot wel þey are in doute; " Vnwarned fro þeym y went oute; " ffor when y out of þe castel &yogh;ede, " Y spak to non, —þat ys þer drede,— " Ne seyde whider þat y wold suld. go, " ffor doute & treson drede. of my fo; " & for y cam nought sone suyth. agayn, " Wene þey now þat y be am. slayn. " Bot þat my folk doun ys born, " Slayn, & [eke] þe castel lorn, " Hit may do tene & greuaunce; " Bot y lyue, God þanky þe lyf þank god þat. chaunce! " I schal me haste, out y schal will .I. wende, " Pes for to seke; þe kyng ys hende. " Er any more skaþe falle, " Y wyl acorde me wiþ þem alle. " &yogh;yf he wyþ sege sperre me her-yn, " More wo þan ys, þen scholde bygyn." ll. 9501-9502. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. To þat conseil Igerne redde,— Alle tymes þe kyng scheo dredde;— In armes boþe ilk oþer hent, Þe kyng hure kyste, & out he went. ¶ When þey þei were. passed, alle þre, Ilkon was, as fel to be, com estre dut, Wace , ii. 28, l. 9022. & come dryuande vntil þe host; After þe Erl he spyrde most, Who gaf conseil for to go, Þe castel to take, þe Erl to slo? Þe soþe þenne sone. was hym told, Of on & oþer, symple & bold. Þe kyng þer-fore was wo ynow, He wraþed wyþ hem þat hym slow; Bot longe nold he þer-fore mourne, To Tyntagel a-geyn gan tourne, & to þeym of þe castel spak & seide: "y rede &yogh;e turne &yogh;our bak, " ffor he þat bataille on me bed, " Þe Erl &yogh;our lord, [he] ys now ded he is dede. ; " Now schol &yogh;e of non fynde socour " Agayn[e]s me to stande in stour." When þey herde þe kyng þus seyd, Þer socour lorn, þer heued hede. doun leyd, Þe castel anon til hym þey &yogh;olde, & leet hym do what þat he wolde. He &yogh;ede anon to dame Igerne; Als he had don, he teld hire &yogh;erne, Al how he by hure lay, & how he wente from hure away:
text.164: ¶ Rex desponsauit Igerniam. " Y am," he seide, "wyþouten wyf, " & þou art a sengle woman of lyf; " Y wol þe wedde, &yogh;yf þou wilt so." Dame Igerne consented þer-to: " Of no deseite nere wist y; " Bot of þy weddyng, sire, graunt mersy." Þe child scheo scho had. conseyued byforn, When tyme fel, hit was born: Arthur was þe childes name, A noble man, of ful gret fame. A doughter þey hadde,—Anne sche hight,— Þat gyuen was til a doughti knyght, Vntil sire Loth of Lonneys; Hys sone was Wawayn þe Curteys. Syþen regned Vter ful longe, & þan fel hym in. an yuel stronge; Bedrede doun ful longe he lay, & languissed so forþ fro languysced fro. day to day.
text.165: ¶ D[e] Octa, filio Hengisty. Þo þat kepte Octa, Hengistes sone, & Ebessa, Cosa. at Londone in prysone, Þey greued þem of þer þei were greued of. longe lokyng, And Octa gaf þem mykel þynge. ffor gyftes gyuen ofte & gret, Þey leet hem scape of þe prison sket, & wente wyþ hem ouer þe se In-til Saxoyne, þeyr contre. Þer gadered Octa ful gret host; Toward our kyng þey blewen he lewe. bost; He purchased purueid. hym a fflute on flod; Wyþ men of armes & with knyghtes & with. archers god Toward Scotland þey gan vp ryue, Pyled & brent, men broughte of lyue. Our kyng þat lay in langoryng, langoure . . . . . socoure. ¶ De langore Vtery Regis. Of hym was non help ne socuring His lond for to fende & fend no. were, He myghte nought ryse armes to bere; Þer-fore he bad alle his barouns Don after Lotes to do after sire loth. somouns, ffor he was doughti, noble & wys, knyght of gode auys. & sley cheuentayn of god auys. douhty man large & wys. Sire Octa þat hadde folk ynowe, Oueral þe Bretons þei pyled þe bretons ouer robbed. & slowe; He bolded hym wyþ mykel pryde, Þat þe kyng ne myghte go ne ryde; To meschef he putte al þat he fond, Man & wyf, þorow al þys lond. ll. 9577-9578. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Bot often Lot wyþ hym met, & ofte hym chaced þorow with. baret. Many tyme of hym he wan, & eft on hym þat oþer ran:— Hit ys custume þat werre bygynne, Somme to lese, & somme to wynne:— ll. 9583-9584. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Lot ful often son. dide hym fle, & chaced hym vnto þe se; Bot gret dedeyn [was] of þe barouns, Þat wold nought come for Lotes somouns,— Þey þought hem al [so] als. gentil of blod, & al so mykel in stede stod At ylka tyme, or more þan he, & also mykel of rente & fe;— Þus þey delayed, deleyd. long was þe drede, Til to. þe kyng sey how þat hit &yogh;ede; ffor Octa, al þe Norþ he wan, & of the Southe to seint Alban; Þys wan he for þe barons defaut, Þat for Lot nolde gyue wild gif non. assaut. Al þe lond, to þe kyng þey pleyned Þat þe barons alle all þam. feyned. ¶ Bot hereþ now of þe kynges wyl, Þat lefte He ne left. for syknesse ne for yl Þat he ne ros vp ful auster, & dide hym make a liter Corneled kirneld. as an hors bere, & seyde þis word þat alle myght here: " Now schal y se ho schal wyþstonde, " & ho wyl come for my sonde!" He somounde firste þo til his werre Þat deyned nought for Lot come nerre. Þey come, & were ful sore agrysen Whan þey wyste þe kyng was rysen. To þe toun of Wyrolhram Verolhram. Þe kyng & alle þe barons cam: Seint At saynt. Albon, þer lygges he, Þat highte Wyrolhram Verolhram. þe cite. Þer com þey to þe toun wyþ wyn; þe kyng com þat toun to wyn. Octa & hyse were alle þer-yn. Þe kyng byseged hit aboute, Dide make engyns stronge & stoute. Þe toun was þanne so strong & fyn, Hit hadde no dere doute. of non engyn; Octa & hyse were ryght full. bolde, Þey hadde god folk & syker holde, & seyde, 'hit was neuere [to] fere it was schame to bere fere. ' Of half a dedman lyggyng on for a half dede man in a. bere, ' Ne for swyche on to kepe þe For to hold þer. gates loken; " Cowardyse of vs scholde of þam. be spoken, " ffor to haue of swylkon drede, " Þat in a bere to bataille &yogh;ede." Alas! hit he. was no Cristen man, Þes þis. Octa þat so fer wan. His ouerwenyng & his pryde Dide þem opene þe gates wyde, & com stoutly vnto þe byker; Bot þer hap was al vnsyker; was not siker. For the next two lines P. has— þer fals trouth did þam misfalle. þat fell to wyn he wan þam alle. ffor synne of Octa, fals & fursworn, Dide al his felawes & hym be lorn; ffor slayn was þere sire Octa, & his cosyn sire Ebessa; Oþer ynowe &yogh;it þey skaped, Vntil Scotland þey hem raped, & ches þeym a prynce, sire Colgroyn, Þat was sire Octa cosyn. Longe þey lendend lenged. by þat cost, & gedered þere þam. anoþer host. ¶ But for þis noble ouercomyng Dicta Vtery. Þat God gaf Vter oure kyng, ffor ioie he stirte vp out. of his bere Als he hadde be had bene. hol & fere, Al armed in ire[n] Irne. & stel, & bolded alle his barons wel, & seyde, þus standynge, & low: standand & louh. " More worschip ys, as me þynkeþ men say. now, " In a bere for to lye, " In syknesse wynne þe maistrie, " Þan be a man hol & sound, " & schamely lygge ded on schamfully leid to þe. ground. " Octa despised me many a day, " ffor þat y sek in bedde lay; " Skornful wordes þey me bed, " & held me bot an half man cald me bot a man half. ded. " Þe half dedman ful felonlyk " Haþ slayn his fos, boþ hol & quyk. " Þe hole & quyke ar dede & fled; " &yogh;yt lyueþ þe syke þat lay in bed; " &yogh;it schal will. ] y folewe þem þat fle! " Do dight &yogh;ow alle, & wendeþ wyþ me! " ffor no þyng ne schal no sekenes sall. y leue " Þat y ne schal exyle .I. sall exille þam. & reue, " & &yogh;elde þem ful harde stoures, " Þat my lond destruyde, My lond þei destroied. & &yogh;oures." ¶ When þe kyng had seyd his wille, Hys barons bed hym byleue stille Til he were warysched of his syknesse, Or his penaunce y-swaged lesse. or a partie suaged les. Þus departed alle þe barouns, & chased after þe Saxouns. When þe chas was al lefte, & þe Saxoyns were gadered eft, Þey conseilled hem, & toke þer red, How þey might do þe kyng to ded: Þey seide, '&yogh;yf þey myghte þe kyng destruye, ' He hadde non eir þat scholde þem noye; '& al so lange as he myght lyue, ' Bataille dirste þey neuere hym gyue, ' Bot &yogh;if hit were þorow tresoun, poyson. ' To gyue hym venym & or. poysoun.' Consilium explora|torum. ¶ Þen ches þey men þat couþe swilk dede; To go þider þey gaf þem mede: To Wyrolhram Verolhram. þey bad hem go, & fonde to fond. þe kyng for to slo. In pouere pure. wede þey dide þem dight, & þyder þey come byn & com þidir þat day. seuenyght; Alle manere langage þey couþe Þat semeþ comes. wel in traytours mouþe. Þey &yogh;ede aboute þe court to spye Wher þey myght do þer trayterye. So yuel þey spedde of wele þei sped neuer. þer pray, Þat þey ne myght come þer þe kyng lay. So longe al wey to þe all gate so long to. court þey ferde, Þat þey perceyued & often herde Þat for certeyn was hit told, Þe kyng drank nought bot water cold, Þat was best for his peyne, & euere of o welle certeyne Þat sprong vp byside his halle, & beste water forby alle; Non oþer þyng þought hym so god, Þat best ageyn his yuel stod. When þo þat his deþ so sought, Wiþ þer wyles auailled nought, Þey wente & venymed þat welle Of þat he drank, als þey herd telle. ¶ When þey had don þat wykked dede, Out of toune sone þey &yogh;ede, De morte Vtery. & ay lystned what were listenand whan. þey herd seye,
text.166: Arthurus nobilissimus Rex Christianitatis. This is the heading to the page in the MS. How þe kyng schold þe kyng were ded or suld. sone deye. Þe kyng, whan he þe water drank, He wax al blak, & bolned rank, & deyde sone yn son within. a þrowe Byfore his meyne þat hit men þat þei. sowe; & so dede did. fele oþer mo Þat drank þerof, to deþ gon go. & þis lasted a god whyle Til men aperceyued þat gyle. Þen &yogh;ede þe comune alle atones, & stopped þe welle wyþ erþe & stones. So longe ber þey erþe þer til, Þat er was welle, now ys an hil. When sire Vter oure kynge Was ded, & don his endynge, At Stonhenges, as he seyde, Bysyde his broþer men hym leyde.
text.167: ¶ Arthurus, filius Vtery, factus est Rex, & coronatus apud Cyrencestriam. The Erchebishop his conseil held, Of erles, barons, & knyghtes of scheld; Ilkon after oþer sent To come to comune Parlement, & after sire Vteres sone Arthorghe Arthure. To come to Circestre, þe noble to Cecestre. burghe; & þere bitaught hym þe coroun, Þorow comun graunt of ilka baroun. fful &yogh;onge þen was he, lond to welde; &yogh;elde. ffyftene &yogh;er þan was his elde; At Circestre þat tyme þar Was first tyme þat he croune bar; croune on hede nouht he ne bare. Some of his þewes y wil descrye; I trowe y schal nought mykel lye: Noiant ne vous en mentirai, Wace , ii. 39. l. 9250. ¶ Craftily dide he mannes dedes, Doughtiest knyght at alle nedes; Þan of myrþe most was Man of myrth most. in halle, Glad-chered, louely, & lordlyest of alle; & glad to gle his gestis alle. Ageyn þe proude, proud herted man. was he; Ageyn þe meke, debonere suete. & ese; Þe hardiest man hym self to fende, Bleþely gaf, largely wold spende; Þat nedful was, & hym bysought, Þat he myghte, he werned hym warned he. nought; Mykel loued he ioie & worthly worþi. þynge, Doughti dedes made of menyng; Nobliche his court he ledde, Richely alle hyse he fedde; Ilka day come tydynges newe; Gestes of ioye, wyþ knyghtes trewe; Ouer alle prynces þe pris he nam Of curteseye & of wysdam; Was no þyng so noble of þewes, As men reden of hym, & schewes. ll. 9767-9768. The Petyt MS. leaves out these lines. Wace has for them, "Et de valor et de largece." ii. 40, l. 9264. When he had take þe regalte, & mad oþ by an othe he mad. his wille fre, ' Þat Saxons schulde neuere haue pes ' In stede of his þer þey ought ches,'— Hys fader & his em þey slow, & oþer wo þey wroughte y-now,— He dide somoune þe folk, & fette; Largely he gaf, & wel þem hette, & bad hem be redy wyþ hym to wende: Þey passed &yogh;ork toward to. þe norþ ende. Colgrym of Saxons was After þat Octa. cheuetayn Syn Octa was at Wyrolhram slayn; ¶ Þe Scottische men wer at his cry, ¶ Colgrim princeps Saxonum. Þe Peytes wyþ hem were ay redy A-geyn Arthur, & at. al þer myght, & redy wyþ hym for to fyght. Bysyde þe water of Douglas, Þere þey mette att a pas: Þe partys were bolde, & þoughte wel þat wele wild. byde; Many on wer slayn on ilka syde. Desconfit was þer sire Colgrym, Vnneþe he scaped vnneþis fled he. wyþ mykel pyn; Toward &yogh;ork Colgrym fley, Arthur hym pursued faste & ney; folowed bi bank & begh. &YOGH;ork he tok for drede & doute, & Arþur byseged hym wyþoute.
text.168: ¶ De Balduk fratre Colgrym. Colgrim had a broþer on þe se, Balduk, þat hadde gret meyne; He abod þe kyng of Alemayne, Þat cam wyþ host toward Bretayne. Son hym was told of on & oþer Þat Arþur byseged Colgrim had biseged. his broþer, How in bataille [he] was How he was in bataile. disconfit. To londe he drow hym þenne as drouh full. tyt: In a wode by þat cost, ffyue mile Balduk busched he bussed. fro þe host; & many were in his compayny, Six þousand armed redy, Þat scholde haue stolen þat ylke nyght Vpon Arþur, al redy dight. A man perceyued þer enbuschment, & til Arþur þe bodeword sent. When Arþur wyste þat þey wer þer, He calde to consail þe Erl Cador Þat was lord of Cornewaille: Hys lyf to lese ne wold he faille. " Cador," he seyde, "Balduk wyþ gyle " Ys enbusched fro vs four es bussed hiþen bot fyue. myle. " Tak sex hundred of gode knyghtes, " Þre þousand oþer, de la geude (foot-soldiers), Wace , ii. 42, l. 9317. &yogh;yf þou myghtes; " Al vnwarned on þem falle, " Lightly may þou wynne þem alle." Sire Cador dight þem al redy, & wente wyþoute noyse & or. cry. Al vnwarned right þore þey ware; Sore wele. to smyte wold he nought spare; Þe most del was slayn of More þan half was slayn. þat frape, Vnneþes myghter myght. any a-scape; &yogh;yf any of hem ascape myght, Þe derknesse mirknes. saued hem þat nyght, & wode letted þem to renne; P. leaves out this line. Þe redy wey couþ þey nought kenne. P. leaves out this line. ¶ Balduk fledde, & durst nought byde, ffro busche to busche busk to busk. on ilka syde; Lorn he hadde lost he had. his men ilkon, Conseil couþe he take at non How he moughte his broþer helpe,— Of gret los of tynsell (loss). mighte he make his &yogh;elpe,— ffayn he wolde wyþ hym speke, Bot of his enemis ne he ne. myght him wreke. He couþe of notes & of layes, & of harpe he knew þasayes; all þe saies. He feyned hym as a iogelour, him a Ioguloure. (comme jong|lère, MS. du Roi, 27; come Juglères, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé; Wace , ii. 43, l. 9336.) & cam to þe ost of kyng Arþour; His hed, his berd, he dide al half. (par mi, Wace , ii. 43, l. 9341.) schaue; Men wend a he. were a folted knaue; Als a gleman gan he synge, & couþe a party of harpyng. Longe he &yogh;ede þus aboute, Non ne wende of gyle ne doute; Bot he was boþe wyly & sley; slehi . . . . . neghi. Þe wal he neighede ful ney; slehi . . . . . neghi. He spak to þeym, & þey hym knew, Doun to hym a rop þey þrew, & he knytte hym þer-inne al, & þey drow hym ouer þe wal. Netheles þey were at meschef, ffor to ascape þem were ful lef; Bot sone com þem tydynges gode, Þat sex hundred schipes on flode schippes gude. (â cinq cent nes, Wace , ii. 44, l. 9355.) Out of Alemayne were comen, & in Scotland had hauen nomen.
text.169: ¶ De potestate Cheldryk contra Arthurum. Til Arthur cam bode als quyk, com tiþinges all quike. Þat þider schold come þe child com kyng. Cheldrik Wyþ mykel people folk mykill. on ilka syde, Þat Arthur schold nought dur abyde. Þe beste frendes þat were hym couþ, Conseilled hym turne toward þe South, & gyue no bataille at þat tyme, Bot let his folk sprede & ryme: " Hys folk ys fresche fell. & ful auster " & twyes so fele fell. as we haue her; " & &yogh;yf þey folewe vs ouer Humber, " Þe sonner schul we þem a-comber; " Þen schal vs come folk ay fresche, " & þey schul euere wexe þe lesse." To þat conseil he gaf god tent, & to Londone right fro þenne fro þiþen to london. he went. ¶ Þe folk hadde sorewe & wo, Þe drede þei dred. þat al to deþe schold go; Þat hadde castele, þider þey drow; Þat non ne hadde, þey hem slow; To holes & hilles men crep crept. for nede; Þat sykerest was, had ful gret drede. had grete nede.
text.170: ¶ Hic Arthurus misit pro Ohele, Rege Mynoris Brytannie. But men gaf Arthur in conseil, To sende for his cosyn Ohel, Oheile. Kyng of Bretayne, his sister sone: By lettre his nedes gan hym mone, & preyed hym of help a stounde, Or elles he scholde go to grounde: The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " Bot y som help of þe now haue, " Or of som oþer, my lond to saue, " Wyþynne a þrowe hit schal be lorn, " Þat oure auncestres han had byforn; " & schame hit were til oure lynage " So sone to lese myn heritage." fful wel he Ohel. vnderstod his nede. Wyþ al þe poer þat he myght spede He made no long soiournynge, Hors & harneys armes. he dide bryng, ffyftene þousand helmes clers, Douse mil orent chevaliers. Wace , ii. 46, l. 9392. Wyþoute seriauntz & archers. God wynd þey hadde þat gan hem dryue, At Southaumptone þey dide vp ryue. Mikel ioye made sire Arthurgh, kyng Arthoru. & feire receyued hym in toun & burgh. Wolde þey make no lenger long. delay, ffor þey nadde neyþer drede naffray; þei had no drede of non affray. Bot sende messegers [ful] smert, MS. snert. & folk com til hym wyþ ful god hert.
text.171: ¶ De bello apud Lyncolniam per Arthurum. To Lyncolne wente ilka baroun, ffor Cheldryk hadde biseged þe toun. Wyþoute noise, sp[e]che, or cry, Þey come to Lyncolne al stillely; stilli. No scaþe &yogh;it þe toun had taken, ffor þey wyþynne held þem wel waken. Þe host was aryued on a þrowe, Bot horn ne trompe dide non þat trompe ne horn non did. blowe, Ne oþer dene in dyn on. none manere, Til alle were splayed ilka banere, Alle þey wroughte at on a-vys, & priuely þe felle o priuely fell on. þeyr enemys. Neuere &yogh;yt byfore of no Saxon Was er are. so gret destruccion, In no stude þer men wyst whare; ffor sex þousand wer slayn þare. Þey caste kest. þer armes, þer horses let, Naked þey fledde on þer fet, In to þe water faste þey ran, Of þeym were drenkled many a was dronkeld many. man; Þe Bretons on þem were euere prest, Þey suffred þem nought þei þoled þam. to haue no rest. A wode byside hight Calydoun, Þat now men calleþ hit ffyskertoun; By þe water side þe wode was set, Þer-inne had þey gret recet. Þe Bretons byhalued þe wode aboute, Þat no Saxon dirst come wyþoute; Arthur dide hit loke so streit; ffor þe for on þe. nyght he dredde deseit, He dide hewe tres & pykke, & palysed hit aboute ful þykke; Tre ouer tre, stok ouer stok, As þikke as men myghte hem schok. ll. 9941-9942. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. His ost was logged to þat oþer on þe toþer. party, Þat non com in, ne &yogh;ede forby. Þo in þe wode hadde no mete, Ne non þem broughte þat mought out gete, Ne nought had purueyd þer byforn, Neyþer bred, [ne] mele ne corn; Þey were so hasted, faste þey fley, Bot helpless weren fer or ney. ll. 9949-9950. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Þre dayes hit was þey nought ete, Ne nought drank þat was wete; Þey sey wel alle þat þey schuld deye, Þorow force myghte þey make no weye. Þey toke conseil oþer weys, ' To leue armes & harneys, ' In pes to þer schypes to go 'Wyþouten any more wo, ' & þey schold leue þem god hostage, suld leue gode ostages. 'Þer best men of noblest lynage, þer lynages. ' & gyue hym truwage ilka &yogh;er ' In pes, wyþouten wo & wer.' And Arþur gaf hem þe grauntyse ffor to wende forþ on þat wyse: Ostage he tok atte remenaunt, One stroke too many in the second MS. n. Þat þey schold holde þe couenant; He deliuered þem schipes wyþoute mo harmes, & lefte þer robes, & harneys of herneis &. armes; Al senglely Sengli. to schipe þey went, No þyng was þem gyue ne lent; & &yogh;it he dide gret curtesy Þat wyþ þe lyf gaf hem merci.
text.172: ¶ De reuercione Regis Cheldryk apud Totenes. Þey set vp sail, þe wynd hem blew, So fer þei seyled þat non þem knew. When þey were so fer born Þat we of þeym þe sight had lorn, &yogh;ut þoughte þey more treson & gyle, Þey turnde þer flute wyþynne a while Bytwix Ingeland & Normandye, Þey dighte eft hydeward þer nauie, & entred in til Dertemuthe; Dertmue. Neyþer fond þey arest ne was þer non mad þam rescue. rescue; At Totenes toke þey hauen & Toteneis þei toke. lond; Al &yogh;ede to deþ þat by-forn hem to dede bifor þam. fond. In þe contres þey spredde aboute; To go to deþ dede. al was in doute; Robes þey refte, armure þey tok, Tounes brente, houses doun schok. ll. 9987-9988. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Þe contres trauersed þey ouerþwert, Ouer al was wo, & no whar & noure. quert; Deneschire, Douerschire. (Neversire, MS. du Roi, 27; Venescire, MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3. Colb.; Wace , ii. 50, l. 9480.) & Somersete, & a partie of Dorsete, Al þey wastes, wasted. & robbed þe god; Was þer non þat hem wyþstod; Þe knyghte þat aughten haue fell haf. ben at hom, To Scotland wyþ Arþur þey nom. Þe Saxons dide so mykel scaþe, Þey robbed in to þe toun of Baþe; Bot þey of Baþe held þem wyþoute, . & þey byseged hit alle aboute. ¶ Arthur werred vpon þe Scottes, ffor þey had don as foule þei did as fole. sottes, Holpen helped. Colgrim & Cheldryk, & ageyns þer lord do so wyk; Bot when he wyste þat þe Saxons Brek couenaunt, & dide tresons, & hadde byseged þe toun of Baþe, Hei seyde, "þe Saxoyns false me ful raþe." Þer ostages ilkon he heng .War. Heye on galewes, wyþ rop & with a. streng. When þer ostages to deþ wer done, Toward þe souþ he hyed hym sone Ohel his cosy[n], & his meyne, He lefte sek in a cite, In Aclud, þer-inne he lay, . Þat was þe name by þat day. Wyþ al þe folk Ohel myght spare, Toward Baþe, Arþur was &yogh;are. Cheldrykes sege he wolde remue, His men wyþynne he þoughte rescue. In a playn by a wode syde Arthur dide his folk abide, To arme þem, & til ordeyne Whylk schuld go, & wyþ whilk seyne. Hym self was armed fynly wel 2 Wyþ sabatons, & spores, & iaumbers of stel, Doublet & quysseux, wiþ poleyns ful riche, Voydes, breche of maille, wyþ paunz non liche Hauberk wiþ plates y-burnuscht ful wel, Vaumbras & rerbras, wyþ coters of stel, Þer-opon an aketon wyþ stof & al sylk, His cote of armes þer-on; in world was no swylk; 2 2-2 with gode chambres of Iren & stele. & a Hauberk þat non was sui lk. abouen an acton mad of silk. For swylk , l. 10,032, L. has swyik. & þen girt & gird. wyþ Caliborne, þat gode brond; A bettere cam neuere in no kynges hond; Ten fote longe was þen þe blade, In Im in the MS. Ramesey & oþer stedes þe merke ys ymade; in Rameseie þe merk is made. (En l'ile d'Avalon fu faite, Wace , ii. 52, l. 9516.) ffro þe hilte vnto þe pomel Was twenti vnche large, meten ful wel; Tuelue Inche grete þat tyme as fell. Þe brede of þe blade was seuen inche & more; . Wond was hit y þat world smite ful I trow þat wild smyte. sore. The Petyt MS. adds two lines not in Wace, ii. 52,— Arthure luffed it wele Inouh. Mishapped him neuer whan he it drouh. An helm he had on his hed, no betere vp on om in the MS. P. has, His helme was gode non better on. molde; 5 A riche corounal wiþ perre, al of brent golde, Þe nasel & bendeles of gold ful bryght, Þer-opon a dragoun selcouþ of sight; 5 5-5 þe nasell befor was all of golde. þe bendeles of gold burnyst bright. a dragon aboun selcouth in sight. Aboute his nekke heng his scheld, Pryd-wenne pridwen. hit highte, many hit byheld; Þer-on was purtrayd, next hym by, Þe ymage of oure swete leuedy, In nede to byholde hure face, Ageyn his enemis to haue grace. Hys spere was gret, his lance grete. he cald hit Ron, Roit, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé; Roil, MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3. Colb.; Rederon, MS. de Ste.-Genevieve, Y, f. 10; Wace , ii. 54, note c. ; Ron, Galf. Mon. vii. 2. Wyþ an hed by-fore, ful noble þer-on; Hit was long, & swyþe gret, P. leaves out this line. Þer was no scheld þat he ne þorow schet. P. leaves out this line.
text.173: ¶ De recuperacione belly & montis per Arthurum. When Arthur þe kyng. was armed wel, & his folk dight ilka del, Al softly he bad þem go, Þat non schulde byfore oþer þro Til þey come vnto þe bataille. Bot þe Saxons durst nought assaille, Bot fledde vntil an hey hyl, Þat non myghte wel wynne þem til. Þey helde þat hil als castel strong, & defended þem ferly full. long, As þey were closed wyþ with in. a wal; Bot atte þe laste hit stod no stal. Arthur saw þe hil was taken, & longe þere þey held hem & long mot þei hald þam. waken; Tene hym þoughte þey fro hym brak, & til his men þus he spak: ¶ "Lordynges," he seide, "þis hil ys hey, . " & we may nought wel com þem ney " Bot hit were þorow long destresse. " Þe lengþe fayn woldy schorte wald .I. schorten. lesse; " Ageyn to Scotland woldy wald .I. be, . " Ohel my cosyn, fayn woldy wald .I. se." He bad monessed. þem wyþ wordes smert Þat [þey] schold alle & bad þam. be gode of hert: " Lo! here byforn vs þan ar þo " Þat han vs wrought ful muche wo! " Þyse are þat han wasted our lond, " Þat riche was, & farre vs fond! " Þise are þat slowe our auncessours, " Als wel myne als &yogh;oures! " Þis ar þo þat vs assailled, " & often in werre vs trauailled! ll. 10,081-10,086. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " Venge vs now we se hem here! " Let hem abye late þam bie. our godes dere! " Lat þeym bye þey toke byforn, For these lines the Petyt MS. has— þei haf don vs many trauaile quyte þam þat þei scored on taile. " & let hem now lese, for we haue lorn! For these lines the Petyt MS. has— þei haf don vs many trauaile quyte þam þat þei scored on taile. " & y schal &yogh;elde, &yogh;yf þat y may, " Þe fals oþ þat othe. þey swore þe toþer day; " Þer turnyng y wole rescowe, " Þat þey come til Dertemuwe. ll. 10,093-10,094. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " &yogh;yf y may ought wyþ hem mele, " Hand of hand strokes schul to hand strokes. dele, " Þey schul neuere eft haue power " In bataille to neighe me ner!"
text.174: ¶ De occisione Saxonum apud Bathoniam. Wyþ þat word he smot his stede, Byforn þem alle vpward he &yogh;ede; Hys launce ful wel he bar þe point, Hys scheld byfore ful wel was ioynt; Þe firste Saxon þat wyþ hym met, His dayes were no lenger set. Þen bygan Arþur to crye, " A-geyn þes Payens, helpe, ?MS. helper. P. help me. Marie!" & bar on hem þe breste byfore. . After hym þe Bretons gon bore: " Þe firste strok þann ys myn!" On he mette, & m[a]de hys fyn; Þen myghte men se þe Bretons strike, & felle þe Saxons doughtilyke. felled þe sessons douhtilike: and P. adds— Ilkon wald haf bien þe breste & at his power Arthure neste. Arthur þen egred þem & he þam egred. so wyþ sawe, ffo[r] schame ne myghte þey hem non mot þam. wyþdrawe; Þey byhalued þem aboute, & ryden þorow þe Saxons route. On ilka syde doun þey fley, & euere Arthur vpward stey Wyþ Caliborn drawen in his hond; Was non his dynt þat myghte wyþstond, Þat hym ne byhoued nedly deye; Þer-fore þey fledde, & gaf hym weye; So fele he slow, & broughte til schame, ffor þus þey counted þat couþe þem ame, ffour fyue. hundred he slow, mo allone Þan his host dide ilkone. Ded was Balduk, slayn was Colgrym, & Cheldrik fledde wyþ mykel pyn; Toward þer schipes to Toteneys Þey fledde, & lefte al þer. oþer harneys; Lyghtly to go, wightly to fle, . Þey leften al, & fledde to þe se. Arthur perceyued wel ynow Þat to þer schipes þey fledde & drow; Þen bad he sire Cador of Cornewaille Take ten þousand of gode apparaille; aparaile. & after hem swyþe hey spedde, & ouertoke þo þat fledde; ffor Arthur to Scotland went: Ohel a messeger hym sent, & seyde 'þe Scottes byseged þe castel, ' & hadde ner taken sire Ohel.' Cheldrik fledde til his nauye; But Cador was queynte & wyly; By a bywey bigate. to Totenes lay, Cador & hyse toke þat way, And to þe hauen wel raþer ore. cam Er any Saxon to schipe nam. Sire Cador, þe mene folk he tok, He gaf þem þe schipes for to loke, & bad þem ryde houe. fer fro þe land, . Þat Saxons ne raughte no bot wyþ in. hand. Syþen went he wyþ alle his ost, & y þe contres kepte þe cost, & kepte þem euere as þey come; By ten, by twelue, Dui et dui, trois et trois, Wace , ii. 58, l. 9616. vm-while þey nome; Armure & robes hadde þey cast, Þat þey were lyght to fle right fast; Þey hadde but swerdes on þer hypes, Sone to come vnto þer schipes. Als þey passed þe water of Teyne, Were þey war of Cadores seyne. Cador syne. When þey hit sey, þey held hem schent, Hider & þyder a-wey þey glent. As þey tok þe hil of Teynewyk, tenwik. Þer was he slayn, þe kyng Cheldryk; Þe oþere þat wende wel haue scaped, To deþe were þey al to-fraped; Þo þat ascaped to þe hauen vnslayn, When þey com þere, þey were vnfayn, ll.10,169-10,170. The Petyt MS. transposes these lines. ffor þey kept [hem] atte brynke, In to þe water þey dide hem synke. On alle halue wax þem wo; To wodes & hilles fledde somme of þo, Þeym to hyde, þat non ne wyst, Tyl þey deyde for hunger & þirst. thrist. When Cador had mad þe contre clene, Þat no Saxon were more sene, He hyed hym faste toward Scotland. In Aklud, Arthur he fond, & Ohel wyþ hym, his cosyn, Of his seknesse warisched fyn. Þe Scottes sessons. þer sege remued When Arthur cam, Ohel rescued; Al þe contre gan þey weyue, & fledde a-wey vn to Murreyue, Murif, Wace , ii. 59, l. 9652. Þer þey hoped best to be, . & closed þem in a strong cite; Þere þey hoped Arthur to byde, P. leaves out this and the following line. A-geyns þem what wolde bytyde. Arthur wyste hit certeynly Þey gadered ageyns hym party; He hyed hym þide[r]ward ful &yogh;erne, & þey herd hit seye, & fledde &yogh;it ferne Right vnto þe Louh Lumyne: En l'estang de Lymonoi, Wace , ii. 60, l. 9660. . A selcouþ þyng hit ys to see.
text.175: ¶ De admiracione Lacus Lumine in Scocia. The next fourteen lines are not represented in the MS. du Roi, 27, but are in four of De Lincy's other MSS., du Roi, 73, Cangé; 7515 3.3. Colb.; de l'Ars. 17, B.-L.; de Ste.-Genev. Y. f. 10. Wace , ii. 61, note a. ¶ In þat louh ar sexti iles— In þo þe dwelte longe in þo þei duelled long. whyles— & ilk an yle haþ a rocher rochere. . & a water dep & cler. In þo roches foules reste, & ernes brede, & make þer neste; &yogh;yf any sorewe or any wo, Or any werre or any þro, Schal in þat lond tyde or gynne, Alle þe ernes þat brede þer-inne Schul crie & &yogh;elle, & make rere, Þat al þe contre aboute schal here, & feighte to-gydere four daies or fyue, & al to-pulle þe feþeres, þer fedres. & ryue. Þys louh, Luminie men calle, Sexti watres þer-inne falle, & alle dwelle þer-inne ilkon; Non rennes out to þe se but on. Wyþynne þis lough had þey dwellynge, P. leaves out this line. Þe Scottes, for Arthur oure kynge. P. leaves out this line. Arthur byseged alle þe loughes, & gadered botes, chalans, The heavily-laden boats that navigate the Seine from Paris to Havre, are still called chalans. De Lincy, Wace , ii. 61, note þer fedres. . & trowes, Þat non myghte brynge þem ne gyue . Mete ne drynke, wyþal to lyue. So wyþynne a lytel while So mykel hunger was yn þe ile, Men sey sauh þam. by hundredes & þousandes Ly lig. ded for hunger on þe sandes; Men seye þem go & falle right doun P. leaves out this line. ffor hunger, þat was lord of toun. P. leaves out this line. Gwylomar, Diramaurus, Wace , (ii. 61, l. 9690), MS. du Roi, 27; Gillamurus, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé; Ghillo|marus, MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3. Colb. þe Irische kynge, . Com ouer þe se wyþ many lordyng To helpe þe Saxons scottis. in þer nede. Lytel, y wene, myghte þey he mot. spede! He aryued ryued. vp by þat cost Þer Arthur lay, & al his host. Arthur & hyse a-geyn hym nomen, Bot þe Irische wer sone ouer-comen; He dide þe Irische wyþ force to fle A-geyn til Irland, ouer þe se.
text.176: ¶ De vastacione Scocie, & lamentacione Scotorum. But &yogh;yt Arthur nought ne left Þat he þe Scottes byseged eft. Þen come þe byschopes of þe land, & religious relikes bryngand, And preyed Arthur of mercy; & als wyþ hem com many ledy, Alle barfot, & bare þe & all bare. heued, Þer her to-rent, vestéures descirées, Wace , ii. 62, l. 9706, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé. or litel leued; &yogh;onge childre wyþ hem brought, & reuly gretyng, gretand. mercy bysought, Mekely fulle doun til his fet. Byschops, abbotes, & ladis abot &. alle gret, & asked hym 'mercy & pes, ' To saue þo childre helples: " Þyse ladies þat þis sorewe haue, " &yogh;eld þem þer lordes, þer lyues life. to saue! " &yogh;eld vs þo þat are on lyue! " Let hem nought alle to deþe dryue! ll. 10,253-10,254. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " Let vs nought alle so dere a-bye bie. " Þe false Saxons felonye! " ffor hit was neuere by our wille " Þat þey com here to do &yogh;ow ylle! " Of þer comyng had we no frame, " Þer dwellyng dide vs mykel schame; " Al day were we wyþ hem noyed, " Oure lyf[e]lode lifelade. þey ete & stroyed, " Catel þey bar a-wey, & spended; " Had we non heued we had no hede. þat vs defended! " Þat we þem halp, servis, Wace , ii. 63, l. 9736. ys no trespas; " Maugre oures, forsoþe hit was; " Þeir force was more þan oures, " We nyste of non to haue socoures. " &yogh;e wot þey are of þe lawe Payen, " & we, as &yogh;e, ar men Crysten; " Þer-fore þey dide vs þe more wo. " At ilka tyme, boþe to & fro, " Wo dude þey vs! & worse haue [we] wars haf we. now! " & þat ys non honur til &yogh;ow, " Vs to slo þat crye mercy, " & deye for hunger so deolfoly. " Þou hast vs wonnen; lef vs þe lyf, " Lord to lady, husebande to wyf! " & gyue vs lond on for to lyue! . " Trewe hostage we wol þe gyue. " Þorow righte reson þou scholde vs spare, " ffor we ar Cristen as &yogh;e are; " & &yogh;yf we deye in swylk destresse, " Cristendam ys mykel þe lesse; " Þan ys þy peryl mykel þe þe perill mykell. more, " Þat þou wraþest wrethis. Crist so sore." Arthur wiste þey seide reson, & wel excused hem of þe Saxon. ffor byschope & clerkes þat hym bysought, & þe relikes þat þey brought, & of þe lauedies ladies. hym rewed sore, . & &yogh;onge childre þat þer wore, He graunted þem alle þat þey ches, Lyf & lymes, & his pes. ¶ Ohel byheld þe lough, þat lake, De primo Lacu in Scocia. & til Arthur þer-of he spak: " Arthur," he seyde, "y haue merueille " Of þis lough & of þis entaille: " So many yles, y telde sexty, " & ilkon haþ a roche hey; " & so manye ernes nestes, " & þer cri þat ilkon kestes: " A wonder me þynkeþ hit þink how it. may be, " Of ilka þyng þat y se!" De secundo Lacu ibidem. ¶ Þen seyde Arthur vnto Ohel, " Of þis ne merueilleþ me no del; me mervailes neuer a dele. " But of an oþer ys selcouþ more, " & so schaltow seye when þou comes þore: " Þat lough ys here yn þys contre, " Cornerd as a cheker quarre; " Twenty fot of lengþe, as þe P. has þe , no as. "Vint piés de lonc, et vint de lé," Wace , ii. 65, l. 9780. brede, es, " & fyue fot hit haþ of depnes; " In þe water, atte at foure. corners, " Are fisches inne foure maners: " Þo þat are y þat o corner, " Neuer more come þat oþer ner; " Ne þe fisches alle foure, " Ne wyþ oþer menge ne voure; meng noure. " Ne no partyng ys þem bytwene . " Of erþe ne ston, but water clene, " Ne oþer þyng þat may bywyte, man may wite. " Þat myghte þer mengyng wyþ-sitte; " I ne wot &yogh;yf hit be þorow kynde, " Or craft of clergie, as men may of clerk þat he mot. fynde.
text.177: ¶ De tercio lacu versus Walliam iuxta MS. iux with a contraction, above. P. has walliam mirabili. Seuerne. ¶ " Of anoþer ys more selcouþ, " & þat lough ys in þat souþ, " Toward Walys, bysyde Seuerne. " When þe flod flowes þider flewes þer. in &yogh;erne, " Þe water wexes noþyng on hey, " Þan þe flod come neuere þer ney; þan þe flode . . . . . nehie. " Als longe as flod þer-ynne flowes, flewes . . . . . grewes. " Þe water of þe lough no þyng ne growes, " In no stede, by bank ne bre, " Þat any man may perceiue or se. " But when þe flod drawes ageyn, " & ys atte þe ebbe & es þe ebbe in. certeyn, " Þenne bygynnes þe lough to flowe, " & ouer þe bankes to renne & rowe; " Wyþ rysyng risand. wawes, & wyþ grete, " ffer aboute hym wil he wete. " &yogh;yf hit beo a couþ man of þe contre " þat goþ þider þe water to se, Qui véir l'aut, le vis torné, Wace , ii. 66, l. 9809; Si gens totius patriæ illius, facie versa, prope as|taret, Galf. Mon. ix. 7. " & feleþ fles. þe wawes þat so wetes, " Hit rennes on hym, & doun hym betes. " Of-ten of þo þat so haue gon, " Han be drenkled manion. " &yogh;yf any connyng conand. man of þo " Standeþ stille, or sidlyng can or sidelynges. Se home i vient, le dos avant, Les talons tornés, re|culant, &c., Wace , ii. 66, l. 9816-7; Tergo autem verso, non est irro|ratio timenda, Galf. Mon. ix. 7. go, " He may stande on þe brynkes " Al so lange as hym god þynkes: " Schal he neuere take latche. scathe, " Ne haue wetynge haf wettenes. ne waþe." Ohel seyde, "yt is wonder selcouth. þyng, " & selcouþ ho made þe gynnynge!" MS. gymnynge. P., ferly who mad þe gynnyng. Þan dide Arthur bemes blowe, Hornes, belles, þat men myght knowe Þat he wolde þennes wild þien. turne, & remue his host fro þat burne. His barons þat come fro ferne, He bad hem renne hom ryght þam wend home. &yogh;erne, To wyte how hit for fore. at home, & glade þer wyues whan þey come. Wyþ mykel ioye & mykel play Wente þe ost homward þer way; Of Arthur made þey mykel pris, How he was hardy, large, & wys, & seyde "neuere or in Bretaigne " Was so noble a cheuentayne!" Vntil &yogh;ork Arthur gan turne; Þere al þe &yogh;ol he made &yogh;ole mad þer. soiourne. ¶ On þe &yogh;ol day he made his feste . Wyþ þe many. barons of his geste. fful mykel enpeired was þe toun, Kyrkes, houses, were beten doun; Þer burgeyses were bygged riche, . Wast & Eyuere[?] was hit liche.— wasten & way was all o liche. Þe bischop was slayn wyþ þe Saxons, & oþere manye religions;— Al he dide hit bigge ageyn . As hit was byfore in þe right. certeyn. Hym serued a prest, a ful god man, a gode man. Hys name was cald sire Pyran; Piran. (Pyram, Wace , ii. 68, l. 9842.) He gaf hym þe erchebishopes se, & bad hym 'kepe þat dignite, ' & holy kirke a-geyn restore, ' Þat þe Saxons had wasted byfore.' Pes he dide oueral alle. crye, . Þat non dide oþer vylenye, But in lawe, right, & skyle; Husebande men, bad hem tyle; ll. 10,389-10,390. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. ffrankeleyns þat hadde desheritison, He dide þem seke did þam. in ilka toun, & gaf hem a-geyn þer heritage, Restored þem þer oþer damage. Þre þer were, doughti & gode, Noble men, of kynges blode, Loth, Aguisel, & Vryen, Þe northe langed to þyse þre men; Þyse þre departed þe northe lond Þorow Arthures gift, y vnderstond. þorgh Arture gift as .I. fond. To Lothe he gaf al Lounes, tot Loënois, Wace , ii. 69, l. 9874. Lot . . . . . ad consulatum Londone|siæ, ceterarumque comprovinciarum, quæ ad eum pertinebant, reduxit, Galf. Mon. lib. ix. § 9. Al þe contre, right as hit es. Scotlond he gaf sire Anguisel; Vryen had Murreue vntil Morey till. (Morayshire?) his del; & alle to holde of hym þer þynge, ffor Arthur was þer chef[e] chefe. kyng. Sire Lothe þat weddede Anne, Wawayn þer sone at Rome was þanne To norise, als þe romaunce seys, & he highte Wawayn þe curteys.
text.178: ¶ Hic desponsauit Guenneueram. When Arthur hadde his lond iustised, & don als he hadde auised, Genoyre Genièvre, Wace , ii. 69, l. 9882; Guanhumara, Galf. Mon. lib. ix. § 9. he wedded, & mad hure quen: Norysched wyþ Cador had scheo ben; Sche was sire Cadores cosyn, & born was of þe Romayns lyn, ffor hure moder was of Romayns roman. kynde. So fair as scheo myght no man fynde; Y-now scheo couþe of curtesy, Large gyuere, & spak giffer spekand. louely; Of body was scheo swyþe auenaunt, ffair contenaunced, contenance. wyþ swete semblaunt. Alas! þey myghte non heyr haue, Neyþer maide maiden. child, ne knaue.
text.179: ¶ Deuicit Hyberniam. When wynter cold was al away, & hete comen of someresday, & fair weder on se to fare, P. transposes these lines. A flute on flode Arthur dide &yogh;are; P. transposes these lines. He seide he wolde til Irland, & wynne hit al to Bretons hand. Longe tyme wolde he nought waste, He dide somoune his folk on haste, Erles, barouns, knyghtes, squiers, Alle þe &yogh;ongest bachelers Þat wel myghte, & best couþe Stonde in werre, & were of &yogh;ouþe. Vpon Irland his fflute gan lende; Swyþe vp to lande gon þey wende, Vitaille to seke, & mele & corn; Bestes slayn to schipe were born, Lyflode al þat þey myghte gete, To sustinaunce vntil þer mete, Ilkadel to schipe þey drow, . & vitailled hem wel y-now. To Gwylomar, þe Irische kyng, Com bode sone of þeir comyng; Þat Arthur was aryued þere, . Al his lond for to conquere. Þe folk pleyned hem aboute; Þer godes were lorn, was lost. & þey in doute. Þe Irische kyng dide folk somoune . Þorow-out þe lond, of ylka toune, Of vpland & of burghe, P. transposes these lines. To giue bataille to kyng Arthurghe. P. transposes these lines. When boþe partis come to þe fight, Þe naked Irische were nought dight; Hauberk ne scheld ne myghte þey bere, Ne fro þe arewes couþe þem nought were; Þey nadde neuere seen non ar. O syde þey fledde here hider. & þar; Ilkon made oþer agast, & conseilled hem to fle ful fast To wodes, to hilles, þer lyues to saue; Oþer socour þey wyste non haue. Þe kyng fley til a wode syde; Arthur hym folewed, & dide hym byde, & al wyþ force hym þer tok; & he swor hym vpon þe bok, To holde of hym his heritage & &yogh;elde hym ilka &yogh;er truwage. Þer-til he gaf hym god hostage, To holden his fewte & homage.
text.180: ¶ Hic transfretauit, & Orchades cepit. When þat was pesed & brought til ende, Til Island MS. Ingelond. Island , P. [Arthur] dight hym to wende. Island MS. Irland. Island , P. Islande, Wace , ii. 72, l. 9941. sone al he wan, ffor lord þey knew hym ilka man. Goneweys Geneweis. Gonvals, Wace , ii. 72, l. 9945. þe kyng of Orkeneye, How Arthur wan, wel herde he seye; So dide Doldan of Gotland, & Rumarek þe kyng of Wentland; Et Doldamer rois de Gollande Et Romarec de Guenelande. Wace , ii. 72, l. 9946-7. Tyl alle þre was hit told Þat Arthur was a conquerour bold. Þyse þre kynges, þey hym dredde ffor þe gret host þat he ledde; Þey durste nought stande hym ageyn, Ne þey ne hadde non host certeyn, Ne þey ne wolde þer lond destruye, Ne hym ne þeym to-gedere noye. Þe beste consail þey toke on hand, & wente to Arthur into Island, MS. Irland. Island , P. Islande, Wace , ii. 72, l. 9941. & for þeyr landes made alle pes. Arthur þem þanked þat þey so ches; Louely tok he þer alle here fewte, ffor þey come alle so wyþ wylle fre. When al was syker & certeyn, Til Ingland he turnde com. ageyn; & when þey wyste þat he cam, Wyþ ioye alle a-geyn MS. ageym. P. ageyn. hym nam. Twelf &yogh;er Trente ans, Wace , MS. du Roi, 27; Douze ans, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé, &c. ( Wace , ii. 73, note a ). after þat comyng, In reste & pes he regned kyng, Þat neuere on hym no werre bygan, neuer no were on him nam. Ne he ne werrede vpon no man. He tok so mykel of curtesy, Wyþoute techyng of any hym by, þat non ne mighte conne more, Neyþer þorow kynde, ne craft of lore. In alle answeres he was right wys, Of alle manhede he bar þe pris; Of non þat tyme ne was swylk speche, Þat til his nobleye mighte reche,— Nought of þe Emperour of Rome,— . Þat he ouer hym ne bar þe blome; In alle manere þat kynge schold do, Non oþer hadde such grace þer-to. He ne herde neuere speke of knyght Þat losed was of dedes wyght, Þat he ne &yogh;erned hym for to se, & for to haue hym of meyne; of him mercy. &yogh;yf he for mede serue hym wolde, He ne lefte for seluer ne for golde.
text.181: ¶ Hic ordinatur Tabula Rotunda. For his barons þat were so bolde, Þat al þe werld pris of þem tolde, ffor noman wyste who was best, . Ne in armes doughtiest, Dide Arthur ordeyne þe round table Þat &yogh;it men telle of many a fable. At þer bord in tyme of mete, Alle þis noble knyghte schold þo douhty knyghtes suld. ete; Non sat wyþynne, non sat wyþoute, Bot alle euene rounde aboute; Non sat first, ne non sat last, But per by per, in euen cast; pere bi pere euen kast. Non sat heye, non sat lowe, lawe. But alle euenlyk men myghte þem knowe; euenly for to knawe. Non was set at non ende, . But alle a round, for o round &. alle were hende; Non wyste whiche of pris who of þam. most was, Þer-fore þey sete alle in compas; Alle at ones doun þey seten, . At ones ros when þey hadde eten; Alle were þey serued of o seruise, Euenly, alle of on assise.
text.182: ¶ De gloria Curye Arthury. What knyght had ben in al þe werld, . Had his los be neuere so wel byherd, þof his los had bene wele herd. Were he ffrenche, frankis. were he Bretoun, Normaund, fflemyng, or Burgoiloun, Spaynard, Gascoyn, or Angeuyn, Scot, Irische, Pykard, or Peyteuyn, Daneys, Norneys, or Selander, Henner, ffryson, or Katelaner, Arragoneys, Lombard, or Brabaunt, . Prouyncial, Nauerner, or Alemaunt, ll. 10,547-10,552. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Of wham he held his fe, or how, ffro þe Weste [or] Est vntil west vnto. Moungow, He was told of non honour Bot he had ben wyþ kyng Arthour, & hadde taken of his liuere, Cloþ or queyntise, þing. þat knowe myght be. Of ferne landes many on namen, & til þat court for worschyp camen, To lere honur & curtesy, & here þe prowesse of knyghtes hardy, & to here þe faire gestes þat knyghtes broughte & telde at festes. Somme come to se his faire wonyng, & se & here þere selcouþ þynge; ll. 10,559-10,566. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Pouere men, þey louede hym alle, & riche honured hym in halle; ffele kynges of ferne stede thede. Sent hym gyftes for doute & drede; Þey wyst hit wel, &yogh;yf þey wold ryde,d . His werre durste no kyng abide;d Kynges aforced þer casteles aboute,d ffor alle landes of hym hadde doute,d þat &yogh;yf he come, he scholde þem lese,d Or gyue hym truwage as be wold chese;d . þer-fore ilkon at þer myghtd Aforced þer cites, & wel þeym dight. ll. 10,571-10,578. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line.
text.183: ¶ De nobilitate Arthury. But in þyse twelf &yogh;eres tyme ffel auentures þat men rede in ryme; . In þat tyme were herd & sen Þat somme seye, þat neuere haþ had. ben. Of Arthur ys seid many selcouþ . In diuerse landes northe & souþ Þat men holdeþ now for fable, Be þey neuere so trewe ne stable. Al ys nought soþ, ne nought al lye, Ne al wysdam, ne al folye; See the lines 10,040-7 in Wace , ii. 76-7 from MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé, against the embellishers of the Arthur story throwing discredit on it by their fables. Þer nys no þyng of hym seyd þat hit ne may be to godnesse leyd. þat ne it may to gode laid. More þan oþere were his dedes, . Þat men of hym so mykel redes; Ne were his dedes hadde be writen, P. leaves out this line and the next. Of hym no þyng men scholde haue wyten. MS. wryten. Geffrey Arthur of Monemu, . He wrot his dedes þat were of pru, & blamed boþe Gyldas & Bede, Why þey wolde nought of hym rede, Syn he bar þe pris of alle cristen siþen he was pris of all. kynges, . & write so litel of þei wild not write. his preysynges, & more worschip of hym spoke þer was of him was. Þat of any of þo þat spekes Gildas, Or of any þat Bede wrot, . Saue holy men þat we wot. In alle landes wrot men of Arthur, Hys noble dedes of honur: In ffraunce men wrot, & &yogh;it men wryte, . But herd haue we of hym but lyte; Here haf we of him bot lite. Þere-fore of hym more men fynde In farre bokes, als ys kynde, Þan we haue in þys lond: . Þat we haue, þer men hit fond; ll. 10,609-10,612. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Til Domesday men schalle spelle, & of Arthures dedes talke MS. takke. P. talk. & telle. Now ys Arthur of pleyn age, . He conseilled wyþ his baronage; & his gode knyghtes hym redde, Þat he had fostred & forþ fedde. He seyde he wolde ouer se he wald wend. to Fraunce, & wynne hit al wyþ dynt of launce. But first he seide 'he wolde bot first he wild. to Norweye, ' Þe kyng had sent hym bode þe kyng sent. (Sicelins li rois mors estoit, Wace , ii. 77, l. 10,052.) he hoped to deye; " & Loth, myn neuew, schal he his eyr; " To make hym kyng y am in speyr; " His neuew he ys, of next degre, " Of blod ys non nerrer þan non heire bot. he." Right as he seyde, also he Sichelyn said & þus. þought, He wende þe barons wolde so haue wrought; But when þey seye þat he was ded, Þey toke þem til anoþer red: Loth to haue, þey hym forsok, . & anoþer kyng þey tok; ffor alle þus. þey seide wyþ o mouþ, ' Þey wolde haue no kyng man. vncouþ; 'Þey hoped nought þey schold hym fynde . 'Als godliche as þer owen kynde. ll.10,635-10,636. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. ' Alyens,' þey seyde, 'he wolde auaunce, ' Þat schulde be þeire appurtynaunce. ' A heued þey wolde haue þem aboue, ' Þat hem wolde auaunce & loue.' Þorow þat consail & þat reson, Rycolf þey ches, was a baron, & coroned hym, & now ys mad him. kyng; & þus haþ Lot þus gate hast. lorn þat þyng. " ffor help," seid Arthur, "Loth haþ bysought; has souht. " ffaille hym by no weye wol y nought; " Y wolde his honur & [his] his. right, " & þat schal y he[l]pe at my & help þerto þat .I. myght. " Rycolfes coroune y wolde abate, " Þat þe Noreys gef hym so late."
text.184: ¶ De conquestu Norganie. Tyl Arthur com þer folk ynow; To schipes on flode faste þey drow; Þe wynd blew, & gan hem dryue, Vp in Norweye gon þey aryue. Ricolf was god, & wolde nought fle Ne remue hym out of þe contre; He gadered host, for wel he wende Ageyn Arthur hym self defende; But his wenyng was al alle. veyn, ffor Ricolf & hise wer alle þer sleyn. When Arthur hadde Norweye wonnen, Þe barons alle ouer riden & ronnen, Loth, his neuew, he gaf þe croun, . After Ricolf þat was doun. Loth made Arthur þenne feute, Als til his chef ouer al þat fe. ¶ Lothes sone, sire Wawayn, Had ben at Rome to lere Romayn, Wyþ Supplice þe Apostoille pape. (St. Simplice, pope, 468-483 A.D. De Lincy, Wace , ii. 79.) to wone, Honur to lere, langage to kone; & þere was he dubbed knyght. And holden hardy, strong, & wyght. When Supplice had don his ende, Tyl Bretayne-ward Wawayn to bretayn Wawan home. gan wende. Now ys Wawayn comen hom, . fful blithe ys Loth al of his com; Noble he was, & ful curteys, Mykel honur of hym euere men seys: honour of him men rede & seis. He loued mesure & faire beryng; Pruyde ne bost loued he no þyng; Vnkynde, false, & fykele, fals & fikell lesyng. he hated; Lesynges, alle swilk he abated; auauntour alle suilk he bated. More he gaf þan he by-hette, Wel more he dide þan terme of sette. Now ys Loth in Norweye seised, & Wawayn comen, þat mykel ys preised. is comen & preised. Alle þo men þat were of myght, Þat weren &yogh;onge, & couþe in youth þat couth ouht. of fyght, & loueden þat lufed. more werre þan pes, Arthur til hym alle swyche Arthure all suilk men. ches; Of swylk gadered he many on, & schipes on se ful god won. When his host was styf & stark, He schiped to-wardes Denemark. Achil, þat þen was kyng of Danes, Saw Bretons & Noreys come alle at anes Wyþ Arthur, to wynne his lond, & for to destruye al þat he þei. fond. But Achil þoughte, as kyng ful wys, Þat He sauh. Arthur oueral hadde þe prys; He wiste wel he schulde conquere His lond of hym, &yogh;yf he come þere; But he seide 'he wolde nought if he suld not. so ' Hym seluen ne his lond fur-do, P. leaves out this line. ' Ne suffre his folk to be slayn, ' Ne his tresor spende in vayn, ' Ne his casteles beten be casten. doun, . 'Ne kirke robbed, to robbe. ne brenne toun;' But faire he spak, & wel he hette, & wysly gaf giftes wel bysette, giftes gaf & wisly sette. So þat of Arthur he had grauntise, Þe lond in pes for his seruise; & Arthur þen his seruise tok, Omage he swor hym on þe bok. ¶ Arthur was glad þat he þus wan, So sone þe kyng bicam his man; But &yogh;ut he þoughte to wynne wel he wild wyn. more. Of þe beste knyghtes he ches þore, & squiers bolde, & gode gode & slie. archers, . Þat louede werre, & knew þe maners— I ne wot how manye þe hundrethes ne. þousandes Þat he so gadered y þo landes;— Of gret folk mad he purueaunce, ffor he seyde he wolde to ffraunce: fflaundre he wan, Boloyne he tok; Tounes, casteles, for hym þey quok; His folk so wysly gan he lede, Struyed he no lond als he &yogh;ede, He tok no þyng fer ne hende, But mete & drynke, & hors prouende; &yogh;it toke þei non wyþ no maistrie, But bought hit þere hit was to bye. Þat tyme þat þis chaunce gan falle, Þat now hat ffraunce, þo hight hit Galle; Þe Romayns þat ilke tyme hit held, Was þer þan. no kyng bar croune ne scheld; & ilk &yogh;er toke þey þer-of truage, Syþen sen. Iulius wan hit in seruage.
text.185: ¶ De ffrollo, Romano Regente ffrancie. Frolle, a doughti bacheler, Had hit in kepyng many a &yogh;er; To Romayns þer. byhoue gadered þer rent, & at termes to Rome termes home. hit sent, Or bar hit hym self to þe Emperour. ffrolle was a ful hardy man in stour, He was comen of Romayns blod, He dredde douted. non þat ageyns hym stod. Al day tydyng men hym told, Þat Arthur com wyþ host ful bold, & þat no man myghte dwelle ne be But &yogh;if he helde of hym in fe. Þat herde ffrolle, & was ful right. wo, . & seide hit schuld nought þat wey said it suld not so gate. go. He dide somoune did somond. alle to come Til hym, þat helde þer fe of Rome, ffor to brynge hors & armes, . Þe lond for to fende fro harmes, P. leaves out this line. & doughtily to-gydere stande Ageyn Arthur þat was comande.
text.186: ¶ Hic gens ffrolly cecidit. ¶ Hit was nought longe bytwyxt hem set Ar þat. þer hostes ? final s added by a later hand. to-gedere met. ffrolle mysfel atte firste pres, ffor ner alle his beste folk he les, What y-slayn & ouer schaken, . & nerhande hym self had ben taken. Hit was no wonder was ferly. þat he fledde, ffor þe gret host þat Arthur ay ledde; Was non þat couþe hit noumbre couth noumbre it. ne seye, Þe folk he tok, comynge in comand i þe. weye; Hit was no lond þat he þorow sought, Euere þe beste wyþ hym he brought; Þat doughti was on horse or fote, . Wold he, nold he, wild he ne wild he. forþ he mote: Somme wente for his fair speche, & somme for drede of oþer wreche, & somme for he gaf largely, & somme for his grete curtesy, tant por la noblesce de lui, Wace , ii. 84, l. 10,210. & somme for los & doute of ded, tynsell & doute of dede. Knowlechyng til hym þey bed: Of ffraunce many a lordyng Comen to holde com & held. of hym þer þyng.
text.187: ¶ De obsidione ffrolly per Arthurum. ffrolle fledde faste to Parys, Hit was þe strengest cite of pris; He knew no bettere recet to haue Ageyn Arthur, þat myghte hym saue; ll. 10,783-10,784. P. transposes these lines. Night & day dide his trauaille To warnische store. þe toun wyþ vitaille. Mykel folk to Paris fledde, & Arthur þider faste hym spedde; & Arthur vnderstod ful wel Þe purueaunce of ffrolle þer purueiance. ilka del; Þer-fore he hasted his sege to sette, . His purueaunce for to lette. Arthur byseged hym so streit Þat ffrolle mighte wyþ no deseit Of vitaille helpe hym at nede, By londe ne by water lede Ner al a monþe, as men teld, Þat ffrolle þe cite of Paris held; & al þat tyme Arthur þer lay, . He ne remued night ne day. So mykel folk was þer-ynne, Þe raþer bigan þer fight to gynne; soner gon þer faute begynne. (Et de viande poverté, Wace , ii. 85, l. 10,239.) Hit was despended, þat þey in drow; Þey hadde no tyme to drawe inow; ffor hunger gan þey make mone, Men, women, & childre, ilkone. &yogh;yf ffrolle wylde as þey wolde, Þe toun had ben ful sone &yogh;olde; Þey preied ffrolle þorow þorhout. þe burghe To make pes wyþ kyng Arthurghe. ffrolle saw þey pleyned þem sore, & þer vitaille was namore, & seye wel þey þat þei. alle wylde Þe toun vntil Arthur &yogh;ylde; & [þat] þat. þought hym schame & vyl; Hym self had leuere be in peril, & auenture hym his deþ to take, Þan wyþ his wille Parys fursake; þe toun forsake. " Strengþe of body or wille y fonde." Tyl Arþur he sente his sonde: ' &yogh;yf þat he wilde bytwyxt þem to tuo. ' To-gedere fighte, wyþoute mo, ' & whilk of þem were ouer-come, ' Or slayn, or wyþ force nome, ' Tak hym þe lond til his wylle, ' So þat þe folk nought ne spille.' Þat bode cam Arþur wel to hert; His gloue he gaf vp al so smert, & tok hostage o boþe partys, Of Arthures host of Arthure. (cil de l'ost, Wace , ii. 86, l. 10,274.) & of Parys, Þe bataille scholde be in a pleyne . Bytwyxt two watres, Marne & Seyne.
text.188: ¶ De bello inter Regem Arthurum & ffrollum. When þey were armed & redy dight, & were comen þer þey schold fyght, Men myght þer men mot. se folk tremble & quake, . On boþe partis gret deol to make, Handes wrynge, on knes to wreng on knees. falle, On Godes name to crie & calle, ' Þat he myght wynne, þat pes wold haue, ' & þe lond fro werre myght saue.' Arþures folk stode & byheld, Redy [digh]t A long piece has been torn out of the MS. The gaps are filled in from the Petyt MS., except as noted below. wyþ helm & scheld, & by[sought]e God inderly praied god interly. To [graunt] Arþur þe maistri. Þy[se two] knyghtes þat forþ were fet, N[obilly di]ght, on horse wel set, T[o assay]e þem how þey were wyght, [Þe lanc]e to reyse, þer scheld to ryght. [Who myg]hte ho mot. wel telle, & soþ to seye, [Þat sui]lk Suilk. wer non þat tyme als þey; [Ilk o]f þeym was horsed wel, . [Had a]rmes in armes. stronge as any stel; By sight myght non þer chese þe best, Ne whilk þen semed doughtiest; Ne whilk schold wynne, ne haue þe gre, . By sighte myghte þer non hit se. ll. 10,855-10,856. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. When þey were bone, redy to smite, & þer hors horses. sondred a lyte, Wyþ speres þey smot, MS. snot. P. smote. þe bridel brayd, Þer scheldes sette, þer launces on lance. forþ layd; Þer horses at þer power runnen, Þe partis wende haue all. lorn or wonnen; But ffrolle failled of his dynt,— I trowe his stede a syde stynt,— & Arthur smot hym in þe scheld. Þe hed Iren. was god, & ful wel held, & ffrolle out of his sadel cast So fer so þe launce might last. ffrolle vp stirte, & sydlynges glent, His scheld dressed, his launce vp schelde dight his lance he. hent; Til Arþures stede þe point he bar, Þorow þe breste þe herte he it. schar. Arþur fel; he moste nede; He was a fote, ded was his stede. Þe Bretons seye he had þat fal, Þem þoughte for wo þey al to-swal, to sualle. Þe erþe dunede stonyed. for þeir cry, To passe þe water þey were redy, Þe trewes to breke þey were ful wylde, To haue gon ouer in to þe ilde; But þey sawe hym sone vp a-geyn; Þey wyþstod þen, & were fayn. When he was vp, he hadde no rest, . Wyþ ffrolle to fighte he was ful prest, He leyde his hand to Caliborne, Þat neuere for armes wolde scurne. Þer-wyþ on ffrolle ful sore he sought, & ffrolle a-geyn ne dredde hym nought; Agayn Arthur he stod & stynt, Nought abaischt hym for abaist for him. no dynt; His swerd had drawen, he lyft hit heye, On Arþur he let hit sore fleye: Þe dynt was gret, for he was strong, Þe fir out fley, þe sparkles sprong, Þe helm he claf, & þe basyn, & þe coyfe þat was so fyn. Þe swerd was scharp, & ful wel bot, In þe forehed Arþur he smot, Þorow þe flesche, vnto þe pan; After þe strok þe blod out ran.
text.189: ¶ De occisione ffrolly, Regentis ffrancie. When Arthur felde felte. þat he was wounded, Noþyng he ne Noiþer he. stinte ne stounded; ffor, ful of yre, wyþ colour teint, Was he neyþer abaischt ne feint; Caliborne he hadde in hande, He tok hym byre þe strok teysande; bir þe stroke teisand. Abouen Aboun. his helm ful faste he dref; Hed & nekke & breste he clef. to þe girdill þe body clefe. Þey of þe cite mad deol ynow, & þe Bretons þer-fore þey low; What sorewe so þey made al gates, Agayns Arthur þey opened þe gates, And let hym in, & alle hyse, & dide mad. hym omage & seruise. When he had homage of lef & loþ, Hostages he tok to halde þer oþ; At Parys to soiourne he ches; Baillifs he sette to &yogh;eme þe pes; He parted his host in haluendel, & þe halfendele. Bytaughte he þem to betaught he vnto. sire Ohel, & bad hym 'go to wynne Burgoyne, ' Peytowe, Nauerne, & Gascoigne, ' & Lorreyne, &yogh;yf lorenge if þat. he myghte, .
