' Assaye þem wyþ loue or fyghte.' Ohel dide his comaundement, He tok þe folk, & þyder went; And alle þo landes & wan all þo. þat y haue seyd, . To gyue truage on þem he leyd.
text.190: ¶ De austeritate Gwytardi. Gwithard, MS. Gwichard. P. Witard. (Guitart, Wace , ii. 90, l. 10,375.) þe Duk of Peyters, Was a fel knyght & a fers ffor to kepe his heritage, Nought ne wolde gyue he wild gyfe no. truage; Often he turnde Ohel þe vys, & often of hym wan þe pris, & often a-geyn hym he les . Er þan he wolde come til are he wild com vnto. þe pes. Ohel destruide ner al þe lond; Þat he wyþouten castel fond, Al was destruyed, & al was reft, Þe selue vynes þe vineis. þey ne left. When Gwytard Witard. saw ner al was lorn, So þat he ne mighte be byforn, he myght not be forborn. He saw hit was non oþer bote, . Bot &yogh;ede & fel Arthur to fote, & dide mad. hym homage & feute, Of hym to halden al hold all. his fe. Syþen loued Arthur Gwytard Witard. ful wel, . Non so mykel, but only Ohel. Þo oþere contres south fro ffraunce, Arthur þem wan til his alliaunce.
text.191: ¶ Hic remunerauit Arthurus famulos & seruientes. When Arthur had geten alle þo landes, & wonne hem wyþ dint of his handes, Til þo men þat trauailled sore, Wel of elde þat wyþ hym wore, &yogh;ald hem þer sond & þer seruise, Vnto þer contres he bad þem wyse. But þo þat were &yogh;onge & wylde, Þat neyþer hadde wyf ne childe, & louede to bere spere lufed to bere helm. & scheld, Nyne &yogh;er in ffraunce he þem held. Manye wondres by times selcouth be tyme. sers Bytydde Arthur þo nyn[e] &yogh;eres; Many a proud man lowe he brought, Til many felon, wo he wrought; Enuyous men he hated alle, Þe mysproude ful lowe dide falle. ll. 10,965-10,966. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Þer haue men bokes of al his lyf, . Þer are his merueilles red ful ryf; kid full rife. Þat we of hym here alle rede, Þere were þey writen ilka dede. Þyse grete bokes so faire langage, . Writen & spoken of ffraunces on france. vsage, Þat neuere was writen þorow Englischemen, Swilk stile to speke, kynde ne no kynde. can, But ffrensche men wryten hit in prose, . Right as he dide, hym for to alose; In prose al of hym ys writen, Þe bettere til vnderstande & wyten. ll. 10,977-10,978. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line.
text.192: ¶ Hic diuisit Arthurus Prouincias, & dedit Ducibus Comitibus, Baronibus, Militibus, & aliis, secun|dum probitates suas. Arthur at Pasches, At þe pasch. at Parys, He held his feste of gret[e] fest of grete. pris: Til alle þo þorow hym had lorn, Restored he als þey were had. byforn; Riche or pore, gentil or þral, . Þat he þem aughte, he &yogh;ald paid. þem al. After þat he was worthy, He &yogh;ald þer seruise largely: To Kaye þat was his stywarde, Aungowe he gaf hym til his part; He gaf also sire Beduer, Þat was of fe his boteler, He gaf hym in fe all Normandie, But þenne hit was cald þat tyme men say it hight. Neustrie; Boloyne he gaf to sire Holdyn, And Mayne þe Mannes. (Le Mans, Wace , ii. 92, l. 10,422.) to Borel his cosyn; He gaf giftes of honurs, & landes & rentes, to vauasours.
text.193: ¶ Reuersio Arthury in Angliam, in Mense Aprilis. When he had feffed his barouns, & mad his priues lordes of touns, Þe nexte April, when somer gan, Til Ingeland wente ilka man. When men wiste þat þey wer comen, Ageyn Arthur faste þey nomen; Þey made suche ioye, non myghte be more; Hys longe dwellyng þem for-þoughte sore; Ladyes kyste þer lordes swete, Modres & childre for ioye gon on childir for Ioy. grete, Sones welcomed þer fadres home, & made al murthe for þer come; at þer tocome. Lemmans leue ilk oþer kest, P. leaves out this line. Of more þey esed hem when þem lest; P. leaves out this line. Neueus nyftes, A.-Sax. nefa , a niece. sistres broþer, Ilka frend welcomede oþer; Þey stode in ilka strete & sty, In grete routes men passed for-by, in gashadles men passed bie. Þey spirde to spir. at hem 'how þey hadde faren, ' & whi þat þey so longe waren, ' & how þey spedde of þeyr conquest, ' & what þey wonne whan þei wan. so fer est, ' & how þey ferde in al þer wo: . " We wole namore &yogh;e fare vs fro." & þen þey teld hem al þer chaunce, How Arthur hadde wonne ffraunce, & of merueilles þat þey had sen, & in what peryl þey had ben. The Lambeth MS. has the next two lines twice over; first in this form,— Alle þe lordes of þis Londe þat Arthur byfore hym fonde. The Petyt MS. wisely leaves out these lines. Þe lordynges of þys lond Þat Arthur bifore hym fond, Riche presentes þey hym sent, . Hys longe dwellyng mykel þey ment; & he ageyn was ful curteys, Some gaf he hors or oþer harneys; Gladly he gaf, & largely. . ffor to schewe his curtesy, ffor to schewe his grete prowesse, & do by-knowe his grete richesse, & for to speken of his dedes . Þat alle kynges doutes & dredes, ll. 11,033-11,036. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Þey conseilled hym his lond to somoune, At Whitsonday, Qu'à la Pentecoste, en esté, Wace , ii. 94, l. 10,458. to do hym coroune. At Kerlyon in Glamorgan, & Klamorgan. Dide somoune þyder did somond þidir. ilka man. Karlyoun was som þat. tyme riche, Rome & hit lykned y-liche; Hit standeþ on a water men calleþ Vsk/, To Seuarne hit rennes by bank & busk; In Vsk men myghte þider wende, Outlandes fer þat þider wol lende; On þat o syde ran þat ryuer, Þat oþer side, on þe toþer. fforest, ful of der; Venisoun þer was ynow, Plente of fysche in water þey drow; Large medes wyþ gras plente, Lond to tile, non bettere myght be. Two kyrkes were in þe toun, Þat tyme had þey gret renoun; Of seint Iuly was þat on, Þat oþer was of seint Aaron. Seint Iuly in martirdam gan deye, Nonnes were at his abbeye; Seint Aaron, þer was þe byschopes se, at saynt Aaron was þe bisshop see. Þe heued kyrke of þe cyte; Þer-of Arthur was [þe] ffoundour, & did. set hit in seint Arons honour; Þer were chanons of clergye, & knewe þem wel in þat knewe wele of. astronomye; To knowe þe sternes, þer tente þey þer wittes. leyd, & til Arthur often oft tymes. seyd, Þat what þyng he was aboute, He schulde spede wyþoute doute: Wel was þat tyme at Kerlyoun! Fele was þan a karlioun. But siþ sen. þat tyme haþ hit go doun. ffor þe plente of ffysche & flesche, Of wode & water, hey & gres, Of housyng, & of oþer aysement By water & londe men broughte & sent. Þen seide Arthur he wolde þer holde ffeste wyþ alle his barons bolde, & at þat selue samenynge He seyde he wolde be corouned kynge.
text.194: ¶ Exe quot Reges Comites & Barones venerunt ad coronacionem Arthury. Messegers MS. Messe essegers. P. Mes|sengers. he dide sende ffor kynges & ducs, fer & hende, And for erles & barouns, Knyghtes of castels, lordes of touns. A legat fro Rome was sent See Wace, ii. 100, l. 10,563. He gives the "legation" to Arch|bishop Dubrice. . ffor to make þe corounement/; Erchebischopes were þer þre,— At Londone was þenne þe se, Þat oþer was at Euerwyk, At Kaerlioun was seynt Dubryk/;— Of Scotland king Agusel, Anguisell. Þat til Arthur was ful lel; Of Murreue þe kyng Vrian, Wyþ hym com his sone Ywayn; Stater of Southe Walys al, Of North Walys þe kyng Cadwal, Cador þe Erl of Cornewaille, ffor Arthur hadde many trauaille; Sire Moryond þe Erl of Gloucestre, Sire Mauryce þe Erl of Wyncestre, Gurgoynt þe Erl of Hereforde, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. of Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). & sire Beus of Oxenforde, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. of Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). Sire Vrgence þe Erl þat was. of Bathe, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. of Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). Þere þe Saxons dide scaþe; Sire Cursal of Chestre was, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. of Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). Of Dorcestre sire Ionatas, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. of Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). Emoraund þe Amorand. Erl of Salesbury, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. of Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). & Kynmar, kyng of Kaunterbury, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). Sire Baruk, Erl of Circestre, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). & sire Iugens of Leycestre, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). Sire Ergal, þe Erl of Warewyk/, These lines are from the Arse|nal MS. Wace, 171 B.-L. Wace , ii. 97-8, note ( c ). Hys men come to court ful þyk/.
text.195: ¶ De filiis Magnatum. Of þer childre hit seis þe names; . To nemne hem here, litel hit here it ne. frames: Þer was Porfodes Porsud. sone, Donaunt; & sire Regines Regin. sone, Elaunt; & Coyles Cohel. sone highte Keneus; & Catel sone, Catellus; & oþer names selcouþ to telle, But hit ys nought on þem to dwelle; Þyse serued atte rounde table; To rekene þem alle hit ys but fable. So manye þer were in chaumbre & halle, Men schuld yrke to telle þem alle; What of þo þat y fond writen, . & of þo þat fewe men wyten, Hit are but fewe þat can þem telle, & þo þat can, þer-to ne wyl dwelle. ll. 11,123-11,126. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line.
text.196: ¶ Nomina Regum. Outlandische Outlandes. kynges þat of hym held, . Þat bowed vntil Arthures scheld, Þo þat he wan wyþ his hand, P. transposes these lines. Gwylomar þe kyng of Irland, P. transposes these lines. Þe kyng of Demark, sire Askyl, Loth of Norweye com hym tyl, Goneweys þe kyng of Orkeneye, (By Irland he cam in his weye,) Doldan þe kyng of Gouthland, . & Reumarek, kynmare. kyng of Wentland, Of Nauare þe kyng, & of Gascoigne, P. transposes these lines. Sire Liger, þe Erl MS. Erk. P. erle. of Boloyne, P. transposes these lines. And of fflaundres, þe Erl Holdyn, Of Chartres, þe Erl Geryn,— He was a man noble & fers, Wyþ hym come alle þe dusze pers,— Sire Gwytard, witard. þe Erl of Peyters, & sire Caye, Key. lord of Aungers; Of Normandie, sire Beduer, (Of fe þe kynges boteler,) & of Manns, þe Mans. (Del Mans, Wace , ii. 101, l. 10,591.) þe Erl Borel, Of Bretaigne, sire Ohel; P. leaves out these lines, though they are in Wace, ii. 101, l. 10,593-6. Sire Ohel & þo of ffraunce, P. leaves out these lines, though they are in Wace, ii. 101, l. 10,593-6. Þey were of noble contenaunce, P. leaves out these lines, though they are in Wace, ii. 101, l. 10,593-6. Wel clad & arayed y þe richest, P. leaves out these lines, though they are in Wace, ii. 101, l. 10,593-6. & horsed alle for þe best. P. leaves out these lines, though they are in Wace, ii. 101, l. 10,593-6.
text.197: ¶ Pro quantis comoditatibus venerunt ad Curiam Arthuri. Hit was no baron in al Spaigne, Ne þennes in-til þien vntill , Alemaigne, Þat he til Arthures feste ne ferde, Þat doughti was, & þer-of herde; Somme, hym seluen for to se, & to byholde be holden of. his meyne; & somme, to se on of. what wyse . Þey ordeigned þer faire seruise; & some, to se þe Table Rounde Þat neuere byforn þat tyme ore or þat. was founde; & somme, to se his faire paleys; . Somme, to biholde his riche harneys; Somme, þe folk to by-howe; & somme, his knyghtes for to knowe; & somme, for his geftes gode; . & somme, for his noble fode; & somme come for to haue bailly; & somme, to lere þere curtesy. ¶ When Arthures court was Arthure courte was all. plener, & alle were comen, fer & ner, Þe erþe abouen about. stired & quok, So faste hors & man þer schok: Þer was puttynge, þristinge, & þro, Wyþ fot-folk þat come to & fro, Innes for to teme & take; Þat non hadde, pauilons did make; Þer maistres mareschals ferde aboute, Deliuered innes stedes. (soliers et cambres, Wace , ii. 102, l. 10,616.) wyþynne & wyþoute; Bordes broughte, cordes & cables, & made mangers mad maniores. to stande in stables. Þen mighte men se þe ladies þan mot men laddes. (escuiers, Wace , ii. 102, l. 10,619.) lede Many fair palfray & stede In mud, in mires, to soille & dasche, Siþen in wayers to watre & wasche, Syþen to wype, & to mangers teye, Hey & prouende byfor þem leye. ll. 11,185-11,188. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. ¶ Þenne come chaumberleyns & squiers, Wiþ riche robes of on. mani maners, To folde, to presse, & to pyke, & somme to hange, & som to strike, Manteles, forours forres. of riche pris, Of meneuer, stranlyng, veyr, & strinkled with. gris; Oþer pelure ynowe þer were, . Þe names of þem y ne wot what are, Lomb or boge, conyng or hare, Y ne knowe me nought in swylk chaffare. ll.11,195-11,198. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Þe On þe. morn when þe feste schuld be, Come þe Erchebischopes of þer Archbisshop of his. degre; Wyþ hym, him. of Rome cam þe legat; And oþer bischopes of mener stat; &, right als þe story seys, Dubrice corouned hym in his paleys; A legat of Rome & he Dide þer þat solempnete. When he was corouned on þat wyse, To þe kyrke þey &yogh;ede to þer seruise; Þe two Erchebischopes þat þer war, Þey ledden hym, ys armes vp bar, Chascuns un bras li sostenoit, Wace , ii. 103. l. 10,643 (from the MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé; whence the next line comes too). & sette hym in a riche chayer, . Þer he scholde his seruise her. ffoure swerdes of golde were born Wyþ foure kynges hym byforn,— Þat seruise fel to þer fell ilk a. (Cist mestiers lor apartenoit, Wace , ii. 104, l. 10,649.) scheld When þat Arthur his feste held,— Þe kyng of North Walys & of Scotland, & of Southe Walys (þus wryten y fand), Of Cornewaille, þe Duk Cador, Þe fferþe swerd bar he þor; Þaw þof. his stat were nought so hey, &yogh;it was he man ful wel man most. worþy. Dubrice, þat was a noble prelat, & of Rome þe Legat, Dubric, qui de Rome ert légas, Et de Charlion ert prélas. Wace , ii. 104, l. 10,658-9. See p. 387, n. 2 above. Þat office þey dide, þey myghte best, Of dignete þey were heyest.
text.198: ¶ De Regina Guenore. Þe Quen Guenore, on hure syde Was serued of mykel pryde, ffor scheo had byfore y-sent After leuedys & maydens gent Þat were of hure owen hir awen. kynde, & oþer of pris þat scheo myght fynde; Quenes, cuntesses, oþer laydys mo, Comen to mayntene þe fest þo; ll.11,233-11,234. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. And in hure chaumbre vpon a pal Þey corouned hure wyþ a coronal. When with. scheo was corouned, þe leuedys Led hire to kyrke of Seint Iulys; Þer were þe nonnes of religion, & þer þe Messe schulde þer suld hir messe. be don.
text.199: ¶ De processione eorum. To ben a twynne, þer to be. so þey ches, ffor to departe þer mykel pres; Þey myghte nought be in o stede, . ffor folk vnryde, & mykel crede. krede (crowd). A.-S. cread , a company, troop. Lye , in Bosworth. ffoure ladies wente þe same assise As þe kynges dide Arþures seruise, ffour white douues byforn hure bare;— Þe ladies, kynges wyues ware;— & after þem come oþer leuedys Richely cled in pourpre & bys, In cloþes of golde þat schon so schene, . & oþere in scarlet & in grene, ll.11,251-11,252. The Petyt MS. leaves out these lines. Wace has others, ii. 105, in|stead of them. Alle were þey richely y-dight; Þer was neuere seyen swyche a & gay to behold in. sight! 6 . I trowe þer were many doude Common dowdy girl or woman. See the Towneley Mysteries , p. 312. If she be never so fowlle a dowde , with hir kelles and hir pynnes The shrew hir self can shrowde, both hir chekys and hir chyn|nes; She can make it fulle prowde with japes and with gynnes, Hir hede as hy as a clowde. . Þat proudly spak for noble schroude; Ilkon MS. Iilkon. oþer faste byheld, And of þe faire, mykel was of teld. 6 6-6 For these four lines the Petyt MS. has,— Grete presse was at þe procession. Ilkon proudere þan þe lion.
text.200: De Cantu ad Missam. When þe Procession was gon, Þe Messe bygan sone anon: Þer myghte men se fair samninge Of þo clerkes þat best couþe synge, Wyþ treble, mene, & burdoun, Of mani on was ful swete soun; Of þo þat songe heye & lowe, & þo þat couþe org[a]nes blowe, Inow þer was of menestralcie, . & of song gret faire. melodye. Þer myght men se folk come & go To þe kyrkes, boþe to & fro, Of knyghtes & [of] of. squiers bolde To listne song, leuedis liste songe ladies to. byholde; ffro þat o kyrke to þe oþer þey ran; Where was þe beste, wyste no man; At neyþer þem þoughte þey dwelled longe, Ne nought were ful to here þe songe; ll. 11,273-11,276. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. &YOGH;yf hit had ben at her pay, Þat song had lasted al þat day. ¶ When þe Messes were boþe done, were don. . & homward þey were al bone, Þe kyng dide of his atir tire. þar Þat he vntil þe kirke bar, & tok anoþer of lasse peys; Þe quene dide þe same weys; Þeir heuy atir þey dide of boþe, & in lightere dide þem cloþe. ll. 11,285-11,286. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. text.201: ¶ De nobile Conuiuio & seruientibus. Þe kyng was set vp at þe des, Þer was in ful about him þe. mykel pres, But aboute hym þe lordynges sat, Ilkon after his astat. ilk a lord after his state. Kay was styward, chosen of alle To serue byforn þe kyng in halle; Hys cloþyng was god riche. (Vestus d'un vermel sig|laton, Wace , ii. 107, l. 10,742.) & fyn, . & þe pelure of eremyn; pelore of hermyne. Wyþ hym serued byfore þe kyng A þousand y þe same cloþynge; vestu d'ermine, Wace , l. 10,745. Out of the kechene serued sire Kay, & alle his felawes þat day. ¶ Sire Beduer on þat oþer partie, He serued of þe botelerye; boterie. Wiþ hym was clad in eremin pelore of hermyne. A þousand þat serued of þat brouht. þe wyn: Was þer non þat serue bad, But he in riche pelure were clad. ll. 11,317-11,318. The Petyt MS. leaves out these lines, but they are in Wace, ii. 108, l. 10,755-6. Þe kynges coupe sire Beduer bar, & &yogh;ede byforn al þat þer war; After hym come alle þe route Þat serued þe lordes barons. alle aboute. ¶ Þe quene was serued ful richely, Hure seriauntz were assigned hir seruantz were signed. redy In alle offices for to serue, & byfore þe ladys kerue. Many a vessel was þer riche, . Of sere colours, nought alle y-liche; Of metes many manere seruise, & seer drynkes of sere drinkes on. þat wyse. Al þe nobleye couthe y nought telle, Ne y naue no stounde Ne myght stonde. þer-on to dwelle, Þe names to seye of þe richesse, Ne of þe men of prowesse; 3 Was þer no lond in al þe werd, Of gode knyghtes so mykel of herd. 3 3-3 Ne þe curteisie ne þe honour of cristiente þer was þe flour. Wace (ii. 109, l. 10,772-82) puts it better for England:— De biax homes et de noblèce, Et de plenté et de ricèce, De cortoisie et d'onor, Portoit Engletere la flor. De tos les resnes environ, Et sor tos cels que nous savon. Plus erent cortois et vaillant, Néis li povre païsant Que chevalier en autres regnes; Et autre si erent les fenes. text.202: ¶ De diuersis Ludis ibidem. When þey had eten, & schulde suld. rise, Ilk man dight hym on þat wyse Þat he best couþe inne playe. þat he couth in play. In to þe feld þey tok her vnto þe felde he toke his. waye, & parted hem in stedes sers To pleye ilkon on þer maners: Somme iusted, þat couþe & myght, ffor to schewe þer stedes wyght; lyght. Somme skipte, & keste þe ston, & somme skirmed wrestrld. ful god won, Dartes schoten, launces cast, . & þo þat couþe, wrastled skirmed. (alèrent escremir, [faire des armes, se battre], Wace , l. 10,807. fast. Ilkon pleide þe gamen þey couþe, Þat mest had vsed in his &yogh;ouþe; Þat best dide in his pleynge, He was brought by-fore þe kynge, & þe kyng gaf hym mede, Þat he was paied er þat he &yogh;ede. ¶ Þe ladies vpon þe walles stey ffor to biholde al þer pley; Who so hadde lemman þan þore. in place, Toward hym turned boþe eye & face; On boþe sides ilk oþer byhelde, . text.203: ¶ De donis Arthury. Þre daies þe feste sat lasted þe feste. — I trowe neuere non was lyke was neuer non as. þat— & when hit cam to þe it com. Wodnesday, Þat þe people schuld parte, to wende þer folk suld parte a. way, Þe kyng þem gaf his giftes riche, Þo þat til his seruise were briche, & for þer seruises held hem at fees; seruise held þer feez. & somme he gaf burwes & cites; Bischopes & abbotes, auaunced þer Abbot & bisshop auanced his. rent Er þan þey fro his court[e] went; And oþere þat of strange landes þat of oþer londes. were, Þat for worschip were come þere, for luf com. text.204: ¶ De Nunciis Lucii Inperatoris Rome. Ryght als þis giftes were in gyuyng, gyffyng. & alle y-serued, knyght & kyng, Arthur sat [vp]on opon. þe des, And aboute hym his mykel pres Of kynges, dukes, erles, Of kynges erles. & barouns, . & of straunge lordes of vnkouth knyghtes. & Bretons, & schulde haue taken leue, & went, Twelue messegers til hym were sent ffro þe Emperour of Rome: Two to-gydere, faire þey come In to þe halle, Arthur byforn, Wyþ olyue braunches in handes born, Wyþ softe pas & [fulle] seine fulle seine (or seme ). Gret þei Arthur & his meyne: Þey seide þei were "messegers, " Comen in pes & in faire maners " Out of Rome, þenne þien. ful fer, " ffro þe Emperour Lucius Iber, ybere. " Þat ys oure lord lef & lord & our. dere; " By vs he sendes his lettres here, " & þe comaundeþ on alle weys . " Þat þou do as þis lettre seys." Þe lettre in his hand þey leyde; List now what þe lettre seyde:
text.205: ¶ fforma litere Lucii Inperatoris. " Lucius, þat Rome had has. in baillie, " & ouer þe Romains haþ þe. maistrie, " Sendeþ til Arthur þe Bretoun " Als on of his enemys feloun. " Me merueilles mykel, & ilka Romayn, " & merueillyng, we haue meruailand we haf. disdeyn " Þat þou dar bere þe so heye, " Ageyns a Romayn open þyn eye. ons open þin Ie. " Y wondre at the bost þou makest, of þe bost þou makes. " & at wham þou conseil takest, whom þou conseile takes. " Ageyn Rome to reyse strif, " Þe whiles þou wost o Romayn has lyf. Whils þou wote a romeyn o lyfe. " Þou gaf þy self a sory chek, " Ageyns Rome agayn Romeyns. to reise cuntek, " Þat al erthe þorow dom hit þorh dome. demes, " & as hed of al þe word hit & hede of all þe world it. &yogh;emes! " Þou wot nought, &yogh;it wist shal hit be, " Ne nought hast seyn, but þou schalt nouht þou sawe bot þou sall. se, " How gret hit ys to wrathe Rome " Þat al þe werd schal iustice & world iustise with. dome! " Ageyn kynde hastou gon! " Reson ne mesure hastou non! " Wheþen come þou? what þyng þe boldes? " Oure truage takes, & has, & holdes, " Oure landes vs reues as þou wyldes, " & til vs no þyng þou [ne] &yogh;eldes! " What right hastow þer vnto? " Þy folye hit ys þat þou didest so! " &yogh;yf þey may longe wyþ þe so leue, " Þat we þorow force þe þem nought reue, " Þen may þou seye, & scorne, þe wheþer skorne & say to where. " Þat þe wolf fleþ woulf fles. (lions fuit, Wace , l. 10,948.) for þe weþer; " & &yogh;it þat he so longe slep " Þat durste nought wake to asaille a schep, " Or þat a got þe wolf goot þe woulf. dyd dare, " & þe grehound lupars, Wace , ii. 117, l. 10,950. fledde for þe hare. " But swilk a þyng may nought bitide! " Namore schal hit on oure syde! " Oure auncestre Iulius Sesar " Wan Bretayne (art þou nought war?) " And tok trewage þer-of longe— . " ffour hundred &yogh;er we gon hit fonge,— " & of oþere ildes aboute; " But now þorow þe we are wyþoute. " &yogh;ut hastou don vs more vilte " Þan al þat los þe losse. we telle to þe, " Þat þou ffrolle, our baroun, seruant. slow, " ffraunce & fflaundres et Bretaigne, Wace , l. 10,964. from vs þou drow! " ffor þou hast of Rome no doute, " Ne til his lordschip wil þou loute, " Y make þe somouns vnto Rome, " & comaunde þe þat þou come, " ffolewyng atte folowand at þis. nexte heruest. a mi-aost, Wace , ii. 118, l. 10,969. " Hit schal nought helpe cheson to kest; " But com, & amende mend. þyn vnright, " Þat þou so slowe ffrolle oure knyght, " & als amende on oþer weye " Of þat we conne kon more. to þe seye. " But &yogh;if hit be so þou make delay, " Þat þou nelt & will not. come at þy day, " Ne come bewe (bow). til oure comaundement, . " Þan telly þe outrely tell .I. þe þat þou ert. schent! " & &yogh;yf þou do, þou schalt þe hide, " & siker I. trowe nouht. on þys half þe se " Þou schalt nought þou sall. dur schewe þe to me; " & &yogh;yf þou on þys half bes, halfe bees. " & leue þe þer in Romaynes hondes! þe in þe Romeyn handes. " At þat word was noise & cry Of þe Bretons þat stoden ney; Oþes þey swore þat "þey schold deye Que cil seront deshonoré, Wace , l. 11,993. " Þat broughte þat lettre of vylenye! " & for his loue þat sente &yogh;ow hyder, " &yogh;e schul ben honged alle to-gyder!" Lytel letted þey nadde be slayn or hirt; letted þat men þam hirte. But Arthur þenne anon vp stirt: " Bretouns!" he saide, "holdeþ hold. &yogh;ow stille! " Þe messegers schul haue non ylle! " Ne neyþer ille haue ne non ille haf non ille here. here, . " But come & go in faire manere; " Messegers of Rome þey are, " In pes þey come, so schul þey fare; " Þer message þat þei haue seyd, " A lord þey haue, on þem hit leyd." When þe noyse dynne. was wel pesed, & eft hadde þeir sittynge þei had þer setes. sesed, Þe kyng tok wyþ hym two or þre Of his wysest barouns priue, Þat best couþe conseille til honour; Wyþ hym þey &yogh;ede vntil a tour,— Þe name þer-of, hit was in haunt As y fond writen, þe Tour Geaunt— Þer sat Arthur, & þey byside, To conseille how myghte best bytide.
text.206: ¶ Dicta Cadoris Cornubye. Sire Cador spak firste, & low, louh. & seyde, "sire kyng, y schal sey &yogh;ow: " Often in studie haue y ben, " And in gret drede ay bytwen, " Þat þorow ildelnesse Idelnes. of pes " Are Bretons feble & herteles; " ffor Ildelnesse Idelnes [no ffor. ] norischeþ but iuel; " Temptacion of flesche & & mykell temptacion. of þe deuel; " Idelnesse makeþ man ful mas man right. slow, " & doþ prowesse falle right low; louh. " Idelnesse norischeþ lecherye, " & doþ vs tente to such dos vs tent to suilk. folye; " Ildelnesse Idelnes [no ffor. ] & long rest, " &yogh;ougþe in wast awey wil kest, " & doþ men tente to folye fables, " Tyl hasardrie, des, to deez. & tables. " We haue now al þis fyue &yogh;er . " Lyued in lechours vsed rioterie. mester, " & þat. þorow rest & such soiour " Haue we lorn gret haf we lost grete. honour. " Som grace is ronne in Romayns herte ronen in þe romens þouht. " Þat þey chalange vs so smerte, chalenge on vs souht. " Vs to bynime oure landes for to haf our londes. & fees, " & oure conqueste of all our conquest in. oþer contres. " &yogh;yf Romayns be so coraious " Þat þey wil do as þey send vs, " &yogh;it schul þe Bretons wynne þem los " Of Romayns þat in Rome gos; " ffor longe pes louede y neuere, " Ne nought ne schal, þey y lyue sall þof .I. lyf. euere." ¶ Þenne spak Wawayn þe curteys: " Merueillike, Cador, þou seys! " After werre, god ys pes; " & after wo, þe wele god ches; " In pes ys don gret vasselage, " ffor loue men doþ gret outrage." many rage. & at þat word þey set hem doun, Þe kyng & ilka baroun. When þe kyng saw þem set, Alle þat were til conseil fet, Þe kyng þoughte a þrowe, a while he þouht. þen lifte his hed, When þei hadde þer ianglyng leued: carpyny leued. " Barouns," he seide, "þat ben now here, " &yogh;e are my felawes, me & me. ful dere; " When y lese, &yogh;e haue part þer-ynne, " & felawes &yogh;e are when þat y wynne; " When wo or werre haþ me comen, " &yogh;our part wyþ me haue &yogh;e nomen, " As felawes in prosperite P. leaves out this line. " & felawes in aduersete; P. leaves out this line. " ffor wheþer y haue wonne or loren, " &yogh;our hap wyþ me haue &yogh;e forþ boren; " Þorow &yogh;oure help & god auys " Hauy wonnen mikel pris; " By water, by londe, haue y &yogh;ow led, " Þorow &yogh;ow in nede haue y wel sped; " Euere y haue founde all tymes haf .I. fon. &yogh;ow trewe, . " & euere &yogh;our conseil god & newe; " Alle þe londes þat y haue wonne, " Wyþoute &yogh;ow was nought bygonne. " Þe Romayns, as &yogh;e haue herd " By þys lettre þat here ys sperd, þat here is folden & vp sperd. " Me & &yogh;ow þey manace fast, " Wyþ grete wordes þey wene me gast. " &yogh;yf God wil helpe me & &yogh;ow; " Þeir þret schal nought be for þer þer manace is no þing. prow; " Of vs gete þey neuere nought, " But &yogh;if hit be ouer dere abought. bot it be full dere bouht. " Þey haue gret power, & ar ful riche, . " Þer nis no power to þeires non is þer pere ne to þam. liche, " Þer-fore we moste bus vs. bifore purueye " What we wil do, what we wil seye, " & auenauntly Auant like. (avenanment, Wace. ) & resonable, . " & þat we seye, hold hit stable. " A þyng for þought þing be for. þat men wil rede, " Hit is þe bettere mayntened at nede; " An arewe þat ys schoten, &yogh;e se, " Eyþer bihoues ouþer bos. hit men fendit or fle; " Þat same weys byhoues þe sam wyse bos. vs do. " Trewe þey aske, so haue þey had; " Þat ys bihinde, send þem þey bad, " Of þis lond & oþere mo; " & ffraunce wil þey nought will not. furgo.
text.207: ¶ Dicta siue Responcio Arthury ad Romanos. " For Bretaigne wil y first will first. answere, " Writen in lettre þat þey schul bere, sall here. " Answeryng ansuere. for &yogh;ow & me, . " Þat lettre wil y þat hit so be. " Þus wil y seye, þus wol y write " My skile; leste my skill listens. me a lite: " Cesar of Rome þis land first wan, " A[l] þorow fight & force of man; " Þe Bretouns mighte nought þat tyme mot not. defende; " Trewe byhoued þem to treuage bord þam to þam. sende; " & force, &yogh;e wite wel, ys no god right, " But pruyde out of mesure myght; " Hit is no skile, ne lawe non makes " Þyng þat þou þorow force takes; " & swylk giftes men schal furdo, " Þat wyþ wrong was taken so. " Þey repreue vpbraide. vs of our auncessours, " Þat þey ouer-cam þem wyþ harde stours; hard schours. " Of pouerte þey make vmbreyd, vpbraide. " & of trewage þe treuage. byfore seyd; " & of þis þey make auauntement, " Þat here-byforn our fadres schent. " So mykel oughte awe. we greue þem þe more. " & þey ar halden vs to restore; " Wel oughte we hat hem þat hem han We awe to hate þat þei haf. hated, " & bere hem doun & bete doun þo. þat hem abated. " When Belyn turnde to Bretayne, " Of Rome he made Brenne cheftayne, " & bad hym gouerne al þe honour, " & he so regned as Emperour. " Now wil y late of .I. leue. Belyn, " & speke y wil of Constantyn, " Constances sone & Eleynes, Constancius sonne & Elyns. " Þat held Rome als his demeynes. " Constance, of Rome had seynurye fair, . " & Constantyn þen was his heyr, " & y am heir of Constantyn; " Þorow þat desent Rome schal be myn. " Maximyan, Leons leonyne. sone, . " Kyng of Bretayne, at Rome gan wone; " He wan Neustrie, þe Lesse Bretayne, " & al ffraunce & Alemayne, " & al Mongow & Lombardye, " And of Rome hadde þe seignurye; " Þyse were myn ancessours of scheld, " Þat only þe þat þe. honour of Rome held. " Now þorow skil haue &yogh;e knowen " Þat Rome by reson schold Rome ouh to. be myn owen " Al so wel as Bretayne þeyres, " Þorow eld auncetrie til heyres. " Rome had trewage, & hit fur-sok; " & trewe of Rome myn auncestres tok; " Þey cleyme Bretayne, & y cleyme Rome; " Þat we boþe cleyme, &yogh;ut it. ys to come; " Let þem wynne hit &yogh;if þat þey may, . " &yogh;it haue y kept hit al my day. " ffraunce y wan of ffrolle þer knyght; " To kepe hit lengere he hadde lengere þei. no myght; " Þorow force þey wonne hit, als y hit wan; . " Wyþ force so mighte anoþer man. " Wherto chalange þey so bolde " Þat þey ne myghte no lenger holde? ll. 11,725-11,726. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " Þorow right skil haue þey no seruise, " But al þorow force & couetyse, " Þat ys to anoþer al so fre " Als hit was to þeym or me. ll. 11,729-11,730. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " Þe Emperour makeþ vs gret makis his. manace, " Out of þis lond me for to chace, " & in bondes to Rome lede. " Nolde God he scholde god will not he. so spede! " Y preyse hym litel, & drede hym litill he me praises & dredes. lesse! " &yogh;yf he on me wil he to me. seke prowesse, " Encountre he getes er þat a countir he getis or. he go, " Þat eft ne schal he me manace ne Me eft sall not manace to. slo, " Ne to none of myne do ylle; . " So schul we don hym chaunge his wille. " But when þey come to chalangyng, " Bryng Rome, & y schal Bretayne bryng! " & whilk of vs þat most may, " Bere Rome & Bretayne boþ a-way."
text.208: ¶ Dicta Ohelys Regis. When Arþur had seid his resoun, Wel was hit alowed of ilka baroun. with ilk breton. Wiþ o word seide þei alle at ones, . " Wel haue &yogh;e seid, sire, for þe nones!" When þei were stilled a party, ffirst spak sire Ohel þat sat hym by, & seide: "no man &yogh;ong ne old alde . . . . . talde. " Schuld ought amende þat &yogh;e haue told; " But syþen þou sest sen þou sees. þat þou art þret, " & may nought passe wyþoute baret, " Somoun þy folk, & make þem &yogh;are, . " & set þem day when þou wilt fare. " But make no long drecching þer-to, " ffor y wile, &yogh;if þat þou wilt so, " & passe Moungu in to þe mountz, Mongow in to þe mouns. . " & holde hold þe. day of þy somouns. " & &yogh;if we wende so alle wend with þe. to-gyder, " & he se þat we come þyder, " So may bytide, tide. þen schal hym rewe " Þat he bigan þis bale to brewe; " & hit bytydes many it tides often. stoundes, " Þat who so bygynneþ, þat on bigynnes. hym self confoundes. " I trowe þat God wil vs auaunce; " Grace ys to-ward, & gode chaunce. " Þe Emperour sendes after þe; " Sek hym þer-fore, þan. wher so he be, " & baldely bede we on hym þe bars; & bede baldlie on him bares. " Sone schul we se þen ho ys chars; so may we se who vs chares. " Set þe Emperour in swylk a drede " Þat he tys court nere dur vs þat neuer to courte eft dur þe. bede. " Loke what seis þe prophesie,— " Sibille þe sage [þat] þat. wil nought lye:— " Þe Bretons, Que trois roi, Wace , ii. 128, l. 11, 210. of Bretayne schul come, " & þorow þorgh fyne. force gouerne Rome." " ffoure ar tuo er. (Dui de cels, Wace , l. 11,212.) passed, wel we mene; " Þou art þe fifte schal ert þe thrid sall. (Tu es li ters, Wace , l. 11,216.) do þem tene; " Þe fifte þou art, y wot hit we[l], P. leaves out these lines. They are in Wace , ii. 128-9. " Þat Rome schal haue ilkadel. P. leaves out these lines. They are in Wace , ii. 128-9. " Syn so ys ordeyned to bityde, " Wher-to schold we longe sall þou long. abide? " Auaunce now boþe þy self & ous! P. leaves out these lines. They are in Wace , ii. 128-9. " Oure wil to helpe ys coraious; P. leaves out these lines. They are in Wace , ii. 128-9. " Y dar wel seye, so hastou founde, P. leaves out these lines. They are in Wace , ii. 128-9. " ffor we ne doute no dynt ne wounde, P. leaves out these lines. They are in Wace , ii. 128-9. " Ne deþ, ne prison, ne langour, P. leaves out these lines. They are in Wace , ii. 128-9. " So wilne we faste þyn honour! P. leaves out these lines. They are in Wace , ii. 128-9. " Leue nought now, but faste þe spede, " & y schal, &yogh;yf þat þou haue sall help if þou haf. nede, " Come wyþ ten þousand of gode knyghtes, " Horsed & armed with hors & armes. at alle rightes. " & &yogh;yf þou for tresour lette, " Al my lond schal y wed-sette " ffor gold & seluer, þe to take, " Er þou þis viage schuld fursake." or þou þi wendyng forsake. (Seint Dubrice, þe holy man, . At kyng Arþur tok leue þan ffor to chaunge his abyte, & bycam anon bicome ane. heremyte; & Dauid, Arthures em, hit tok, . Þe erchebischopriche Archbisshop see. þat Dubrice fursok.)
text.209: ¶ Dicta Aguselly, Regis Scocie. After þe speche of sire Ohel, Seyde þe kyng sire Agusel, Anguisel. Sire Lothes broþer, & sire Vrien, P. leaves out this line. — . Alle þre were doughti men, P. leaves out this line. — & seide, "&yogh;yf þou wilt werre bygynne, " Spek now to þo þat ar here-ynne, " Þe beste of alle þy baronage, " Þat wyte & herden þe message, " And wite þer wille, what þey wil do, " & what þat þey may helpe help þe. þer-to. " Now ys tyme to purueye P. leaves out this line. " Of help, & god conseil to seye, P. leaves out this line. " Alle þo þat of þe holde, P. leaves out this line. " Riche lordes, & barouns bolde, P. leaves out this line. " Þat oughte to helpe þe þorow skile, P. leaves out this line. " & wel y trowe þat so þey wyle. P. leaves out this line. " No tydynge neuere y ne vnderstod " Þat gladed me so mikel in mod, " As wyþ þe Romayns for to werre, . " Þat alle men in þer daunger sperre. " Y ne may þem nought loue ne preise, " ffor þey ar proude & vncurteyse, " Gode men so mykel to þei. despise, " Þat schul nought liue but þei may not lif bot. in þer seruise; " & þey ar men of non honour, " But couetous to gedere tresour, " Gode men MS. mem. P. men. wyþ-al to noye, . " & þer londes to robbe & struye. ll. 11,831-11,832. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " Y trowe þei schul &yogh;it trowe þam sall. mis-bytide " ffor þer couetise & þer pryde; " Of þys þat þey haue y-sent, haf vs sent. " Þey schul be wrothe er hit be ent; ent = ended. " Wonder were elles, or art me failles, " But þey pleye wyþ repentailles. ll. 11,837-11,838. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " & þaw þey bot þof þe. neuere had hit by-gonne, " We scholde þorow right suld þorgh reght. on þem haue ronne " ffor to venge our auncessours, " & bate þer pride as þey wolde ours. " Þey seide þey had of þeym þei say þai had of vs. trewage, " & chalange hit for here heritage: " I trowe þat þey nere þem þam neuer. non gaf, " But þorow force þem ouer haf, " As þeues robbed þem, & reft: . " Þat wil we chalange of þem now eft/; " Wyþ force þey gaf hit to þe Romayns, " Wyþ force we wil haue hit agayns. " So harde oure force may to þem byte, . " Þat alle oure scaþes schul þey quyte; ll. 11,849-11,852. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " We haue wonnen many a stour, " & ouer al born a-wey ouer all we haf born. þe fflour, " So schul we &yogh;it þer pride abate, . " ffor þer couetise & þeir hate. " Þat we haue wonne, y sette at nought, " But &yogh;if þe Romayns to ryng rounge. be brought; " Noþyng now desire y more mare . . . . . ware. " Þan þider-ward we redy wore, " & þat we were at þe bataille, " To se who scholde whilk suld. best assaille; " Þer schuld sall. we wynne prowesse & prow, " Hors, harneys, tresor ynow; " &yogh;if God vs graunte our lyf to saue, " Þat we þem aske, we schul sall. wel haue, " Rome & al þat þer-to langes; " Þen schul sall. we ryghte, þat now vs wranges. þat þerto langes. " &yogh;yf God wil graunte vs wel to vs forto. venge, " Toward hym we schal &yogh;it sall we fond to. wynne Lorrenge " & Alemayne, &yogh;yf þat we may; . " Algate, &yogh;ut schul we make all gate we will mak. assay! " Als y seye, so wol y rede, " & þat ilke & all þe same. wil do in dede. " &yogh;if God me graunte wel to spede, " Two þousand dix mil, Wace , ii. 132, l. 11,316. schal y wyþ me lede, " & fot folk ynowe, gode at nede: " &yogh;if God wyle, noman schul we drede!" will we sall not. When þe Scottysche kyng had his tale Anguisell his tale had. told, Alle þey seide wyþ tonge o fold, ' Þat schent he schold be of hem alle, Honis soit, Wace , l. 11,321. ' On wham þat þe wendyng schulde nought þat wendyng suld not. falle.' When ilkon had seid his wylle, Arthur listned, & sat ful stille, Let calle did calle. a clerk wyþ inke & penne, & bad hym write he scholde hym kenne. Als he had seyd in alle maners, & bitaught hit He tauht it to. þe messegers ffaire folden, & wel enseled, we seilde. & to þer maister was hit deled, deilde. & dide þem alle gret honour, . Y-now he gaf hem of tresour, & bad hem seye to þe Emperour, Þat "Arthur of ffraunce [is] gouernour, " & of Bretaigne chef & flour, " & schal defendit, castel Sall defend boþe toun. & tour, " & be þer warant & socour P. leaves out this line. " Ageyns Romayns to stonde in stour." P. leaves out this line. " Seis say. &yogh;our lord, y wil nought let " To come þat day þat he haþ set; " No trewage to &yogh;elde, but trewage to bot forto. fet; " Loke he be redy, do þat he het!" Þe messegers þer leue þey tok, Toward Rome þer wey þey schok, & telde þe Emperour, when þey come, Þe grete nobleye of Arthures home, How mykel folk þey wyþ hym fond,— . So doughti þer nar non is. in no lond,— & in what stede his court he held, Al þe stat þer-of, þey teld, How curteisly to þem he spak, " Nought but wysdom MS. wysdon. of his mouþ brak; " Nys non on lyue, cayser ne kynge, " Þat semeþ so wel semes so wele. his beryng, " Ne so curteys þer-wyþ-al; " His giftes ar large, & stonde standes. in stal; " Þer ys no kyng doþ suche it is no kyng to his. costages " Of mete ne drynke, ne giftes of no to gyue. wages; " Ne swilk seruise ys þer non " In no court, as in courte bot. his allon. " To aske hym trewe, hit is for nought; " He þenkes to aske &yogh;e þennes þien. [what ye thence took.] brought." Þe chartre þey schewed þer barouns, . & seide, "swich ys Arthures respouns." When þe Romayns had wel herd How þe messegers answerd, & þeir lettre chartre. acorded wel Vntil þer sawe ilka del, Þat Arthur wolde no seruise do, But haue trewage,—þe lettre wild so,— Þey seide to the Emperour alle aboute, " Wyþ force &yogh;e schul don hym loute. " Passeþ Moungu wiþ host right stoute; P. leaves out this line. " & &yogh;if he come, we schal hym route, " & reue hym his regne, maugre his snoute, " & wyþ righte force hold hym wyþoute." P. leaves out this line.
text.210: ¶ De Consilio Romanorum contra Arthurum, cum nominibus Regum eorum. When Lucius wyste Arthures respouns, He saw & sawe. þe wille of his barouns, & he. dide somoune wyþoute delay To be redy byn þe twentyþ be þe tuenty. (al disme, Wace , ii. 134, l. 11,362.) day, Wyþ hors & harneys to wende al prest Ageyn Arthur toward þe west: " ffor y schal nere stynte no stounde P. leaves out this line. . " Til y come þere þat þey hym founde." P. leaves out this line.
text.211: ¶ Nomina Regum. ffirst com Epistrot þe kyng of Grece, & Sire Otheon, Duc of Boece, Sire Hurtak þe kyng of Turkeys, A doughti knyght & a curteys, Pandras þe kyng of Egipte, Crète, MS. du Roi, 27; d'Egypte, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé; Wace , ii. 135, l. 11,374. & of Cyce Gète, MS. du Roi, 27; Crethe, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé; ib. 11,375. þe kyng Ypolipte,— He was of gret seignurie, An hundred cites at his baillie;— Out of Syre cam Ewander, & out of ffryse þe kyng Teucer, & out of Babilloyne sire Macipsa, Micipsa. & out of Spayne sire Elephatina, Alifatina. & out of Mede þe kyng Bockus, & out of Lubye sire Sertorius, Sertonius. (Sertorius, Wace , l. 11,383.) Out of Bycynie sire Polidetes, & out of Tyre þe kyng Serses, Et d'Iture li rois Xersès, Wace. Sire Musensar, kyng of Mucensar out of. Aufrik,— A lond ferne a ful gret stryk; But he broughte tresor gret plente, P. leaves out this line. & fair folk, & fele, to se. P. leaves out this line. — Þo þat were of þe senatours, Men of Rome most of honurs, Of þeym cam Marcel, Lucius, Catel, lucius katell. Octa, Gayus, & sire Metel, Manye oþere & oþer Inouh. of þe same kynde, Þat noman may þer names fynde; & þey alle þe names wer founde, P. leaves out this line. . Me þynkeþ hit were but tynt, þe stounde P. leaves out this line. To write þe names of so fele hounde P. leaves out this line. Þat were vncristned in þys mounde. P. leaves out this line. When alle were comen, symple & bolde, ffour hundred þousand þer wer tolde, & an hundred & foure score, Alle armed men, hit telles of armes men telle. byfore, Wyþoute fotmen & seriauntye, sargeancie. . Þat þe noumbre kan non descrye. When alle were comen þat þider schold come, At þe Lammesse þey wente remoued. (Entrant aost, de Rome murent, Wace , ii. 136, l. 11,401.) fro Rome, & tok þer weye toward Moungu . Wyþ mykel noyse & cry & heu. hu.
text.212: ¶ De tenentibus Regis Arthury. When Arthur departed his meyne, & schulde go þer þey wold be, By name he made þem alle somouns Er þey wente, alle þe barouns, & preied hem of help at here myght,— But þat þey saued wel þeir ryght;— And how mikel ilkon myght brynge, . Þat wolde he wyte ouer alle þynge. Irland, Gutland, & Norweye, Denmark, Island, & Orkeneye, Sex Set, Wace , ii. 136, l. 11,412. score þousand þey hym het, mette. Of alle þo landes gedered & fet,— Knyghtes were namo of non of alle. (N'estoient mie che|valier, Wace , l. 11,414.) þo, But oþere,—þat on fote most þei kouth not ride þei suld. (N'il ne savoient cevalchier, Wace , l. 11,415.) go; On fote by-houed þem bere þer armes, P. leaves out this line. Dartes, gauelokes, & gysarmes; P. leaves out this line. Þat was þe manere of þer lond, P. leaves out this line. Þey hadde non oþer, ne non þem fond. P. leaves out this line. ¶ Of Normandye & of Angeowe, Of Pykardie & of Peytowe, And out of fflaundres & of Brabant, of fflandres & Boloyne. (Bo|logne, Wace , l. 11,420.) ffour score þousand wyþouten want, essoyne (difficulty). essogne, Wace , l. 11421. So mykel scholde þey fynde of fe, P. leaves out this line. . & namore was þer ryght to be. P. leaves out this line. In ffraunce were þanne twelue lordes fers, tuelfe lorde sers. Þat men calle þe dusze cald duze. pers; Þyse dusze pers, lordes of ffraunce, To Gerny Geryn. (Gérin, Wace , l. 11,426.) of Chartres þey hadde alliaunce; Eche of hem Ilk of þam. fond an hundred knyghtes Þat fel to þer fell þer. fe at alle rightes. Ten þousand hette sire Ohel, & two þousand sire Agusel; Auguisel (or Anguisel ). & Arthur, of þys ilke lond Sexti quarante, Wace , l. 11,435. þousand knyghtes he fond, Wyþ-outen fot-folk & archers, & seriauntz & arblasters; Of þyse y ne fond no noumbre y-writen, Ne of na mo ne couþe men witen. ¶ When Arthur wyste þe certeyn, What ilk lord scholde brynge hym how fele ilk kyng suld bring. ageyn Of men of armes of god array, He preied hem come, & sette a day, At Bareflete in Normandye, Þider scholde come al þer nauye; & ilkon certeynlike þey het him certeynly hette. To be þere at þat day set. Þen went alle hom, kyng & knyght, & purueyd hem þat þey were dight.
text.213: ¶ De Modredo, ffratre Walwyny, traditore. Sire Arthur hadde a cosyn, Moddred he highte, a Modrede hight þat. (A Mordret, un de ses nevos, Wace , ii. 138, l. 11,452.) traitur fyn; A noble knyght he was in stour, But til his e[me] he was to his Eame was he. traytour. Arthur bitaughtym he betauht him. his lond to kepe;— Hym hadde ben bettere haue leid had bien better haf liggen. to slepe; ffor he had loued he lufed. þe quene "Genievre estoit sa seror," says the MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3. Colb.; Wace , ii. 138, l. 11,458. priuely, Arthures wyf, & leyn hure lay hir. by; Nought was perceyued bytwyxte hem to: Who schuld haue trowed hit had be wild haf wend it had bien. so? Who wold haue went so synful lyf, Þat þe cosyn had leyn by þe emes wyf? & namely of swylk a man? Þorow al þe werld his los of ran.— ll. 12,043-12,046. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Arthur bitaught hym Geneuere Goneuere. þe quen, (Alas þat euere hit scholde so ben!) allas if myght oþer wais bien. & al þe lond saue þe lond all bot. þe coroune, & schop dight , his host to Southaumptoune, Þer schipes y þe hauen ryden, Þat Arthur & his folk abiden. Þer myghte men se þe mariners, Many wyght man in schipes fers, sers. Ropes to righte, lynes to leye, lay . . . . . tay. By banke & brymme bi bro bi bankis. to tache & teye, Cables to knytte aboute þe mast, Þe sail on &yogh;erde þey feste ful fast, Ancres, ores, redy to hande, . Roþeres, helmes, right for to stande, Bowlyne on bouspret to sette & boulyne to set boulyne to. (After they are on board, Wace has "Boe|" lines sachent et halent," ii. 141, l. 11,510, from MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé. hale, Cordes, kyuiles, atached þe bordes keuiles atache to. (? kevil: A.-Sax. cæfli , halter, bridle: Som|ner. But kevel , pole, Jamieson, and Atkinson's Cleveland Glossary.) wale; When al was redy in god point, Vnto þe lond þe schipes ioynt; Somme stode in schipe, somme on sand, & som on land. Brygges & plankes þey caste to land, kest to þe sand. Wyþ men & hors with horses. for to charge Cogges, barges, & Galeis cogges. schipes large; Brought yn helmes, hauberks & scheldes, & al þat men yn bataille weldes, Hors in to drawe, hors in to dryue; Men hyed þer-after yn ful blyue. When alle were inne, MS. inme. and mad al &yogh;are, & þey on þer wey[e] schuld[e] fare, To þeym o land þey preieden eft spak to eft. To grete þer frendes þat þey had & praied þam grete þer frendes. lefte: On boþe parties was heuy chere [Whan frendes departed leue & dere.] From the Petyt MS. Left out in the Lambeth. ¶ When alle were ynne, & were o flote, Mariners dighte þem to note, Þer takel for to righte dight. & taille, By þe wynd wel for to saylle; Ancres o bord, sayl drowen heye, ankers vpwond saile drouh hie. Þe wynd blew wel, þer schipe gon fleye, & þe mariners þat weren sleye, þo maistres þat were slie. Ilkon dide þer maistrie: Somme aforced þe wyndas, Somme þe loof, somme þe bytas; som þe lofe som þe betas. ("betas," mot espagnol qui signifie les manœuvres (cordes): De Lincy, on the authority of M. Jal, historiographe de la Marine, Wace , i. 141, note. But?) text.214: ¶ De Sompno Arthury. Sire Arthur hadde weder at wille, Saflyk he seyled, wythouten ylle; Hys folk was ioiful & gl[a]dly let, ffor þeire pathe fare to Bareflet. þei red þam right to barbflete. Atte midnyght men gaf god kep, Arthur fel on slomber & slep; In his slepyng als he gan slepe as he gon. lye, Hym þoughte he sey a Bere flye An hugely gret, a lothly best, a long & an vgly beste. & fley faste towardes flouh fast towàrd. þe est. O þat oþer syde a Dragon vp stey; In to þe west hym þoughte he fley; it flegh. Of his mouþ a flaume cam out, Þe lond, þe water, schon al about. Þe bere assailled þe dragoun, & he defended hym as a lyoun; Wonderly ilk oþer gan assaille, & strong was þanne þer bataille; ll. 12,113-12,114. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Scharply þer ilk oþer smot, . Bitterly boþe þey blewe & bot. Þe dragon was swyft, & sleyly suyftly. (Wace has for the three lines before, only "Mais li dragons "l'ours enversoit," ii. 143, l. 12,540.) swypte, Þe bere in his clawes he clypte, & þriste hym so þat he to-barst, to braste. & doun vnto þe erþe hym cast. Arthur of his slepyng wok, Gret tent of his drem he tok; He askede clerkes sete sat. hym aboute, Wheþer hit mente drede or doute: " Y wolde wyte what hit wolde wild wit what it mot. mene, " & wheþer hit tokned ioye or tene, " & wheþer hit was help or dere, . " Þat þe dragoun slow þe bere."
text.215: ¶ Interpretacio Sompny Arthury. Somme þer were þus hit descried, ' Hym self þe dragon signefied, ' & þe bere som geaunt . 'Þat he schuld make He suld him mak. recreaunt, ' ffro fer schold come, & do gret wo, ' & þorow force he schulde hym slo.' Somme oþer weys gan hit rede, But alle þey seyde he schulde wel spede; Þen seide hym self, "y trowe hit menes " Þis werre, & manye oþer tenes " Bytwyxt me & þe Emperour. " Let God al worthe, my creatour!" ¶ At þat word þe day gan sprynge, Þe sonne ros faire y þe mornynge, & at þe sonne rysyng in god tyme Þey come to Bareflete er pryme. ffro of. schip to londe ful sone þey &yogh;ede, & in þe contre aboute gon sprede; He seide he wolde his folk abyde, Þo þat were nought come not comen. þat tyde. Longe while long stounde. dwelled he nought, Þat tydynges men hym tiþinges men to him. brought, Þat þider was comen a geaunt, & longe þer hadde ben his haunt; Out of Spayne was he comen, MS. comem. & [had] had. Sire Oheles nece y-nomen; Mayde Eleyne was hure name, He had hure taken to do hure schame, & had hure brought vnto an hil, Þat non ne myghte ne durste dar. com til.— Micheles Mount men calles call. hit now, . Þere þe geaunt Eleyne slow; Was þer non auter ne altere no. (mostier ne, Wace , ii. 145, l, 11,575. no chapel Þat ilke tyme þat þis chaunce fel; Aboute þat hil þe water flowes, . Comeþ þer non þat he ne rowes.— Þer it. was non þat hadde þat myght Þat wyþ þe geaunt durst ones fight; Somme þer were vmwhile wylde fonde, wold som tyme fond. & hym assailled by water & londe, But he gaf nought of þeir MS. his. P. þer. assaut, ffor þey fulle euere in þeir fell in all. defaut; ffor grete roches at þem he cast, & þer schipes to-rof & brast. Many were drenkled, fele were slayn, Þo þat ascaped, hit was wyþ payn; Þer-fore þe contre was ner al fled, Þeir wonyng fursoke, þeir godes led, & lefte þat lond wast & wylde, ffor man or best, wyf or childe. Þe geauntes name was Dynabrok, . A grysly grimly. man was on to loke.
text.216: ¶ De Gygante Dynabroke. When Arthur hadde herd þe pleynt, How wyþ þe geaunt þe folk was teynt, He calde sire Caye & Beduer, The three next lines are in De Lincy's MS. of Wace, though turned out by him in favour of another MS., vol. ii. p. 146, note MS. his. P. þer. . & ilk of þeym tok a squyer; Armure dide þey wiþ hem lede, & ilk of þeym tok hym a stede. He nolde schewe hit to namo . Þat he wolde suld. to þe geaunt go; &yogh;yf alle had wyst he wente so one, Þe ost had ben abaischt ilkone; He tristed wel in trasted wele on. Godes grace Þat he durste hym schewe his face, & on his grete owen. vaillauntise Ar þat. he durst take þat emprise. Al þat ilke night þey ryden, Þat þey no whar neuer. stynte ne biden, Til hit was y þe morn[e] tyde Þat þey seye wel þere bysyde A bot standynge at a stage; Þen hoped þey þere was þe passage. Two hilles wyþynne þe water wore, Þat on was lasse, þat oþer more; O þe more hil þer was a fyr, ffro ferre þey sey hit brenne schir; 2 Þe lasse hil was nought so drey ffro þe more, but euene ney; An oþer fir was on þat hil; 2 2-2 a noþer fire was on þe lesse hill. Þer-fore Arthur was al wyl all will. On whilk hil þe geaunt was, Ne non couþe kenne hym þe righte pas. Þen bad he sire Beduer "go " To serche þe hilles to & fro; " & when þou wost þe certeyn, " Hye þe þanne to me a-geyn." Þenne Beduer dide hym in þe bot, & on þe nexte hil he smot. Beduer stod, smote. & hym auysed Whider-ward þe weyes wysed; Þe nexte wey he tok vp hey, & als he wente he herde a cry; Gret pleynte he herde on make; A party gan his herte quake; He wende hit hadde þe geaunt ben, . Þat his comyng had wist or sen; He drow hys swerd al so smert, & gadered hardinesse of hert, & þought þat &yogh;yf he wyþ hym mette, Wyþ hym to fighte he wolde nought lette. But al þat þenkyng was in bot. vayn, ffor on þe hil aboue þe playn He fond a fir brennyng an hy, brennand hie. & a toumbe newe þer-by; Als he bar his swerd in hande, By þe toumbe he sey on sittande, A womman, ner al naked, Aboute hure hed hure her to-schaked; hir haire schaked. Biside þe toumbe þis womman lay, & often cried "wey la way!" & mente þe vilenye & þe peyne, & seide, "alas for þe, Eleyne!"
text.217: ¶ De Tumba Elene, & de nutrice eius. Beduer sey þe toumbe was newe, & of hure deol his herte gan rewe. Whan scheo perceyued sire Beduer, Scheo saide, "cheytyf, what wiltow caitife what dos þou. her? " Som synne haþ þe hyder y-brought, " Þat þy deþ her hastow dede here has. sought; " Þis day ys þe schape to deye, " &yogh;yf þe geaunt þe se wyþ eye. " Þis ilke hil swyþe þou weyue, " So þat he þe nought perceyue." " ¶ Wyf," he seide, "for par. charite, " Let þy gretyng, & spek wyþ me, " & sey me what þou art, & why " Þou wepest here so delfully, " & ho ys leyd here on þis graue; " & sey me soþ, so God criste. þe saue!" ¶ " I am," scheo seyde, " a wo-bygon," " An helples þyng, a waryed on, " & grete for a maydens I grete for mayden. myshap sen. " Þat whilom y norisched at my pap, " & souke y gaf hure of my brest; 3_3 at souke .I. gaf hir of my pap. I. norissched hir of my breste. " & þis ys hure toumbe One stroke too many for um in the MS. þat þou sest; " Eleyne scheo highte, Oheles nece, . " Of flesche was non so fair a pece. " To norische sche was me taught, to me scho was bitauht. " Alas þe while y euere hure aught! " So cam þis fend to þys contre, " & tok boþe Eleyne hir. & me, " & broughte vs here vnto þis hyl, " So þat noman dar come vs tyl. " Eleyne he wolde haue furlayn, " But sche ne myghte nought wyþ þat payn; " He was so huge, grete. ouer mesure, " & scheo so &yogh;ong, þat myght nought dure. " Þorow gret destresse hire herte brast, " In his armes scheo &yogh;ald þe gast, " & yn þys toumbe y haue hure leyd; " & þus hit was so it is. als y haue seid." ¶ Þen seid he, " wherto dwellest þou here, " Syþen sen. sche ys ded þat was þe dere?" " Sire," scheo seyde, " y wil þe telle " &yogh;if þou durstest durste. so longe dwelle. " Sire, for y þe se of body auenaunt, " & gentil man by [þi] be þi. semblaunt, " When y sey Eleyne so schamely deye, " My wit was lorn, & al a-weye; " Wyþ force he dide me leue stille, " His lecherie in me to fulfille. " On God hym selue y take witnes, " Þat al maugre myn hit es! " & ilka tyme þat y him se, . " Y wilde be sonken, for y ne may fle; " & y trowe he comeþ right hope [expect] he comes. sone, " His lecherie wyþ me to done. " Y telle þe ded, &yogh;yf þou here bydes, . " No þyng ne saueþ þe, ne hides; " Swyþe þou fle, y gyue þe red, " Y wolde nought þou were so wild not se þat þou were. ded. " &yogh;onder ys he, y schal þe kenne, " On &yogh;one hil þer þou sest brenne; " Sone to come his tyme schal be, " Þer-fore, sire knyght, y rede þou fle, " & let me haue my self my sorewe, " My wille ys to be ded to die. to morewe." Of hure wo sore hym ouer þought; forþouht. But he ne wiste what hure dought, Ne to make ne he to mak. long dwellyng. He turned ageyn vnto þe kynge; & als scheo seide, so he hym tolde, How Eleyne deyde, & scheo in holde, & he scholde fynde þe geaunt Y þe more hil, þer was his haunt; " Out of þat stede þe smoke cam comes. fro, " We may hym fynde &yogh;if þat we go." ¶ ffor Eleyne had Arthur sorewe ynow, & abod til þe flod wyþ-drow. widrouh. Vntil vnto. þe ebbe a stounde þey bod, Wiþ þer hors þen ouer þey rod, & wenten bote a softe schorte. pas Tyl þei perceiued wher he MS. scheo. P. he. was. Þeir stedes & þer palfreys Þeir squiers helde, wiþ oþer harneys; But sire Beduer & sire Kay &yogh;ede wiþ Arthur vp þe way. Arthur seide, "y wil proue my might, " Wiþ þe geaunt alone to fight; " Hold &yogh;ow here byhynde a lyte; " Alone on hym wil y first smite; " While till. y may my selue saue, " Oþer help wil y non haue; " Me þynkeþ hit were no vasselage, " Þre til on; hit were outrage! " Nere þe les, &yogh;yf þat &yogh;e se nede, " Bettere ys help þan ouer drede; " ffor men seye, 'hit ys folye P. leaves out this line. . " ' In strengthe to mikel for to affye.' " P. leaves out this line. Þey seide, 'for prowesse ne for &yogh;elp, ' &yogh;yf hit were ned, þey wolde hym help.'
text.218: ¶ De Occisione Gygantis Dynabrok per Arthurum. Arthur alone þe hil he tok Puis ont tot trois le mont puié, Wace , ii. 152, l. 11,867. . Vnto þe geaunt Dynabrok. By a mykel fir he sat, Rostyng a swyn gret & & roste suynes flesch full. fat, & oþer flesche biside was sode; som rosted & som was sothen. His bryn, les guernons (moustaches), Wace , ii. 153, l. 11,872. his berd, þer-wiþ al lothen, his bryne his berde þer with was broþen. & al to-soilled to solied. wyþ þe spyk: I trowe þat syght was ful loþlyk; But Arthur þoughte to haue þe grace to smyte er he tok come or he toke. his mace. When þe geaunt of hym was war, fferly he hadde how he cam þar, & stirte vp þenne al o glyft/, His grete mace & toke his mace vp. for to lyft; But Arthur auised hym wel ynow; Als he hys mace vpward drow, Arthur bar on hym wyþ his launce . To combren hym, als of chaunce; Longe þey foughte, a wel god while, But Arthur couþe mykel of gyle; Nere sleighte & queyntise hadde ben, & gile, P. leaves out this line. . Somme had be combred þer in a whyle; P. leaves out this line. ffor kyng Arthur neuere er was P. leaves out this line. Bystad in so hard a cas. P. leaves out this line. Dynabrok a-geyn hym stod . Wyþ his mace, as geaunt wod, ffor þre men, wyþoute þe forþe, Schuld nought haue stired his mace from suld not lifte it fro þe. erþe; He sey wel how he made his mynt, & wiþ his mace he teysed teysed , poised; cp. teyse & tais|and , Sevyn Sages, 1978, in Halliwell. his dynt; He wiste þe strok schulde be gret; Vnder his scheld al he schet, & ageyn his þe. strok hit held. Þen smot þe geaunt on his scheld, & wyþ þat dynt so so was þe dynt. heuy & stronge Þe hilles alle aboute ronge, & al þat was þer-inne, hit schok P. leaves out this line. . When Arthur þat dynt so huge tok. P. leaves out this line. Arthur was stoneyd, stakered, & stynt, But &yogh;ut fel he nought for þat dynt. Anoþer strok wold he nought byde, . But peyned etild. hym to smyte a syde Wyþ his swerd Caliborne; Scharply he gan hym torne; Þat swerd he lifte wel on hey, . & valede his scheld his schelde he auailed (lowered). a party; Endlong & o long. his forehed he hym smot, Þe swerd bot wel, & he was hot, & entamed boþe his bryn Les deus sorcils li entama, Wace , ii. 154, l. 11,896. Þat al þe skyn heng ouer hys eyn. Wyþ þat strok he hadde ben slayn: His mace he held wel þer a-gayn, & his heued a party glent, Þat som of þe strok hit hent; Netheles, wel was hit set; Þe blod al ouer his eyen hit schet; his Ine get. Þen lost he þer al his sight, Þen wax was. he woder for to fyght, Þen was he woder þen he was or, P. leaves out this line. ffightyng als a wylde bor, P. leaves out this line. Þe same weys so dide he; P. leaves out this line. When he sey þat he myghte nought se, etild. He ne lefte for swerd ne oþer hirt Þat he vntil Arthur stirt; Aboute his middel his armes he leyd, & on Arthur so sore he breyd, sare he braid. On heighte he lifte hym four fet; & als he þere hym doun let, Vpon his knes he hym kast. Þen Arthur proued his force fast, Our lady hym halp, his wille was god, Wyþ force he ros, & he vp stod; & Arthur was algate queynte, & his wille was neuere feynte; On þat syde he bar his scheld, & þe geaunt nought ne þe Geaunt nouht he ne. held, Wyþ þat he wroþ, wroþe (writhed). & turnde his syde, & dide his armes armure. opene wyde. When he hym self was fro hym broken, & þat his body was nought loken, not stoken. fful lyght hym þoughte þat he was oute; P. leaves out this line. Wiþ Caliborne þen ran he aboute, P. leaves out this line. And euere on þe geaunt on þe Geaunt with his suerd he. smot, & Caliborne sore vpon hym bot. Þe geaunt glente hider & tyder, þider & þidere. Þe blod so blent hym, he nyst whider; He groped aboute hym for to grapte about if he mot. hent, & Arthur aboute hym euere went/, & smot hym sore woundes with wondes. fele, . Nought of hym ne wolde he spele; spele = spare. & at a turn þe geaunt stynt/, Arthur gaf hym so gret a dynt 11 O þe hed, þat in to þe nekke hit dref, & in to þe schuldres þe panne he clef; 11 11-11 þan doun in to þe hede it drafe. þe panne in to þe schuldres klafe. &yogh;yt he after Arthur raught,— Arthur wyþ-drow & Arthur drouh. his swerd a draught,— Þat he stombled, & gaf a cry, P. leaves out this line. A dredful & a loþly; P. leaves out this line. When he fel, he gaf a lasche As wyþ a blast had falle an asche; & for þat fal Arthur low, He was venged hym þoughte venged wele. y-now; ffro ferre he stod, & loked on hym, P. leaves out this line. & seyde he was a geaunt grym; P. leaves out this line. He bad Beduer he schulde go To smyte þe heued þe body fro, & bytake bitech. hit a squier To schewe hit al þe host plener.
text.219: ¶ Hic narrauit Arthurus Beduero & Kayo de gigante Rytone. Þen telde Arthur to Beduer & He teld Beduer & sir. Kay, Þat he nadde neuere suche affray, Of no geaunt but of on, & þat geaunt highte Ryton; P. has for the next two lines,— he did mykell wonder & wo. & many kynges did he slo. & all þer berdes he did of flo. a pane he mad of alle þo. fful manye kynges had he don slo, & flow þe berdes of alle þo; Til a pane, as a furour, And as a forrour. he did hem tewe: Loke &yogh;if Ryton were nought se how Riton was. a schrewe! Þat geaunt Riton sende his sonde Til Arthur fro ferne fer. londe, & seide he scholde make hym a-ferd But he flowe of his owen awen. berd, & sent hit hym vntil his pane, . To menske hit þer hit was wane; & &yogh;yf he sent hit hym bleþely, He schulde set hit most worschipfuly, suld do it most curteisy. ffor he wolde vrle his pane wyþ-al . Aboute wiþ a ffylet smal; And &yogh;yf Arthur wylde nought Do als Ryton hym bisought, Greyþe hym as sone as Redy him sone als. he myght, ffor Ryton wolde wyþ hym fight; & whilk of þem might oþer slo, His berd he scholde don of flo, & haue þe pane ilka del, Þer-wyþ aboute vrle hit wel. Arthur þen til Ryton went, In bataille he slow hym bataile slouh Riton. & schent, & wan þe pane & his berd; O þe mount Derane de Rame. (Et mont de Rave, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé; d'Artane MS. de l'Ars., 171. B.-L.; Wace , ii. 158, note ( a ).) he was conquerd. Siþen fond Arthur neuere non But Dynabrok, as was Ryton, Þat neuere dide til hym in dede, Þat he had of so mykel drede. Þer þey hym slowe, þer þey hym leued, & Beduer tok a squier þe heued, To bere & schewe þe host aboute, Wher þat þey were, & in what doute. Sire Ohel ful sore byment it ment. Þat his nece was so schent; A fair chapel for hure dide make, Of oure lady, for Eleynes Heleyn. sake. Siþen sen. þat tyme scheo was þer leyd, ffor Eleyne, Heleyn. 'Eleynes Heleyn. toumbe' ys seid; & so men han cald hit ay P. leaves out this line. ' Eleynes toumbe' vnto þys day. P. leaves out this line. When þe host was al comen & &yogh;are, Þo þat scholde wiþ Arthur fare, No þrowe while. wolde he þare lye, But passed sone al Normandie. His folk wax flok wex. wher-so he cam, Þe doughtiest wyþ hym he nam, Out of castel & of cite, & passed Burgoyne, al þat contre; Vntil Hostum, Ostun [Autun], Wace , ii. 160, 12,020. þyder he þought; & þennes tidynges men hym þien tiþinges till him men. brought, Þat þey of Rome com wyþ gret route, & tok þe contre al aboute. ¶ Al as MS. Alas. P. has Als. Arthur schulde a water passe— Albe, Aube, Wace , ii. 160, l. 12,027. hit seis þe name wasse— Al day til Arthur men tolde, Wiþ passand men Li païsant, Wace , l. 12,028. & spies bolde, Þat þe Emperour was þere bysyde; To conseille what best myghte bytide, him how best mot tide. His pauilons, his penceles, þykke Nought fer fro þenne had þey don wyk: fer þien had þei doun pikke. (A.-Sax., wician , to encamp.) " Þer are so manye of so many. Romayns, " & þyn host may nought & þou has non oste. þeym ageyns. " ffoure haþ he agayns ere agayn. on of þyne; " & &yogh;if &yogh;e assemble, þou MS. þi u or þi n . most If bataile go þou sall. tyne." Arthur seide, "Godes help ys ney! " He wot ho schal haue þe maistri." He left nought for no manace; Vpon Albe Aube, Wace , l. 12,041. in a strong place A castel he dide reyse & set, &yogh;yf he had nede to take recet; him were nede to haf resette. Smertly to make þei were al bon P. leaves out this line. Wyþ folk ynow, & sone had don. P. leaves out this line. When al was ended þe grete vp in þe. tour, He leyde in He did. his harneys & his tresour, &yogh;yf chaunce come þei moste wyþdrawe com þat him bord fle. To rest hem þere a litel þrawe. þer in tuo daies or þre. (R. Manning follows the Arsenal MS. of Wace (ii. 161, note ( c )) in the last four lines.
text.220: ¶ Arthurus misit nuncios ad Inperatorem. When þe castel was al dight, & defensable for kyng & knyght, He ordeynd messegers sent messengers. to wende, . To þe Emperour he þoughte to sende, Two erles þat were of noble lynage, & wel spekynge, wele spoken. of god langage: Geryn of Chartres, a man of pris, Wiþ Beofs of Hamptone, Beus of Oxenford. an oþer ful wys; Wiþ þise two wente sire Wawayn, ffor he spak wel þe speche Romayn; ffor he had longe wiþ hem ben, P. leaves out this line. & his connynge þey hadde wel sen; P. leaves out this line. ffor þat skile Arthur hym sent, P. leaves out this line. Þat he wist best what þeir speche ment; P. leaves out this line. & Arthur taughte þem þus to seye, When þey schulde wende þer weye: " Sey þemperour he go to Rome, " & to ffraunce non hender come, " Ne til no landes þat y wan, . " Ne chalange hit as man be chalenged þorgh no. Romayn; " Þo ar myne; & myne schul be; " Romayn of þeym schal neuere haue fee. " &yogh;yf he wil nought turne ageyn, " Byd hem abide þe stand to. bataille pleyn, " & auenture at alle vs all to. chaunce " To dereyne þe ryght of Rome & whilk sall derayne þe Reme of. ffraunce. " As longe as y may ffraunce may it. saue, " Þe Romayns schul hit france sall he neuer. neuere haue. " Wyþ bataille, sey hym, y hit wan, " & schal & so. defend hit fro ilka man. " Wiþ force, þer-of had þey first fee, . " Wyþ force þey les hit a-geyns me; " & now wiþ bataille schal hit be sall be. sene " Who schal haue hit quyt & clene."
text.221: ¶ De nunciis Regis Arthury ad Inperatorem. Þe messegers þat wente þo nedes, Horsed þem on gode stedes: & armed þem at alle rightes, As fel vnto noble knyghtes. Oþer Bretons herd her-of seye, & wente to mete hem bifore & led þam alle þre. on weye, And preied hem à Gauvain, Wace , ii, 162, l. 12,080. hertely for to do Som þyng, or seye þe Romayns to, Þat þe werre myghte algate go Er þey comen þe court fro: " Hit haþ be longe it has bien long. manaced & þret, " But so ney to-gydere were we nere & now so nere togider ere. set; " Schame hit were þat eyþer &yogh;ede " Wiþouten bataille or vaillaunte manly. dede. " &yogh;yf so bitide &yogh;e þat. hit bygynne, " &yogh;yt schul Bretons prowesse wynne; " Þer-to algate dos &yogh;our trauail, P. leaves out this line. . " & þat we may, we wil &yogh;ow vaille." P. leaves out this line. Þen seide Wawayn, "in alle manere " Of vs schul &yogh;e som tyding here; " & &yogh;yf &yogh;e se þat we ought dwelle, . " Tydyng þer-of men schal telle." ¶ Þe messegers passed a mountayne, & þenne a wode, & syþen a playne; ffro of. þat playne a partye helded, & þer-on were þe Romayns telded; fful semly wyþouten bost Þey come rydyng al ridand. þorow þe host. þe Romains on ilka side aboute, Of þer tentes comen þei com. oute Þo messegers to byholde, Þat semed noble bodies men. & bolde. Þey asked what tydynges þey brought, Or þider for þe pes þey sought: Wyþ non þey stode, ne tales helde, Tyl þey come to þe Emperours telde. When þey were at his pauyloun, Þere-byfore þey lyghte alle doun, & bitok þeir hors Bitauht þer hors. þeir pages, To stande right stille at certeyn stages.
text.222: ¶ Hic venerunt Nuncii coram Inperatore. By-fore þe Emperour come alle þre, & seide þeir message as men auise, Geryn & Beofs beus. boþe ful wys; And þe Emperour seide hem his auis, & spak ageyn þeym & teld agayn. boþe fast. But þenne spak Wawayn atte last: " We ar come fro þe kyng Arthour " To þe, sire Lucius, Emperour; " We are his knyghte to lyue & deye; " His message y schal þe holy I sall þe. seye. " Þys ys þe message gretyng. þat he þe sendes: " He comaundes þe, & defendes, " Þat þou of ffraunce nought entremet, " Ne no fot þideward ferrer þou. set; " ffor Fraunce he holdes as his demeynes, demeyng . . . . . romeyns. " & euere schal, for alle Romeynes. demeyng . . . . . romeyns. " &yogh;yf þou of hym wilt ought chalenge, " Þorow bataille wil he hym venge. " Þorow bataille first wonne &yogh;e ffraunce, " & les hit after þorow a chaunce; " A-geyn Arthur &yogh;e hit les " Þorow bataille, as þe party ches, " & now ys holde as his conqueste, P. leaves out this line. " & schal while þe sonne ryseþ est. P. leaves out this line. " & &yogh;yf þou sette chalange þer-ynne, . " Þorow bataille byhoueþ þe hit wynne; þorgh þe bihoues it wyn. " Þorow bataille schal hit be dereynt, " Þy chalangyng & al þy pleynt, " & sone assigned set. wyþoute delay, " Com to morn, & prof proue. þy day, " & wyn hit &yogh;yf þou wynne schal! " Or al to lese, or wynne haf. hit al! " &yogh;yf þou wilt nought turne a-geyn, " Al þy dwellyng is in veyn, " ffor þou hast lorn, & we haue wonnen, P. leaves out this line. " So ferre we haue þy lond ouer ronnen." P. leaves out this line.
text.223: ¶ Responcio Lucii Inperatoris. Þenne seyde þemperour to þise þre, " To turne ageyn, hit schal nought be. " ffraunce ys myn, þider wol y go; " ffor &yogh;if y lese hit, me schal be wo; " & &yogh;if y ha lore hit .I. haf lorn. at vnskyle, " Y schal hit wynne eft when God sall wyn it whan grace. wyle." Þus he seide, for wel he wende P. leaves out this line. Þey hadde no force Fraunce to fende. P. leaves out this line. A knyght þer was, hight Quyntalyn, Syb þemperour, & his cosyn, Contrariously to Wawayn spak, & vyleynlike he gan hym lak: vilensly behynd his bak. " Bretons," he saide, "ar bot auaunturs, " & manace mikel at rebours; " Þer bostful wordes ar nought to seke, " Þer dedes ar nought worþ a leke. " &yogh;e manace ay 'hit schal ben so;' . " &yogh;our dedes ar noughte þat &yogh;e do. " Al day bostfuly &yogh;e þrete; " Doþ hit in dede! manace &yogh;e do in dede þe manaee. lete!" Wawayn hym listed, & gram low, listend him Inouh. But smertly out his swerd he drow, & smot his hed of þer al quit, & bad his felawes horse þem tyt, And seyde vnto þe Romaynes alle, . " Bretons schul rise, & &yogh;e schul falle! " &yogh;ow were wel bettere at Rome burgh, P. leaves out this line. " Þan reyse baner a-geyn Arthurgh!" P. leaves out this line. Þer-wyþ sire Wawayn his hors hent, & homward alle þre þey went.
text.224: ¶ De probitate nunciorum Arthury. This heading is two lines lower in the MS. Þe knyght courte. was frayed, no wonder was, Þe Emperour cried "alas! alas! " Slayn þey haue sire Quyntalyn . " Now right here byfore myn eyn! " &yogh;yf þey a-scape vs alle fro, " Merueille mervaily. may men telle of þo." Romayns ronne out of pauylons, & hasted fast Suythe. after þe Bretons. Ilkon tok þat þey myght hent, & after þem prykede faste, & went. On þer was þat hadde a stede, Þat byfore alle þe oþere &yogh;ede, & cried ful loude, "abyd! abyd! " &yogh;yf þou dar, turne, & to me ryd!" Sire Geryn herde what he seyde, & turnde hym, & his spere forþ leyde, & of his gode hors hym cast Als fer as þe spere wold last. Þen seide Geryn als he lay þore, " Þyn hors bar þe ouer faste fer. byfore; " &yogh;it were þe bettere ha ben at þe ost P. leaves out this line. " Þan fort ha foched þy deþ wyþ bost, P. leaves out this line. " & haue holde þe fer o drey, P. leaves out this line. " ffor now þe ouer-þynkeþ þou come so ney." P. leaves out this line. ¶ Beofs þou gapid. of Oxenforde þen loked bak, & listned how þat Geryn spak, Saw þe Romayn ded þer lay, P. leaves out this line. . & his hors wente forþ o stray; P. leaves out this line. Þen þoughte sire Beofs, Beus. "y am to blame " But y do til anoþer þe same." His hors he turnd þen, and abod, & til anoþer Romayn rod; & wyþ his spere lance. he bar hym yn Þorow-out þe þrote, byneþe þe chyn. Gapyng he lay at erþe al gaspand he fell & lay all. streked Als he was wyþ þe launce cheked. Þen seide sire Beofs, Beus. for þat he gaped, þou gapid. " To þe mete fuer sone hym full sone þou. (De tex morsiax vous sai je pestre, Wace , ii. 168, l. 12,211.) raped, " But ly now stille þer, ar lig now still ore þat. þou ete, " & &yogh;if þy felawes þe ouer gete, 8 "Sey, 'þe messegers wente here forþ god spede, " '& wiþ suche musseles he can &yogh;ow fede.' " 8 8-8 to þam may þou þe soþe say. þe messengers went bi þis way. ¶ Þen cam anoþer ride faste A noþer com ridand fast. byforn, A noble knyght of Rome born,— Marcels, hit seyþ his name Marcell it sais þat he. hight,— & hadde an hors was ferly lyght; wyght. Of þem alle last horsed he was, P. leaves out this line. & passed þe formest a gret pas; P. leaves out this line. And for gret haste, as of chaunce, He hadde furgete at hom his launce. He sporede his hors, forþ faste with sporse he smote þe hors. gan schake, Wel wende he Wawayn for to ha take, & seyde, "hit were ful gret ferlik P. leaves out this line. " But he broughte Wawayn to þem al quyk." P. leaves out this line. Wawayn wondred hym ferne hed selcouth fer. fro . Þat his hors myght so wel go. ffor Marcel neyghed Wawayn right hende, Wawayn to take ful wel he wende; But his hors com so smertly, & passed Wawayn fast hym by, & als he by Wawayn glent, Wawayn had his swerd out hent, And clef his heued at o dynt, Þorow helm, þat at þe breste þorgh þe helme to þe sadill. hit stynt; His gode armure auailled nought, Wyþ þat strok to with þe drauht. þe erþe he sought. In his fallynge, seide Wawayn, " Marcel, y rede þou turne a-gayn, " & go to Quyntalyn to helle, " & on myn half þou hym telle, " Þat þe Bretons þat &yogh;e þus chace, " Wel more con do þan more do þan þai. manace. 7 ."Sey Quyntalyn, 'we hym by þe grete, " '& more wol gyue þan we wol hete!' " 7 7-7 & more þai gife þan þei hete. bi þe Marcell Quintelyn .I. grete. Now to-gydere þey gonne þem drawe, & oþer þre þey dide of dawe; Lenger to iuste myght þey nought stande, But þem defended al wyþdrawande. & were fleand. Þe Romayns on alle halue hem ilk half þam. went, Wiþ swerd & spere strokes þey suerdes & lances strokes. lent, But neuere for strok þat þey þer tok, P. leaves out this line. Of stirop ne sadel out ne schok, P. leaves out this line. Ne drowen blod, ne gof þem wounde, P. leaves out this line. Ne stopped þem þer wey no stounde. P. leaves out this line. ¶ Þenne had Marcel a neuew Þat was horsed vntil his prew: In his wey Marcel he fond, Liggyng slayn þer Slayn he lay. on a lond. After þe messegers trauersed [he] þe feld; & Wawayn houed, & byheld Þat he cam so gret a spurne, . He had no leyser his hors to turne Vntil he cam among þem alle, & of his hand his spere lance. let falle, & drow his swerd, scharp to byte: P. transposes these lines. He wende Wawayn wel to smyte; P. transposes these lines. & as he lifte his swerd vp heye, At his hand Wawayn let fleye, & smot of boþe hand & arm, . So þat he dide namore harm. Anoþer strok he scholde haue had, But wiþ þe Romayns þey were ouerstad, So ferly fele after þem schok. But for al hem, þat alle gate. þe wode þey tok, Þat was bitwixt hem & Arthures hold, Þe newe castel y lang er told. .I. ore of told. (p. 438, l. 12,521).
text.225: ¶ Hic misit Arthurus in obuiam sex mille armatos. Arthur our kyng, þat was at home, . Wondred þe messegers nought ne come; Sex þousand sent he for drede, To socoure þeym &yogh;yf þey had nede. Þey come & passed to þe wodes side, & þere wyþstode stode. for to abyde. After þer messegers þey gaf þer tent, &yogh;yf þey of hem had any glent; Þey seye gret folk in partyes sprede, Þat folewede þre þat to þe wode &yogh;ede. Þen perceyued knyghtes & squiers Þat þo þre were messegers Þat þey come fore, & after sought. . Pryuely þey stode, auised þer þought, Siþen þey gaue a cri ful gret, At ones vpon þe Romayns þei schet, Al vnwarned in þer vys. Þenne sprad þe Romayns in partis; Somme þat fledde were ouer-taken, & somme prisoned, & halden prisonde holden. waken, Somme slayn & beten doun, . fful fewe were leten to full was giffen for. raunsoun; Wiþ mikel wo any ascaped, P. leaves out this line. Þat he ne was fruscht & al to-fraped. P. leaves out this line.
text.226: ¶ Petreus, Romanorum tribunus. A noble man was þere of Rome, Of alle þer knyghtes he bar þe blome, Petreus Peredur, MS. du Roi, 27; Pet|reius, MS. du Roi. 73, Cangé; Wace , ii. 172, l. 12,310, and note. his name hight, A worthi man, & mykel of myght; What for his prowesse for richesse. & god knyght, Ten þousand men he ladde in fyght. had þorh right. He herde of þe Bretons assaut, & how þer men were att defaut; " Smertly wyþ ten þousand scheldes " To sokere hem go we to socoured þer men in. þe feldes." Wyþ þo ten þousand þat he brought, Vpon þe Bretons harde he sought, Þat maugre þeires he dide þem go In to þe wode þer þey come fro; O þe playne myghte þey holde no place, P. leaves out this line. Þat to þe wode he gan þem chace; P. leaves out this line. & when þey were in wode teld, Ageyn Petron þer owen þey held. Petrens often on þem gan pres, presse . . . . . lesse. But mikel of his folk he les, presse . . . . . lesse. ffor þe Bretons stirt out & slow, . & eft in to þe wode þem drow; By þe wodes side in a busch brusse. Was many a stour & many a frusch. many fight & many frusse.
text.227: ¶ Iterum misit Arthurus quinque mille armatos. Arthur merueilled ferly strong Þat þe messegers dwelled so long, & what þem letted, & þorow wham, or for whome. Þat þe sex þousand hom ne cam. home ne come. Þen cald he swyþe he cald Nu sonne. (Ider le fil Nut apela, Wace , ii. 173, l. 12,336.) sire Ider Þat was a doughti bacheler: " Tak fyf þousand, Set mil, Wace , l. 12,337. & smartly fare, " Þe sex þousand sekeþ, wher þey are." Sire Ider dide as Arthur bad, . & for his wendyng fele were glad. Als Ider & his folk forþ ferde, Gret noise vnder a wode þey herde; Þey hied þem þanne, & wel go[d] a full gode. pas, . Þey dredde þem sore of som mys cas. dred sore þer was som kas. Þen say Ider þat sire Wawayn & Geryn, & Beof, beus. foughte oþer a-geyn.
