In to þe most pres Ider þen sprong, & gaf a cri, þe wode al rong. Þanne were þe Bretons alle abouen, Þe Romayns route bakward schouen: When Ider had met wyþ þe Romains route, . Of dynt ne deþ no dede. had he no doute; Lytel þey þoughte hem self to saue, P. leaves out this line. So fayn þey wolde þe werre haue; P. leaves out this line. Þe Romayns þey ouer ryden & ronne, & þer gode stedes wonne; & þe Romayns atter power P. leaves out this line. Stryken & stoden ageyns Ider; P. leaves out this line. Manye were on boþe partys Slayn þer for to wynne pris. Petreus, he þat y of tolde, þe noble Romayn fers & riche romeyn & so. bolde, He mayntende þer was mayntenure. bataille, & sette his folk wysly his folk he set right. to assaille; Wel couþe he stande, wel couþe he scurne, P. leaves out this line. & faire wyþdrawe hym, & eft returne. P. leaves out this line. Bytwyxt þem with him & þam. were many chaces, ffele turnynges & fele wanlaces: Þat hardy was, he fond hardy; Who so couþe iuste, he fond redy; Þat wel couþe fighte, þer fond his fere; P. leaves out this line. . Þat nought ne couþe, þer myght he lere. P. leaves out this line. Al þe Bretons, oft astray þey rod, Non held to-gydere, ne oþer abod. 1 ffor prowesse þat þey &yogh;ernde al day, Þer-fore þey nere of non array; Þey nadde warde how þat þey &yogh;ede, But þat prowesse wer do of armes dede. 1 1-1 For these four lines P. has four at the bottom of the page in a fresh hand (or with a fresh pen), and then two over leaf in the same hand and with the old pen:— & to do som dede þat day. þerfor þe rode on þat aray. þei ne rouht how þei &yogh;ede. bot þat þei did of armes dede. to do som þei &yogh;erned all day. þerfor þei rode at non aray. ¶ Petreus bygan auise hym was auised. more, Hys beste men a-boute hym wore, He couþe in werre wel stonde in stour, & at his nede gete at nede seke. hym socour; fful wel he halp þere help failled, P. leaves out this line. & wel hym rescowed when he was sailled; P. leaves out this line. God tent til on. al his men he tok, When þey astraied, whideward where þei straied whidire. þey schok, & alle relyed þem wel ageyn, . Þat ilkon wyste his certeyn. Beofs Beus. of Oxenforde perceiued wel Þe comynges of Petron ilka del, Þat wyþoute los schold losse suld. þey nought go But &yogh;yf þey mighte Petron slo,— Sle, or take in pleyn[e] feld,— ffor his confort þe Romayns MS. Bretons. P. comyng þe romeyns. vp held. Hider & þider þe Bretons went, Al out of array, & were ney schent. Þe beste barons bretons. of þem alle, Beofs Beus. to consail gon þey[m] See l. 12,896. P. gon þam. calle: ¶ "Lordes," he seyde, "spekeþ wyþ me, " Þo þat til Arthur wol leaute. " Bygonne we haue a cuntek, " But Arthur wot nought of þis chek; " Wyþoute his wityng is þis tyrpeyl, . " Þer-fore y cald &yogh;ow to conseil; " &yogh;yf hit falle wel, wel schal vs be; " &yogh;yf hit ne do, we gete maugre. " But &yogh;yf we in þys firste stour between lines 12,899 and 13,000, a hundred line numbers were, by oversight, left out. " Haue þe pris, haf þe gre. & bere þe flour, " I telle vs schent, ilka man, " & mikel maugre þat we hit gan. we it began. " Hit was &yogh;our conseil as wel as oures, . " &yogh;e preied vs to bygynne þyse stoures: " Þe bettere þer-fore peyne &yogh;ow to do " Þyng þat y schal conseille to; " ffonde we now euer-ilkon " ffort acombre þylke for to slo &yogh;on ilk. Petron; " Quik or ded, vs bos bus. hym haue, " &yogh;yf [we] þis If we to. day our folk schul saue; " & elles schul we nere gon heþen, " Þat we ne schul myl sall mykell. be byneþen. " Þer-for, lordynges, alle to-gyder " ffolewes whar y turne, or whider, " & helpeþ wel when &yogh;e se nede: . " &yogh;yf we gete hym, ful wel we spede." Alle þey seide, "what so bitydes, " We schul þe folewe wher sall ride þat way. þou rydes; " Go we þanne, þat God vs a-vaille, P. leaves out this line. . " So þat we of hym ne faille." P. leaves out this line. Beofs Beus. aspied & saw hym full. sone: " I se Petron! make &yogh;ow al bone!" Beofs Beus. smot þe hors wyþ þe spores, & þey after, ouer feld & fores; fors (? not A.-Sax. for , way; but fur, furh , E.-Engl. fore , furrow: Stratmann's Diet., p. 228). Wilde he nere stynte ne ses Vntil he cam in to alle þe pres Þer Petron was, & til hym rod, . Hors til hors þat þey bistrod; Til hym ful faste Beofs Beus till him fast was. allied, & on hys felawes wel hym affied. ¶ Beof Beus. by þe nekke Petron hent, & doun til erthe boþe þey went; Beof Beus. fel doun al by hys wylle, & held Petron al ston[e] stone. stille; Beof Beus. dide þere a ful gret wyle, . & putte hym self in gret perile. Beofs held sore, & Petron drow; P. leaves out this line. Petron had go, nad Beofs be tow. wild go but Beus was touh. Þe Romayns Petron wilde rescouse, rescouh. 8 But Bretons a-geyn þem faste gan brouse, Wyþ scharpe speres to-gidere sett, 8 8-8 þe bretons ageyn þam fast sette. & al to-frusched þat þey wiþ with scharp lances togider mette. mett: The Petyt MS. leaves out the lines from here to l. 13,058; and then puts lines 13,061-62, before lines 13,059-60. When speres myghte namore serue, Þer swerdes drowe, ful faste to kerue; Wyþ hardy herte ilk oþer on hew, In armes hente, of sadeles þrew, Helmes bowed, & þorow were steke, Scheldes clef, & swerdes breke, Hauberks ryuen & al fur-mailled, Stedes slayn, stumbled & failled, Men were slayn, & feld to grounde, . & manye cast þat hadde no wounde; So þykke þey were to-gydere in þrong, Ilk oþer wroþ, ilk oþer swong, & ilk oþer of sadeles wrast, . & vnder ho[r]se fet wer cast; Non knew oþer, þey were so ney, But by þer speche or by þer cry: Bretons cried " P. inserts þe here. kyng Arthour," & Romayns, "Lucius P. inserts þe here. Emperour." Þe Bretons faste on þem abated, & þe Romayns ful sore þem hated; Þer couþe non knowe Non kouth knaw. for certeyn . Whilk was Breton, whilk was Romeyn, But by þer speche þat þey spak, Or any out of þe pres ought ony out of þe pres. brak. ffayn wolde Wawayn Petron haue, . & Beofs Beus. wold þey al-gate saue; He brak in to þe tuo þer. mykel pres, To smyte sore wold he nought ses; On alle sides he smot aboute, P. leaves out this line. & made þeym rounn for roume; or roum , room, space. þorow-out þe route; P. leaves out this line. Was þer non stod in his weye, P. leaves out this line. Þat his dynt ne dide hym deye. P. leaves out this line. Sire Ider on þat oþer on þe toþer side. syde, ffor Geryn durste no Romayn byde; & Gerin durst non abide. Ilk on for oþer bolded here hert, & smyten strokes so grete & & þer strokes were so. smert Þat no Romayn durst bide þer dynt, . But fer on bak dide þem stynt; Þen was Petron alle a-glyft. Þe Bretons vp sire Beofs vp Beus. lyft, & horsed hym ful wel a-geyn, & toke Petron, þe maister Romayn; Þorow al þe pres þey hym led, P. transposes this with the following line. & wiþ hym vntil wode þey fled, P. transposes this with the preceding line. & dide hym þer he mighte be syker, & eft al newe bygonne to new bigan þe. byker. But þen had þey no gouernour Þat couþe meyntene þem in stour, Vassalacio Brytonum. Namore þan schip or barge þe schip. can, Þere hym wanteþ a steres þore it failes steris. man. ¶ Þenne broched þe Bretons among þem alle, Man & hors many hors. þey dide doun falle; Þat were fallen, þey ouer schok; & þo þat fledde, þe fleand. þey ouer-tok; Somme þey slowe, & somme þey held, & somme þey spoyled spoiled. y þe feld; Al were slayn þe moste frape, maste frap. . ffayn wer þey þat myghte a-scape. fo þei were þat myght it scap. Þen turnde a-geyn alle þe Bretons, & come to wode to þer prisons, & led laid. þem alle wiþ sire Petron, & presented Arthur wiþ ilkon. Þen þanked he his messegers, & alle þe oþere þat were þer pers, & seide hem, "&yogh;yf hit may be wonne, if it be wonnen. " Þe game þat we haue by-gonne, þe werre þat was begonnen. " He wolde suld. amende þer rente & fe, " &yogh;yf þat tyme myghte bitide or mot tide. be."
text.228: ¶ De Romanis incarceratis. Þe kyng dide his prisons loke Wiþ wardeyns þat hem vndertoke. Þen seide men of conseil wys, ' Best was to send hem to He suld þam send vnto. Parys 'Wiþ men of armes þat scholde armes suld. þem lede; ' To hold hem in court hit were drede.' Þen was ordeyned wyþ hem schold go— ffor rescours waityng (watching). & for takyng fro— Cador, Borel, & Erl Richer, & sire Beduer his boteler: Noble of blod were alle þyse, & in þe mornynge schuld þey ryse, To conueye hem & conueie. þe passages alle, þer most deseite & drede myght falle. & when þey were passed ylkone, Let oþer mener wiþ hem forþ gone. þe mene folk suld þan all one.
text.229: ¶ Nunciatum est hic Inperatory hoc Infortunium. Þe Emperours hadde ful gode Emperour had his. spies . Þat hadde knowynge on had knowyng of. boþe parties: Þey come & teld hym oþe eue byforn him beforn. ' Þat þe prisons erlik arly. at morn ' Vntil Paris schuld ben led; . 'To holde þem þare þey are a-dred.' Þen bad þemperour take ten þousand, To go þat nyght fer byfore hand, Rescours of þeym &yogh;yf þey might make, & þe prisons fro þem take. Þyse were þo þe Emperour sent, Þat on þe nyght byfore went: Sertorius, of Lybye kyng & sire, Sire Ewander þe kyng of Syrie, Cire. Carice, Caritius, Wace , ii. 181, l. 12,516. Catel, & sire Wylters, Þyse were of Rome, kynges pers, Þise were chosen by somouns To make rescours of þe prisouns; & þey toke þe wey at euen late, & passed bifore our men þe gate; & when þey in þat weye cam Þat right forth to Parys nam, In þat weye gan þey reste, & priuely enbusched þer þey sey beste. bussed þer þei sauh best.
text.230: ¶ Exe pungna inter Brytones & Romanos qui de nocte eos precesserunt. Als þey were busched bussed. redy to byker, Come Arthures men, wend haue be haf bien. siker; Natheles, &yogh;it hadde þey doute, Þer-fore þey dide sondre þer route: Sire Borel & Erl Cadore, Wyþ þer folk riden byfore; Sire Beduer & þe Erl Richer, Þyse were þe prisons ner; Wyþ hem come men fif hundred, sis cent, Wace , ii. l. 12,542. Þat fro þe prisons were nought sundred. On Borel & Cador þat formest went, Þe Romayns a-side sideslepis. on hem glent, & ffelonly on þem gan strike, & þey defended hem doughtilyke. Sire Richer saw, & Beduer herde, Þat þer enemis þer weyes þat wikked men þe way. sperde, & wyþ þer felawes faste gon fight,— . Armed men wiþ swerdes bryght;— Þey dide þer he did. prisons þer wyþstande, Þe mene men toke þem on hande, In siker saufe. stede wiþ hem to byde Til more sykernesse myghte bityde. Wiþ haste spors. ilk man tok his stede To helpe þer felawes in þer nede; Þenne by-gonne Bretons to bolden, . & here partie wel vp holden. Þe Romayns ronne a-mong þe Bretons To seke after þer prisons; Þe Bretons to slo, tente tentid. þey nought, But hider & þyder here & þare. þe prisons sought; & while þey &yogh;ede aboute to seke, Þey ne spedde nought worþ a leke, ffor mykel of þer folk þey les Als þey soughten in þe pres. sought about with res. Þe Bretons hollyk to-gyder riden, At þeir assautes to-gydere byden, To-gyder wente, to-gydere camen, P. leaves out this line. . In alle stedes were þey samen; P. leaves out this line. ffor þey to-gydere so wel held, Þey slowe þe Romay[n]s doun in lay many romayn in þe. feld; In foures foure. routes þe Bretons hem set, . Þe sykerer sarer. wiþ þe Romayns þey met; Sire Cador wyþ þe Cornewaleys, his Cornwales. Sire Beduer wyþ his Herupeys, Dwellers in the south of the town of Paris, from the little river Bicvre: De Lincy, Wace , ii. 183. Sire Borel & sire Richer, Ilkon hadde þer bataille batailes. ser. Þe Romayns al aboute wond; wend. ffaste þey lore, & nought ne fond. les & nouht fand.
text.231: ¶ Roborati sunt Romany per consilium Ewanderi. Ewanden, Ewandere. þe kyng of Libye, Saw þe Romayns force doun flye; He relyed þen his folk a stounde, & sey þe prisons myght nought be founde; " To seke prisons ys tynt trauaille," He bad þem tente al to þe bataille; He sette þem alle in swylk certeyn, Þat þe bettere party þey wan a-geyn; Of þe Bretons þey felde ynowe, & foure of our beste men þey slowe,— Sire Iders Heere yder. sone þe Bretoun, & Irelgas of MS. &. P. Heriglas of. (See the name above, pp. 167, 173, ll. 4753, 4919, &c.) Hiresgas de Peritum, Wace , ii. 184, l. 12,590. Peryron, Sire Alydauk of Tyntagel, . Þat was lord of þat castel, And Mauryk/ Cador/ Caneys;— kador keneis. (Amauris li Orkanois, Wace , ii. 184, l. 12,594.) Souereyne knyghtes þey were, hit seys. oiþer bret or walsch whedir it sais. Þe Erl Borel, a gret lordyng, Hym smot Ewander þe kynge; In at þe mouþ Borel he bar, Þorow-out þe þrote o two he schar. ¶ When þey seye sauh how. sire Borel fel, ffor wo þe Bretons al to-swel Þat þey so þeir lord lordes. les Wyþ þe Romains of þe romeyns were. grete pres; Ageyn o Breton were MS. were were. ten Romayn; a breton seuen men told. Nere grace had ben, al had be slayn, if ne grace had bien all had bien sold. Al had ben ded & doun born, & þer prisons had ben lorn; But Vtred, a lord of Peyters, Guitar de Poitiers, Wace , ii. 185, l. 12,610. He was cheftayn of fforreyers, keper of foreris. (foriers, Wace , ii. 185, l. 12,611, forragers. He com dryuande þat ilke while, ffor hit was told hym of [þat] gyle, him all þat gile. Þat Romayns come rescours to make, Þe Bretons to slo, þe prisons to take. Wiþ hym come þre þousand knyghtes, & archers gode at alle rightes, & on þe Romayns smyten ful tit, smote full tide. Þat had our Bretons ner desconfit; Þeir scharpe speres & lances on. scheld forþ leyd, An hundred þei felde atte smote doun at þe. firste breyd, Þat neuere eft þey ne ros, . Of þe Bretons to wynne los.
text.232: ¶ Iam Romany tymorati sunt. Þenne were þe Romayn[s] al a-baischt, & al was schent þat or was trayst; Þey wende Arthur & al his ost Had folewed þem in þat cost; Þe Peyteuyns faste þeym assailled, & þe Bretons nought ne failled, Þe ton quiked þe toþer to lyue, Þe Romayns to greue, fast gon þey stryue, ll. 13,247-13,248. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Þe Romayns in haste turnde Romeyns gaf bak. & fledde, Þey hadde no clos, but oueral spredde; klos ouer all þei spred. To þer logges þer þey hem busched, bussed. Þey fledde, & þer wer al to-lusched. to lusshed. But Ewander þat slow Borel, & ffyue hundred sis cent et plus, Wace , ii. 186, l. 12,641. wyþ sire Catel, Were alle slayn & don in hold, Wyþouten lordes þat more were told. Þat þey wold haue, al þey hadden, Prysons y-nowe alle þey ladden; inow away laden. Þer þe bataille was, þey turnde ageyn, & tryde þe Bretons fro ilk & souht ilk breton fro. Romeyn. To seke Borel his men had hast, Þey fond hym sone, &yogh;eldyng &yogh;eldand. þe gast. Þe wounded men to saue þey sought, & þe slayn to erþe þey brought. Þe firste prisons þat Arthur sent, Þo þat were charged, to Parys went; Þe oþere prisons þat þey last hent, Of þeym til Arthur þey made present, & telde þem wel of him all. þeyr deseit, How þeir hap was ner ouer-streit, & how Vtred was þer socour, . & grately meyntende þem in & mayntend þam in þat. stour, & bed hem bad him. boldely to bataille wende; Of þemperour gat þey he. þe fairere ende. ¶ Þemperour herde herd how. þe Bretons sped . Þorow þe help of sire Vtred, & þat sire Ewander was slayn, & þe oþere y-do to payn; Grace til hym wold non bytide, But euere mys happed on mishapned. his syde; Þer-fore mykel he was dismayed, Þat werre was gonne, gunne (begun). he was nought payed; Al þe day he studied & þought P. leaves out this line. Wheþer he wylde werre forþ or nought; P. leaves out this line. To take þe bataille forþe to werre. mykel he dredde, ffor he no tyme byfore ne spedde; Of þys to conseille he nyste at wham, Or leue al til anoþer cam; &YOGH;yf he left til anoþer wore, Þen shulde hym schame þat he com þore; Þus he þoughte to do or lete, ffor drede of Arthur þat was so grete. But þis conseil had he of som, Þat he schulde remue til Oston, Oscom. (Ostom [Autun], Wace , ii. 188, l. 12,682.) & passe by Langres þe contre, . Þat nyght to reste in þat cite. At þe morn he gan to ride, & cam to Langres y þe euen tyde.
text.233: ¶ Inperator pre præ. timore fugiit: tunc dixit Arthurus. Arthur herde hit sone seye How to Oston þat till Ostum. he tok þe wey, & wolde nought to bataille stande Til hym com more help til hande; But þer-til Arthur nought ne radde, So longe abide til he folk hadde, But as priuely as men myght, He dide his ost remue þat nyght, & let lete. Langres on þe left, & þe wey til Ostum Hoscum. hym reft. By o weye bi a gate. þat he wiste gayn, He passed hilles, wode, & playn, Til þey com þer þe stret lay hey, In a valeye þat hatte Swesy; hate suesi. Þorow þat veleye alle camen, Þat fro Ostum Hoscum. to Langres namen. When þey were þere he bad þem rest, & syþen ilkon þer armure on kest, To be redy, what tyme þey mette, Swyþe on hem to-gydere sette. Þer harneys & þer frapaille Þat fel nought to be in bataille, Vnder an hil he set þem þere, As þey armed men alle were, Þat when þe Romayns on of. þem had sight, Þe mikelhed multitude, Wace , ii. 190, l. 12,717. schuld make þem aflight. ofright. A legion esciele, Wace , l. 12,719; but "légion" for legion , l. 13,338, below. þe kyng ches & tok, Þe Erl of Gloucestre had þo to lok,— A legion ys of folk þat wex, Sex þousand, sex hundred, sexti & sex,— & tauht hym on an hil to byde: " Meue nought, for ought þat may bytide, " Til þat y come, when y se nede; " Þorow þe, we þe way. (The text's þe =thee.) may stande & spede. " &YOGH;yf swylk auenture bytide or be, " Þat þe Romayns turn bak & ffle, " ffolewe þou affter, þenne, & slo; " In god tyme þider þou go." Sire Moronthe seide hit schold Mornith [or Morinth ] said it sall. be don. &yogh;it tok þe kyng a legion Of doughti knyghtes horsed wel,— . Þey bere þe name of þe beste eschel,— In more sight were þo set, Hym self was chef, & he þem get; Þey were þo þat þe rounde table preised, Þat he had norisched & vp reysed,— A-mong þo was þe his. dragoun Þat Arthur bar for gonfanoun;— Þat oþer was þe toþer wer. set at his pay On eyghte in auht. (7, Geoffrey; 8, Wace. ) batailles of gode array; Alle were þey knyghtes gode, & hardy men þat wel stode; He bisoughte þem at her might, When þe fotmen schulde fight, Þat horsmen come ouer-þwert, Wace makes half the "com|pagnes" foot, and half horse; and Arthur prays them— Que cil qui à ceval seroient, E cil à pie se combatroient, D'entravers les Romains féris|sent, Hardiement les envaissent. Wace , ii. 191, l. 12,744-51. Geoffrey is clearer, bk. x. ch. 5. & trauersed þe Romayns smert. In ilka bataille was teld þus euene tald euen. — . Þus fond y write as y schal neuene— ffif þousand, fif six, says Wace; five, Geoffrey. hundred, fifti & fyue, Of þe noblest knyghtes o lyue, Wel armed at her wille, & hadde no doute of non ylle. Þus were þey sett, right as y finde, ffoure byfore, & foure byhynde; Bytwixt þise foure was folk þe moste, . Alle þe comune of þer hoste, On hors, on fote, arrayed ful wel, P. leaves out this line. Þat were nought set in non eschel. P. leaves out this line. Þe fotmen also ful doughti ware, P. leaves out this line. . In ilka bataille for to fare. P. leaves out this line. In ilka bataille of lordynges, Two cheftayns chosen, erles & or. kynges: ¶ Sire Agusel hadde þe first bataille, Wiþ sire Cador of Cornewaille; ¶ Beofs Beus. of Oxenforde hadde þe secounde, Erl Geryn of Chartres halp hym þat stounde; ¶ A-child Achill. (Echille, Wace , ii. 192, l. 12,768.) of Denmark þe þrydde conreye, correie. Wyþ sire Loth, kyng of Norweye; ¶ Þe ferthe had Ohel of Bretaygne, & wyþ hym was þe gode Wawayne. Wawayn chefetayn. After þo foure, oþer foure ware Renged & set to bataille &yogh;are; ¶ Of þat on, was Kay Iustiser, & wiþ hym was sire Beduer; P. adds,— Beduer had his herupeis. kay angeuins & chinnoneis. ¶ Þat oþer eschele had sire Holdyn, & sire Gwitard Witard. þe Peyteuin; ¶ Þe seuenþe thrid. had Iugens of Leycestre, Wyþ sire Ianatas Ionathas. of Dorcestre. ¶ Þe Erl of Chestre, sire Cursalen, Sursalem. & of Bathe þe erle Vrgen. Baruk of Circestre, of Baþe Vrgen, Þe eyghteþe bataille to þem was þe auhtend was to þam. allied, fful mykel on þem Arthur Arthure on þam wele. affied; Þe seriauntz sargeancie. & þe archers, & oþere noble arbalasters, alblastrers. Þo were set wyþoute þe pres To kepe þe Romayns at trauers; But bifore Arthur schuld þeos alle wende, & Arthur was þen y þe last ende.
text.234: ¶ Comendacio cum pulcris verbis per Arthurum. When Arthur had set ilka bataille, & taught hem when how. þey scholde assaille, Lystneþ listens. þe grete curtesy He spak til his barons alle on hy, & þe grete mykell. preysynge he made, His men to bolde, þeir hertes to glade: " Lordynges," Barons. he seyde, "ioye me ledes " When y þenke on &yogh;oure doughti gode. dedes, " Of &yogh;oure þewes, of &yogh;oure conquest, " & euere fynd y &yogh;ow hardy & prest; " &yogh;our prowesse & nobleye, hit wexeþ ay, " Maugre þo þat wolde sey nay! " When y byþenke on &yogh;oure godnesse, thynk on &yogh;our gode dedis. " Þat Bretaygne, &yogh;our lond, in oure tyme ys our lond in &yogh;our tyme es. " Hed of þritty kynedames, " & lorde ouere þem, as men hit & lady so men hir. names, " ffor þat ioye myn herte ys tykel; " In God & &yogh;ow y affie me mykel, " Þat &yogh;ut schul we oure land auaunce " Þorow Gode godes. grace & &yogh;our god chaunce. " Of dedes of armes &yogh;e haue þe pris, " & haue ouercomen þe Romayns twys! " Myn herte me gyueþ, þat grace hit schapes, . " & tyme neigheþ, & þer-to rapes, " Þat we schul þis day, in þis were, " ffro þe Romayns þe maistri bere. " Norwey, Denmark, we haue ouer-ronne, " ffraunce & fflaundres þorow & france þorgh. bataille &yogh;e wonne, " Wel schuld we wynne þe lasse worthi, " Syn &yogh;e of þe beste hadde whan of þe best we haf. maistri. " To seruage þey wene vs to drawe, " & gyue hem trewage þorow awe, " & ffraunce to reue vs, rote & rynde! " Swilk folk wene þey here to fynde " Als þey out of þe Est brynge:— " Wommen con bettere of fightynge!— " On Crist we schul hope & affye " A-geyn þe houndes of Paynye! payenie. " ffor houndes, schul &yogh;e neuere fle, " & Romayns ar nought worþ a be! ere not als we. " Wel wot y, & &yogh;e schul wyte, " Þat y schal se ho wel schal smyte, " ffor y schal be at ilka dede, " & y schal helpe at alle nede."
text.235: ¶ Responcio gentis Arthury. Þys þat he seide was wel herd, & alle at ones þey hym answerd, " Maistrie ne pes wolde he non &yogh;elde; . " Bataille was set, bataille þey wylde. " Þey wylde deye þer in þe feld, " But &yogh;yf þe maystrie wyþ hem held." MS. hem. P. leaves out lines 13,445-46. Þey swore al þat myghte be sworn, ' What chaunce so was leid hem byforn, ' Þat ilke chaunce þey scholde haue alle, ' God or wykke, wheþer God let falle.'
text.236: ¶ Dicta Lucii Inperatoris. Lucius Yber was born in Spayne, . Of Rome emperour & cheuentaigne. &yogh;ong man ynow was sire Lucy, More þan þritti, but nought fourty; Don he hadde in þat age Many a doughti vasselage; ffor he was strong, lastynge to stand. in stour, Þer-fore was he mad Emperour. O þe morn erlyk, on a þrom arly on a thrum (mass). Þey meoued fro Langres toward Ostum Wyþ mikel folk & gret[e] route Þat spredde in lengþe & brede aboute. Þen herde þemperour by spies seye Þat Arthur had trauersed his weye; He perceiued þen his bold-hede, & sey þat he hadde of hym no drede, Þat eyþer bihoued ouþer burd. hym to bataille stande, Or turne a-geyn, & be fleande: To turne a-geyn were cowardise, & þat were schame til hym & hyse. Kynge, prynces, & dukes, alle þo P. leaves out this line. Þat were wyþ hym, two hundred cent mil, Wace , ii. 196, l. 12,875. & mo, P. leaves out this line. To conseille alle he calde þem for consell he cald his men. to, To wite at hem what he schuld do: " Lordes, peres, men of honurs, " Doughti lordes, bodies. gode conquerrours, " &yogh;e are comen of þo auncessours " Þat ful wel stode in alle stours; " Þorow þem ys Rome, wel haue &yogh;e herd, " Halden hed of al þe werd, " & so schal be, y gyue so sall .I. gyf. &yogh;ow a gyue, " Al so longe as y may lyue. " Þey wonne þe londes þat we now heyre; " Schame hit were we scholde now peyre. " Gentil þey were, oure kynde hit mones, " Of doughti fadres, of doughti sones; " Þer-fore doþ dos. now þat in &yogh;ow es, " Likneþ &yogh;our fadres in liken þour fadres. doughtines! " Better hit bot it. were in bataille pyne, " Þan faderes heritage to tyne; " & þat schul we on none wyse, " Heritage lese for feintyse! " Þyse wordes for yuel seide y nought now, " ffor y fond neuere feintise in &yogh;ow; ll. 13,491-13,494. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " &yogh;our fadres were gode, so ar &yogh;e, " Or bettere þan þey, hit may so be. " &yogh;e wyte & se, as se & wate als. wel as y, " Þat by þat weye we schul go by " Vntil Ostum, hit ys wyþ-set; " But wiþ bataille or baret— " I ne wot wheþer þey be robbours " Or þeues þat wolde haue ought of ours;— " Þat weye þey haue vs wyþ-sted " Þat y scholde &yogh;ow haue inne y-led; ll. 13,501-13,504. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. " Y trowe þey wende þat y had scurned, " ffor þat y now ageyn ward turned. " Nay for soþe, þat þought y nought! " Y wolde þey hadde on vs more sought; " Ouer fer byfore vs þey han hopped, P. leaves out this line. " & oure right passage haue þey stopped; P. leaves out this line. " But þer forgate schal þem nought vaille; " Arme vs, & gyue we þem bataille, " To do þem bak be dryuen & & do þam bakward to be. born, " Þat passed vs so fer byforn! " &yogh;yf þey stande, we schul þem smite; " &yogh;yf þat þey fle, þen schul þey wyte " Þer pryde þat hem so haþ schent, " Þat þey þe weyes our way. byfore vs wente."
text.237: ¶ Hic habetur magnum bellum inter Inperatorem & Arthurum in valle Swesy, inter Ostum & Langres. When Lucius had þus gat seid, fforþ þey ferde alle at o all þei stirt forþe at a. breyd, & armed þem ilkon right wel, & sette ilk man til his eschel: Kynge & prynces kynges & dukes of Payen Were medled among Cristen, Þat her landes of Rome held, & to in. þer werre seruise of scheld. By milers & by centeners be Centiners & Millers. Sette þey þe bataille þer batailes. seers; Horsmen, fotfolk, Hors folk fote men. on ilka partie, Were somme set lowe, & somme heye, Right after þat þeym god þought. Þat were of prowesse, & of pruesse in. bataille dought, When þey were dight & set In twolue batailles, þo þat hym get, Doun wyþ þe hil þey toke com. þe weye Al sarrely in to þe sarrely vnto. valeye; & þat o syde toke all þe to side to. þe Romayns, & Arthur þat oþer euen þer-gayns. þe toþer euen ageyns. Þe Romayns comen fro-ward þe west, P. leaves out this line. . & Arthures folk were al prest; P. leaves out this line. On boþe sydes þey gonne to blowe Trumpes & pipes a wel god þrowe; & trumped als a full gode þrewe. Þe batailles neyghed ney & ney, blowand neghed nehi & nehi. Sadly passing, passand. and softely. When þey seye þat þey might nehi mot. mete, Wyþ bowes & arblastes alblastes. gan þey schete, Dartes, launces, launced. stones, kaste, . On boþe parties þykke & faste; Vneþes myght any open his eye, So þykke atones gon þey fleye,— Also þikke as snow þen þat. snew, Or al so hail þat stormes blew,— Þorow scheldes smiten, & þorow paunces. P. transposes these lines. After þat schot, þey schote after schotyng þei striken. launces; P. transposes these lines. ffer weys mighte men here þe brusche, frusse. . A þousand breken at o frusche. braken at þe brusse. After launces, wyþ swerdes smiten, & wyþ axes & daggares þat wel And oþer wapens þat. biten; Þer was bataille merueillous, Neuer non byfore so perilous, Ne non so asper ne so þyk, P. transposes these lines. ffor ilk was oþer euen MS. euem. quik. P. transposes these lines. Þat wel couþe feighte, he fond his mecche, P. transposes these lines. Cowardie halp þer no wrecche. P. transposes these lines. Al þe valeye aboute schok, P. transposes these lines, puts them after the next couple, and then adds— som þat were striken turned. & defended strokes skurned. So harde þe parties to-gidere tok; P. transposes these lines, puts them after the next couple, and then adds— som þat were striken turned. & defended strokes skurned. ffull harde to-gydere gan þey hurte, Þat on a-geyn þat oþer burte. Manye doun fulle, & fele þer fele doun fell & many. stod, & mani on lay drenkled in blod; Many knyght of sadel was wrast, kast. . & many stede wyþ hem were cast, was wrast. & many oþer wente o stray, Þe bridles bidell. broken, & sadeles a-way. Wel þey foughte a ful long stounde, Inouh of fight ilk oþer founde. Ilk fonded oþer to haue to grounde. So vaillaunt was neuere so siker to wynne was. no Romayn Þat myghte þe Bretons ruyse ones bring þe bretons abak. ageyn, Ne þe Bretons of þem nought wan, So wel þey stoden ilka man; Neþeles, foure batailles of oures Had hard encountre & scharpe were ay fightand in þo. stoures,— Agusel Anguisell. & sire Cador, . Beofs & Geryn, þyse were þor, Beus & Gerin þise &yogh;ede before. Achil, Loth, & sire Ohel, & sire Wawayn þat dide so wel,— Þyse foure wyþ were. In comun , the Lambeth MS. n has one stroke too many. þe comun host, . Alle had þey ful hand al-most. Noman mighte þer wel was þer non kouth lightly. chese Whilk of þem schold wynne or who suld wynne ne who suld. lese, Til þat o bataille forþ to þat eschel to bataile. spred, Þat sire Kay & Beduer led. Þey saw þe Bretons nought ne wan, Þe Romayns helde as þey bigan; To þem þey seyde þey wilde suld. al-gate. On al þe pres þey gonne hem abate; In to al þe þrong þer was þykkest, P. leaves out this line. Kay & Beduer in gonne brest. P. leaves out this line. fful wel faught Beduer, & so dide Kay; . Þo þat þey hitte, ded þey lay:— Þus seyde þo þat stode þem ner, Þat neuere styward ne botyler Þat serued kyng ne kayser, So wel halp at here power;— fful mikel þey dide, & more þey scholde &yogh;yf þey had lyued, & Crist hit wolde. Byfore þey breke þe Romayns route, P. leaves out this line. Þer folk folewode, & hadde no doute; P. leaves out this line. Many a strok þey gaue & tok, P. leaves out this line. Out of þer sadeles mani on schok. P. leaves out this line. Sire Beduer among hem presed, Romayns to slo nought sle he. ne sesed; O þat oþer side Kay ne blan, ffor he feld doun hors & man. &yogh;yf þey hem self couþe haue meþed, þamseluen kouth haf mythed. . & als þer strokes couþe haue leþed, kouth haf lithed. And þer folk wolde haue byden, And alle to-gidere þat þey had þat þei had togider. ryden, Til þat oþer bataille had comen, . & þenne alle at ones nomen, Gret prowesse of þem had ben told, & saued þer bodies, þat sone were cold. þer lyues lightly was sold. Alas! &yogh;yf þat God had wyld! wilt . . . . . spilt. Þer hardinesse þem seluen spild! wilt . . . . . spilt. Þey þoughte to perce þe host þorow-out, ffor þey hadde hertes ful fers & wist þam self strong. & stout, & on hem self ouer mykel affyed, Þer men to hem were so þam wele. allyed Þat þey ne roughte rouh. where þey &yogh;ede, Ne nought rewarded how no tentid not. þey were in drede: ¶ A bataille þey mette, & smot þer-in, Nought of þe Romayns, but of Sarazyn,— Of Mede he was, Bokkus he hight, Kyng he was, & ful god knyght.— A ful gret host þys Bokkes ledde, Our Erles were hardy, & nought ne dredde, Right on þem alle fulbut þey vnto þam alle smertly. riden; Þer was a bataille ful sore smyten Bytwixt þe houndes Sarazyns, & Herupeys & Angeuyns. Bokkes rod in wyþ a gleyue, ffayn wold he Beduer deseyue; In att þe brest Beduer he smot; Þe glayue was scharp, & ouer fer bot; Scheld & hauberk þorow he brak, Þe spere fley out al þe dynt com out. at his bak. Þen fel Beduer; myght non hym saue; But Ihesu Crist his soule ay haue! Kay fond Beduer þer he lay, ffayn wold he haue þe body a-way, Of alle men he louede hym most; & þenne gan faste relie his host, & gaf eft bataille to þem of Mede; Wyþ force he dide hem flitte þat stede. Als he schuld þer þe body vp fange, He dwelled þer-on He was duelled. a litel to lange, ffor þenne com Sentor, com sir Sertor. kyng of Lubye, Wiþ gret power of paynye, & on sire Kay smot he þore, full sore. & wounded hym ferly sore; ille þore. But for no wo, wounde, ne dynt, Þe body ne lefte he, ne tynt. His gode folk was hym aboute, & holpe hym of þat mykel doute; Þē ? for þen , the accusative of þe. If so, it's the only instance in the book as yet. bodi þen to þe dragon brought, Maugre þo þat on hym sought.
text.238: ¶ De probitate Irelgas, congnato (cognati). P. nepotis. Beduery. Sire Beduer cosyn niès, Wace , ii. 204, l. 13,061. hight Irelgas: Yreglas. . When he wyste þat harde cas, What of his frendes, & of his kynde, & oþer þe beste þat he myght fynde, Þre hundred men wiþ helmes bright, & wel horsed, & al wel dight, When he had samned þem ilkone, " Lordynge, to &yogh;ow now make y my mone! " At þis nedes helpeþ nede helpes. now, " Of þo houndes þat myn em of þo þat myn eam. slow! " Of Bokkus, þe kyng of Mede, " Aspieþ hym wel in ilka spies him in alle. stede!" Þey serched ouer al vp & doun Til þei seye his gonfanoun; When þey hit seye, þer þei it sauh. þider gon þey drawe, On Kaliborne þey cried a þrawe. Irelgas, noman wyþ-stod; His em to venge he was ful wod; He dredde non of alle þe renge, But þat he myght þer his em venge; fful wel hym halp þen his felawes alle, Wyþ speres dide þey many on falle, & on þem ride, þat doun were cast, & Bokkus bataille trauailled fast. Bockus trauersid at þe. When þey til his bataille were comen, . So wel þey dide, þat þorow þem nomen; But Irelgas was euere byfore, After hym his folk held wel þe score; Syde & oþer, þey lefte no þyng Vntil þey fond Bokkus þe kynge. When Irelgas was wel auised, His hors on hym his þe. bridel wysed, He teysed his dint, Bokkes to smyte, Þe swerd was god, & wel wold byte, Þe helm[it] clef, þe hauberk tar, taar. Þorow-out þe breste þe swerd hym schar, in schaar. I trowe þe soule to helle went, But Irelgas by þe arm hym hent, Þat þe body fel nought doun; He leide hum & laid. ouer-þwert hys arsoun; Þe knyght was god, þe hors was stronge, He turnde þer-wiþ out of þe þronge; Þe body to þer dragon bar,— Wel holp his men þat his men wele halp. aboute hym war,— Bysyde his em þe body þrew, & on peces hym al to-hew; all till hewe. Al to-hewen þer he hym let; þei him lete. The eating by dogs and birds is Langtoft's, i. 209. Houndes, foules, his body ete. When Irelgas had don þat pris, " ffelawes," he seyde, "graunt mercis! " Turne we &yogh;ut now. on þem a-geyns, " & folewe faste o þe Romeyns, " & on þise houndes þat mys byleue, on þam þat nouht ne leue. " Þat oure Cristene so mykel greue!" Þey turnde ageyn as men hardy; P. leaves out this line. Þen myghte men here noise & cry; P. leaves out this line. Swerdes, helmes, men mighte se glyder, P. leaves out this line. & sparklyng as þey smyte to-gyder. P. leaves out this line. Holdyn, þe Erl of fflaundres, held Gaunt & Bruges Briges & Blemes. vnder his scheld; Of a bataille he was cheftayne, P. transposes these lines. He countred wyþ Alyfatyn of Spayne. P. transposes these lines. So longe þat on þat oþer assailled, & ilk on oþer so trauailled, Þat slayn was sire Alyfatyn, & slayn was þe Erl Holdyn. Lyger, þe kyng of Babilloyne, Rod to Iusted with. þe Erl of Boloyne: Ligiers, qui ert quens de Boloine Josta al roi de Babiloine. Wace , ii. 207, l. 13,149-50. Geoffrey, x. 10, has Micipsa of Babylon killed on the Roman side, and Lodegarius of Bolonia on the British. Slayn was þe erl, slayn was þe kyng, & oþer þre mad þeir endynge, Baruk, Vrgens, & sire Cursal; Wiþ ilk was gret folk wyþ-al. Sire Vrgens of Baþe was sire, & Baruk of Circestre & Wilteschire, Baluk erle of Wilcheshire. (Bal|luc quens de Guitesire, Wace , ii. 208, l. 13,158.) & Cursal, Erl of Chestre was; Þise were slayn þer at þat pas. Þer men gaf bak, & turnde agayn, & com til Ohel & til Wawayn:— Swilk two knyghte, ful wel þou knyghtes wele to. leue, Wer non syn Adam was, & Eue;— Þer men & þey were gode ilkon, In pres, pres. (presse ne torbe, Wace , ii. 208, l. 13,177.) in pleyn, þey douted non. Þo þat first on Bretons brak, Þeir cheftayns slowe, dide þem gyue bak; Alle þo þey slowe, & dide þem fle, & turnde þem ouer, þat men myght se. ouer Iambe leue. So harde strokes þe Bretons gaf, Þe Romayns route al ouer-haf, Þat þe Romains, wold ho, wild þei. ne wolde, fflede vnto þe Egle of golde. (Egle ys ern Herne. on Englische roun; Þat was þe Romayns gunphanoun.) Gomfaynoun. Þere þey fond þe Emperour, & of al Rome þer was þe flour. When þey seye þey come so ner, Þe Romains were þem ful auster; Nere herd þey seye, ne sawe hit writen, P. leaves out this line. Swilk a stour to Romayns smyten, P. leaves out this line. A doughty erl þat highte Kynmar, Wiþ sire Ohel þat tyme was þar; Don he hadde gret vasselage, Þe Romayns slayn at ilka stage; Mighte no Romayn hym a-scape, P. leaves out this line. Þat to þe deþ he dide hym rape. P. leaves out this line. A fotman þenne his bowe vp drow, It sais a fote man a disceit drouh. & Erl Kynmar atte lasste algate. he slow, & two þousand of þe Bretouns, Wiþoute men of grete renouns. noble men of ronons.
text.239: ¶ De tribus sociis nobilibus. Þre noble knyghtes gode men. þer were, & wyghte; Iugens, Iaguz. hit seyþ, þat on so hyghte,— Out of Bolayn, Boloyn. (Boloan, Wace , ii. 209, l. 13,202.) þeþen was he, A borough y wene, MS. were. or a cite;— a toun .I. wene or a cuntre. Þat oþer highte Rykomarkus, Þe þrydde men calde Boklonius; Þer wer non þre in al þe not þre in all þat. stour Þat wroughte after so gret honur; &yogh;if þey had ben dukes or kynges, Of þem had ben grete preysynges; Þer was no Romayn bitwyxt hem cam, P. leaves out this line. Þat awey wyþ lyf fro þem nam; P. leaves out this line. Were he neuere so doughty, P. leaves out this line. . On lyue passed non forby; P. leaves out this line. Right to þe Emperours owen bataille Þey ne lefte Romayns to assaille. Þat seye Romayns, þey dide gret wow, Þey closed hem, & alle þre slow. When Wawayn wiste, & sire Ohel, Þat her gode folk doun so fel, Was neuere lubard ne lyoun, libard no leon. . Ne wilde wolf ne dragoun, Þat was so wod, beste to byte, As Wawayn was Romayns to smyte. Sire Ohel als on his partye, Many on dide he ded doun lye. Þe Romayns wel þem defended, Grete strokes on þe Bretons spended; P. adds,— wele were þei smyten & wele smote. bretons þe biten bretons þam bote. But Wawayn was euere fresche & prest, When oþer ne myghte, þan was he best; Was þer non helm wiþ stel so rank Þat his swerd þorow-out ne sank, Ne hauberk non, wyþ maille gret, P. leaves out this and the following line. . Þat his spere ne þorow schet; Þat tyme manion dide he deye, & þo þat myghte, made hym weye; Among þe moste euere he presed, His harde strokes nought ne sesed; Right to þe Emperour Lucius, Of Romayns he made rescous. Lucius was &yogh;ong, ynow had elde, Hardy & stalworthe, armes to welde; Bytwyxte þrytti & þritty & more lesse þan. fourty Was þe elde of sire Lucy.
text.240: ¶ De Insulto Walwyny ad Inperatorem. Lucius knew wel sire Wawayn, & he hym ful wel ageyn; Ilk on oþer auisement sett, But þemþerour ful wel he MS. he. P. & þe Emperour wele he. let; He hoped wyþ Wawayn for to fight, ffor he was man preised of myght, & &yogh;if he myghte ascape of chaunce, Þer-of at Rome wold he wild him. auaunce. Right anon no after þe sight ne. þrowe abyden, But swyþe smertly to-gydere riden; Þeir schaftes schiuered, & fleye in feld, But þey fel nought, ne donward held; Gode were þer brunyes, & stronge of maille, P. leaves out this and the following line. . Þer-fore þer dyntes myghte nought vaille; Wiþ swerd to smite þen þey hem hasted, On many manere ilk oþer tasted Ilk oþer to slo, ilk oþer to wounde, P. puts this line after l. 13,837. How eyþer myght oþer on what he mot. brynge to grounde: Þei proued byneþen and a-bouen, Wyþ swerdes poyntes sadly þei suerd poyntes sidelynges. schouen; fful wel þei couþe ilk oþer assaye, P. leaves out this line. . & þer as was peril ilk oþer affraye; P. leaves out this line. fful sone schuld eyþer to deþ haue gon, P. leaves out this line. &yogh;yf þey nadde be let of non. P. leaves out this line. Þe Romayns perceyued þer bataille hard, & relyed þem to þe þei alied þam at þer. standard, & come to socoure þemperour Þat was in a perilous stour; fful litel failled he MS. þey. nadde ben he ne had bien. lorn. Þen were þe Bretons bakward born, Bretons wyþ-drowe, & Romayns wonne, fer þei fled on þam was wonnen. & many on ouer riden & ronne. Þer was Wawayn in gret doute, . Þe pris of Rome was hym aboute; Ohel & he a-scaped þorow, þam þorgh. & wente & teld hit til Arthorow com & teld till Arthorgh. Þat þey had ben at þat standard, . & ner al slayn, & dryue bakward.
text.241: ¶ Confortacio Arthury. When Arthur sey his men gaf bak, Þe Romayns boldely on þem brak, & poyned or pryked þem poined þam ouerpriked. wyþ pres, & þey wyþ-drowen hem, & erþe þey þei fled bak & þe feld. les, Þen wolde Arthur no lenger byde, Ne myghte, &yogh;yf he wolde saue his syde; He cam criynge criand. wiþ his bataille, " Agayn, &yogh;e Bretons, þe Romayns asaille! bretons ageyn romeyns assaile. In Lamb. MS. a later hand has put t before assaille. " Y am Arthur, þat wil nought sall not. faille! " At al &yogh;oure nede y schal &yogh;ow vaille! " Y am Arthur þat hider &yogh;ow ledde, " Þat neuere in feld for no man fledde, " Ne deþ, ne dynt, ne bataille dredde! " In alle stours wel haue y spedde! " Y am Arthur, schal make &yogh;ow weye, " & Romayns to Rome for drede do romeyns to ryme romeyns to. fleye! " Loke þat non of &yogh;ow recreye, " Ne at þys iourne feynte ne þat &yogh;our fight feynt. ne feye! " Þenkeþ now of þink now on. &yogh;our grete bountes, " How fele we haue wonne landes & fees! " To day ne schal y fro þys sall I of. feld fle " Til al be wonne or lorn þorow me!"
text.242: ¶ De crudelitate fortissimi belly inter Arthurum & Inperatorem. He smot his stede, & forþ to gon. go, Romayns to felle, Romayns to slo; Þo þat hit seye, myght hit wel seye, saugh it mot wele say. So mykel folk for hym gan deye, So many helmes for hym þorow dryuen, Scheldes clouen, hauberks ryuen, Þat Caliborne hadde þorow byten, Hedes, armes, legges, schankes armes. of smyten; I may nought seye al, ne how, At ilka dynt a man he slow. As þe lyon for hunger snacches & sleþ slos. þe best þat he first lacches, katches. So ferd Arthur wyþ ilkon, Many hors, men, a man ne hors. lyue left non; Wham-so he myghte reche or smyte, Þough þof. he hym wounded neuere so lyte, Leche craft couþe hym nought seye; saue. . ffor any medisine, nede most he deye: no medicyne þat he mot haue. 7 As þe wolf chaseþ þe schep, He dide þe Romayns by-fore hym lep; 7 7-7 all for drede befor him fleih. as schepe agayn þe woulf ne deih. This simile is in the MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé, of Wace, though not in De Lincy's 27, Wace , ii. 214, note ( a ). And als Arthur after þem schok, Sertor of Lubye he ouer-tok; His hed he smot of at o dynt, ffor non armure þe swerd ne stynt; Seide Arthur þen to þo þer ware, The four lines 13,903-6, are in the MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé, of Wace, though not in De Lincy's No. 27 Wace , ii. 214, note ( b ). " Schame þe tyme þou armes bare! " & þat þou come me so ney, " Caliborne to make blody!" Arthur ouer-gat in ouertoke. anoþer pres Þe kyng of Bythayne, bitinie. Pollydetes, Of a lond of Payenye: A wonder strok a selcouth. Arthur let flye! By þe schuldres þe hed of plat; Þe hed fel doun, þe body vp sat. Þorow Arthures wordes & dedes trayst, Þe Bretons MS. Romayns. P. bretons. bolded, & Romayns abaischt; Netheles þe Romayns wel abod, Ageyn þe Bretons stifly rod, & foughten laid at. as þey were wod, Wiþ gret strengþe a-geyn þem þei. stod. ffor Arthur saw þey wolde nought scurne, He gaf þem strokes wyþ Caliborne. Þemperour þenne taried soiorned. nought, On Arthures folk ful sore he sought, But þemperour ne Arthur þe kyng Mighte nought mete for no þynge; Mikel was þe pres, ful þykke þe þro, Þey myghte nought mete; Arthur was wo. ll. 13,925-13,926. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Wel faught þe Breton, & wel þe Romayn; A þousand wyþynne a þrowe were slayn; Might noman wyte ho schulde &yogh;ut wynne, Ne whiche of hem wer oute ne inne; ne whas was ouer no whilk was In. Þer was þe flour of boþe partis, . & neyþer side bar noiþer bare. &yogh;it þe pris. Moreont, Morinth. of Gloucetre cheftayn, Meoued aboue vpon aboun on. þe montayn; He sey þe bataille was ful long, . Ne non ne fledde out of þe þrong; He hadde a legion of folk þat wex Sex þousand, sex hundred, sexti & sex; And alle knyghtes wyþ helm on stede; . & þoughte þat Arthur hadde nede; He sey non þat hym ne sauh þat non. gaf þe feld, & til þe Bretons þer owen held; He þoughte þorow help of a lite . Þey scholde þe Romayns desconfite, & for to venge Arthures maynten Arthure. tene, Of þe Romayns þey schuld make clene. He com doun al pryuely, Þat non ne herde noyse ne cry; Byhynde þe bank he cam al hot, & on þe Emperours side he smot, & his þer. bataille perced þorow out. . Þen gon þey baysche þat er wer þan þei bessed þat are was. stout, Þe Romayns þenne no lenger langer. byden, Þe Bretons folewed, & þem ouer ryden, & al fleynge & fleand. lightly þem slow, & spoyled hem, & al to-drow; Syn had þey no grace to stande, Ne myghte relye, recouer. but euere fleande. Þer was þemperour slayn of chaunce Þorow-out þe body wiþ a launce;— Y can nought seye ho dide hym falle, But sire Wawayn, men seide hit said þei. (See Langtoft, i. 216.) alle; Y þe laste bataille þat in sprong, . He was slayn þer þam. among; Þe certeyn can þer noman ame, P. leaves out this line. But sire Wawayn bar þe name;— P. leaves out this line. Among þe dede þey hym founde, amang þe dede þei him fonde. & wiþ a spere was his wounde. lance was his wonde. Þe Romayns alle faste þey fledde, & þe Payens for drede spredde; Whilk of þem þat swyþest nam, Þe Bretons kept þem as þey cam; Þey were wery alle to slo, ffor wery, manion let Many of þam lete. P. trans|poses this line and the one above it. þey go; Þe blod ran þer doun. as water stremes . In chynes, in creuesses, kynnes in creuesse. & in semes; Gode stedes & palfrays &yogh;ede o stray, ilk his þer. ways. Arthur was glad þat þorow here dome Had so abated þe pride he had abatid þe pris. of Rome; ffor byforn, seyden so said. alle þe Romayns, Þat non myght standen þem ageyns; Þerfore þanked Arthur God Almyght, Þat gaf hym þe maistri of hem þorow fight.
text.243: ¶ Et sic finitur bellum incomparabile. Þenne dide he seke alle þe Bretons, Erles, knyghtes, & barouns, & dide þem carie bere. to þer contres, & byried þem at here cites, Til heremytages & til abbeyes, Þer men holy bodies leyes. bedis sais. He tok þe body of þe Emperour, & dide hit kepe at with. gret honur, & sent hit to Rome to do in graue; ' Oþer truwage schuld þey non haue: ' &yogh;yf þey any oþer lord fond ' To aske truwage of Arthurs lond, ' Eyþer of Bretaigne or of Fraunce, ' Hym schulde falle þe same chaunce; " & Arthur preyes &yogh;ow, for þe arrerage . " Þat &yogh;e receyue now þys truwage; " And &yogh;yf &yogh;e chalange hym any mare, " He schal &yogh;ow sende swiche sall &yogh;ow send suilk. as þyse are."
text.244: ¶ De sepultura Mangnatum Brytannie Mortuorum. Kay, þat was wounded byforn, Vntil þe castel bastell. was he born; he compassed or he &yogh;ede. boþe þe length & þe brede. He compassed hit in lengþe & brede Er he to þe bataille &yogh;ede, he compassed or he &yogh;ede. boþe þe length & þe brede. & gaf hit name, & cald hit Chymoun; Chinnun. . I ne wot why, ne what resoun. Sire Kay liuede nought but a stounde, He hadde so manye dedly wounde; Þey byried hym at an heremitage Bysyde Chymoun, Chinnun. at a passage. At Bayouse Bayon. in Normandie Þey seide sire Beduer schulde þere lye; Þey biried hym at a kyrke name-couþ, Wyþoute þe &yogh;ate toward þe souþ. To fflaundres þei bere þe erl Holdyn, In Tyrewane Terruane. (Chaverne, MS. du Roi, 27; Teruanes, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé: Wace , ii. 218, l. 13,414.) þei biried hym in; Sire Liger was boren to Boloigne. & Arthur lefte in Burgoyne, Al þe wynter he dwelled þer-inne, & tounes dide he manie bygynne; In somer he þoughte to Rome haue gon, . &YOGH;yf he ne hadde lettyng of non.
text.245: ¶ De Moddreto traditore. He was passed þe mountes pleyn, But Moddred dide hym turne ageyn. A day as he to þe mete went, . Out of þis lond lettres These 'lettres,' and the 'trompes' of the next line are from Langtoft, i. 216. were sent, & right as his trumpes blewe, A messager þat he wel knewe, Þe lettres in his hand he leyde, . & til his owen mouþ he till him with mouth. seyde, ' Þat Moddred, his sister sone, ' Had y-don hym gret tresone; ' He had taken of þe lond homage, ' & leyd in casteles gret don in kastellis gode. hostage; ' &yogh;it wil he nought be þer-by, ' But waiteþ þe bot waite him with. more vileny: " Þy wif til hys hore haþ gon. drawe, " Ageynes cristen mannes lawe; " & Cheldryk, kyng of Germye, Gernimie. (Saissone, Wace , ii. 221, l. 13,461.) Wace has this Cheldrik bit after Arthur's reaching Whitsand, l. 14,072, here.) " Ys comen, & brought gret partie; " By-&yogh;onde Humber, vntil Scotland, " Cheldrik haþ þat in his hand; " & al þat langes vntil Kent, " Vntil Cheldrik gyue þey &yogh;eldes. rent; " To holde wyþ Moddred wyþ at. his might, " Trouþe to-gydere haue þey plight. " Seuen hundred schipe lyn schippes ligge. by þe stronde, " ffour score þousand þer come er comen. to londe " Of men of armes, wyþoute pytaille, " Ageyn þou comest, to gyue þe &yogh;ow comes to gyf. bataille." ¶ When he had þus til Arthur teld, How Moddred no feyþ ne trouþe hym held, & synfullyke had reysed stryf, His lond hym refte, for-leyn his wyf, He made his plainte to sire Oel, & preide hym to kepe ilkadel Burgoyne & ffraunce boþe wel; Til hym he tryste as to þe stel: " Toward Bretaigne y wil me spede, " Þe outlandeys wiþ me lede, " On Moddred wil y bataille bede, " & take vengaunce of on. his misdede. " Lytel y preyse al my conquest " Þat y haue wonne in þys est, est or weste. " &yogh;yf y now leue Bretayigne, my fe, " Bretayne myn heritage þat fel to be. " I schal me hye a-geyn to come; " On alle manere y wil to Rome." He iorneyed þen fro land to land Til he come to Whitsand. He pleyned hym sore of Moddred, Þat fro his conquest had don hym conquest him. fled. ¶ Arthul Arthur. had purueid hym a flet, At Whitsand were þey in water set; Moddred herde wel þat tydyng, ' By Whitsand cam Arthur þe kyng.' Modred gadered his hostes to-gydere, Of hyse & oþer þat come þydere; Arthur he hoped he durste hoped wele to. abide, Wyþ-sette þe hauenes on ilka syde. Þe lond wolde nought Moddred lese, Ne repente, ne to þe pes chese; He wyste hym self so coupable, To aske þe pes hit was but fable.
text.246: ¶ De bello inter Arthurum & Modredum traditorem. Arthur dide his flete eft dight, To Romeneye þey redde þem right; But er þey were of schipes nomen, Er was Moddred a-geyn hym þidere. comen, & letted hym to haue entre, Þey mighte nought come vp fro mot nouht com out of. þe se. But Arthures men mighte wyþ trauaille; ffalse Moddred þey gonne gon þam. assaille; & he a-geyn was ful bold. gon þam. . ffor he hadde so siker hold, Arthures folk were more schent; ffor to þer schipes þey gaf þer tent To stere þem boþe fer & hende, . Þey tenden nought hem self to fende; & tent it nouht þemself defend. Þey mighte hem nought fro arewes couere While to whils. þey stode on bankes ouer; Þer-fore were manie at meschef, . & þer lost was þer tinsell. more gref. As þey to londe fro botes stirte, Many were slayn, & fele were hyrte, & mescheuously þen fel such cas at suilk a chance & suilk a caas. Þat sire Wawayn slayn þer sir wawayn þore ded. was, & sire Agusel Anguisell. of Scotland By hym lay ded on his hand; þe sand. — Þe soþe ne saw y write, ne how, . Wheþer þat bowe or swerd hem slow;— & manye oþere were slayn þore, Þat Arthur pleyned hem ful sore, him sare. But non by þe tenþe del tendele. . As Wawayn & Agusel: Anguisele. He had so mikel sorewe for þo P. leaves out this line. Þat he þoughte in non oþer wo; P. leaves out this line. Þeir sorewe myghte he neuere furgete; . Siþen eet he neuere gladly bliþely. mete. But whan his folk land had taken, A party gan his sorewe ouer schaken; Þen myghte Moddred haue no duree, . Ne no fot helden ne nouht stand. his meynee; Þaw þey were fele, þey were nought prest, P. leaves out this line. Þey had be norisched in pes & rest, P. leaves out this line. Þey couþe nought fighte, ne þei couþe not. to-gydere wone, Ne at in. tyme stande ne schone, Als Arthures folk in werre couþe, Þat had hit vsed fro tyme of þat it vsed in þer. &yogh;ouþe.
text.247: ¶ De occisione gentis Moddredy. Þat ilke day at Romeneye Arþur dide manion deye Of Moddredes folk here & þere, & mo schulde, &yogh;yf þe nyght ne were. Arthur sey þe day gan faille, He bod & stynte his folk to taille; He gaf al tente til his owen conrey. Þat while to whils. fledde Moddred a-wey; Al þat night Moddred fledde To seke recet, but yuele reste bot ill. he spedde; He wende Londone wolde hym receyue; Þey wold hym nought, but let hym weyue. Temese & Londone he passed al, At Wynchestre þer tok he stal, Þere he herbergwed al a nyght MS. myght. Ageyn þer wille, al þorow myght; Of þe burgeys he tok feaute & homage, al at. þeir maugre. De Sepultura Walwyny. ¶ Arthur wolde no soiour make, But Moddred wold he sle or take; But sorewe ful þough, did hym gret pyn, Of sire Gawayn Wawayn. his dere cosyn, & Agusel þe Scottische kyng: Arthur made here byrying was at þer birieng. At Wybyry, þat ys in Walys; . Þer lye þey boþe, seyþ Peres tales. See Pierre de Langtoft's Chro|nicle , Rolls Series, vol. i. p. 220, l. 16-17. Now comeþ al Arthures turnes Arthur. sorewe & drede. To venge hym on þe false Moddrede, Day ne night ne wolde he blynne. To sege Wynchestre, Moddred wyþynne, He dide þe contre somoune al out, & vmbyleide þe toun about. Þen sey Moddred he was in clos, & byseged bised. wiþ his fos; He þoughte þat &yogh;yf he so longe lay, Wel schulde he nought wynne a-way, Þat nedly taken schuld he be, . & maugre hym his. &yogh;elde þe cite. Among his men he made a cry, & bad hem alle arme hem redy; Wyþ hym to fighte leuere he wylde . Þan, his vnþankes, to þem þam him. &yogh;elde. His men in bataille gan þem his batails set how þai suld. renge, & wente right out hym MS. hyn. for to venge; Þe parties sone to-gydere ran, & lorn was þere þen many a man. Moddredes partie &yogh;ede al doun, ffor his folk had no fuisoun; Hit was no wonder he hadde no grace, P. leaves out this line. . ffor traitour scholde nought spede in place. P. leaves out this line. He sey his side no tyme ne spedde; ffor his misdede he had misdone. þe kyng he dredde; Hym self he þoughte algate þouh for. to saue, . Siþen he ne sen he. mighte no grace haue; His priues alle til hym he tok, Þo þat Arthur alle fursok, Þo þat Moddred hadde forþ brought, P. leaves out this line. Þat neuere louede Arthur nought; P. leaves out this line. Priuely wyþ hem he fledde a-wey, & lefte þer al his left in bataile þat. oþer conrey. To Souþhaumptone he tok þe sty, & huyred hym schipes al redy, & swyþe anon þey gonne forþ & son onward were to. saille; ffor drede he fledde til Cornewaille. Þo þat Moddred byhinde hym left, Alle were þey slayn, þer lyues & lyue. reft, & wan þe toun doun. of þem ilkon; But wo was hym Moddred was gon. Sire Vrienes sone, Iwene he hight, Gentil of blod, and ful god knyght; Agusel cosyn was sire Iweyn, Þe reme of Scotland he gan to cleym, In scotland he mad a cleyme. P. adds— for he was next of his kyn þerfor mad he cleym þerin. He left hit til He gaf. Iweyn in herytage, & Iweyn made Arthur homage. Iweyn had laught gret honour, Ageyn Moddred he stod in stour, & dide & seyde Moddred gret schonde, P. leaves out this line. . Þe while Arthur was out of londe. P. leaves out this line. At &yogh;ork to soiourne was þe quen, Scheo herde what wo hem was bytwen, Þat Moddred ne myghte in bataille dure, But euere was at desconfiture. Scheo þoughte scheo was þen mykel to blame ffor þe vylenye & þe schame þat Moddred hadde brought hure inne, & wyþ hym hadde y-leyn in synne, & wedded hure ageyn þe lawe,— He ne lefte for kyng kynd. ne Godes awe,— Scheo hopede þat hit scholde yuele hoped ill it suld bind. ende, . Hure noble lord so foule to schende, & hure self for euere y-schent. P. leaves out this line. So mykel sorewe in herte scheo hent, P. leaves out this line. Scheo fledde away out of þe toun To Walys, vntil Carlioun; Sch[eo] &yogh;ald hure til scho did hir in. þat nonnerye, & tok þe veil for hure folye; Þer-inne was scheo hyd & sperd, Þat noman non. of hure more herd. ¶ Moddred had sesed þen Cornewaille, ffor al Ingeland all þe toþer. gan hym faille, & sente aboute to landes sers lond sers. After knyghte & souders; Payen & Cristen knyght of scheld, Alle þat wilde, at soud he held. He sente for Irysche & Noreys; P. leaves out this line. Þe Saxons come wyþ þe Daneys; P. leaves out this line. ' Þat hadde nought on to lyue, P. leaves out this line. ' Lond,' he seyde, 'he wolde hem gyue;' P. leaves out this line. He highte & gaf to forthe his sped, P. leaves out this line. As man byhoues þat haþ gret ned. P. leaves out this line. But Arthur sore sone. ouer þoughte &yogh;yf he wiste what hym doughte; He dredde mykel his grete comynge, P. þe grete comyng. . Payens among þe Crystene to brynge. Arthur wolde no lenger byde, But gadered folk on ilka vpon his. syde Of alle þe contres heþen to cuntres vntill. Humber; fful manye þer were, as seys þe many he had it sais no. noumber. &yogh;yf Arthur hadde lenger abiden, Þe sykerere myghte Moddred haue ryden. When þe kyng had folk ynow, Toward Cornewaille he hym drow, & com in þer by þat cost Þer þat Moddred logged þer Modred lay with. his host. Þen seide Moddred, 'he wolde nought fle, ' But abyde what chaunce so he wild stand what chance mot. be; ' He schulde er suld ore. putte hym self to deye, ' Er he wolde eft fle his weye.' or he suld eft fle aweie. Moddred hadde fourty þousand, . In a wode busched to stand By-syde a water, Tambre, Joste Camblan, MS. du Roi, 27; Joste Tanbre, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé: Wace , ii. 229, l. 13,659. y wene, Þat þe parties ran was þe parties. by-twene. Stronge were was. þe hostes, gret was þe hate, & wrathe Hatered. to-gydere dide þem abate. Þorow hate & ire to-gydere þey ran, & Payens loues no Cristen man; Þerfore þe bataille was merueillous, & þe slaughter more hydous. ll. 14,265-14,268. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. On boþe partis were slayn fele, ffor þer non wolde oþer [forbere ne] for non wild oþer forbere no. spele. 2 .When Arthur sey Moddred feloun, . He rod til hym wiþ gret raundoun; Byfore hym dide bere his dragoun, Moddred to smyte as a lyoun. Moddred he smot, & he smot hym, . On boþe partis were woundes grym. 2 2-2 From Langtoft, i. 223, lines 18-23. But Moddredes side gan misfalle, ffor he was slayn, & his men alle; & als was slayn þer y þat stour, Of þe Rounde Table þe faire flour,— Þe faire &yogh;onglynges so mykel y-preised P. leaves out this line. Þat Arthur had norisched & vp reysed, P. leaves out this line. Þat he had Arthur. gadered of alle landes, Þe doughtiest þat were of handes;— & Arthur hym seluen þore, Men seyþ, he was wounded sore; &, for his woundes were to drede, Þer-fore he dide hym self þei did him. lede In to þe Ilde of Aualoun. & þus seys ilka Bretoun, Þat on lyue þere he ys, Lyuende man wyþ blod & Man in blode & in. flesche, & after hym &yogh;ut þey lok. Maister Wace þat made þys bok, He seyþ sais . . . . . dos . . . . . sais. namore of his fyn Þat þan. (Qu'en dist, Wace ii. 230, l. 13,690.) doþ sais . . . . . dos . . . . . sais. þe prophete Merlyn. Merlyn seide sais . . . . . dos . . . . . sais. ful merueillouse, Þat Arthures deþ was dotouse; dede was doutous. (dotose, Wace. ) Þer-fore &yogh;yt þe Bretons drede, & seyn sais . . . . . dos . . . . . sais. þat he lyues in lede; But y seye þey trowe wrong; ffor &yogh;yf he now lyue, his lyf ys long; & &yogh;yf he lyue þys ilke day, P. leaves out this line. . He schal lyue for euere & ay. P. leaves out this line. Nought þan y trowe þe Bretons Bot þe bretons londe. lye; He was so wounded, he moste dye.
text.248: This heading is two lines higher in the MS. ¶ Nomina dominorum occissorum, tam ex parte Arthury, quam Moddredy. The following names are from Geoffrey of Monmouth, bk. xi., chap. 2. See too Langtoft, i. 224. .Þyse were þe lordes of renoun . Þat on Moddredes side &yogh;ed doun: Brumyng, Egbright, Elays, Cheldryk, Gyllarion, Syllatel, Gylomar, Gylopayk. Gillasell. Gillomar. Gilopatrik. ¶ Þo þat deyde on Arthures syde, . Þat were lorn þat ilke tyde: Egbright of Norweye, Askyl of Denmark, Cador, & Cassibolon, doughti men & stark; & many oþer lordes les oþer lese. þer lyf, . Many lady wydewe, þat Many widow þat ore. was wyf. Arthur was born til Aualoun I þe &yogh;er of þe Incarnacion ffyue hundred, Sis cens, Wace , ii. 231, l. 13,599. & two & fourty, Syn Iesu lyghte in virgyne sen Ihesus lighted in. Mary. But al þe roialme was ffor þe regne men were. in speyr, ffor of his body was non heyr.
text.249: De Rege Constantino post Arthurum. But Cadores sone highte Constantyn Of Cornewaille, Arthures cosyn, He tok hym þe roiame in He bitauht him. kepyng; Vntil he cam, bad hym be kyng. "Mais ainc puis Artus ne re|"vint," adds the MS. du Roy, 7515 3.3. , Colb. Wace , ii. 232, l. 13,706. ¶ Of Moddred were two sones left/, Þat þe lond wold hym haue reft; Proude men & riche were þey; Þey seye þe force &yogh;ede al awey, Þe gode knyghte þat þer ware, Were y-slayn, þe land was bare. Þey seye þat Arthur nought ne com; To haue drede þey nyste of whom; Þe newe kyng nought þey dredde, . But gadered folk, & hostes ledde,— Þo Saxons þat Moddred held, Þat ascaped vnslayn y þe feld,— To þem alle were ef[t] þei wer. alyed; . Þe kynges men ouer al þei spyed; Of Londone þat on london þei. sesed þe cite, & þe beste of alle þe contre; Þat oþer, Wynchestre & al þe schire, & wende haue ben wend haf bien. lord & sire. ¶ Constantyn herde of þer estre, & hyed hym &yogh;erne vnto Wynchestre, & in a kyrke he hym fond. ffor al þe kirke ne wolde he wond; Byfore þe auter seint Anfrybal Amfiball. (Aufibal, MS. du Roi, 27; Amphibal, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé: Wace , ii. 233, l. 13,727.) His hed he smot of quitly ? quitly = quite. al; quikely smote his hede of all. And when þat on al þus Whan þe ton þus gate. was ded, On þat oþer, bataille he bed; But he ne durste nought hym abyde, In a kirke he gan hym hyde, But þat stod til hym him till. no prow, ffor in þe kirke he hym slow. Þre &yogh;er holy was he kyng; At Stonhenge he mad at þe stonhengis did. his endyng; ffor Conan his cosyn þere hym slow Treterously,—but y not þorgh treson .I. ne wote. how,— & in þe same stede ys leyd, Wyþynne þe carole, karolle (circle). þe story seyd. ¶ De Rege Conano. After hym was kyng his him kyng was þat. cosyn Conan, Þat was a folt, a mysproud man; Pes couþe he non &yogh;eme his lyue, But suffrede his folk ay to. fighte & striue. In cites was ay contek & tene, P. transposes these lines. Þe barons werrede þem by-twene; P. transposes these lines. His men & he were sonder seldom. saught, By stoundes often & oft tymes. to-gydere faught; Hit semed wel he couþe no god, . Syn he furdude his owen blod; Hys oþer Em tok wyþ werre & wow, & boþe his Emes eam. sones he slow, ffor þey were righte heires of þe lond, Þat after hym self of blod men fonde; Þer-fore he was þe more to blame, P. leaves out this line. Þat his owen blod so broughte to schame. P. leaves out this line. ffour &yogh;er he regned, & in tresoun, . & deide in dampnacion; He regned & dide,—his died in. feble hap,— And after hym regned sire Vortap; In þe Latyn ys writen þus, P. leaves out this line. Hys ryghte name ys Vortapus. P. leaves out this line. ¶ De Rege Vortapo. In Vortapus time ryse Saxones ros þe sessouns. To haue wonne þe lond eft sones: Þer chaunce was god in þeir rysy[n]ge, tisyng. Gret skaþe þey dide vnto þe kynge. His secounde &yogh;er his grace cam, & hardinesse in herte he nam, Huyred souders, & gaf þem wages, & destruyed þe Saxons lynages, Þat non durste in his lond abide But þorow truage at terme & tyde. ffour &yogh;er he hadde þe lond in pees; At Londone he made his deces. De Rege Malgo. After hym cam his sone was his cosyn. (ses niès, Wace , ii. 235, l. 13,764.) Malgo; Til alle manhede he gaf hym to; Alle men hadde of hym doute, He wan þe ildes ouer al aboute, & of kynges he tok feaute, As whilom hit was woned whilom was wont. to be; Of doughtinesse, of body feir, P. leaves out this line. He lyknede his auncestre als heir; P. leaves out this line. Of knyght-schipe noblely knyghtschip nobilly. he proued; Alle his kynde ful wel he loued; Large he was, of &yogh;yftes bolde; gode. Tresor wolde he neuere holde; He let nought þat day to lyuen, P. leaves out this line. But he had som what of his gyuen, P. leaves out this line. Þat alle of with. hym were glad & blythe, . And þanked hym ful many syþe. þanked god for him oft siþe. His þrydde &yogh;er was yuel ill. to lyke, He vsed þe &yogh;ede to. synne Sodomyke,— Þe synne of Sodome, as men fynde, . Is a sinne ageynes kynde;— At Wynchestre, at his baþynge, Sodeynly mad he his endynge. ¶ De Rege Cariceo. After Malgo, Carice þei ches, A nyce þat louede nyce man luffed. no pes. ffor he was ai sorwful & wroþ, Þer-fore was he alle men loþ. Þat herde þe Saxons he was gremande, þe sessons herd he was gremiand (A.-S., gremian , to irritate, provoke) & þoughte he myghte nought dure ne stande. Ouer al aboute hym þey ros, & oþer aliens, Bretons fos, Þat come wyþ Gormound by þe se side. . Þe nauye of Gormound spredde ful wyde, He destruyed þe Bretons alle, & þer name for euere dide falle, And þe name of þe lond [was] lorn, Þat highte Bretayne longe byforn: A þousand &yogh;er byfore or. þe Incarnacioun Hight hit Bretaigne, for loue of Bretoun, Euere vntil Gormound cam; . Þe name of Bretayne þenne a-wey nam. Listneþ now a litel pas, P. leaves out this line. When Gormound cam, & what he was: P. leaves out this line.
text.250: ¶ De Gormundo de Aufrico. Gurmound was a noble knyght, Of noble lynage, of mykel mykell of. myght, Stalworþe of body, hardy of wille, P. leaves out this line. He dredde noman for god ne ille; P. leaves out this line. Kynges sone he was of Aufryk, Þat is in heþenesse a ful fer stryk; Of al Aufrike was he heyr, But þer-of ne tok he ward ne bot he was in anoþer. speir; ffor, Aufrik he gaf til his broþer, & seide he wolde purchace hym oþer, He seide he wolde toward þe west, By þe se syde, to make conquest, & croune wolde he neuere bere But he hit wan wyþ force & of. were. Merlyn þe clerk longe byforn Of Gormound spak, er he was born, 5 & seide, 'þe wolf vpon þe se ' Schuld do alle þe Bretons fle:' 5 5-5 Que ce seroit uns lus marins, Wace , ii. 237, l. 13,814. Þus seyde Merlyn wyþ herte ful sor, Þe Bretons tyme for euere mor, Til Cadwal & til Cadwaldre &. Conan . Þeir bones broughte wer brouht. ageyn wyþ man. ¶ fful wel he cald hym 'wolf of drede;' He robbed oueral as he &yogh;ede. He purchased hym, þorow robberye, Men ynowe, & fair nauye,— An hundred & sexti Cant et cinquante, Wace , ii. 237, l. 13,817. þousand bolde Of men of armes knowe & armes & bowmen. tolde, Wyþouten gelde & maryners, & sergauntz, & gode serganz gode &. archers;— Schipes he hadde, y ne wot how fele; Alle he tok, & non wold spele. Water & lond, long & brod, He ouer sailed, & al þorow rode; Ildes þorow &yogh;ede, kynges ouer-cam, P. leaves out this line. Þeyr landes sesed, þer godes nam. P. leaves out this line. So longe he ferde farde. o þe se sailand, & kynges slow by se & sand, Al holy his flute gan dryue, Vpon Irland he gan aryue; Irelend wild he ryue. Þe lond sone til hym gan falle; Irische kyng he dide hym calle; Þen seide he 'he wolde to Bretaigne, 'Wiþ Bretons to make a newe bargayne.' mak bargayn. Saxons were manie &yogh;yt in þys lond, . Þorow trewage þat men þem in bond, & when þey felde hem ought felt þam out. of might, In Hengistes landes hengist lond. þey claymed right, Thwancastre, Lyndesye & Kent, Of þyse Hengist furst hadde rent/, & þat he gaf Octa his sone,— By Scotland þer gan he wone;— Þey chalangede hit of auncestrie, . Al þat was Hengistes partie; Ofte þey wan hit þorow dynt, & often hit a-geyn þey tynt; Often þer-fore þey gaf hostages, P. leaves out this line. & also ofte made þey homages; P. leaves out this line. To þe Bretons oþ þey swor, P. leaves out this line. & often ageyn þer oþ þey for; Neuere held þey lenger feyþ ne ryght Þan þey sey tyme & terme of till þei sauh tyme þat þei. myght,— Þat a kyng was ded or doune, Or &yogh;yf a feble on hadde þe croune;— Þenne þey ryse, on Bretons ronne, . Vmwhile þey les, vmwhile þei wonne; &yogh;yf a discord were bitwixt þe Bretons, P. leaves out this line. Euere medlande were þe Saxons; P. leaves out this line. On wham-so ros contek or wo, P. leaves out this line. . Þe Saxons were redy þeym to slo. P. leaves out this line. ¶ Northumberland was al þeyr home, P. leaves out this line. Þere þey wonede, þennes þey come; P. leaves out this line. Hit was gyuen þem first to bigge, P. leaves out this line. . Al wast was hit wone to ligge; P. leaves out this line. But þer dwellynge mended þat contre P. leaves out this line. Wel bettere þan hit was wone to be. P. leaves out this line. Of Gurmound &yogh;ede þe word ful wyde, Þat alle landes he wolde þorow ryde; Payen he was, þey herde wel telle, Cristen men to struye & þe cristendom forto. quelle. When þey herde of hym þus speke, . Þey hoped þan he scholde þem wreke; Wyþ þe Bretons þei made al pes, Þe whiles to whils. messegers þey ches, & sente til Gurmound ouer þe se, & hette 'to holde of hym þer fe ' Wyþ þy he wolde come to Bretaigne, ' & gyue hit þem, & be cheftaigne, ' & be hym self lord & kynge, ' Wyþy þey helde of hym þeir þat. þynge, ' Þat leuede on his owen lawe, ' & brynge þe Cristene alle of dawe: " ffor &yogh;e ar Payen, & so ar we; " O lawe we wolde þat al schuld wild all on. be, " & swylk a kyng wolde we haue " Þat þe Payen lay might lawe mot. saue." ffaste hym bisoughte, & þus þey hym het, him þei souht & þus þei hette. So þat Gurmound mad & Gurmund had. redy his flet, & seide 'he wolde auenture his chaunce, 'Hys Payen lay for to auaunce.' To schipe he wente at a tyde, O Northumberland he gan ryde. Gurmound acorded wiþ þe Saxons, ' To voide þe lond of alle þe Bretons, ' & gyue hit þe Saxons in fe ageyn.' Of þys made þey foreward certeyn, & þat þey schulde gyue hym truwage, & þer-til swore, & gaf hostage. Oueral þenne was sorewe & drede Whenne þe Payens gonne bigan. to sprede! ffor þey of noman hadde mercy, But alle deide delfully; Þe Cristen blod [þat] er was gentil, P. leaves out this line. Was turned to Payen so vyl. P. leaves out this line. Þe Saxons ledde þe Aufrykans, & destruyed þe Cristen wans; wanes. Knyghtes, clerkes, to deþ were don, & namely alle religion; Was non spared of Cristen cristens. tonge, Neyþer womman ne childre noure women no childir &yogh;ong. &yogh;onge. Byschopes, abbotes, þat reliqes had, When þey fledde, a-wey þeym lad, & manye in þe erthe þey dalf, Þat now men fynde on many half;— Crosses, belles, men haue founden, P. leaves out this line. . In welles, in watres, vp haue wounden, P. leaves out this line. Þat tyme were casten, so to saue, P. leaves out this line. ffor þey myghte nought alle wyþ hem haue;— P. leaves out this line. Cors seyntes bones wyþ hem bare; . & hidde in erþe manion &yogh;ut are. Alle fledde þat fle might; Þe hardiest was ful sore afright. all ofright. . Theof, þe Theon. Geoffrey of Monmouth says, bk. xi. § 10, that the Arch|bishop of Caerlion, with those of London and York, Theonus and Thadioceus, fled into Wales with their relics. Langtoft makes only Thon and Tadyke go, i. 230. He has the bishop eating herbs, l. 14,575, above. erchebischop of London, To wode he fledde, & was nought fonden; Sire Thadok, þe erchebischop of &yogh;ork, He liuede in kerres, as doþ þe stork/; Þey liuede wyþ herbes of þe ryuers, . In wast, wyþ bestes, at stedes sers; Non þeym tok to castel ne tour, ffor þey wyste of no socour; Halles, chaumbres, alle þey let, To Walys fele fledde wale many fled. on fet. & somme þat mighte hauen hent, In schip to litel Bretaigne went/; Þe mene folk & þe poraille ffledde in to Walys & Cornewaille. ¶ Þe kyng fledde fro cost to cost, ffor he myght gete to-gedere non host Þat durste stande Gurmound agayn, The second a is an e altered. Erl, baron, knyght, ne swayn; Ne þe kyng durst hym nought se, P. transposes these lines. ffor non wilde stande, but alle wold fle. P. transposes these lines. Seint Bede telles in his gestes I cannot find anything like this in Bede. See note 2 , p. 510 below. . How þe Bretons brak Godes heste[s]: hestis. Why þat meschaunce gan on þem mischefe on þam gon. falle, In his bokes he writes hit alle. Of eighte The MS. has also .viij. over the word, and a later red note at the side in Latin— " ¶ Nota: ¶ consilium Iuuenum, " ¶ Latens odium, ¶ Singulare co| " modum destruunt regnum." þat Auht (for of eighte þat). he wrytes, y telle þe þre, . In stede of an autorite: Nota. . Propre profit, & pryue hate, &yogh;onge mennes conseil þey toke algate; ffor by befor. alle þyse þre þey ches, . And mest þorow þyse, Bretayne þey les.
text.251: ¶ Caricius, Rex Brutonum, versus est in fugam. Gurmound soughte faste & spyrede, Þe kyng to haue, mykel to mykell. he desyred; Carice to folewe, faste he spedde, . & euere Carice byfore hym fledde; To Circestre algate he wan, & Gurmound hym folewede, þe Gurmund & ilk an. Aufrican, Byseged þe toun a ful long while, . & brente hit wyþ a queynte gyle. He telleþ he telles. (he = Wace; see vol. ii. p. 242; Geoffrey of Monmouth, bk. xi. ch. 8; La&yogh;amon, iii. 168.) first of a meschaunce Of kyng Lowys cosyn of ffraunce,— His name was cald Isambert— . He dide hym selue a folie apert; To Gurmound cam, & wyþ hym spak, His Cristendom fursok & brak, To venge hym on his em Lowys Þat hadde hym flemed fled. out of Parys. A deuel he was—þe soþe was sene— Tant fu lo chaitis decéus Et forsenés et mescréus. Wace , ii. 242, l. 13,941-2. Our God to fursake, Tant fu lo chaitis decéus Et forsenés et mescréus. Wace , ii. 242, l. 13,941-2. hys em to tene. ¶ Gurmound aspied oueral ilk estre How best he mighte bisege Circestre; Tentes & pauilons he sette, Engyns dide mak & fette; Þe toun he seged so straite aboute Þat þey wyþynne myght naught oute. Þey wyþynne ageyn þem kast, Wyþ tymber & ston þey closed þem fast,— Engines on walles þey hadde ynowe, . Out of carneles, arblastes drowe,— ll. 12,623-12,628. The Petyt MS. puts these lines after line 14,638. See next col. On dayes þey wroughte on þer clos, On nyghtes þey woke for þeir foos. Þough al þer clos were þof all þer clos was. right god, . & skyle þey seye a skill þei sauh. & vnderstod, Þat atte laste,—nylde þey, wylde,— wild þe ne wild. Þe toun byhoued þem burd þam. nedly &yogh;elde; Þey wyste hit wel, & nought ne wende . Þe toun for euere þey mighte defende. mot þei not fend. Nought for þan for þat þouht. þey were dismayed, ffor gyle al day þey were affrayed. P. puts here two fresh lines, and then lines 14,623-28, above:— neuer þe les þei hald þat þei mot haue. so long þe mot þer lyues saue. þe toun he seged all about þat þei within myght not out. þei within ageyn þam kast. with timbir & stone klosed þam fast. engynes on walles þei had Inouh out of kirnels alblastes þrewe. þat god forsoke.
text.252: ¶ Exe qualiter Villa Cirencestrie obsita est Þey wyþoute ofte of. þem assailled; Þe toun was strong, in veyn for nouht. trauailled. Þen sey Gurmound hit halp þem Gurmund sauh it helped. nought, Þe sautes þat þey on hem he on þam. sought, & longe byhoued þem þere to lye long burd him þer lie. . Er he schold wynne hit or he wan it. wyþ maistrie. Castels a kastell. aboute þe toun dide make, Bretaxed & carneled, bretaskes kirnelles. (a bretes|ques et à cherniax. Wace , ii. 243, l. 13,976.) þer-inne to wake. Isambert, þat on he tok, Þeyr estres for to spye & lok; An oþer he tok his owene barouns; Þe þrydde gaf he to þe Saxouns. Vntil hym self he made a tour; Þer-inne he lay, & held soiour, Þer-inne &yogh;ede he vp & doun, And spied þe estres of þe toun. Þey of þe toun were bolde & stout, By tyme vmwhile þey camen tymes vmwhile com þei. out Al armed, as men hardy, & dide þe Payens gret vyleny. By-twyxten þem was many a chace, many manace. & putte þer lyues ofte did þer lyues all. in grace; fful often dide þey many foul Of þei did þam many. chek, & often were þey in þe brek; On boþe sides, to wynne pris, . Boldely bede þey ilk oþer þe vys; But þey wyþoute were euere þe mo, P. leaves out this line. Ageyn to toune dide þem go; P. leaves out this line.
text.253: per Gurmundum, & capta per Passeres. On eyþer half slewe þey manye a boþe half slouh many. man, . Of Bretons, Saxoyns, & Aufrican. When þey had dryuen þe Bretons in, Þe Walsche men þe walles. myghte þey nought wyn; Þe toun ful longe þer owen held. . Þe ost wyþoute leye in þe feld, & hadde destruyed al þe contre, ffourty myle aboute, & & oþer þer next tuo or. þre.
text.254: ¶ Audite iam quoddam Mirabile de cremacione Cirencestrie. But listneþ now a selkouþ Þat neuere er fel by norþ ne souþ, Ne neuere contreued in elde ne &yogh;ouþe, P. leaves out this line. Ne conseil gyuen of mannes mouþe: P. leaves out this line. Þe Payens wyþowte leide nettes & lynes, laid many lymes. & sparewes toke al day by tymes; After þat, luytel notes After nottes. þey toke, & holede þem, þe kerneles out schoke; Þey dide y þe schelles, skellis. fyr & tunder, Brymston & Bronston. flax,—þys was a wonder,— & feste þem by þe sparewes fet; P. leaves out this line. At euen homward fleye þem let; P. leaves out this line. Þe sparewes fleye at euen to reste, Til houses þere þey were woned þer þe wont. to neste; In eueses þey crepte, & in þe þakkes, eues þei crepte & in þak. & in hey & in corn stakkes; korn stak. Þe fir, þe tonder, þe brymston þe tundir bronston & fire. hot, Kyndled on lowe, & vp hit smot. Þe Bretons wyst nought how hit brent, Ne on what manere þe fir was sent; Þey armed þeym alle redy to fight; Ouer fewe our fo. þey were, & hadde no myght. Þe kyng þer in-to Walys skaped, See Geoffrey's account of the utter destruction of Britain, and his upbraidings against the Britons for their quarrels and sins: bk. xi. ch. 8, 9. & þo þat myghte, wiþ hym þeym raped;— Syþ herde y nought telle of wham whom . . . . . bicom. Whiderward Carice by-cam;— whom . . . . . bicom. & right þus þusgate. Circestre was taken, Þat longe held þe Payens waken; & for hit was wyþ sparewes brent, Þo men þat þorow þe contre went, On Englische cald hit "Sparewes Toun," & Frensche men "Cite de Mischeroun," on frankis Cite de moshon. (La cité as moissons, Wace , ii. 246, l. 14,033.) ffor to mene þe queyntise 6 How hit was wonne, & on what wyse. ¶ When Gurmound had al ouer riden & ronne, & Bretayne til his hand al wonne, Þat no Breton 6 6-6 how sparowes brent it & on what wise Gurmund stroied many cites. many hastels & cuntres. many heremytage & abbay. þorgh him wer brent & brouht away. & many fair toun mad wasten. þat neuer &yogh;it was bigged ageyn. in many tokne is sene. Quomodo diuidebat regnum. þat whilom ware now is all grene. Whan Gurmund þe lond all wonne. þe bretons ouer riden & ronne. þat non so hardy. durst hym abyde, . Ne ageines hym in bataille ride, To þe Saxons he gaf þe lond Þat he in Northumberland first fond. And &yogh;yf MS. &yogh;yt. P. if. dide Gurmound so, he dide right, He sykerede sikerd. þem byforn, & hight; & þo þat &yogh;erned Hengistes þyng, Þorow Gurmound hadde þer &yogh;ernyng; ffor he gaf þeym þorgh Gurmund had þei. þe lond of Kent, Þat longe wyþ Hengistes þat fro Hengist. blod was went. A lynage of þe out ildes he out of þe Ildes. (de l'ydle [ or des isles, MS. Reg. , 20 A. xi. ] joy|naunt à Saxonye: Langtoft , i. 232.) dide allye, Þat langed vntil Saxonie; Men þei were of gret honur, . & doughti for to stande in stour;— ' Anglysche' kalde þei al Anglis cald þei. þat kynde, To knowe where men mighte hit fynde;— Gurmound þe lond to þem hit gaf, . But þe oþere Saxoyns be þem ouer haf, & made Anglische þam. souereyns for to be, ffor to holde hit & þei suld hold. of hym in fee; In Northfolk was first þer wonynge; .
