'Estangle' hit hight for þer comynge; Anglys, þat contre first þey aught, & of Anglis, Estangle hit laught: Þus fondy in Maister Waces boke; . Of Peres of Langtoft also y toke, & of Gyldas þer-to y leyde, Right as Peres þer-of seyde; Of alle þre bryng y to place, . Gyldas, Peres, & Maister Wace. But þe Saxons acorded for no þynge Þat þe Anglys schuld be þer kyng; " Þey hadde wel leuere," þe Saxons þei. seyd, ? MS. sayd , with a altered from e or vice versâ. . " Þat þe lond were in partis leyd, " Þan þe Anglys of þe out ildes " Schulde be chef of alle þer gyldes." of þer Gildes.
text.255: ¶ Diuisio Regni per Gurmundum, secundum Gyldas. Gurmound sey þey acorded nought, . He parted þe lond as hym best þought: In Kent a kyng ordeyned he, The following division of Eng|land into seven kingdoms, or a Hep|tarchy, is given by Langtoft, i. 230-2, and he says he took it from Gildas. & Caunterbury was þe chef cite; Southsex was þat oþer estre, . & þe chef toun was Chichestre; Cirecestre. Westsex þe þrydde thr [ i ] d. of renoun, P. puts these lines after line 14,756. & Wyltone was þer chef toun; P. puts these lines after line 14,756. Middelsex þe ferþe founden, . Þe chef toun þanne was Lounden; Estangle þe fyfte kynge-riche, kingriche. Þer chef cite þenne was Norwiche; Northwiche. Southfolk langed al longed als. þer til, . Of Estangle hit ys þorow skyl. Þe syxte was Merce, now ys Lyndeseye, Þe hed toun þer to Lyncolne lay; Þe seue[n]þe roialme of rente & fe, . ffro Humber, al þe northe contre Vntil Scotland, als hit lys, & &yogh;ork þer chef toun was of pris. In Gildas bok þus y fond, . Þat Gurmound parted Ingelond; departed þe lond. (Neither Gur|mond's name nor any division of England into seven parts is men|tioned in Gildas's Works or Life, or in Nennius. See too Sir F. Mad|den's note in La&yogh;amon , iii. 417.) Siþen vpon ffraunce he ran, To wynne hit, for Arthur hit wan.
text.256: ¶ Declaracio Hystorie secundum Benedictum Bedam. Now haue þe Anglys haf Anglis. þe seignurye, . Þat are þe kynde of Germenye. Þe Saxons als, þat now are on, Spred y þys reomes ilkon. Ilke a kyng desired diuersed. his lawe, . Of alle myghte noman seye no sawe, So fele þer were now & now, What þey wroughte, couþe non sey how; But þat seynt Bede of þem alle seys, Elles schulde non haue knowe what weys, . Ne no story forto haue writen; But as bot þat. Bede has nothing about Engle and Scardyng below: see l. 14,820-3. seint Bede doþ vs to wyten Whilk were gode, whilke were elles; . And of byschopes al so he telles, Þat &yogh;e in his bokes rede; To telle hit here hit ys no nede; Hit were a degyse diuers. þyng, . But whan þe lond was til o a. kyng. ¶ Longe after, þus write y fond, How a Breton chalanged þys lond: 'Engle,' þe story seyþ he hight, . And broughte a chaumpion for to fight,— 'Scardynk' Skardyng. highte þe chaumpioun Þat cam wyþ Engle þe Bretoun;— On al þe lond he sette chalange, . ffor his auncestres wolde he venge, & take vengeaunce of þe Anglys Englis. Þat chased þe Bretons out of þys. Alle Anglys þys all þe Englis. Engle dredde . ffor þe grete poer þat he ledde. þys Engle sente vntil þe barouns, & alle þe kynges he made somouns, To holde of hym al her ryght, Or he schulde wynne hit of hem wiþ þorgh. fyght, . Eyþer þorow pleyn bataille in feld, Or wyþ chaumpion staf & scheld. Þys Skardyng was ferly strong, . ' When ilkon hadde his porcion, ' Held hym kyng & bar coroun.' He acordes wyþ Gyldas; . As Gormond gaf hit, als so. hit was. text.257: ¶ Interpretacio Anglorum secundum Sanctum Bedam. To Rome men ledde þem for to selle,— . & seint Bede so herdy telle,— See Eccl. Hist. , bk. ii. ch. l, ed. Giles. To Rome, he seys, marchauntz MS. Marchaumtz. P. Merchanz. þem led, & solde þem þere, & forþ þem fed. Als þey to selle were often set, . On þem to se, þe folk wel let; Manie burgeses of þe burgeis of þat. cite Come þe faire childre to se. Among amang . . . . . a. alle þo þat þyder nam, . O amang . . . . . a. tyme seint Gregore wiþ hem cam; When he sey þo semly sitte, sawe þat semly sight. Wheþen þey were, wolde he wyt; ffor he seide þat 'he sey neuere er, sawe neuer are. . 'So faire childre of huyde ne her. of hide no haire. " Of what lond," seide he, "þis childre be?" Men seide, "of Bretayne, a fer contre." He seide, "fair folk ys þere-inne! . " Þer faces to se, hit ys gret wynne! " Wheþer ar þei Cristen," he seide, whedir be þei cristend. "or non?" " Þey are Paiens," þey seide, "ilkon." " Alas!" he saide, "so fair mankynde, . " Þat þe fend in pyne schal bynde! " So fare persones, so bright of ble, P. leaves out this line. " Þat in merknesse euere schul be!" P. leaves out this line. Þeyr kynde he asked, "how men þem how he said þis kynd men. calle?" . " Anglys," þey seyde, "so het þey alle." " Angle!" he saide, "a name of grace! " ffor angeles ar þey lyke of face. " & wel oughte swylk be heires of heuene; . " Þer name ys Angle, Angel to neuene. " Of Bretayne þey are, &yogh;e tolde byforn: " What highte þe contre þei were inne born?" Þey seide, "y þe norþ side of a þe. schire; . " Þe contre men calles hit Deyire." Deire. " Deyire!" he seide, "ful wel sey &yogh;e; " ffro Godes ire þei schul falle & fle, Ire þei sall fle. " & be cald til his mercy, . " In blisse wyþ angles to wone hym by! " What hette þer kyng? can &yogh;e me telle?" " &yogh;e, sire," &yogh;a sir. þey seide, "þeir kyng hight Elle." Seint Gregore at þat name low; . He seide, "þat name ys wel y-now; " fful wel," seide he, "certes, &yogh;a! " ffor hit bitoknes Aleluya; " Alleluya, a song of honour . " To worschipe Crist oure Saueour." Seint Gregore to þe pope to pape. &yogh;ede, & preyede bisouht. hym for oure grete nede 'Þat he mighte to Bretayne wende, . '& Cristendom by hym þem sende; 'He seide his wille were wel þer-to '&yogh;if þat þe pope wolde hit so.' But þe court wolde nought consent . Þat seint Gregore so fer went, ffor he was ablest, next pope in lite next for. to be After hym þat held þo þe se. Whan he was pope, furgat pape forgat. he nought, . But on our nede ful wel he þought, & sente forþ hider seint Austyn. By þe Ilde of Tanete cam he at þe Ilde of Teneth he com. in, Þat ys þe est side of Kent: . In Tenet lond seint Austyn hent;
text.258: ¶ De Parentela Ethelberty. And in þe tyme of his comynge, Of Kent Ethelbright Ethelbert. (Aldebar, MS. du Roi, 27; Artelbert, MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3. , Colb.: Wace , ii. 250, l. 14,141.) was kynge; And þe kynedam of Ethelbright, . Til Humber was he chef in right. Þis Ethelbright, Ethelbert. (Aldebar, MS. du Roi, 27; Artelbert, MS. du Roi, 7515 3.3. , Colb.: Wace , ii. 250, l. 14,141.) as we fynde, He was of Hengistes kynde; Del linage as Englois estoit, MS. du Roi, 27; De linaige Han|guist, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé: Wace , ii. 250, l. 14,142. Gurmond þen sesed in þat kyndam . Þe kynde þat of Hengist cam. Þyse wordes of seint Bede y tok/, Þe fifte chapitre of þe secounde capitle of þe. bok; Þorow þat chapitre capitle. It contains also the following genealogy, but does not name Gurmond. al y wyst . Bytwixt Ethelbright & Hengist. Hengistes sone, Oysk was his name, Kyng of Kent, & of noble fame; ffor fame of Oysk, of Kent þe kynges . Longe were þey cald Oysynges. Þis Oysk was noble, & so ferlyk, Hys sone men calde hym Oyrik; Octa cam of Kyng Oyryk, . & Octa sone highte Irumeryk; Irminerike. Irumerykes Irminerik. sone hight Ethelbright,— Þus, seiþ seint Bede, þe kynde &yogh;ede right. Of Ethe[l]bright haue I told þe kyn; . Now turn ageyn to seint Austyn. Þe lengþe of þe Ilde of Tenet, þis ilde Teneth. Sex myle þen ys þe met, myle is it mette. & þre myle þen is þe brede, . By two weyes þat me wil þat men it. lede; & of þys ilde boþe endes Al aboute, þe se hit wendes. In to þys ilde seint Austyn cam, & ffourty felawes wyþ hym nam The MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé, of Wace, reads "Quarante clerc for|"ment prisié," but De Lincy's MS. du Roi, 27, has "Qatre clerc saive et enraisnie, ( Wace , ii. 250, l.14,136.) The "qatre" may refer to the three bishops, Mellite, Just, and Laurence, of lines 15,159-61, below, with Rufinianus, Bede's fourth ( Eccl. Hist. , i. 29). Bede says here, nearly fourty men. This page and the next four are Bede's ch. 25, bk. i., expanded. Of Cristene & of frankis &. religions, To make Ethelbert þe kyng. somons 'Þat he scholde to Rome wende, . 'To knowe þe lyf wyþouten ende, 'Þat Ihesu Crist, Lord of myght, 'Þat in þe Virgine Marie lyght, 'And ys, & euere more schal be, . 'Sothfast God in Trynite.' When þe kyng wiste swilk men were comen, & in þe ilde hadde hauene inomen, Þat dide ne seide to noman ille, . He bad þey schulde leue stille, & be serued þat þem was nede Of mete & drynke, wyþouten drede, Til þat hym seluen cam þem to, . To wyte at hem what þey wild do. Þe kyng had herd seid wel byforn say biforn. Þat Ihesu was of Marie born, & hadde y-taught a newe lawe; . Of-ten þer-of he herde in sawe; & his wyf was Cristen, In ffraunce born of Frensche frankis. men, & in swilk foreward scheo hym took . Þat scheo hure lawe nought fursook/; Þat ladies name was Dame Berk/. Berke . . . . . clerke. Wyþ hure cam ouer a noble clerk/, Berke . . . . . clerke. A byschop þat highte Sire Leothard, . To holde his wyf þat foreward, 'Þe kyng schulde nought furdo hure feythe, 'Neyþer for loþ, lef, ne leythe.' noiþer for leue ne for laith. Þe kyng a day til Austyn set, . To come to þe Ilde of Tanet: Þe kyng durste come no couert courte. til, But stod & bod vnder an hyl; Of for. wiche-craft he hadde doute, . Þer-fore of couert courte. he held hym oute; In toune ne hous ne com he nought, P. leaves out this line. ffor drede of gyle þat mighte be wrought. P. leaves out this line. Þat his poer mighte hym be raft P. leaves out this line. . Þorow word or werk of wychecraft/; P. leaves out this line. Þus he hoped, & wel he wende, After hym þer-fore dide he sende. When his message til Austyn cam, . His felawes alle wyþ hym þey he. nam, & byforn hem dide bere a croys Of seluer, & alle wyþ o voys a voyce. Songen þey þe Letanie, Aduentus Regis ad Augustinum. Austyn & al his companie, . Þat Ihesu Crist wolde suld. þem here, ffor wham whom. þey made þeir preiere. When þey he. come byfore þe kyng, . Seint Austyn made a prechyng, & seide, 'Seint Gregore til hym he sent, 'ffor hym & his amendement, 'And somoned hym þer for to come . 'To Cristes lawe, þe lawe of Rome.' He tolde hym of þe Incarnacion, & sithen of al his passion, 'How Ihesu tholede woundes fyue, . '& deide, & ros fro deþ to lyue, 'And stey steih. til heuene, God & man, 'Til oure kynde þe blisse vs he. wan; 'And how he ys ful of mercy, . '& til ilka synful man redy, 'Þat in god hope til hym wil calle: 'Til his blysse he brynge vs alle!'
text.259: ¶ De Responcione & curialitate Regis. When þys prechyng was [all] all. don, . Til hym seide þe kyng ful son: " ffaire are þy wordes, & swete, " & þy byhestes þow vs byhete! & þe hotes þou dos vs hete. " & þat þy God ys milde of mod, . " Als þou seide, y vnderstod. " But for &yogh;e aren &yogh;ut er &yogh;it. so newe, " & non of vs &yogh;ow neuere knewe, " Þer-fore &yogh;it y ne may . " Leten leue. oure forfadres lay, " Þat we longe on haue y-leued, " & til oure Godes þer-inne y-cheued; " And &yogh;oures &yogh;it we nought ne knowe; . " Þer-fore we schul byden sall bide. a þrowe; " & &yogh;e are of so fer contre, " And als pylegryms, so seme &yogh;e, " Vs þys newe lawe to preche. . " And &yogh;yf hit be soþ þat &yogh;e teche, " And amonges vs [þat &yogh;e] wil lende, " Y schal nought be to &yogh;ow vnhende; " Takeþ &yogh;our wonyng wher &yogh;e wyle, . " & þat yow falleþ to haue in skile; " And alle þo þat &yogh;e may wynne " Til þat lawe þat &yogh;e bygynne, " I graunte &yogh;ow my wille fre, " &yogh;yf hit be sike[r] certeyn. þat y may se." . Þe kyng þem graunted at þer comynge, I þe cite to make a þer. biggyng,— Doroberma or Dorobernia. þe cite þen hight, . Þat Caunterbury now cald ys Now Canterbirie is þe name. right;— He dide þem haue swiche haf suilk. purueaunce Þat neded for fell vnto. þer sustinaunce. To preche þe folk he wernde warned. nought, . But do as good[e] þem by-þought. as þam gode þouht. ¶ To þe cite þey come singand; Þe cros byfore, men bare in hand; A table þey broughte þeym bytwyx,— . " Of merci, Lord, we preye to þe, " Do þy wrathþe from þys cite, " And fro þy holy hous al-swa! . " ffor our synnes we singe for we haf synned. Alleluya!" text.260: ¶ Rex baptizatus est a biscopo Augustino. Syn ffortiger [tyme] þat tyme þat. Hengist cam, Til þat seint Austyn broughte Cristendam.— . Seint Austyn hadde þere wonynge Good while er Long ar. Wery he was, for fer gon, So were his felawes euerichon; ilkon. & þe grete hete þem greued, & þe folk þat misbileued Als þe folk þat . . . . . misleued. Had don hym so foul despit, Boþe he þoughte, & seide ful tyt, Þat he wolde make hym al &yogh;are, & fro þat wikked folk wild fare. But Ihesu Crist wolde hit nought; He spak til hym, for he so þought: " Let al þat leue all þi. þought ilkadel, " & trist opon myn help right wel! " Þou art my seriaunt, & paies me; " Þy þought & dede, wel y hit se; " Of mi grace to þe y graunte, " Þat þow dost, y holde couenaunte; " Heuen ys open to þe redy, P. leaves out this line. " And for wham þou askest merci." P. leaves out this line. When seint Austyn had sen & herd God of heuene þat hym answerde, He þanked hym of his swete grace, An[d] kneled doun in þat place, & kyste þe erthe fele sithe; He grette for ioie, so was he bliþe. When he had longe preied & gret, . Doun y þe erthe his staf he set/; Þer right as he sey þer where he saw. þat sight, He pighte his staf þer doun vpright: fitched his staf down right. & þer of þe erthe a water spronge Þat ys now a ryuer longe, & neuere byforen was non sen, Ne no man wonyng wonand. had þer ben; ffor noman mighte liue ne dwelle . Wyþoute ryuer or water of welle; & for þer was non neuer byforn, Was þe contre wast & lorn.
text.261: ¶ Quare vocatur Cernel. Seint Austyn gladed his felawes . Of Godes sight & of his sawes; & for [he] hadde sen right þer for he had sene þere. Þe sight þat he saw neuere er, ' Cernel' he calde Chernel ha cald. Said to be Cerne Abbas in Dorsetshire. Mad|den in La&yogh;amon , iii. 419, &c. þat ilke stede, ffor he saw God, & herde his bede. ' Cerno' ys on Englische, 'y se;' ' El' ys Ebrew, 'God' schuld hit be; For the next two lines P. has— Cernel þis word may be trod I. sawe or .I. se god. Saint Austine did it write. þat he sawe god wele is to wite. Do to-gyder Cerno & El, Þat ys called Cernoel. When Englische men Englis. & Saxons— ffirst þe kynge, þen þe barons,— Hadde receiued þe bapteme, & children also crystned in creme, Mykel ioye seint Austyn mad, & þanked God wyþ herte glade. Toward Walys, Bretons he fond, Ageyn þe Englishe Englis. defended þer lond, Ageyn al þe Englische Englis. poer, Monke, abbote, Monkes Chanons. & seculer. Þorow Gormound þe Englische Englis. had hit wonne, . & ouer þe Bretons riden & ronne, & in to Walys dide þem chace, Þer þey wonede, biggand a place. Þo religious whilom wer her, . Þen woned þey þor in stedes ser. Of þo ilke religiouses religious. ffond seint Austyn many houses, a hous. Abbote, monkes, wyþoute vitaille, . Þat lyuede alle on þer trauaille. Seuen bischopes sey fond. he þere, Þat in Walys wonynge were; An erchebischop of gret more. degre, At Kerlion was þenne þe se; At Bangor al-so als. was an abbeye Of blake monkes, but none greye; Two þousand, þat was þer lot, Þeyr abbot highte sire Dynot. Þyse two þousand, at here deuis, þise Monkes at þer auys. Were departed in seuen partis; Þre hundred were euere in o hundreth were in a. couent Vntil labour set & sent/; But on to lyue, had þey nought But by þer trauail þat þey wrought.
text.262: ¶ De comitiua Monachorum in Bangor qui noluerunt Augustino obedire, sed omnino eum renuerunt. Seint Austyn for þe bischop Les set évesques, Wace , ii. 256, l. 14,276. sente: To wite his wille til hym þey wente: He seyde 'he was of Rome legat, ' & of Ingelond þe prymat, " Þer-fore &yogh;e oughte þorow auh þorgh. reson " Of me receiue þe benisoun, " & be bowynge vntil bowand vnto. (Et estre en sa subjesion, Wace , l. 14,281.) me." Alle þey seyde þat schulde nought be: " Oure prymat, of Kerlion es; . " He ys our heued, he schal vs bles; " He ys confermed of þe Court of Rome; " We nyl stande at non oþer dome; " & for Englische mennes Englis men. sake, . " Ageyn þe oughte we ageyn vs auh. to take; " Þaw a party reson hit wolde, P. leaves out this line. " Ageyn þe Englische we oughte holde; P. leaves out this line. " ffor þey vs chased cached vs. out of our fees, " & wone wyþ wrong in oure contres, " & we Bretons ar Cristen men, " & þey are of lawe Paen, " & now late conuerted are. " Oure vilenie certes for sothe. hit ware " ffor to be to þeym suget, " & late leue. hym þat has vs get. " Þo we holde for oure enemis " Þat haþ þem brought to swilk[e] pris; " We wile neyþer of þem ne þe " Comune wiþ-al, ne blessed comon with all no blissed. be." Seint Austyn seyde namore;— . Þer yuel wil þem ouer-þoughte wikked will him forþouht. sore;— Til Ethelbright he turnde agein, & telde hym how þey hadde disdeyn To bowe ought to þe Englische bouwe on to þe Englis. (For lines 15,329-3, Wace has "Al roi Aldebar le mostra," ii. 257, l. 14,305.) blod, Or til any þat wolde þem god. Þe kyng wrathed þer-wyþ-al, & seide til Austyn, "fonde y schal " Þat oure kynde, þat now are ayres, ere heires. . " Schal do þem bowe, maugre þayres." He sente his sonde þenne als so quik/ In to þe northe, to þe kynge Ekfrik, Ekfrith. (Elfroi, MS. du Roi, 27; Elfrit, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé: Wace , ii. 258, l. 14,308.) & bad hym come wyþ alle hyse Þat til hym dide any seruise, & telde how '[þey] þei. of Kerlyoun ' And þey of Bangor, wyþoute resoun ' Han despised al þer kyn, ' ffor þem forsaken seint Austyn, ' Ne til hym nold bowe on none wyse, ' But al for vs gan hym despise.' He sente aboute for alle þer kynde ll. 15,344-15,347. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Of þe Englische þat þey might fynde. At Leycestre made þey somonynge, samnyng. Of southe souht. & northe, ilka kyng; Terme þey sette to make þem &yogh;are So forth in to Walys to fare. Brochivail or Brochmail , or Brochinail (Brocival, MS. du Roi, 27; Bro|china, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé Wace , ii. 258, l. 14,327). wyþ þe Bretons held, De Comite Leycestrie. Of Leycestre he bar þe scheld; He had don þe Bretons somoune . Þorow þe contre, fro toun to toune, Ageyn þenglische þe Englis. for to go. But þe Bretons were al to fo; Brochiuail was þer desconfit; Til a wode he fledde ful tyt, & his men were slayn al doun; Þe kyng Elfryk wan þe toun. Monk & heremite, ilk a tail . Þat hadde þer hope on Brochiuail, Alle were þey don to swerd, Lered & lewed, al so lewed & lered mad ferd. ferd. De Occisione Monachorum. Þe monkes þat were of at. Bangor Bysoughte þe kyng wyþ herte sor Þat he wold haue on þem mercy, & of þe kirke saue þe clergy; Þey preied alle, monk & clerk, Chanon, heremite, man of werk, Riche & pore, alle barefot. ffor al þer preiere fond þey no bot; On hem were þe Englische ful feloun, Þe ouer hand hadde, fel als þe lyoun, Monk ne clerk wolde þey non spare, P. leaves out this line. ffor þe[y] byforn vnbuxom ware; P. leaves out this line. Of prest ne clerk gaf mad. þey no kep, Namore þan wolf doþ of þe schep; Ouer mykel was þeir ire, Of so fele to make martire; Two þousand, & two hundred mo, So manie of þem dide þey slo. Syn seide þey þat þey wolde wende, Bangor to struye, & brynge til ende; But &yogh;it þey seide þey wilde abide, . To purueye þeym when þey wold suld. ryde.
text.263: ¶ De Morte Augustini Anno Domini .Dc.iiij to . See Bede's Eccles. Hist. bk. ii. ch. 3 To Caunterbire cam seint Austyn, Þer he deide, & made his fyn; He deide &yogh;yt er seint Gregori, . A &yogh;er byforn, als seyþ þe story; þe date of Crist, to telle fro, Sex hundred &yogh;er, & foure MS. fyue ; but see line 15,398, and lines 15,403, 15,406. P. has rightly four. mo; In his liue was his ordinaunce, . In his stede bischop Laurance. When seint Gregore passed his lyue, P. leaves out this line. Þe date was sex hundred &yogh;er & fyue. P. leaves out this line. When Ethelbright had regned her . In Kent syx & fifty &yogh;er, He was byried ful solempnely, sollemly. & dame Berke was leid is laid. hym by. Twelf &yogh;er after sent Austyn . Lyued Ethelbright er he made hys fyn; Þe date of Crist þus fele to mene, neuen. Sex hundred & euen fiftene. & sextene. . Ethelbrightes sone highte Edbalde, Þe righte feyþ wolde he nought halde; His wikkednesse ys to mene; To Iust & Mellite dide he tene; He & Sygbertes sones segbert sons. þre, . In to ffraunce dide þem fle. Edbal, þorow Edbald þorgh. a vision He knew wel he had mis-don, & þorow þe byschop Lauraunce . He hadde on Crist god affiaunce. Þre of Sygbertes sones Segebert sonnes. were slayn, Þe bischopes come to londe agayn. Wace, ii. 260, l. 14,365. Bretons of Walys herde wel how Þat þe Englische þe Englis þer. monkes slow; Þey gadered þem to consail How for. to venge þat tyrpayl. Þre noble men were in þat cite, . Þo þre made a gret semble; Þo þre weren alle kynges, & of þe Bretons lordynges: Bledryk, of Cornewaille was sire, & lord ouer al Deueneschire, Lietesire, MS. du Roi, 27; Nevesire, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé: Wace , ii. 261, l. 14,372. Als þe water of Ex rennes ffro þe hed,—þer men hit kennes,— Vnto þe se þer hit gos yn; Longe helden hit þe Bretons kyn, Euere til Adelston cam; He dide þat kynde mykel scham. ll. 15,429-15,434. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. ¶ Of Northe Walys, Cadwan was kynge, & Mergadu of Southe Walys of south wales Margadu was. lordyng; Al was hit þeires vntil was þeirs vnto. Seuerne, Byside þe hille of Maluerne. But Athelstan, þorow force & eye, He drof [þem] by&yogh;onde þe water of Weye. Drofe þam bi&yogh;ond þe water a weie. Bledrik, Margadu, & Cadwan, Ost þey gadered of mania manya. (Cp. manion , the on and a being treated as part of the ad|jective.) man. Englische, Englis. Saxons, þey assailled, & þe Englische Englis. þem sore trauailled. Elfrik was wounded, þe deþ þat. he dredde, In feld[e] he gaf bak, & fledde; ffele of his were þere slayn, . But he ascaped wyþ gret payn:— (Sire Bledryk of Cornewaille, He was slayn in þat bataille);— No wonder þey hym yuel bitid, þof him ill bitide. . He had no mercy þat mercy cryd. cride. Of þe monkes y telde biforn; Wyþoute withouten. mercy were þey lorn. Syre Cadwan & Margadu Cadwan Rex Brytonum. Gadred hostes, & bostes blew; To Leycestre boþe þey went, & helden þere a parlement. Þorow comun conseil of elde & &yogh;yng, Ches þey Cadwan þer kynge. Þenne bolded faste þe Bretons, & Cadwan MS. Cadwam. sente aboute his. somons To þe Englische Englis. kynges in alle contres . On þys half Humber þat held þer fes, & 'but þey wolde til him MS. þem. P. wild to him. (þem might stand for þe Bretons of l. 15,461.) cheue, 'On oþer halue he schold þem greue.'
text.264: Tranquillitas facta est inter Reges. (Written along the top of this page (66) of the MS.) Þey seye hit was non oþer bote; Þey come & fulle fell. Cadwan to fote, Þat ys to seye, made hym feaute, & he þer alder chef schuld aller chefe to. be;— I hope al com þem þat wo, . ffor þe monkes þey dide so slo.— Cadwan seide he wolde passe Humber, Elfrik to struye & to comber; Elfrik for to bring to komber. Northumberland al wold he struye, he wild destroie. & al þer kynde for þem schold kyng [with a little d over the g ] for him. noye, Oþer oiþer. in bataille he schold hym slo, Or do hym fle þe reome fro. Elfrik herde his manace, . How to wo he wolde hym chace; He assembled gadred togidir. his barons Þat Englische were, & þe Saxons. Englis wer & sessons. Grete ostes were on ilka syde: Wise men þer were dide þem abyde, Li gentil home del païs, Wace , ii. 263, l. 14,423. & ilkon seyde his auis Þat frendes hadde on boþe partis: " &yogh;yf þyse kynges to-gidere smite, " Þe sorewe til fele wyl nought be lyte; " Non of vs schal neuere more P. leaves out this line. " Þe grete los ageyn restore; P. leaves out this line. " Þer-fore y rede we fonde to abate . " Þys kynges wrathes, þer ire & wrath þat now is. hate." & so þey dide right als þey redde; ffrom on til oþer so wel þey spedde, Þat þey boþe grauntede þe pes; To make hit syker, ostage þey ches. Al þer richesse rightes. for to saue, Þey sette þe lond, what ilk schulde wilk it suld. haue: ffro Humber, northe, Elfryk schuld be, Cadwan fro þeþen al fro þien. þe southe contre: Þus was departed ilka scheld, & þat pes ful wel þey held; ffor neuere was loue of lordynges So mikel as was bytwyxt þo kynges; Þat þet on hadde, þey hadde hit bothe, P. leaves out this line. Noþyng mighte make þem loþe; P. leaves out this line. Wyues þey toke, þer loues to ferme, boþe at a terme. Two sones had þey at o terme; þei had þer luf to ferme. Elfrykes sone highte Eadwyn, Cadwanes sone highte Cadwalyn; In o &yogh;er were þey born. ffor þe pees schold nought be lorn, Dide þey þer sones to-gedere &yogh;eme; Þat þe ton þat oþer schulde queme, In on þei were clad & fed, Of o maister lered & led; & when þey were waxen on elde, P. transposes lines 15,517-18. Armes to bere, & wepne bere wapen. to welde, P. transposes lines 15,517-18. & þem self wyþ wit couþe lede, Scheld to bere, & ride on stede, In to Bretayne dide þem sende, ffor whi þer loue schulde more Faithly þer luf to. amende; ffor þer was Cadwanes kynde, . Of Maximiens conqueste, conquest of Maximian. we fynde; Þere were þey knyghted boþe to-gyder, & dwelled þer til þei come hider. When tyme was þer fadres schuld deye, De Morte Regum. By messegers þei herdit herd. seye; . Ouer se þey hadde passage, & receyued þer heritage. ffrendes þey were þe firste two &yogh;er, Als þer fadres loueden her, lufed here. & helde þer landes als þey or lay Departed by þer fadres day; Eadwyn fro Humber northward, Þe southe was Cadwalynes part;— But Cadwalyn had mo & betere cites, & larger londes and rentes of rent. & fees Þan Edwyn hadde, by mikel þynge; . Þe southe þer-fore was chef kynge, & coroune bar ouer þem ilkon, & alle þe oþere schulde bere non. Coronacio Cadwalini. At Cadwalynes coronement, Alle kynges til his feste went. Sire Edwyn þere hym by-þought, Australes semper dominabant Boriales. Cadwalyn of a bone bysought, & preied hym þat he mighte be Wyþ leue corouned in his contre. . Þys bisoughte þe kyng Eadwyn, To haue leue of Cadwalyn. ' Conseil,' seid Cadwalyn, 'he schuld take; ' Als conseil gaf, so schulde men make; " But y schal wite what ys to done, " & þou schalt haue answere right an ansuere. sone." Afterward, no þrowe ne no while. was, Þei mette atte water of Douglas, To conseille þem, & to wyte How þat þyng best mighte site. Bytwyxt þem was þe water, y wene, & messegers &yogh;ede ay by-twene. Manie skiles forþ were cast, How hit mighte be mad studefast. As Cadwalyn of his hors doun lyght, An heuinesse, a &. gret vnmight, On Cadwalyn gan to lepe, Þat nede most he þer right nedely behoued him. slepe, Brian kept hym als he lay, Hys cosyn, þat was in kosyn & had. (ses niès Brians, Wace , ii. 266, l. 14,505.) gret affray Of 'þat þat Edwyn hadde bysought, ' Þat neuere or byfore was wrought, '& now wil graunte swyche a foly, . 'To lowe his stat þat or was hey.' & als he his lord kept/, Ouer hys heued ful sore he wept, Þat wyþ þo teres þat he let, Made he þe kynges hed al his lord hede. wet. ffor sorewe & sobbynge, Brian quoke, So þat his lorde þer-wyþ a-woke, & he byheld Bryan fast. . Þe kyng had wonder, & was agast: ogast. " Brian," he seide, "what tydinge now? " What eilest eiles. þe? why gretes þow?" " No wonder," seyd Bryan, "þaw y grete, " &yogh;e ar in wyl &yogh;our worschip to lete. " In no kynges tyme here byforn " Was þe croune so mykel or lorn mykell lorn. " Als hit ys now in point to be; " How hit schal turne, wel y hit se. " Of oure auncestres, ilka Bretoun " Byfore alle oþere bere of all holy had. þey þe croun; " & now y drede hit schal nought .I. hope it sall not. so; " Þat or was on, now schal be two. " Þe hole coroune þat or had on, " &yogh;yf hit be two, y telle hit gon. " Þyse Englische sc[h]ul haue Englis sall haf. so gret pride, . " Þat wo schal waxe on ilka syde; " ffor þer kynde so ryst kynde rises. on heyghte, " Þat non of oures dar wyþ þem feighte; " Syn Malgo tyme was no kyng . " Þat myghte of hem wynne any þynge; " & now ys Edwyn so wel wyþ þe, " Coroune to bere, þer non schuld be. " & y se &yogh;e þenke nought . " What þey til oure kynde han wrought: " Þey slowe þe kyng Aurelius, " & so þey þenke þat þey schul vs; " And certeinly ful wel þey may, . " ffor Bretons power gos faste away; " Syn Arthur deyde here byforn, " Þe scheld of Bretayne has ben lorn."
text.265: ¶ Cadwalanus dixit Bryano. Þe kyng listned what Bryan seide, . & in his herte ful wel hit leyde: " ffor þyng þat þou hast greten sore, " So schal hit tyde neuer so ne sall it tide no. more. " Þat hol was, hol schal byleue, . " Þe hole coroune non schal me right croune sall .I. not reue. reue." Til Edwyn he sente bode hastif, 'Þat als he wolde his loue & lyf, as he will in luf haf life. 'He schulde namore suld no more. þer-of speke, ' Þe coroune wolde he neuere breke, ' Ne his conseil wolde nought consent ' To suffre non oþer corounement/; ' Hit were neyþer reson ne lawe, ' Þat on was, by elde dawe, ' & now schulde be gyuen to two, ' So for hym schuld hit neuere go; " Hit schal ben hol, als sall be hole þat. now ys; " ffor/ me ne schal hit neuer be less; " Ne here no lenger wyl y lende, " But in to Walys wil y wende." ¶ Eadwyn was ffel & proud; Til hys messager he seyde a loud: o loude. " Schal y neuere eft hym byseke, " Ne þer-fore bowe, ne be meke; " Swilk ffraunchise y schal haue frenschip .I. sall haf. here, " & als he haþ, þe same manere." Cadwalyn seide, 'but &yogh;yf he left, ' Wyþ force hit schulde ben hym refte.' On þys manere parted þey boþe, & neuere frend, but euere wroþe. Edwyn þer-on was ful brym, To &yogh;ork he &yogh;ede, & corounded crouned. hym. Als Cadwalyn was in Wales, . Of þys was teld hym many tales, Þat Edwyn for þys despit Dide hym coroune al so tyt. MS. tys. P. did croune him so tite. Cadwalyn herd hit sone seye; whan kadwalyn herd it say. Til Humber wiþ host he tok þe weye, & on Edwyn gan to renne, Men to slo, tounes to brenne. Edwyn he þoughte desherite, . & &yogh;yf he mighte, his heued of smite; But Edwyn was of ful gret wille, He wolde nought fle for drede ne wild fle not for dede no. ille, Ne he wolde neyþer trewe nouþer wild he treus. ne pees; Bataille he wolde, & þer-to ches. Wyþ Cadwaly so harde he met, & Cadwalyn fley atte ferste fled at þe first. set; Toward þe southe he wolde haue fled, P. leaves out this line. But Edwyn his weye wyþ-sperd; P. leaves out this line. & Cadwalyn fley hym byside, for Edwyn lette his way þat tide. P. transposes this line and the next. In busches & wodes hym for in to wodes him. to hyde; By sties & bi outen (out-paths; cp. by|paths). paþes þat he fond, So he fley in to Scotlond, & euere Edwyn after fley. Cadwalyn, gret pyne he drey; A schip he tok, til Irlond went, But Edwyn mighte hym neuere hent, But schop hym swyþe wiþ alle bot suyth in to þe south did. haste, Cadwalynes londes for to waste. Casteles dide he bete right doun, P. leaves out this line. Contres destruied, toun by toun; P. leaves out this line. Al his lond he þorow &yogh;ede, P. leaves out this line. Til alle he dide sorewe & drede. P. leaves out this line. Of Bryanes sister men hym told, At Wircestre scheo was in hold; Edwyn þere hure out þien hir. toke, To &yogh;ork he sent hure for to loke; Wyþ his wyf scheo was seruaunt/, . Mayden gentil & auenaunt/. In þys kynges court, Edwyn, Was a clerk couþe of deuin; De Pellitho Sortilego. ffer in Spayne was he born, Of chaunces couþe he telle byforn; He knew alle þe foules cry, al vol des oisiax volans, Wace , ii. 270, l. 14,602. & couþe y-now of astronomy. Pellith highte þat ilke clerk, . He serued Edwyn of god werk; ffor Cadwalyn myghte neuere, for wele ne wo, No tyme in hauen to schipe go, Ne in se hiderward ryde,— . ffel hit neuere so god a tyde,— Þat þys ilke þat ne þis. clerk deuyn Als swiþe teld hit Teld it euer. til Edwyn. He knew alle manere roun, . & many manere coniurison, & mani chaunces couþe descrie By sciences & artz of clergye. þorgh quantise & clergie. De infortuniis Cadwalini. ¶ Cadwalyn was ofte on fflote Wyþ many fair[e] schip on schote, & wel þe wynd gan hym dryue Vp vntil þys lond to arryue; But euere Edwyn cam hym byforn, Þat his trauaile was euere lorn, & al was þorow þe clerkes engyn, þis clerk engyne. Þat warned ay þe kyng Edwyn. Cadwalyn hadde sorewe & site Þat he was ay at desconfite; ay discomfite. & manie oþere sore hit ment, Þat out of londe wyþ hym were went, & fur-&yogh;eden lond & lyth, P. leaves out these lines. ( fur|&yogh;eden went by, gave up: Stratmann , p. 212). Þat wyþ hym byde many wo sith. P. leaves out these lines. ( fur|&yogh;eden went by, gave up: Stratmann , p. 212). To þem he seyde, 'he wilde wende ' Til lytel-Bretayne to seke frende: " Wiþ þe kyng Salamon woldy with kyng Salmon will .I. speke; . " He may me helpe my bale to wreke. " He &yogh;erneþ me to se & haue; " Somme of mine &yogh;yt may he saue." Infirmacio Cadwalini. He sailed al day, & on þe nyght, Vmwhile boþe wrong & ryught, right. Til he com in-til an ilde, ' Gernet,' Gerneron, Wace , ii. 271, l. 14,626. a litel land ful wilde; No lond nyster L. nyster = ne ys þer. ferrere west, P. leaves out this line. Þer þe sonne goþ to rest; P. leaves out this line. By-twyxt Bretayne & Cornewaille Is þat ilde wyþouten faille. & bynne a while þat he cam No while ne was he. þore, Þe kyng iueled swyþe þat þe kyng euelid. sore; Þe ffeuere agu ful sore hym agew þat him wele. hatte; But sone he chared, & wel swatte; Dont cil retorne ki bien sue, Wace , ii. 271, l. 14,634. Venison he &yogh;erned sore he &yogh;arned. to ete, He ne mighte wiþ non oþer mete. Þe kyng comaunded til Brian— He nadde non oþer leches man— Þat he schulde seke hym suld gete him. venisoun, . Or hys iuel schulde brynge els his euell suld bring. hym doun: " But &yogh;yf þat y som venison haue, " No þyng so sone may me saue; " Hit ys no tale wher-of hit be, P. leaves out this line. " But þat þou mightest gete hit me." P. leaves out this line.
text.266: De gratitudine Briany. Brian hadde ful gret longyng P. leaves out this line. ffor to saue his em þe kyng, P. leaves out this line. & took þo men þat were wont Go to chace, & &yogh;ede to hont. 2 Þey soughte þe dales & þe playnes, Þey soughte busche & montaynes, & þorow mores & þorow lynde: 2 2-2 For these three lines P. has one:— þei sauh dales & &yogh;orgh þe lynde. ffond þey neuere hert ne nouþer herte no. hynde, Ne wilde bor, ne bukke ne do, Ne hare, cony, ffowen, no ne conyng foune ne. ro. Þen hadde Brian sorewe ynow, & seide, "how schal myn em fare, how, " Þat y may no venison fynde?" But he dide als a man ful kynde; He schar a pece out of his þe, thee. & lardid & rostoid, lard it & roste. as fel to be, & dightit dight It. for þe kyng right wel, & he et hit ilk a del, Jo ne sai se il en gosta, Mais il gari et respassa. Wace , ii. 272, l. 14,661-2. And passed wel þo þat hache; wele þat age. . So swete a mete neuer or et he. When þe kyng felte hym of might, Þer schipes alle to þe se he dight, & aryued vp at a toun— ' Achidalet' En Quidelès, MS. du Roi, 27; a Kindelet, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé: Wace , ii. 272, l. 14,665. was þe name Breton; &yogh;yt men seyþ after þe flod P. leaves out this and the following line. Wace has for them— Entre Dunan [Dinan] et la marine, Et encore i pert la ruine. ii. 273, l. 14,667-8 Men knowes þere þe toun stod.— Þe kyng welcomed Cadwalyn, . & ofte compleyned his mikel pyn; & his in, to make soiour, He dide hym haue at grete honur; ll. 15,769-15,770. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. & hight hym 'he schulde in a stounde ' Helpym help. to brynge Edwyn to grounde: . " But certes, meruaille y haue " Þat grete Bretayne may &yogh;e nought saue. " fful wel kept hit Sire Belyn, . " & Maximian & Co[n]stantyn, " And Lucius dide vs Cristen be,— " But Arthur ys ded, wel may men wele .I. se,— " Þey lore þe les. neuere a foot of land. . " Myn heritage y holde in hand; " So woldy þat þou didest þyn " Ageyn þe Englische paen Edwyn." Cadwalyn seide sire Salamon, " Oure kynde conqueste is longes our kynges conquested long is. gon. . " Wite þou wel þo conquerrours " Were myn auncestres & &yogh;ours, " & ve[n]iaunce fel on many fele. of þo, . " Þat of þer blod cam na no. mo: " On riche men hit [is] a veniaunce, " Childre to gete þat haue no chaunce; ll. 15,789-15,790. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line.
text.267: ¶ De translacione nature Brytonum. " Þenne goþ heritage out of kynde; . " When nought of þe blod men fynde, " Þen schul men gyue hit for good " To þem þat han hated al þe blod. ll. 15,791-15,794. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line.
text.268: De lamentacione & planctu Cadwalini ad Salamonem. " Lucius þat brought vs Cristendam, . " Non heir of his body cam; " Aliens had hit after hym, " Þat til oure kynde were ful brym. " Co[n]stantyn & Maximian, . " Non heir of þer body haire of þam ne. ran; " Ne Arthur, þe noble kynge, " Of his body cam no þynge, " Ne of Conan, ne of Vortapus, . " Ne Malgo, ne of Caricius; " Of alle þise, heires com þer heire was. non, " But out of kynde ys hit al gon; " ffor God hit wolde þat þey non hadde, . " Þat synfully þeir lyues ladde,— in alle synnes þer lyfe þei lad. " Þey vsede alle manere synnes, P. leaves out this line. " ffor synful lyf oure kynde blynnes,— P. leaves out this line. " Ne God wil namore þat þey be . " Keperes of þat dignete."— Sire Gildas writes & seyþ þe same, Not in our present Gildas's works or life, or in Nennius. Þer-fore am y nought for to blame.— Al þe wynter þer he lay, & purueid hym fro day to day ffolk & schipes for to gete, Opon þe se to haue a fflete.
text.269: De Briano. At the side in the MS., two lines higher. In þys þat þey made purueaunce, Bryan seyde 'he wolde o chaunce ' Til Ingelond wende priuely, ' &yogh;yf he by sleyghte [Pellith] mighte come if he Pellith mot com. by; " ffor also longe as he ys on lyue, " In Ingelond may we neuere arryue; " ffor he can telle þorow his art, " Whider we wile, & to what part." Bryan auntred auentured. hym al in drede, . But God hym gaf wel for to spede. At Barbeflet a barbflete. to schipe he went, At Southaumptone hauene he hent; ffaire cloþes wolde he non ne wild he. were, But dightym al lyke to Bot dight als. a beggere; A schort staf he dide hym make, Als palmeres in handes take, & dide þer-inne a wel longe full gode. pyk P. transposes lines 13,835-6. Squar grounden, scharp, euenlyk; P. transposes lines 13,835-6. He feyned hym croked many a tyme, As he hadde longe ben a pylgrime; He let hym al[s] he had ben lened him as he were. ( let : cp. A.-S. læ¯tan to pretend (Bosworth), se gerere (Stratmann). wery, . & al-wey spirde & spired after þe kyng. priuely; After þe kyng he spird vm-while, P. leaves out this line. ffor non hoped til hym no gyle. P. leaves out this line. So queyntely aboute hym about he. wond, Þe kynges court at &yogh;ork he fond; He dide hym þere among þe poraille, Wyþ bagge & burdon of þeir entaille; Wyþ hem he stod, wiþ hem he wente, . But euere his eye & as his I&yogh;e. o syde he glente; He saw his sister wyþ a bacyn, Water for to feche þer-in. & Brian stirt forþ in hure weye, & stille stilly. seide þat he wolde seye. When scheo hym knew, sche gan to grete; He seide "Þy gretyng I rede þou lete, " ffor &yogh;yf any man me aparceiue, . " ffro þe deþ may y nought weyue; " Þer-fore þou lete now al þy mone, Quomodo Brianus occidit Pellitum sortilegum. " & drawe vs by oure self al one." ll. 15,8853-15,858. The Petyt MS. leaves out this line. Þey &yogh;ede out of þe pres a lite, Þat non ne scholde hem se ne of þam mot se no. wite. He asked after þe clerk Pellith: Wiþ þat he com þer also tyt. " Lo!" scheo seide, "wher he comeþ here!" & telde of Pellit al þe teld him all pellith. manere. " Haue god day," þen saide Bryan; " Do þyn erende as þou bygan." Toward Pellit he gan hym hye, . ffro hym ne lefte he neuere his eye: of him com neuer his I&yogh;e. Pellit among þe pouere &yogh;ede, Als he schulde haue bet þer nede, To & fro euere als a fool; & Bryan folewede him ay on hool, him on hoole. And right in al & amang. þe moste pres, Among þem alle, Pellit he ches; His staf ful sleyly staffe priuely. vp he warp, & putte þe longe pyk so scharp Ageyn þe herte, in at þe bak, Þat he fel doun; no word ne spak/; Cried he neyþer wo ne way, P. leaves out this line. . But ded he was, & þer he lay. P. leaves out this line. Brian lefte his staf right lete þe staffe lig. þere, & drow o syde, as nought & &yogh;ede beside als nouh. ne were, & as queyntely as he might, P. leaves out this line. O drey he held hym out of sight; P. leaves out this line. Among þe pore he hidde his face, & sleyly wroughte, sleih he was. & hadde fair grace. Al þat ilke day he sculked, Among þe pouere men folk. he hulked; When þe night cam, he was ful fayn, His wey he tok to þe gate he toke. south a-gayn. What day, what night, boþe nyght & day. (Que nuit que jor tant trespassa, MS. du Roi, 73, Cangé: Wace , ii. 276, note ( b ).) ful faste he spedde, Þat til Oxenforde algate he redde. A Sesecestre vint sor Esse, Wace , ii. 276, l. 14,755. Þen com þe folk wyþouten sesse ses . . . . . pres. Aboute Brian for to presse; ses . . . . . pres. Þe Bretons alle, & þe of & of. Cornewaille, . & out of Walys cam gret & of wales þe. pedaille; Þey frayned hym faste 'when & askid him wheþen. he cam, ' & whider he wilde, and to wham; " & what nede ys now in hande P. leaves out this line. " Þat Cadwalyn comeþ nought to lande? P. leaves out this line. " And where he ys, we preye þe telle, " And wheþer he schal come or dwelle." " Sertes," he seide, "wyþynne a þrowe " &yogh;e schul wel vnderstande & knowe " Þat Edwyn schal nought dur abyde, " But &yogh;if bot a. mischaunnce hym by-tyde. " But warnische casteles, do make toures, " ffor &yogh;ow schal sone come socoures." Of alle þe grete moste. he wiste þer wille; Þer-fore ful baldely boldly. & stille Dide he vitaille þe toun Essecestre, Wace , ii. 277, l. 14,775. ful wel, . Defensable wyþ bretaxes bretask. & pel. He sente hys em a messeger, & telde al on what maner Þat he had slayn þe clerke Pellyt, Stored Oxenforde til his profit. Of þat bode þe kyng was paied, His wendyng was nought delayed; Night & day made hym redy; Ten þousand he hadde til his nauy, What of hise owen, & what of his what. of ffrendes Þat kyng Salamon þat Salmon. wiþ hym sendes. When Cadwalyn þat he. was al &yogh;are, . Til he was forþe, gret was his care; At Totenesse he gan vp ryue; Glad was þe folk he was on lyue; & gret sorewe made þe kyng Edwyn Þat slayn was so þe clerk Pēllyn. ¶ Penda, þe kyng of Lyndeseye, Melcie, Wace , ii. 278, l. 14,791. How Bryan dide, he herde wel seye; Gret force of folk Penda dide fet, Cadwalyn for to wyþ-set. Oxenforde Essecestre, Wace , ii. 278, l. 14,797. he byseged aboute, But Brian heldym wel wyþoute. When Cadwalyn was ryued on lande, Til hym cam ful smert tydande ' Þat an Englische kyng Penda ' Byseged Bryan, & was his fa.' Cadwalyn was al an-ired; enired. To rescowe Brian he desired; Als faste as All þat. he mighte, he hasted; Iornes to make, folk he tasted; & when he was þe toun ought ney, . He bad þem reste þat were wery: " Rest &yogh;ou now restes &yogh;ow. for &yogh;oure trauaille; " Þe smertloker smertlier. &yogh;e may assaille." Þe folk of Oxenforde were þe toun was. glade Of þe ioye þat & grete Ioy. Brian made; Gret ioie þer was, Ioy he had. he was so ner, & more of his grete power.
text.270: De remotu obsidionis, & capcione Pende Regis. Cadwalyn was fel of hert, Þe sege he assailled smert; ffor he had longe be born a-bak/, Þe hertiloker fellier. on þem he brak/; He douted neyþer deþ ne noiþer dede no. dynt/. Þat tyme was many a man þer tynt/; Hertly felli. were þey halden waken; And Penda, maugre hym, his. was taken, And smertly don in syker hold; ffor no raunsom might he be sold, Ne for no man loþ ne leue, But he wolde to Cadwalyn cheue, & holde of hym his heritage, & don hym feaute & With feaute & with. homage. When Penda hadde to Cadwalyn Obliged hym, & mad his fyn; More loue to make, & bate stryfe, Pendas Penda. sister he tok to wyfe, And wedded hure on Cristen lawe. To god migh[t] noman Penda drawe; As was Penda yuel Penda was euer ill. in dede, . As telleþ so sais. þe boke of seint Bede. Eccles. Hist. bk. ii., ch. 20, A.D. 633. But see Bede's partial praise of Penda in bk, iii., ch. 21. ¶ Cadwalyn þanked his barons, & nameliche of nameli. þe Bretons, Of al þer trauaille & al þer ylle Þat þey had þoled wiþ gode wille; Al he schulde auaunce þer lore Þat þey had lost for hym byfore; & alle þo þat dide hym noye, Of hem he gan ful faste destruye; He passed þe Humber wyþ folk ynow, Tounes brente, & men he slow.
text.271: De occisione Edwyny & filiorum eius. This heading is at the side in the MS., five lines higher. ¶ Of his comyng Edwyn herd seye, . How he nought spared in his weye; He gadered alle his retenauntz, retenance . . . . . sergeance. Knyghtes, squiers, & seriauntz, retenance . . . . . sergeance. & alle oþer þat of hym held, And comen alle in-til Hatfeld; Hatfield, in the West Riding of Yorkshire, about seven miles north|east of Doncaster. Giles, note to Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. ii., ch. 20 [A.D. 633]. Wace calls it Elfede, ii. 280, l. 14,847. Þyder þey samned, boþe partys, Þat longe had be stronge enemys. Penda þat schrewe, þe þat ilk. Sarazyn, . To helpe he com wyþ He com to help. Cadwalyn. & Edwyn was hardy & bold, And eighte & fourty &yogh;er was Auht & fourti wynter. old; Þer was he slayn, hys sone hym wyth, A god knyght, was cald Osfryth. MS. Offrith and Offriht. P. Osfrith in both cases. Esfris, Wace , ii. 280, l. 14,852. Elleuen &yogh;er was Edwyn kynge Er þan he tok his cristnyng; & þer-inne two wyues he tok . Er he þe Paen lawe fur-sok; Gwenburghe, þe ferste highte so, Wyþ hure had he childre two; Osfriht MS. Offrith and Offriht. P. Osfrith in both cases. Esfris, Wace , ii. 280, l. 14,852. & Eadfrith, þus þey highte, . & knyghtes were þey boþe wyghte. Dame Ethelburgh highte þat oþer, Þe kyng of Kent was hure broþer, See Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. ii., ch. 9 [A.D. 625]. Sire Ethelbright hure fader was, . Þat we byforn han rad in pas. Seint Bede spekeþ sais. of þys Edwyn, Syn he fursok þe lawe Sarazyn, So god a Cristen kyng was non P. transposes the couplets, lines 16,011-2, and 16,013-4. . In al þis lond als he alon; See Bede, bk. ii., ch. 16, and Pope Honorius's letter to Edwin, in Bede, bk. ii., ch. 17. He was cristned o þe Pasche day, At &yogh;ork fursok his Paen lay; Syx hundred &yogh;er þe date was þo, data . & passed seuene & twenty mo; Emfled, his doughter born, Sche was cristned a &yogh;er byforn. ll. 16,017-16,018. The Petyt MS. leaves out these lines. See Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. ii. ch. 9 [A.D. 626]. Whan he þe Cristendam þoughte our cristendom gon. take, . Þe kirke of &yogh;ork he dide first make; But longe er hit was brought til are it were brouht to. ende, He was slayn wyþ folk vnhende; But seint Osewald, þat gode man, . He ended þat Edwyn bygan. Bede, Eccl. Hist. , bk. ii. ch. 20. Sire Edwyn was syx &yogh;er Cristen kyng in þys lond her: What cristen, what heþen þral, P. leaves out this line. . Seuentene &yogh;er he regned in al; P. leaves out this line. Þat selue &yogh;er Oswy þat &yogh;ere þai he. was slayn, His cosyn Osfry MS. Offry. P. Osri. y þe same payn, Þe &yogh;eres of Crist six hundred wore, . & þrytty &yogh;er, & þre more; Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. ii. ch. 20. But he doesn't give Oct. 4: says only "before" Edwin's death on Oct. 12. Þe ferþe day þat ys y þe ides Of Octobre, ho so hit bydes. Þer he lay, a chapel ys wrought, P. leaves out this line. . & &yogh;it ys þer folk þat þyder han sought. P. leaves out this line. Of Cadwalyn now schal we seye; He slow þe kyng of Orkeneye, Sire Cadan, & sire Gabaon,— . Þe Scottische kyng was þat on,— & manie oþere lordes mo, ffor wham whilk. was mad ful mykel wo. Cadwalyn hadde neuere mercy Of Edwynes Edwyn. (Wace says generally, of those "Qui contre lui orent esté," ii. 280, l. 14,858.) kynde he mighte com by; Man & woman he slow al day, P. leaves out these lines. See Bede, Eccl. Hist. , bk. ii. ch. 20. & childre þat in þe cradel lay; P. leaves out these lines. See Bede, Eccl. Hist. , bk. ii. ch. 20. Alle he slow hem, The MS. m has one stroke too many. olde slouh alde. & &yogh;onge, . Þat til Edwyn teld told. any tonge. &yogh;yt of Edwyn was left on quik, MS. quit. P. quik. Hys emes sone Eame sōn. See Bede, Eccl. Hist. , bk, iii. ch. 1. þat highte Osrik/, Þat rescowed resceyued. þe heritage; . But luytel held he hit in age, ffor Cadwalyn wrought hym so wow, His two cosyns & hym he slow; Þowh al he hadde Crysten feyþ, P. leaves out this line. . To þo Crysten he dide ouer leyþ, P. leaves out this line. Þat &yogh;ong & olde, al &yogh;ede to ded, P. leaves out this line. ffor o man þat hym mys bed. P. leaves out this line. Seint Bede blames Cadwalyn; . Of wille he calles hym 'barbaryn,' Bede, Eccl. Hist. , bk. ii. ch. 20. See p. 578, l. 16,672-4, below. — 'Barbaryn' ys a Sarazyn is sarezin. straunge, To mercy þat wil nere turne ne chaunge;— ffor al þe werd, world. so ferde he, . On lyue wolde he non let be. Þat slaughter lasted so gret stounde, Vnneþes a Cristen man men founde, But turnde vnto þe lawe Paen, . Þat er was brought to be Cristen, Vnto þe tyme of seint Osewalde,. Þat þe feiþ a-geyn MS. a geym. P. agayn. dide halde; Vnto þe reame he hadde right, . And was ful Of wille. fre, & gentil knyght; He sente for þe bischop Aydan, Bede, Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 3. Of Scotland was þat gode man; Þat bischop cam, his folk to preche, . Þer Cristendam fro Paen wreche. to reche.
text.272: De Miraculo Sancti Osewaldy. This heading is at the side in the MS., three lines higher. Of þys Osewald, seint Bede telles, & manye of his miracles spelles; Of on to telle, It is in bk. iii. ch. 6, of Giles's edition of Bede. See too William of Malmesbury, bk. i. ch. 3. mykel y charge, . Þat how. he vnto þe pore was large. Þe pore folk spirde, & men þem tolde Wher Osewald schulde hys Pasche holde. O þe Pasche day in tyme of mete, . Þe pouere gaderede, god to gete; &, right as þe borde was leyd, Þe cloþ[es] spred, þe graces seyd, Þey serued þe kyng in a seluer dische— . Wiþ what mete y ne wot y-wys.— His aumener Ambner. (so.) stod þe kyng before, & seide þat so. 'manie pouere were þore, " & &yogh;yt þer comen on ilka syde, . " Of &yogh;oure almes our almos. help to byde." Þan tok þe kyng þat he schuld ete, & brak þe dische wyþ al þe mete, & bad hym parte hit a-mong Bad him departe amang. hem alle, . Boþe mete & syluer, as hit wold þe siluer as best wild. falle. ¶ Aydan sey how þe kyng hit brak/; Dixit Aydanus: 'non in|'ueteras|'cat illa 'manus.' Þer-fore til hym þys word he spak: " Nere mote þat hand rote ne elde, " But hol wyþouten ende to welde." & so hit ys right als Non oþer it is bot as. he seyde; In schryne at Peterburgh is hit leyde; At þe abbeye, in þe kirke, . Þe kyng Penda dide hit wirke. Oswald was sib Edwyn byforn; Of Acha his sister was Osewald born; Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 6, at the end. Þer-fore Cadwalyn wilde nought sesse, But faste on Osewald werre gan presse; To Scotland he chased Osewold. Oswald . . . . . bald. ffor Cadwalyn had more folk, & bold, Oswald . . . . . bald. Osewald fledde, & gaf hym place, So þat Cadwalyn left hys chace; His folk hym þoughte trauailled sore, But Penda at þat tyme was þore; He bad hym folewe, Osewald to take, . Or don hym þe lond for-sake. When Osewald wyste þe certeyn, Þat Cadwalyn was turnd ageyn, Ageyn Penda wolde he stande, ffor hym nold he be fleande. In a feld Osewald gan byde, To bide þe bataille what so & stand to chance what mot. bytyde;— ' Heuene-feld' þe name ys cald, Bede, Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 2. "Celestiels cans en françois," adds Wace, ii. 282, l. 14,890. Probably "Bingfield," Northumberland: Madden, in La&yogh;amon , iii. 429. . ffor þe loue of seint Osewald;— In þat feld a crois he lyft/, & bad þem alle nought be aglift/, oglift. But to. come & knele byfore þe crois, And Iesu preye al wyþ o voys, " Þat he þys day stand vs by, " A-geyn Penda, Godes his. enemy, " Þat wyþ wrong vs onoyes, . " & our Cristen men destruyes." & þe cristendom destroies. Alle þey dide as Osewald bad, & preyde Ihesu, þat his blod schad On þe croys for mannes nede, . 'Ageyn Penda wel þat day wele to. spede.' Alle were þey of gode repentaunce, P. leaves out this line. & wel y-schryuen for alle chaunce. P. leaves out this line. Syn sien. þey dight hem to þe bataille, & Penda gan hem faste assaille: His host was gret, & wyde y-spred; Ner were þey slayn, & Penda fled. Penda ascaped wyþ mykel pyn, & pleyned hym vnto Cadwalyn, & seide, 'bot he venge hym wolde, ' Of hym schuld he namore neuer. holde.' At þat tyme þus hit byleft/ . Vntil þey samned þer hostes eft/: Þe bataille was byside Þyrlwal, thirwall. Þat whilom closed þe northende al; þat som tyme closed þe North all. & þere was many myracle schewed, Þat witnesseþ boþe lered & lewed; . Þe cros dide þere many merueilles, P. leaves out these lines. This is the end of the extract from ch. 2, bk. iii., of Bede's Eccl. Hist. Halp man & best of þeir trauailles. P. leaves out these lines. This is the end of the extract from ch. 2, bk. iii., of Bede's Eccl. Hist. De Rege Osewaldo. &YOGH;yt Cadwalyn & þys Penda . Þoughte to wirke Osewald ful wa: Þey gadered hostes, þise enemys, & come on Osewald in twey partys. In a stede hatte Mazerfeld, Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 9. [A.D. 642.] . Þere Osewald schewed schewed Oswald. his scheld, Þere he seyde he wolde abyde. Grete were þer batailles on eyþer grete folk was on ilk a. syde; . ¶ Osewald wyste he schuld þer deye, & mighte nought scape by mot skape on. no weye; De Morte Osewaldy. In his fallynge he seyde on hy, " Of alle our soules, Lord, haue mercy!" Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 12. Þat was þe laste werde he seid, P. leaves out this line. & fel doun, & þer he deyd. P. leaves out this line. Of þo men þat þys word herd, A byword in al þe contre ferd, " God haue our soules! quaþ Osewold." Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 12. . Þys byword was longe y-told, long tald. Þys þey seide at ilka rage, P. leaves out this line. & longe had þey hit in vsage: P. leaves out this line. Þis word witnesseþ wel seynt Bede, P. leaves out this line. . Þat longe was vsed in many lede. P. leaves out this line. Nyne wynter bot nyen &yogh;ere. was he kyng, & eighte auht. See Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 9. & þritty &yogh;er was &yogh;ynge; Þe date of Crist ys told was þan. redy, . Six hundred &yogh;er, & two & fourty. Þyse wikkede kynges men . . . . . slouh . . . . . bouh. þat hym slow, For the short original of the next fifteen lines, see Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 12. Dide henge his lymes on a bow; men . . . . . slouh . . . . . bouh. A tre þey dide sette þer fore; . Handes, armes, þey dide þorow bore; ¶ Hys heued heng a &yogh;er to mone; But Oswy, his broþer, sone sister sonne. De Rege Osewy. Was kyng, & tok þe hed hengand, . & biried hit at ffarnelland; Of an ilde hit ys þe name, To Durem langes Durham hous longes. þat same. A quene þen was lady of [þo] quene was lady of þo. landes, . Sche dide take armes wyþ þe armes &. handes; Þat on scheo biried vnder molde, Þat oþer ys kept in seluer & golde, In seinte Petres kirke to holde. . & after þe Quen þe toun was tolde; 'Bebba' Bebba. (Bede has Bebba in his Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 16.) for þe Quen hit is calde; A nyce name, for soþe y halde; & for hit was so nice a name, . I wene trow. þey chaungede hit for schame, (Er þanne hit highte Methamstede,) Peterburgh, þat semely sede. Longe after Osewald was ded, . Holy kirke mykel peyne bed: ffor al þat he þer-inne had wrought, Wyþ stronge men with strange. was al doun brought; Prest & clerk þey slowe right doun, Þat al was wast ner Waste was left. ilk/ a toun, & þe goodes a-wey iborn; Til Osewy cam, ner al was lorn. & for he was his broþer sone, Un des frères Osgal, Wace , ii. 283, l. 14,929. Hym fel to haue þe regione. Þo þat þer were, conseil þey held, & bitaughte Osewy þe scheld. Osewy saw þe folk al pouere, ? MS. u. P. pouere. & þe land at no recouere; recouerere. Þe power of Cadwalyn was mikel, & Penda poyned hym als a prykel; He sey his power ne was nought/ &yogh;yf Cadwalyn werre on hym sought/; Leuer hym were in loue to bowe, Þat þey namo of his men þat no mo of his folk men. slowe, Þan in werre bere hym ouer heye, P. leaves out this line. & euere be on þe werre partye. P. leaves out this line. Til Cadwalyn his sonde sonne. he sent/, Þat he wolde com til parlement/; And þyder cam he al wyþ leue, . ffor Cadwalyn wold hym nought greue. Al þus þe pes was þer y-graunted, þus gates was þe pes granted. & in loue longe haunted; But Oswy MS. Cadwal. P. (like Geoffrey) Oswy. (Osgal, Wace , ii. 284, l. 14,951; Oswi, MS. Cangé, 73, ib. ) mikel kynde hadde, Þat often conseilled þem & radde ffor to werre vpon Osewy, Þey cleymed of hys land gret parti; But Osewy defended hym als a man, So þat of hym neuere þey ne Of him neuer nouht þei. wan. On, Alfriche, Ane Alfrith. (His brother, says Geoffrey , bk. xii. ch. 11.) cleymed of his right; Ouer Humber he chased hym þorow com with him to. fight; On þys half he fledde hym fra, & cam & pleyned hym to Penda, And preied he wolde hym mayntene Agayn Osewy þat was so kene, & þe lond þat he might of hym & if he mot þat lond. wynne; He schulde haue his part His parte suld be. (Wace says only that Penda is promised peace and truce, ii. 285, l. 14,960.) þer-inne.
text.273: ¶ De coronacione Cadwaliny. Penda seide he dirste naught/, ffor Cadwal & Osewy were al saught for kadwalyn at on was brouht. : " But fonde i schal, by som queyntise, " Of Cadwalyn to haue grauntise; P. leaves out this line. " & &yogh;yf y may gete his leue " Wyþ &yogh;ow to holde, y wold hym greue." Þan fel hit at þe Whitsontyde, Cadwalyn no lenger wolde byde; At Londen set he his coronement/. Alle his barons þyder went/ ffor to be þer at his feste, Malicia Pende. . South, north, west, & est; But þider cam nought þo Osewy; bot Oswy þat tyme not kam. I ne wot for what hit was, ne why. for whi no wham. When Penda hit perseiued, he made gret fare faire . . . . . þare. . ffor þat Osewy was nought þare: faire . . . . . þare. To Cadwalyn he made his pleynt/, & seide 'Osewy was fals & feynt/, " Syn he cam nought for þy somons " To þy court, als oþer barouns. " Alle ar þey comen, ilka Bretoun, " & ilkan Englische & Saxoun; " But Osewy tok þy somons in veyn, " To come to court he hadde has. disdeyn." Þe kyng excused hym curteysly: " He haþ has. som gret encheson why; " Perauenture he haþ has. som syknesse " Or oþer greuaunce þat makeþ hym stresse." " Nay," seide Penda, "hit ys nought so! " Þou sest sees. nought what Osewy wil do! " In þys tyme of þy corounement/, " In-til Saxoyn haþ into saxone has. he sent " After souders, as soudeours was. was me told, " To venge þe deþ dede. of Osewold. " When he seþ tyme þat he may, " On þe to renne he wile assay. " But, Cadwalyn, wil þou giue me leue, " I schal hym brynge til a mescheue, " Þat eyþer schal y don hym fle, " Or quik or ded bryng hym to þe." Seide Cadwalyn, "þus may hit make; P. leaves out these lines. (Dist Cadualan: j'en parlerai; Wace , ii. 286, l. 15,000.) " Neþeles y schal conseil take." P. leaves out these lines. (Dist Cadualan: j'en parlerai; Wace , ii. 286, l. 15,000.) He calde þe Bretons hym aboute, And dide Penda go wyþoute, & þe Englische euerychone; So þe Bretons left were. al-one. ¶ Cadwalyn seyd, "lordes alle, " Seyeþ sais. now what wil best byfalle " Of þys þat Penda haþ bysought; " Wheþer hit is god whedir is it. to do or nought." Þenne spak first sire Margadu, Lord of Southwalys, for þer prou: " Longe hit is þys was bygonne, long is sen þis wo was gunnen. " & &yogh;yt is hit nought al ouer ronne, " Bytwyxt vs & þe Englische kynde, . " & &yogh;it wot non how hit wyl bynde; will ende. " Hou so bitwyxt/ hem be strif or stresse, " Vs to noye euere ar þey fresche; fresse. " Be þey byneþe, be þey aboue, " Vs ne wil þey neuere loue, " Ne þer trouþe wyl þey nought holde; " To do a felonye ar þey ful bolde. " Haue þys y þyn herte ful streit, " How þat. þey haue don vs many deseit grete desceite. " So fele tymes here byforn; " & also often hastow sworn " Þat þou scholdest &yogh;it brynge hem heþen; " But þyn oþ ys ay byneþen, " Syn þou sest þat þou may nought " ffulfylle haf. þy dede wyþ þy þought,— " Ne per chaunce ys nought þy wille,— " Suffre þat on þat oþer spille, " Suffre MS. Ne suffre. P. suffre. þat on þat oþer schende, " Ne entremet þe at neyþer non. ende. " Penda is Englische, & noþyng not. good, " & Osewy ys of Englische blod; " Make we þer-of no maner iangle, " Suffre þe dogges ech oþer soffre þe ton þe toþer. strangle, " Suffre hem eyþer on oþer renne, P. leaves out these two lines, and transposes the next two. " & ilkon oþer robbe & brenne; P. leaves out these two lines, and transposes the next two. " & þorow meschaunce of fight or flyt/, mischefe of fight & flite. " Þys lond mai happe so may þe lond. of þem be quit." Þen speke þe Bretons at o breyd, " Sire Margadu, þou hast wel Margadu þou has wele. seyd! " To at. þys conseil alle we holde, " Right as sire Margadu haþ vs. tolde." " Penda," þey seyde, "do what þou wilt " To Cadwalyn! hit is no gilt." Penda proudly tok his leue; Oswy algate wold he Of þouht he forto. greue; He gadred gret host on his side, P. leaves out this line. . & Penda cam wyþ ful gret pryde; P. leaves out this line. He sembled his host purueied oste. ful hastely, ffersly to struye sire full felly to werre on. Osewy. Osewy sone herdit herd. See Bede's Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 24 (A.D. 665), on Oswy's offer and the battle. seye . How Penda on hym wold lyue & deye; He douted sore his wykked res, & sende to Penda for þe pes; ' & &yogh;yf he wolde þer-to graunt, ' He wolde hym gyue in god couenaunt ' Gold & siluer at his might, ' His lond to haue wyþoute fight.' Penda seide 'he wolde nought leue: ' He scholde hym chace, þe coroune reue.' ¶ Wyþ Osewy was an holy man, De Episcopo Bischop he was, his name His name was bisshop. Aydan; Aydano. He preied God for þer nede, . Ageyn Penda Osewy wel spede: " Louerd! þou quenche se se lord. his wykkednesse! " His grete power, þou make hit lesse, " & suffre vs neuere fele þere smert/, . " Þe ffelonie of his wikked hert/!" When Osewy sey no loue wolde sende, But at his power he moste hym fende, At his powere he wild defend. He gadered host on hys syde, . And Penda cam wyþ ful gret pryde. At a day bataille was set, Boþe hostes to-gedere met. MS. ment /. P. mett. In gode hope Oswy MS. as we. P. Oswy. were inne, . Þat he schulde þe maistrie wynne; He tristed wel y þe Holy Gost/, P. leaves out this line. & Penda tristed on hys grete host. P. leaves out this line. Þey smette to-gedere so bitterlyke . Þat eyþer ilk. side fond oþer quyke; He þat hit gan, þe worse he hadde, þat werre bigan þe wars had. ffor Penda party al to-schadde; Hys grete host &yogh;ede al doun, Penda periit/ Anno domini DCLV to . & slayn was þere þat feloun; fful wel he spedde þat gaf þe dynt, . ffor Penda lyf & soule was tynt; Þe &yogh;er þat he to deþ[e] dede. &yogh;ede, . Þe date was, as seyþ seint Bede, Sex hundred &yogh;er, fyfty & fyue. Þe day þat Penda les his lyue, Vpon Twede Twede, Langtoft , i. 256; Winved, Geoffrey , xii. 13; Vinwed, Bede , which is Winwidfield, near Leeds, says Giles. þe bataille was, . Þrytty dukes slayn y þat plas, Et li pluisor de ses amis, Wace , ii. 289, l. 15,068. On Penda syde euerilkone, ffor whilke manye was mad many mad. mone. Wolfrith his sone a-scaped þat pyn, . & cam & told hit to Cadwalyn. Cadwalyn gaf hym his heritage, & he til hym made his homage. ¶ Cadwalyn, þat kepte þe lond, A trewe iustise men þe folk. hym fond; He regned foure & fourty &yogh;er, 6 What in pes & [what] in wer. At Londone wax he syk, & deyde, . Þe Bretons þere his body leyde; 6 6-6 He died at london þei laid him þere. But for to haue menynge of hym, How he was noble, meke, & grym, Of coper þey dyde make a knyght, & an hors of coper al dight; Set hym þer-on in kynges wede, Als he was wond wont. to ryde on stede; Þer byside þey leyde his body, Abouen at a gate ful hey, In Londone, toward þe west: Longe hit stod þer wel y-fest; stode streitly fest. Byside, þey sette a chapel Of seint Martyn, a fair iuwel. Þus þey dide, for gret nobleye, Hys dede dedis. for to mene & seye. Cadwaladrus Cavalances, MS. du Roi, 27; Calawader, MS. 73, Cangé: Wace , ii. 290, l. 15,091. was after Cadwalyn nota. Cadwala|drus His fader, & Penda cosyn; Penda cosyn, his sister sone, Cadwalyn wedded, y dide &yogh;ow mone. See above, p. 553, l. 15,968. Cadwaladrus was a ful god kynge, . And louede God ouer of. alle þynge;
text.274: ¶ Exe de fame, Pestilencia mortis, ac corrupcione Aerys, & Exilio Brutonum. In his tyme failled þe corn, ffor þer was non as was byforn. Of þat defaute cam gret dere, Et en après fu la cherté, Wace , ii. 290, l. 15,096. . & gret hunger oueral was here; Þre dayes to go, &yogh;yf on might dreye, Er he fond any mete to bye,— Oþer in burgh or in cite, . Or vpland, or in or vpland in. any contre,— But &yogh;yf þey any bestes tok, Or fysche in riuer or in brok, Or any leues or rotes seþ, . Þat henged on heg hang on hege. or on heþ: Al was elles turnd to faille, Might noman lyue on his trauaille. ¶ &yogh;yf þys meschaunce cam mischefe com. ferly sore, &yogh;yt þer was an oþer more; So gret a man-qualm cam þer-wyþ, Mortalité fu de la gent, Wace , ii. 290, l. 15,107. Bede ( Eccl. Hist. , bk. iii. ch. 24) and the Saxon Chro|nicle both mention a great pestilence, A.D. 664, as Madden notices in La&yogh;amon , iii. 432. ffro deþ vneþe might non haue for dede mot non vnneþis haf. gryþ, Þorow roten eyr, þorow &. wykkede wyndes, In alle stedes men dide died. gret myndes; Now &yogh;ede þey vp right hol & fer, P. leaves out this line. No Of Bretons in next line. was any lefte . Of Bretons þat mighte tile þe lond efte. Þat vengeaunce was so ferly grete, Hit spared non, but al þorow schete; So fele ley ded by ilka in ilk. weye, Þat þe quyke ne mighte hem on erþe leye; þei fond non quik in erþe þam to lay. &yogh;yf any had leyd a cors in pyt/, P. leaves out this line. Hym self fel þanne ded þer-myt/. P. leaves out this line. So mykel was þer sorewe & drede, Left hous & lond, a-wey þey &yogh;ede; What for moryne, what for dere, Tant por le grant chierté de blé, Tant por la grant mortalité. Wace , ii. 291, l. 15,127-8. ffewe þer wore þat might liue here; Of his long lyf can noman seye, P. leaves out this line. . Þat ses his frend sodeynly deye; P. leaves out this line. Þat sees his neighebur brenne hym by, P. leaves out this line. To saue hym self he ys bysy. P. leaves out this line. Cadwaladrus, þe kyng of þys lond, . So mikel wo ouer al he fond, To Luytel Bretaigne for sorewe he fledde; Þat were on lyue, wyþ hym þem ledde. Alayn he highte, þat þanne was kynge, Þat was ful fayn of hys comynge. When þe Bretons heþen hyen. went, Þer faire wonynge mykel þey ment/. Þey seide hit was a vengeaunce One stroke too few for the u in the MS. strong, . Ageyns God þey lyuede wronge; " Now schal we lese our lond þorow synne, " Þat oure kynde han welt wyþ wynne." Þat lered were, þys salme þey songe, . & versled hit al wyþ o tonge:
text.275: ¶ Exe de lamentacione Brutonum. ¶'Deus auribus nostris' hatte þat salme Þat þey seide for þat man-qualme. þat qualme. But at a vers þat is þer-inne, . Pleynyng pleynt. to God þus gan þey gynne, " Vendidisti populum tuum sine precio;" & toward þer schipes þey songen hit so, See Geoffrey, bk. xii. § 15. " Dedisti nos tanquam oues escarum, . " & cetera [per totum psalmum From P. ]." To schipe þen wente kyng Cadwaladres; Wyþ hym þe Bretons þat he ches; Wyþ sorwful chere, & herte With sory & herte full. brym, . fful often made þey pleynte til hym: See Cadwaladres's prayer of nine lines in Langtoft , i. 258-260, the original of which, and of Manning's long prayer here, is Geoffrey of Monmouth's, bk. xii. § 15. " Wo til vs, sinful þat are, " Þat for our wikkednesse we þus fare! " Wyþ synne we wraþed God Almight, . " & þorow his wraþe we lese oure right. " Louerd! of mercy we preye þe, " Space of penaunce gyue vs fre! " Of þis grete wraþe þou stynt! . " Þaw þof. we sinful our lond haue tynt, " Graunte þe gode men þat þou ches, " Þat oure kynde nought al hit les,— " We se þy vengeaunce &yogh;it more may do,— . " Þat neuere þe Romayns mighte come to, " Ne oþere straunger strangere. þan were þey, " Might non brynge vs or a-wey. " Out of mesure þen synned we, . " Als wel to þyne as vntil þe, " Þat we nar ne are. worþy a-geyn be cald " To penaunce, ne oure land to hald. " We wolde no mercy when tyme was; . " Now schewest vs wraþe for þat schewes þi wraþe þat grete. trespas! " Now fynde we wel þou canst right deme! " While we had tyme we nolde þe queme; " Often we faught to fende our land, . " & ay þou gaf vs þe heyer hand; þou gaf vs þan þe ouerhand. " Þou gaf vs grace to wynne þe pris " Al-wey All tymes. of oure enemys. " Now hit ys for nought we fynde, . " We lese hit al by rote & rynde! " We preye þe, Lord, to be suffrable, " & turne oure sorewe grete. to ioye stable, " & come ageyn, &yogh;yf hit þy wille be, . " On oure lond for to serue þe! " Now may þe Romayns come ageyn, P. leaves out this line. " Þe Scottes & Peytes þat dide vs peyn, P. leaves out this line. " & þe tricherous Saxons— P. leaves out this line. . " Þeyr tricherye vs euere mones;— P. leaves out this line. " Þys voyde land schul þey now take! P. leaves out this line. " Voide of vs mighte neuere þey make; P. leaves out this line. " Al þer strengthe dide vs nought fle, P. leaves out this line. . " But Godes wrathe, þat serued we." P. leaves out this line. Swylk sorewe & swilk gret mone Made þe Bretons euer-ilkone . To Cadwaladrus, þer cheuentayne; And alle þey schiped to þe Lesse Bretayne. When þer flote to lande was leyd, Exitus Brytonum. Þe kyng Aleyn byfore-seid Receyued hym wyþ gode wille, .
